Welcome, My name is Kirk Lindo and thank you for taking the time to view my Kickstarter Campaign. I am an Artist, Writer and Publisher of Comics, Graphic Novels and Art Books. 
The purpose of this Kickstarter is to create, print and distribute a Remastered Edition of The Luxura Collection #1!
A 48 page FULL COLOR collection of Luxura's first 4 appearances from the original Vamperotica Comic Series.
HARDCOVER EDITION
This book is available in a HARDCOVER, NAUGHTY and REGULAR EDITION! 
NAUGHTY EDITION!
REGULAR EDITION
 REWARD SPOTLIGHT!
The Vampress Luxura is my original character that was the star of my highly successful Vamperotica comic series which ran for 50 issues and also spun off into several mini-series and magazines.
For those of you that are just discovering Luxura for the first time, let me give you a little information about her history and story line. 
 Luxura belongs to a race of vampires known as the 'Kith'. Although her exact age has not yet been disclosed, she is at least several centuries old. She has made good use of this time, building her own shadow empire that spans the globe. The heart of this empire is a complex in Manhattan, New York. It is a vast network of tunnels, caverns, and trophy rooms.
Luxura is an avid collector. While much of her many collections have monetary value, most items are kept for sentimental value. Amongst the armor, jewelry, clothing, books and weapons, there is the crown jewel of her collections... the Blood Vault. This vault, believed by many to be the largest in the world, contains thousands of wine bottles filled with magically preserved blood. Each bottle is carefully labeled, and displays a portrait or photograph of the donor. In her Blood Vault is every conceivable historical figure that you can think of from Julius Caesar to John F. Kennedy.
Luxura is a strong believer in the rule of law, and actively works to enforce the three main tenets of Kith society- sustaining mortals as a plentiful food source, regulating the Kith to prevent anarchy, and maintaining discretion so mortals are not alerted to the existence of Kith.

This book is a perfect introduction to the Vampress Luxura for new readers and excellent collector's item for existing fans!

It also features a Vampress Luxura pin-up gallery by Kirk Lindo.
All of the art has been carefully remastered and recolored from full sized scans of the original pages.

Hello! My name is Cameron Hines. Born and raised in Columbus,Ohio I am currently a twenty year old open book ready to take on the world. I have recently finished my first novel of many. My plan for the money that is raised through this blessed platform is to invest in getting my book published and advertising my work so it can reach the masses. My intended audience is anyone who can read, including non readers. My creation "Sovereignty of Spades" is a cadenced young adult/ adult fiction story that combines traditional prose with dramatic dialogue to create a distinct, genre-spanning reading experience. Ever since Khalif Kendrix was little, he has played his cards like a king. Labeled as gifted until he transforms into a rebel while in high school, seventeen-year-old Khalif shuns everything he has ever been taught, drops out of high school, and journeys down a dark path into the unknown.
Now a lost soul wandering through the shadows, Khalif is moving loafs and bringing home a few thousand a week. His mother is gone—brutually murdered during a weekday bible study by a white supremist. His father appears to be clueless about how Khalif is making a living, despite living in the same house with him. But everything changes one day when the feds bust five of his drug buddies. Now as Khalif unfurls a new plan to survive, he has no idea that he is about to be led in a direction he never could have imagined in his wildest dreams.
Sovereignty of Spades is the gripping tale of a street-smart kid on an unforgettable journey into the unknown where he hopes to eventually reach his destiny—and more importantly, his true potential.

The biannual anti-aesthetic publication plans the launch of its 3rd issue by November 2020. With the disruption of the fashion calendar and industry at large caused by the global pandemic, MERDE is dedicated to re-evaluating its place within the fashion publishing landscape by sticking to its advertisement free ethos. With this, MERDE needs YOUR help to produce, print, and distribute its 3rd issue. MERDE greatly appreciates the globally dispersed network of supporters and collaborators it has fostered in its first 2 issues, and hopes to feed your desire for subversive fashion imagery going into the future. Every dollar, euro, krone, or cryptocurrency counts!
A self deprecative publication embedded with humour and wit, MERDE reflects on fashion’s cultural landscape by exploring the creative process without a filter. With the aim to disrupt tired narratives, each issue picks a theme to explore-in all seriousness. Ruled by new visual media, empowered by creative expression - sans labels, sans limits.

This is an Officially Authorized NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD product
For the first time ever, we have compiled all our issues of Night of the Living Dead graphic novels, including Prelude (pre-film story,) and  Aftermath (post film story); into one huge volume. Also know that we never reprinted Prelude and Aftermath since their original release. This new edition graphic novel will be over 230 pages and have all the original dialog. In addition, there will be an all-new art gallery including the four, never published covers by Stephen R. Bissette, stunning art by Richard Bonk, as well as exclusive photos and interviews with the original 1968 cast members. The final book will be over 250 pages of material.
Most importantly, this is an OFFICIALLY AUTHORIZED product for which the creators of NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD will receive a portion of all net profits from each book sold. 
Spectacular wraparound cover by Stephen R. Bissette (c)2013
Here are some comments by the author of Xerox Ferox, John Szpunar:
 NIGHT… of the LIVING DEAD!  
Some time ago, amigo Steve Bissette posted a query on Facebook. I can’t remember his exact words, but the gist of the question went something like this: “In your opinion, what are some movies that every student of comic book artwork should see?” I puzzled over this one for some time. The German expressionists immediately sprang to mind, as well as the works of Mario Bava, Orson Welles, and Terry Gilliam. I thought of Brian De Palma, with his masterful use of the split-screen. Jean Luc Godard came to mind, as well. His brilliant use of jump cuts echoed the comic book sentiment that I believe Steve was referring to. The classic shower scene in Psycho soon followed. And then… I got to thinking about George A. Romero and his self-proclaimed “Cubist” style of editing. “Good Lord!” I thought! George’s movies actually WERE living comic books! And there is no better example than Night of the Living Dead. George was a self-proclaimed EC Comics fanatic, and the influence of his comic book style of editing is evident in ALL of his early films. Dawn of the Dead. Martin. The Crazies. Creepshow. And, especially, in Night of the Living Dead. Move over, Miller and Rodriguez! NOTLD is a graphic novel come to life! All these years later, it would make sense for a team of comix artists and writers to revisit the fertile stomping grounds that George once tread. And what do you know? The time has come! FantaCo Enterprises is proud to announce the OFFICIALLY AUTHORIZED "50th Anniversary NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD" Graphic Novel! Don’t dare miss out on this one! Please stay a while and visit with us. We’re coming to get YOU!!! ~John Szpunar
Original cover of FantaCo's NOTLD #2 by Carlos Kastro
Turning the movie into a graphic novel took us years. The storyboards were done by Eric Stanway, and the lettering was by Mary Kelleher. The appropriately dark and moody B&W art was done by Carlos Kastro - now  a well regarded painter.
The original cover for FantaCo's NOTLD #3 by Carlos Kastro
The original cover for FantaCo's 1991 NOTLD Complete Graphic Novel
New artwork by Richard Bonk (c)2017
 And here is an extra special perk for hardcore NOTLD fans!! We are minting a huge 3 inch coin for the 50th Anniversary. It is done in high relief and looks just incredible. Only 100 serial numbered coins will be produced for the entire world. This coin is officially authorized by Image Ten.

Update: Strrreeetch Goal!
The $4000 Kickstarter goal has been met in only three days! I've decided to create a stretch goal of $10,000 which will allow for full paper upgrades, more pages in the book, and an open gallery night this summer in Vancouver, BC. Keep sharing this Kickstarter to help reach this stretch goal!
Project Pilgrim is my effort to work towards normalizing mental health.
This spring, I intend to walk the 1000km Camino de Santiago and along the way interview and photograph people I meet and engage them in a discussion around mental health. The outcome of my trip will be a website and printed book capturing the comments, insights, and portrait photographs of those that I meet. I hope that this collection of ideas can further the conversation that needs to continue around mental health. The book will be pre-sold through this Kickstarter campaign which will run over the course of March in order to offset the costs of this project. Donations will also be gratefully accepted through this Kickstarter campaign.
A Summary:
The Camino de Santiago, a famous pilgrimage route, hosts ~250,000 pilgrims a year as they walk from Saint-Jean-Pied-de-Port, France to Santiago de Compostela, Spain. There have been multiple movies, multimedia websites, blogs, and several books done about the Camino which have all been very successful. I’ve decided to do something of my own.
This May, I will be walking this pilgrimage alone in order to work towards breaking down the stigma around mental health. On the Camino, people are walking (sometimes alone) for a month or more. They become very self reflective. I plan to tap into this introspection and inquire as to people’s thoughts regarding mental health. I believe that because the people I meet will be especially aware of themselves, they will have some very interesting things to say. My hope is that by collecting many people’s opinions and sharing them with you, we will all come to a better understanding of what mental health is and how to overcome issues we may face.
A picture is worth a thousand words, but a picture with an emotional connection to it is worth many times more. My goal is that by taking people’s photos and asking them about mental health, I can start a conversation that can work towards breaking down the stigma around mental health. Talking about mental health normalizes mental health and my hope is that Project Pilgrim can be one of the many stepping stones needed in order to make mental health an everyday conversation.
So...What Is It?
Project Pilgrim first and foremost is a collection of people’s responses and opinions towards mental health. Over December, 2015 and January, 2016 I took 120 of my friend’s photos which I have paired with their thoughts towards mental health. I will be posting these daily until the end of April (below are some select examples). In May, I will be heading to France and Spain to walk the famous 1000km Camino de Santiago pilgrimage route. As I walk, I will take photos of the people I meet and combine their portraits with their thoughts and responses towards mental health. I will post these photos on the Facebook Page, Instagram, as well as on the website. The end result will be a consolidation of these photos and their captions in a website and printed photo book. This book will be pre-sold at a discount through this Kickstarter over the month of March. Several Canadian organizations are partnering and supporting this project in various ways. More information will be available soon as to who is involved.
Another aspect of this project includes the reason why I ended up dropping out of school last year. I was suffering from social anxiety which led to depression. My social anxiety was highly specific to the particular situation of meeting new people for the first time. After seeking help and going through therapy, I was able to overcome this challenge and I am now ready to use my circumstances as a testament to the benefit of getting help. On the Camino I will be walking alone and will be meeting new people multiple times a day. I will use this opportunity of meeting new people to ask them about their thoughts concerning mental health and take their photo. I hope that by me demonstrating how I am “facing my fears” I will encourage others who were struggling like I was to reach out and get the help that is available.
Test photos for Project Pilgrim. This selection was photos were all taken in Vancouver, BC in December, 2015. Click here to see more test photos.
 What is the Camino?
The Camino de Santiago, specifically the Way of St. James, is a 1000km long ancient pilgrimage route to Santiago de Compostela in Galicia, Spain. For thousands of years, Christian pilgrims from across the world have made their way along this route to the city of Santiago de Compostela where the remains of apostle St. James are reported to be buried. Nowadays, people walk this route for many reasons. In fact, over the last few years only 40% of the people who have completed the Camino did it for religious reasons. 55% did it for "cultural and other" reasons and 5% did it for non-religious reasons.
The French Way of the Camino de Santiago. I will be hiking the Spain portion beginning in St. Jean Pied De Port and ending in Santiago de Compostela. I will then continue on to Finisterre on the coast of Spain.
The Camino is set up in such a way to accommodate for the ~250,000 people who walk it every year. There are auberges (pilgrim hostels) in most towns along the route allowing for pilgrims to walk anywhere from 10 to 40km a day. These auberges offer a dormitory style bed usually with a hot shower for ~€10 a night. Food can either be bought or carried (some auberges offer a shared small kitchen) but most people opt to eat in local restaurants for meals. For meals and accommodation I have budgeted €25/day for my 35 day journey.
The Idea:
My idea for Project Pilgrim came by combining three of my passions: Photography, Mental Health, and The Outdoors.
Photography: Photography is one of my greatest passions. Project Pilgrim will consist of portraits of the people I meet along the Camino de Santiago. These photos will be shared on this site, the Facebook Page, as well as Instagram. Afterwards, these photos and the subject’s mental health response will be turned into a book.
Mental Health: Mental health is something I hold very close to me. In November of 2014, I was forced to withdraw from school in order to address my own mental health issues. Now I want to give back. My hope is that Project Pilgrim will start a conversation around mental health. As I walk the Camino, I will talk to the people I meet about their thoughts and opinions towards mental health. Their responses will be included with their photo as I post along the way. To read more about me and my mental health journey click here.
The Outdoors: The outdoors is where I find my therapy. In my down time, you can almost always find me climbing, hiking, kayaking, or trying something new outside. The Camino consists of walking 1000km across Northern Spain - it’s perfect for me. To read more about the Camino click here.
The name Project Pilgrim comes from the Camino de Santiago. The Camino is a historic pilgrimage route starting in France and ending in Santiago de Compostela in Northwest Spain. Historically, pilgrims have walked this route from all over the world as a spiritual journey to see the reported remains of the apostle St. James. More recently, this pilgrimage has been done mostly for cultural rather than religious reasons. To read more about the Camino click here.
Okay...So Why The Kickstarter?
Book printing companies require a minimum bulk order to print at discounted rates. I will be pre-selling the book through this Kickstarter in order to ensure I meet that minimum order as well as cover the money I have already put into this project (design, website, etc). The $4000 minimum goal will cover all of those costs (there is a cost breakdown below).
Trip Cost Breakdown:
I have done my research for the Camino and found it appropriate to budget $20/day for food and $15/day for hostels over the 35 days I will be walking. The Kickstarter goal only covers the Design Costs for this trip. The other costs will be covered if the Kickstarter reaches a stretch goal of $10,000.
Cost breakdown of my trip. $4000 is what I expect to be the total cost.
Book Cost Breakdown:
In order to remain transparent, below is a breakdown of where your money will be going if you choose the book as a reward. Please note that shipping is not included.
Cost breakdown of where your $33 will go towards for every book pre-ordered
The Book:
A mock up copy of the book Project Pilgrim I made.
The book Project Pilgrim will come in one size (7in x 7in) and feature high quality Proline Uncoated 100lb paper which is durable and is heavier than regular paper. Depending on how much the Kickstarter is funded, the book will contain anything from 36-42 pages. The inside of the book will be simple. It will feature the pilgrim's portrait along with their response to my mental health question for them.
An inside look at the book Project Pilgrim
Timeline:
An estimate timeline of Project Pilgrim.
Above is an estimate timeline for Project Pilgrim. If the Kickstarter is a success, I will open an online bookstore and donation site on projectpilgrim.org for those of you unable to get a book or give during this Kickstarter. However, donations and books are encouraged to be purchased through the Kickstarter as they will help me reach my Kickstarter goal.
Something else of note is the date you will receive your rewards. Current estimates point to late July or early August for delivery of your books and prints. The portrait sessions will happen sometime in the summer of 2016 with a deadline at the end of August.
The Catch:
Here comes the bad news. If this Kickstarter does not reach it's initial $4000 goal, this trip won't happen. All of the work and money I have put into this project will have been for nothing and I will have to make up my lost costs by working instead of doing the Camino. Please make a pledge towards this Kickstarter to make this dream of mine become a reality.
How To Follow Along:
Anyone can follow along without making a pledge towards my trip. Please follow my Instagram and Facebook page dedicated to this project. As well, I have a website (projectpilgrim.org) that I will be posting my blogs and photos on.

DoSo™ Violin
What is the DoSo Violin?
The DoSo Violin is an inexpensive electric violin that sounds great when plugged into a small Fender Mustang 1 guitar amplifier.
As you can hear in the video above, the DoSo Violin is, first and foremost, a great sounding instrument no matter what style of music you play.
It’s also been designed so it can be produced at a low enough price to make it a real option for anyone who wants to plug in and expand their playing opportunities.
With The DoSo Violin You Can Easily Plug in and Rock Out
The Goal of DoSo Violin
Too many violin students give up the violin simply because they feel other instruments offer them more opportunities to play. Now with The DoSo Violin any violinist will be able to join groups like jazz and dance bands or even the garage band down the street.
Our goal is to create a great sounding and inexpensive electric violin so that violinists, especially young violinists, have more opportunities and places to play.
By supporting this campaign you’re helping make the DoSo Violin a reality. We encourage you to get one for yourself or your child or to contribute in order to help put a DoSo Violin into the hands a young musician who couldn’t otherwise afford one.
Our Goal Is To Give Violinists More Opportunities To Play So Fewer Kids Give Up The Violin
Who’s Helped Create The DoSo?
David Mills is the creator of the DoSo Violin but he’s had support from many great friends in the music business.
First and foremost is Fan-Chia Tao, the R&D Director for D’Addario. Having just the right strings (Helicore medium tension) is essential to the sound of the instrument. With Fan-Chia’s support we were able to experiment with multiple types of strings, mixing and matching them with different violins and pickup systems to create the perfect sound.
Tony Pasqualoni is a mechanical engineer, musician and luthier who, in his spare time, repairs violins for the Sam Ash store in New Haven, CT.
Les Schatten from Schatten Design created the V0-2 Pro pickup system.
 Peter Stoney is the musician-inventor who came up with the Fiddle Fretter.
Rich Ferris, the marketing representative for Cremona Violins, helped us determine the perfect stock violin, the SV-175, to serve as the base of the DoSo Electric Violin.
And finally, you, because it will truly be the support of musicians, music fans, educators, fiddlers, violinists and parents of young violinists all coming together to support this campaign that will make the DoSo Violin a reality.
What Are The Rewards?
The primary reward is the amazing DoSo Violin itself. For just $450 you’ll get the DoSo Violin complete with Fiddle Fretter, Helicore strings and a Schatten V02 Pro pickup system. It comes with a plush-lined case and basic bow plus instructions on how to program the inexpensive Fender Mustang 1 amplifier to work perfectly with the DoSo Violin.
The DoSo Violin Is Just $450 and Includes the Case, Bow, & Instructions
At the $40 reward level you can help put a DoSo Violin into the hands of a young violinist through our partnership music schools. We’ll be asking our backers to help select the programs that will receive these violins.
You can also get a CD of music performed on amplified string instruments; Sheet music and MP3 play-along recordings of DoSo Dance Band arrangements featuring – 1st and 2nd violin, alto sax, cello, guitar, bass guitar and drums; or even learn string improvisation in a special class with David Mills in NYC, Nashville or New Haven, CT.
The DoSo Violin Sounds Great Plugged Into an Inexpensive Fender Amp
Why Kickstarter
Our goal wasn’t just to figure out how to make a great sounding electric violin, which was a challenge all by itself, but to make sure that it is actually affordable. Even with the generous support from our suppliers, who believe in the project, we still need to order the parts in bulk to keep the price down.
All the design and and testing is complete, now we just need to put in our order and start putting DoSo Violins into the hands of every violin player who wants to plug in, get down and rock out.
The DoSo Violin Looks Almost As Good As It Sounds
 FAQ
What Do I Plug into?
We recommend the Fender Mustang 1 Amplifier.
Why a Fender Mustang 1 amplifier?
Even a high-priced electric violin will sound scratchy and irritating through a standard guitar amp. Professional players typically run directly through the PA system. A small Fender Mustang 1 amp can be pre-programmed for the violin. We will show you how it’s done. Although the Mustang 1 is small and not very powerful, you can place it behind you as your monitor speaker, and in a band situation, you can drape a microphone over the front to send sound to the PA. (We like the inexpensive Samson R-11 microphone that doesn’t pick up as much white noise as a high-fidelity mic.)
Can you play a DoSo Violin unplugged?
Yes. Although the instrument unplugged is not as loud as a high-priced, finely-carved violin, it still has a great sound. 
What do you mean by “spatial awareness?”
Jazz violinists use the term “frame shifting” to describe the technique of transposing melodic patterns in upper positions, i.e. without using open strings. For example, if you look at the diagram below you see a diagram of a fretted violin neck with five natural modes that begin on E. Those scales can be transposed to any other location on the neck and have the same relative sound. The violinist does not even have to compute the key signature of the new location.
The DoSo Violin Can Help You Discover A New Sense of Spatial Awareness
Tell Me About the Frets…
The Fiddle Fretter we use has real frets, not just marker lines. Like those tied onto a viola da gamba, the frets on a Fiddle Fretter are thin nylon string that you can barely feel. As seen in the video clip of Ben Dean, you can slide above the frets for a true glissando. Beyond that, the frets provide a distinct advantage when “frame shifting” or playing rhythmic double stops – techniques that are extremely useful when playing “alternative styles.”
Can you be as expressive with frets on a violin?
Yes.  Unlike the guitar that becomes mute when you release pressure in your left hand, the violin does not.   You can play with vibrato, but also choose not to and still play in tune.
What if I want an amplified violin without frets?
No problem. We first recommend that you use the DoSo Violin in several situations for a month or two. Especially when playing in a group with drums or horns, you will find that you are more relaxed playing with frets. You will find that you can play with much less vibrato. If, at the end of two months, you still want an amplified violin without frets, you can remove the Fiddle Fretter leaving no trace that it was ever there.

Hey everyone!
My name is George Leakey and I am a wildlife filmmaker (LeakeyStudios), and between April and September next year I will be making a series of short documentaries on some of Africa's most endangered animals, some of which you may be unaware quite how close they are to the brink.
I will look to highlight the issues different animals have facing human conflict, loss of habitat, disease and hunting/poaching, while spending time talking with those who commit their lives to the protection of these species. Those animals will include:
- Trophy Hunting - Fundamental or Detrimental for the African Elephant.
- The pressures and struggles of the African Wild Dog.
My method of filming is modern, using transitions and fast paced music to excite and engage, with use of state of the art technology to tell the story in a different manner to how it has ever been shown before, while making sure the story is central. I find that below BBC NHU and Nat Geo, Wildlife filming is either too subject focused or too cinematography focused, and I want to make sure my films sit in the middle of both.
It will be shown free of charge however the work, time and equipment required for the sort of task, as well as transport means I need all the help I can get. This is something I am truly passionate about, and would love for you to join me on this journey, however not for my sake, but for the sake of those who can't tell their own story.

Chronically Better You has a simple mission: to help patients with chronic disease and mental health challenges live a better life.  
We know this isn’t an easy task to take on. We’re patients, too, and understand how much you’re going through on a daily basis. 
BUT...
Have you ever wondered what it would be like if you were able to make a small change that led to quality of improvements? We know you have - we have too. This is what led us to develop a lifestyle system for those with chronic diseases that is easy to follow and proven to help people reach their goals.  
We spent countless hours studying how some of the most successful and ambitious people in the world spend their time and how they not only reached their goals but exceed them. We learned that these best practices aren’t always possible for chronic disease patients.  
That is where Chronically Better You comes in. We took these best practices and tweaked them then packed them into our Better Life Journal. We’ve developed the first productivity and wellness journal specifically designed for chronic disease patients to organize their lives better and track their mental and physical wellness.
The BIG Better Life Journal features that can change your life:
Periodization - Each journal covers a 13 week period. The concept opf periodization is one commonly used by top athletes and professionals. It allows you to break your goals down into long enough periods of time to make a big change in your life but short enough to not procrastinate. 
Goal Setting - Our system will teach you how to set your big goals and then break them down into more manageable daily tasks. Imagine where you could be if you took one step towards your goal each day?
Tracking - Without tracking your progress you won't know if you're on your way to reaching your goals. Each week there are pages which will help you track what you've done and help you build healthy habits. 
Wellness - Each day you will be able to fill in one physical and mental task you want to complete. This could be listening to a podcast, taking a walk, reading part of a book, playing with your dog, meditating, or training for a half marathon. Whatever you would like them to be. 
Gratitude - The practice of gratitude can change your life. Even when things are hard, we still have to try and find a bright spot. Each morning and night you will practice gratitude which will allow you to start and end your day in a healthy mental space. 
Health Scoring - You will be able to check in 3 times daily to track how you are doing with your disease. Morning, noon, and night you can give yourself a score and take notes. This will lead to figuring out when your power hours are and when your body might not feel well on a regular basis. 
AND MORE!!!!
Better Life Journal
  Our system teaches you how to organize the day, be more efficient with time, track progress, and, most importantly, slowly but effectively change habits. We want to give you a hand in improving daily life and relationships, reducing stress, reaching small milestone goals, and crushing larger long-term milestones.  
Better Life Journal
We’re no quick-fix, but that’s the point. We want to help you make real change in your life - the kind that lasts.  
In the future, we will launch Chronically Better U(niversity), which allows qualified members of our team to more directly teach and lead you in your everyday battles. There’s a whole world out there for you and we want to help you learn tips and secrets so that you can explore it all. Chronically Better U will work alongside our Better Life Journal to do just that.  
So don’t wait! Back our Kickstarter today and take the first step to living a better life and becoming a Chronically Better You.

All funds produced from this fundraiser will go towards the conservation of Grey Partridges through the PARTRIDGE project to help fight the loss of our wildlife.
PARTRIDGE aims to increase farmland biodiversity by 30% on its 10 demonstration sites by 2023. To achieve this ambitious goal, high-quality conservation measures have been implemented on at least seven percent of arable farmland at all 500-ha demo sites. These conservation measures are not only expected to increase grey partridge Perdix perdix numbers but also many other farmland wildlife species.
If you would like to find out more here is our website - https://northsearegion.eu/partridge
Grey Partridges at the demo site
This fundraising page is the opportunity to pre-order and help fund the production of the flying grey partridge pin which will be sold across the continent. When you purchase a Grey Partridge Pin no money will be taken out of your account until our goal of £2900 is reached. When this goal is reached the money will be taken from your bank and the pin will be sent to you after its production. If the goal is not reached no money will be taken from you and the pins will not be produced.

WELCOME TO OUR KICKSTARTER PAGE!
  WHAT IS OCCULT GENERATION?
In a nutshell, Occult Generation is a hardboiled sci-fi supernatural graphic novel set in 1920s New York. It's about a private detective who investigates the murder of a notorious drag performer and in the process, uncovers a secret war between remnants of the confederacy equipped with strange technology and a secret society in Harlem that fights for justice through magic.
Gladys Spencer // Harlem Secret Society
The story pulls from memorable elements of the 1920s era while holding a magnifying glass up to people of color, mystics, immigrants, queer life, gender roles, body awareness, political corruption and the dawn of equity feminism. The readers of the graphic novel are going to see blood, violence, sexuality and other Rated-R material, yet it all has a purpose to tell the story. In all of this, we fully get to examine the spectrum of humanity from a unique historical context without having to hold back with our audience.
Artist Sketches by James Zark
Artist Sketches by James Zark
The art of Occult Generation is a collaboration with real life models and actors that play the characters in the story. We do this by casting talent to embody their characters which allows the energy and emotion to shine through each panel. The beauty of having a photorealistic graphic novel is that it gives a type of sex appeal to the visuals that we hope has our audience wanting more as they turn each page. 
OUR MISSION
As creatives, we have a passion to build pathways of communication and this graphic novel series has the potential to set the stage for important conversations in the comic book community and beyond. Occult Generation is a valuable endeavor that can provide an opportunity for controversial topics to stand in the forefront of discussions in society. Though it is set in the 1920s, the parallels to today's world are very apparent. Our intention with this book is to open up more permission to step outside of the box and allow people to find their own answers around the concepts that matter to them (and to have fun doing it!).
Panel from Issue #1 of the graphic novel
OUR TEAM
Our team of top notch creatives are committed to being fearless about their art and communicate about things that are important to them in the world. Without our unique collaborative process, this would not be possible. Throughout the campaign we’ll share the personal stories of our cast and crew so you can get to know our amazing team yourself.
Astroetic Studios in Downtown L.A.
IMMEDIATE GOAL
Production for Chapter 1 (Issue #1) is nearly completed, yet we need the funds for printing/distribution and to start production on the rest of the book. This campaign will cover those printing and distribution costs so we can put physical copies in your hands and prove how awesome Occult Generation can be.
If we are successful in reaching our goal, we will add stretch goals for Chapter 2 and beyond.
Once this campaign is completed successfully, we’ll work to produce what has been funded through this campaign and announce plans to fund the remaining chapters.
WHAT HAPPENS WHEN YOU PLEDGE?
William Derrick III
When you pledge, it goes directly toward production to cover the costs associated with creating, producing, printing and distributing all things Occult Generation. Among them:
renting studio space & equipment 
crew & model fees 
hair, makeup & wardrobe 
printing and distribution of the comic 
a private jet for the crew (Just kidding!)
Don't forget to check out the perks on right hand column!
Here are some examples of what they could look like:
LONG TERM GOAL
Our larger goal is to finish the book in its entirety (over 200 pages) and get it published. 
Eventually, we will continue to move forward working with more artists and writers where we can create stories that matter to people and truly find new perspectives in the entertainment industry. Occult Generation is merely the beginning and there is much more to come!
Thank you for visiting our page and being apart of Occult Generation!

Welcome to the Glitter+Gold Kickstarter Campaign

My name is Clinton Edminster and my goal is to impel our rational imaginations into the unimaginable depths of the dimension that contains them. My method is to create and curate a novel combination of both static and dynamic art objects, immersive optical loops, sonic chaos, and some cookies, each specifically chosen for their sensory vibration, their impact. The gestalt of these impacts is the point of Glitter+Gold.
Glitter+Gold is a currently unimaginable point in the Dimension of the Imagination. With your help on this project I’ll be able to create an experience that will make it real.
All patrons will receive a password to access a behind the scenes blog at imaginationdimension.tumblr.com that will feature videos, photos, and writings about making Glitter+Gold happen. Check out the updates after donating and you''ll find the password and link!

People in Space
Art, Research, and Communication at the 2010 Shanghai World Expo
The 2010 Shanghai World Expo hosts nearly 200 countries within a 5.28 square kilometer area and is officially recognized as the largest in the 159 year history of World Expositions. Many of the participating countries have created temporary multi-million dollar pavilions to address the theme “Better City, Better Life,” and 70 million visitors from around the world are anticipated to attend between May1st and October 31st.
People In Space is a project organized by American artists from Boston, Massachusetts that utilizes the context of the 2010 Shanghai World Expo as a platform for contemporary art, research, and communication. We see an opportunity to learn from and contribute to this unique event by using our art and inquiry to engage both the people and spaces that define it. Pledges to this project will help us mount an exhibition of our work from Shanghai and the Expo at the Mobius gallery in Boston, MA. Your support will help cover material and logistic expenses associated with the exhibition, receptions and artists talks.
Art:
Approximately 375,000 people attend the Expo each day and many of these visitors will spend over 10 hours waiting in lines consisting of thousands of people in order to enter popular pavilions. With these conditions in mind People In Space has sent out an international call for proposals inviting creative thinkers to submit ideas for actions that engage the waiting visitors in unexpected ways.We have evaluated the proposed actions based on three categories: utilization of the lines, simplicity of design, and strength of concept as it relates to the context of the Expo and its themes. We will implement the selected proposals in and through the lines present at the pavilions as surrogate performers. Artists selected include: Andrew Y. Ames, Jeffery Byrd, James Ellis Coleman, Lewis Gesner, Brian Kane, Heather Kapplow, Alexia Mellor, Michael Oatman, Seth Taylor, Laray Polk, and Julia Wagner. In addition to the projects in lines the People in Space artists on the ground at the Expo will utilize unforeseen contexts as platforms for further artistic actions.
Research:
Our research is intended to provide basic information about the context of the Expo in order to support our art and communication. We have selected three main questions to explore through interviews, direct observations, and the collection of materials available online. What motivates people to attend? How has the Expo organized people and space? What is the most compelling content at the Expo? Using these questions as a starting point to engage visitors, volunteers and organizers we intend to gain insight into the myriad topics associated with the Expo.
Communication
The documentation and relics from People in Space will be contextualized and curated through an exhibition of video, photography, writing and installation at the Mobius gallery in Boston, MA, USA from October 8th - 12th. The exhibition will include opening and closing receptions as well as artists talks throughout that week. Ongoing documentation and blogging for this project will also be present online at: www.BerwickInstitute.org, www.ThePresentTense.org, and www.Mobius.org.
Thank you for your support!
Sincerely,
Daniel S. DeLuca: Artist / Founder / Director
Sandrine Schaefer: Artist / Associate Director
Contributing Artists:
Zayde Buti, Jessica Gath, Marissa Georgiou, Ellen Godena, Heather Kapplow,Jill. J, Dana Moser, Bob Raymond, J.Sal, Lily Sheng, Mark Vann, Jane Wang
Contributing Organizations:
The Berwick Research Institute, The Present Tense, Mobius, SOI
For More information visit: www.BerwickInstitute.org, www.ThePresentTense.org, www.Mobius.org

Mystery Babylon is an original post-apocalyptic comic series unlike any other. Think less "gritty wasteland" and more "ancient Rome with goofy demons and superheroes causing a ruckus."
It's a dramatic-comedy-fantasy comic which follows the adventures of Kick Girl, an immortal demon with an unpleasant attitude. Along with her for the ride is Zero, a happy-go-lucky priest, and Delilah, the destiny-driven cult leader.
At the end of the Apocalypse, all of the demons were sealed away in The Pit. A conflicted Kick Girl made a promise to the dying hero, J.J., never to break the seal. A promise she kept for the past thousand years...

Mystery Babylon takes a unique twist on mythological themes about the end of the world, and mixes it with a lighthearted and expressive sense of humor. It's a fun-loving adventure comic suited for both young adults and not-so-young adults. If you love angels, demons, superheroes, mythology, constant backstabbing, name-calling, awkward romances, and holy water squirt bottles... then this is the comic for you!
There are currently 8 completed chapters in the series, so support the Kickstarter to see how the adventure began!
At 228 pages, this book will be my biggest printing project to date! Here's a mockup to show how the final printed product might look.
Read Jemma's comic, Children of Eldair! You can also find her on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, and Patreon! Big thanks to Jemma for the BEAUTIFUL guest art! I really hope backers will enjoy this free exclusive print! ♥
The goal of this Kickstarter is to raise enough money to print Volume One as a perfect bound, soft cover graphic novel. The book will be 6.5"x10", 228 pages long, full color, on high quality glossy paper.

If funding is successful, I plan to produce Volume Two next. Volume Two would include Chapters 4 through 8 as well as bonus material. After that, we could continue in the future with Volume Three.

All Kickstarter backers will get a very special thanks on the Kick-Girl.com website, grouped by pledge tier!

How can you help? You can back Mystery Babylon at any level that best fits you. If paperback books aren't for you, we also have a reward for a digital download. All rewards will go directly to the printing costs. You can help us immensely by sharing it everywhere! Sharing by both social media and by word-of-mouth can make all the difference!

It's tough for independent creators to get their work out there, but with Kickstarter, we can print fun new stories without the aid of big publishers. It's all thanks to awesome supporters like you that we can make this one-woman comic a reality!
Val Hochberg (Val Brazier) was born in the freezing cold snows of Buffalo, NY but moved to the burning heat of the Phoenix deserts to pursue a comic career. She is both the writer and artist of Mystery Babylon. She has been working on Mystery Babylon since 2010 and doesn't plan on stopping anytime soon!

You can support her on Patreon and get early access to new comic pages as well as other bonuses!

She really likes Star Wars, Dragon Age, giggling, and her Boosterific husband, Scott.
 A big huge THANK YOU! to everyone who supports the comic. Without you, this book would not be possible. ♥

This Kickstarter campaign will expand and update the award-winning 40-minute short documentary, Nefertiti's Daughters — a story of women, art, and revolution — into a feature-length film. All production and filming has been completed, and we are seeking backing to complete the editing and post-production phase by the end of March 2016. 
The original short film began as a successful Kickstarter project less than two years ago, which provided funding for us to travel to Cairo, Egypt in April 2014 for 11 days of production. In 2015, Nefertiti's Daughters saw its World Premiere at the prestigious Aspen Shortsfest, won the Grand Jury prize at the Athens International Film Festival, has since been accepted to 16 festivals, and acquired by Icarus Films, a top documentary distributor.
Events on the ground in post-revolutionary Egypt deteriorated since we filmed in 2014, with a repressive military regime back in firm control after it overthrew a democratically-elected government, and rolled-back the hard-fought gains of the Revolution. As a result, there was a tremendous need to update and expand the short into a fully-formed feature-length film, and the original 40-minute short has provided us with a clear proof of concept, given how the film strongly resonated around the world. 
"Three stories intersect in this compelling short film from director Mark Nickolas: the emergence of Egyptian street art, the oppression of women in the country, and the revolution that toppled President Hosni Mubarak but didn't stop government brutality against Egyptians." —Aspen Times
THE STORY
Nefertiti's Daughters is a feature-length documentary film that spotlights women, art, and revolution, and documents the critical role that revolutionary street art played—and continues to play—during the political uprisings since the 2011 Egyptian Revolution.
Following the ouster of long-time ruler Hosni Mubarak, when millions of Egyptians took to Tahrir Square for 18 days in early 2011 to express their demands for “bread, freedom, and social justice,” an even more repressive military regime under current President (and former Army general) Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has been the subject of growing international alarm.
Beyond Sisi's merciless efforts to crush any oppositional artistic expression — including street art — his regime has been condemned around the world for its increasing use of sexual violence as a political tool against his own people, as well as the accelerated targeting of journalists who are simply trying to do their job and shine light on the actions of the government.
The film introduces a group of courageous, gifted, and internationally-acclaimed female artists and activists, who are deeply involved in the struggle for social and political justice, and illustrates the surprising ways that artwork can become a powerful tool in the ongoing fight for civil and human rights. As the artists speak of their work, and the ways that it is inspired by and responds to a violent and complicated political environment, we are offered a rare window into the struggles of living and creating in Egypt today. 
Through this film, we witness how the revolutionary street art coming out of the Revolution served many functions: memorializing acts of government brutality; calling potential comrades into the struggle; turning the tables on male predators and sexism; and even imagining a world where a woman would be permitted to sing the sacred Adhan, the Muslim call for prayer.
We also learn how street art has long been a key means of communication and dissent during times of political transformation and social instability. Techniques, styles and symbols from Egyptian history are re-appropriated and adapted to become relevant today—including the image of the legendary Queen Nefertiti, a powerful symbol in an ongoing fight for justice.
THE STATUS OF THE FILM
All production for the feature-length version of Nefertiti's Daughters has been completed and we have already begun shifting all efforts into the final editing and post-production phase.
We remain confident that we will be ready to submit to film festivals by Spring 2016, with a specific target of meeting the March submission deadline for the 2016 Cannes Film Festival.
THE FILMMAKERS
Filmmakers Mark Nickolas and Elizabeth Van Meter come to this collaboration following significant award-winning accomplishments with their most recent films.
ELIZABETH VAN METER (Producer and Co-Director)
Elizabeth's first feature-length documentary film, Thao's Library (2015), recently won the Audience Choice Award at the inaugural Bentonville Film Festival, which actress Geena Davis specifically created to spotlight women and diversity in film. As a result, Elizabeth was awarded a week long nationwide theatrical run in AMC theaters in 20 cities across the United States and a distribution deal that will sell Thao's Library in Wal-Mart stores throughout the country, as well as video-on-demand on VUDU. 
Elizabeth's previous documentary work has taken her from the Andes Mountains of Peru to the Tohoku region of Japan (Hand in Hand, Lincoln Center 2014). She also directed and produced 40 short films for Gorgeous Entertainment documenting the lives of Japanese-Americans.
Elizabeth is a graduate of the University of North Carolina School of the Arts. 
MARK NICKOLAS (Director and Producer)
Prior to the accolades received for the 40-minute version of Nefertiti's Daughters, Mark earned considerable national media coverage from NPR, CNBC, and The Atlantic for his first short documentary film, My Life in the Canyon of Heroes (2013), a Smithsonian magazine finalist, which had its theatrical premiere at the Vancouver International Film Festival.
Before moving into documentary filmmaking, Mark was a long-time veteran of national Democratic politics, most notably as an aide to Vice President Al Gore and later managed a number of gubernatorial and congressional campaigns across the country before becoming a prominent figure in the political media world, and eventually entering the filmmaking world. 
Mark earned his bachelor's degree from the University of California at Berkeley, and his master's degree in Media Studies and Film from The New School in New York City.
Both filmmakers live in New York City.
THE FUNDS
Filmmaking is not an inexpensive endeavor and funds for independent documentaries are in short supply. Your donations will allow us to fully finish this film, which involves these specific things:
editing: hire a seasoned documentary editor to work with the filmmakers. 
composer/music: hire a composer for an original film score. 
sound design + sound mix: hire a sound designer and sound engineer to complete the final audio work.
color correction/mix: hire a colorist to correct and refine the film visuals. 
reimburse production costs: reimburse the costs of filming and travel-related expenses for the additional feature-length production.
license footage/materials + rights: allow us to acquire rights and licenses to use footage and images for the final film.
film festival submissions: allow us to pursue an aggressive film festival campaign (75-100 submissions), with festival submission fees running between $35 and $75 for each.
transfer/DCP conversion: convert finished film into a digital format for theatrical screening.
key art design: costs associated with creating the film poster, post cards, DVD and Blu-ray covers, and the electronic press kit.
printing: printing costs for DVDs, Blu-rays, posters, and post cards. 
E&O insurance + legal + accounting: administrative expenses to legally complete the film.
Kickstarter rewards: though we were careful to create great rewards for our donors, we were also cost-conscious in making sure that they accounted for a reasonable portion of the overall budget to create, acquire and ship to you.
THE COMMUNITY
Anything you can do to help our project is so incredibly appreciated. We are grateful for every contribution, Tweet, Facebook post, and words of support and encouragement! We are not here simply to raise money — as important as fundraising is. Kickstarter has shown itself to be a way for filmmakers to build communities, bringing together people who feel invested and are active participants in our creative work — this one — and those that we will continue to make. We hope you'll be with us for journeys to come.
This is a story that the world needs to know about. Thank you for taking the time to consider our project. We hope you will join us on this amazing journey.
Best, Elizabeth and Mark

Apathy and negative stigmas affect the 1.56 million homeless in the united states (one in two hundred people), and the purpose of Hearts Without Homes is to humanize those experiencing homelessness. While helpful nonprofits like Breaking Ground (http://www.breakingground.org/) are combating the problem, the movement in the political area is frustrating. Oftentimes great ideas are bogged down in bureaucracy and the homeless are swept under the political rug. 
Hearts without Homes is a interview/mini-doc with the aims to: 
1. Humanize those that are homeless
2. Inspire real and actual change in the political sphere
3. Provide each interviewed person that is homeless with a care package of living essentials such as clothes, food, water, as well as an informational pamphlet to help them get back on their feet. 
Homeless people are just fellow human beings that were faced with unfortunate circumstances or have hit hard times. They're just hearts without homes.
Interview/Mini-Doc Specifics:
Have Hope founder, Andrew Ooi, will be working with filmmakers Jordan Hill, Seth Gleckman, and Erica Armenta to interview those that are homeless, with a special way to show their humanity. We will be asking them "If you could make any change in the world happen, what would it be?" The goal is to see what global change someone with nothing would wish for: an exploration of the empathy and humanity of those who rarely receive any themselves. 
With the money raised from this Kickstarter, we will create care packages filled with clothes, food, water, and a blanket for homeless citizens in San Diego.

"Dogs and Bobcats" is a short documentary, produced by The Creature Show, about bobcat conservation in New Jersey. Your support will help us finish the film.
Q&A:
Why is there a dog?
Bear is a wildlife detection dog who is helping New Jersey biologists conduct a bobcat population study. (Bobcats are an endangered species in New Jersey.) The goal of the study is to create a baseline estimate of how many bobcats are left in the state.
What else is the story about?
Our story is about:
-Major threats to bobcats in New Jersey, including highways (they're hard to cross) and habitat fragmentation (bobcats prefer large spaces to roam.)
-An initiative called "Bobcat Alley," led by The Nature Conservancy's New Jersey Chapter, to connect bobcat habitat in Northwest Jersey. 
-Ideas about how to help bobcats and other creatures cross highways more safely. 
When will you be finished?
We hope to release "Dogs and Bobcats" by the end of 2017.
What is The Creature Show?
The Creature Show is an ongoing series of short films about threatened and endangered species in New Jersey. "Dogs and Bobcats" is the fifth installment of the series. You can watch past episodes at www.creatureshow.com.
What if you raise more money than your goal?
If we raise more than our goal, we'll be excited to put the funding toward future episodes of The Creature Show, including an upcoming episode about Pine Barrens tree frogs.
 Special Thanks
A special thank you to the groups and people who have participated in or supported "Dogs and Bobcats" to date, including The Nature Conservancy of New Jersey, New Jersey Conservation Foundation, the New Jersey Division of Fish & Wildlife Endangered and Nongame Species Program, and Carla Lee Lewis and family.

We made it!
In just four days, we met the goal. If you still would like to be a part of this project, any further donations will make this film even better and go towards making more projects like this possible.
Disability is a spectrum. Shouldn’t there be equally diverse tools available to people who live with them?
I'm always on the hunt for anything that can help me live the lifestyle I want. Because of a connective-tissue disorder, I have a difficult time walking distances but that doesn't keep me from snowboarding, rock climbing, or skateboarding. I just have a hard time getting to the adventure. 
Typically, the only mobility devices are wheelchairs and mobility scooters. I can either pay a ridiculous amount of money for some giant device I didn't completely need, just push through the exhaustion and soreness, or not go at all. 
I knew there had to be a better option. Physical ability is not as simple as walking or a wheelchair. Disability is a spectrum and there should be a diverse range of tools available to people who live with them, not just scooters and chairs. 
ASSISTED MOBILITY is a documentary film about redefining the idea of a “mobility device.” 
First, I reached out to an electric longboard company, Inboard Technology, and they sent me a beta version of their brand new M1 electric board. I already felt comfortable on a skateboard, so I thought their device might be the perfect fit for me. 
Next, I grabbed a camera and my friend, Jason, and we headed down to San Francisco to see what this board could really do. I figured that if I really want to know how well the board fits my needs, I have test it out in the widest range of situations possible. What better way to do that than going to a strange city with only a backpack and a skateboard?
In ASSISTED MOBILITY, I look at issues of practicality, individuality, and community. I investigate how people with disabilities could find a solution in-between walking and wheelchairs. I talk to experts about how new technology can empower individuals who have previously been restricted by old-fashioned ideas of "mobility devices.”
The film also covers how the board fits into my everyday life as a film student in Provo, Utah. 
Most of the filming is now complete and I’ve started the editing process. I need your help to push this project through post-production and out into the world. I don't need much. Just enough to cover costs like music licensing and festival submission fees, as well as help to offset some of the travel expenses I've already incurred.
A significant amount of time and resources have been volunteered already. I'm grateful for Brent, who let us stay in his beautiful North Beach apartment, and the team at Inboard, who graciously lent us two of their M1 electric longboards.

We're a group of aspiring filmmakers located in Bristol who are trying to raise the funds to bring our project to life. Our crew has studied film for several years now, and we're now putting that knowledge into practice. We've got some challenges ahead, but nothing we believe we can't overcome. 
We are extremely grateful for any size donation.

I've been able to self fund almost $10k to this point between legal and development fees.  We are nearing completion, and with just a little help, this will soon be available to all, free of charge!  Any excess of our goal will go towards additional marketing efforts.
About VIRTUE
Our Mission
Our mission is to provide a platform that gives users the opportunity to define and express one’s own life guiding principles, values, or simply his or her uniqueness through the posting of social media content.
The Categories
Each post a user makes gets placed into a category.  We believe that there is still a tremendous amount of untapped potential in the digital universe for the creation of positive social media content. Nine Categories were carefully selected in order to give opportunity and incentive to describe one’s entire well rounded self – mind, body & soul.  A basic guiding definition is offered for each category, but ultimately, it’s up to user to be as creative as he or she wish.  VIRTUE is designed for U, no matter who U are!  It can be completely different from one user to the next.  It is not aimed or geared toward any particular group, other than human beings. It’s up to you to leave your impact on this world, so start building your digital legacy with VIRTUE, because what’s inside U matters!
Your Top 3
Within each category you select the top 3 posts that you feel best represent you.  Change or rearrange them as often as you like.  As time goes on and you change, keep your top 3’s current so that your VIRTUE profile changes with you. There are an infinite number of possible combinations in which to set your top 3’s.  Keep it simple, or get as creative as you desire.
Balance
On your profile, each category will have a quantity notifier to show how many posts are within. This is to allow for awareness of your dimension.  Show the world the whole you and what makes you unique by defining yourself with all of your top 3’s, but also show how much depth you have beyond those.
Individual category descriptions
Attitude
Are you an optimist or a pessimist?  Attitude is your evaluation of, or expression toward people, events, objects, activities or ideas. This could include, but not be limited to, thoughts of integrity, tolerance, respect, perseverance, courage, patience, etc.
Humor
What makes you laugh?  Your sense of humor can be defined as the trait of appreciating, and being able to express the humorous.
Wisdom
What is your philosophy on things?  Wisdom is the determination of your actions or decisions with regard to the application of experience, knowledge, and good judgment.
Health
What does health mean to you?  Health can be described as your state of overall physical, mental, and social well-being. Posts might include some observations, goals, efforts and/or results, etc.
Beauty
Many say that beauty is in the eye of the beholder.  It can be skin deep or come from within. What you experience as beauty involves your interpretation of some entity as being in balance and harmony with nature, which may lead to feelings of attraction and/or emotional well-being.
Community
How have the places and/or people in your life impacted you?  Your sense of community comes from a feeling of belonging.  A feeling that you matter to someone and/or to a group of people. 
Generosity
What makes you generous?  Your generosity can be measured as your willingness to share, whether it be money, commitment of time, or compassion.  It is the quality of being kind and understanding.
Passion
What are the things that drive you?  Passion can be described simply as ambition, or as a strong feeling of enthusiasm or excitement you have for something or about doing something.
Gratitude
What are you grateful for?  Your gratitude is the quality of being thankful and/or readiness to show appreciation for and to return kindness.

PLAY

Virtual reality is finally emerging as an accessible medium. I am creating an experience that will take us back to the birth of photography, the medium that spawned all subsequent image-based technological innovations.
 I am committed to making this experience as accesible as possible and currently have four venues around the country lined up for 2017. I would like to make entry as little as possible, so am appealing to your generosity to help make this happen.
An early rendering of the virtual room
The installation I am producing will be a portal to the past. It will place you inside the 1839 exhibition where you will see the artefacts and touch the cases that housed them. I will build an actual room with simple structures inside that tally geometrically with the objects you view virtually in your headset.
Actual room build
The purpose of these are to give you the illusion that you are touching the simulated objects in the virtual world. This is a relatively untapped area in VR and one that makes for a uniquely uncanny experience.
Your hand touching the vitrine
Ghost-like auras will indicate the presence of other guests to prevent collisions and enhance the sensation of time-travel.
Ghost like avatars and virtual firepace
A fire will crackle in the fireplace and you will feel its heat as you approach. Various technical innovations from the period will be on display in the glass vitrines.
CG recreation of the Wilmhurst Static Electricity Machine
In amongst them are the early works of Henry Fox Talbot.
Outside the actual room other visitors will wait to gain entry. Rectangular holes in the walls will enable them to look inside at the other guests as they explore the exhibition.
View from outside VR room
These holes are synchronised with paintings hanging on the walls of the virtual room and will simply form part of the décor to those wearing the headset.
View from inside VR room
There will be alternate levels of reality and unreality. This is a virtual reality of a virtual reality of reality.
We have four venues lined up for our tour: Photo London at Somerset House in May, Birmingham Museum & Art Gallery in June, Lacock Abbey in September, and National Media Museum Bradford in November.
Mat Collishaw
I am a visual artist with over 25 years experience exhibiting in galleries worldwide. This is my first foray into virtual reaiity (VR). You can see more of my work at http://www.matcollishaw.com
The team 
We are developing the project with Paul Tennant at Nottingham University Mixed Reality Lab (part of their computer Science department), VMI Studio and The White Wall Company in London. The Mixed Reality Lab are developing the movement detection side of the project while VMI Studio are recreating our VR room in CG. The White Wall Company will be building the actual room. Work has been underway since January 2016 and we are now moving into the final phase. My partners on Thresholds are Pete James (a photographic historian), Larry Schaaf (an authority on Talbot), Paul Tennant (of Nottingham University Mixed Reality Lab), VMI Studio, The Science Museum, The British Library, The Royal Institution, The King Edward Grammar School, Lacock Abbey and The National Media Museum Bradford. 
The project has been kindly supported finacially by King Edward's School, Birmingham, The Schools of King Edward VI in Birmingham, Colmore Business District, Birmingham City University and The Art Fund.
Talbot's early production line
  The English photographer Henry Fox Talbot showed his early experiments in photography in an exhibition of cutting edge science in 1839 at the King Edward's School, Birmingham. These photographs are now impossible to see as Talbot had not by then resolved the process for fixing his prints and they have thus faded with time.
  An early Talbot Photogenic Drawing
  Chartist rioting
The Chartists were rioting in the city that year, demanding the right to vote and voicing opposition to the technological developments of the industrial revolution and the mechanisation of labour taking jobs from real people. Occasionally you will hear a disturbance and see a violent crowd gathered outside in the street, throwing missiles and shouting slogans.
A torch lit mob
As our digital world encroaches on more and more jobs, these issues find a parallel in our world today.
Robots welding, riveting, bonding and installing components

Why We're Doing This:
As you may know Cloud Party are an original rock/Americana band from the Philly/Reading PA area.  We've just finished the recording of our new--and long awaited, fifth album, The Dying Art of Living.  Feel free to watch the dorky video above for more info, or just keep reading!
Here's a song, "Shadow of an Angel," from our third album, Real: 
So you may be asking, if the recording is done, why does Cloud Party need funding? And since Cloud Party has released four other albums, why are they using a Kickstarter campaign for this one?  Good questions!
The first is easier to answer.  The recording IS done, but there's a lot more to releasing an album than the recording.  Normally a record label does all this stuff for us, but the label that released our last album is no longer viable so we're doing all this on our own--the actual pressing of CDs, cover art, graphic design, photos and more.  Without this investment, you can't hold that physical product in your hands!  We've already shelled out some $4000 on the recording, so now is not the time to scrimp on the final product.
The second answer is kind of implied by the answer to the first question.  It's been six years (hard to believe!) since the last Cloud Party album--six years of struggle, for various reasons which we need not go into here.  One of those things, though, was essentially losing what label support we had.  
Also, times have changed!  There's this neato thing called the Internet and things get done on the Internet.  So, with that idea in mind, what better way to announce to the world that Cloud Party is back than to invite you guys to participate in the album itself through Kickstarter? Not only that, but because people will be sort of pre-ordering, we'll have a better idea of how many CDs we'll need. This way, you get to be a part of the party, the album gets done and the word gets out to everyone.
If we happen to raise more money than what's needed for final pressing (about $2500.00 all told) we'll use said cash to promote the heck out of this album and get the word out on radio, magazines, newspapers, the Internet, heck, Rolling Stone. Whatever it takes!  
If you'd like to learn more about the history of Cloud Party, who we are now, and more about The Dying Art of Living, then just continue reading.  Don't be afraid to check out some of the pictures throughout as well as click on links to video and some music.
Cloud Party was formed by me, Jim Speese, with Mark Steffy "back in the day." It has since released four albums and played all over. (We've had some really fun gigs--you've probably been at some.)
Mark and Jim at at gig at Bistro 614, April 10, 2013
The band presently consists of Jim (vocals, guitar) and Mark (lead guitar) and Kevin Adams (drums). Plus newcomers Evelyn Christian (keys/vocals) and Gerry Ronning (bass/guitar) not to mention the occasional appearance by former Zoo Boy, Keith Smoker (bass.)
I have to say  that the band has been my alter-ego for over a decade now, allowing me to express myself as a (musical) artist.  And Mark Steffy is what makes the musical engine run. As you can hear with some of our music, Mark's guitar can be captivating.  Click below to hear Mark's guitar solo which opens the song "The Mansion on the Hill" from the album Real.  
The Dying Art of Living:
Believe it or not, the album's title comes from an off-hand line in the oldest of the songs on the album.
Jim on the AT back in the day . . .
I wrote the song "Alive" when I was hiking on the Appalachian Trail in 1991.  Hiking on the AT (for three months) was the most magical time of my life.  Every painful but sublime step confirmed that I was impossibly alive.  In that song, I imagined a far distant future when I'd possibly forgotten these moments, and wished my future self a memory in song.  I wrote the lyrics and music in my head as I hiked 2 miles for a Coke (the things you do on the AT!)  Fast forward to now. 
Rediscovering the song "Alive" as Cloud Party tried to find a "personality" or theme to the new recording was like reconnecting to an old friend.  I really felt as if I had been contacted by my younger self.  It was a reminder about life, in more ways than one. I've found that my writing tends to be about trying to hold onto the magical moments of life, about lost memories and moments.  So it fit right into an album about loss and life.
Click below to hear Mark and Jim play an acoustic version of "Stay Away from My Heart" (which appears on the new album) live in the studios of radio station WBZH in Pottstown:
I should note that the album is also FUN! "The Superhero Song" is about my life-long dream ("I wanna be Spiderman"--you hear that, Phil?)  Some songs, like "Making Out With Kate" (which we'd been playing for years but had never formally recorded) we added by request (Sara, this means YOU!)  I think that title speaks for itself.
(Click the link below for an ancient video of Cloud Party playing "Making Out with Kate."  I should note the song has changed a lot since then--and the version of CP here is an entirely different band, save for Jim and Mark.)
Cloud Party also finally recorded its first full-bore electric blues song, "These Blues" for The Dying Art of Living. There's also "Sad Eyed Rose,"  an acoustic song, on this album. Click below to hear Mark and Jim playing "Sad Eyed Rose" live in the studios of radio station WBZH in Pottstown.
Some songs also touch on more recent travels, including magical trips to places like The Island of the Sun in Lake Titicaca ("Waiting All This Time.")
Sunset on The Island of the Sun
Of course, I'm not the only one doing this stuff. One of the songs, for instance, is called "Gone" and is mostly Gerry's meditation on moral responsibility (though, frankly,  it reminds me of The Clash.) Evelyn's contribution on vocals and keyboards is integral to the sound of the record (I still call them records) and Kevin's drumming is really freaking good.
The album ends with a little lullaby ("Dreamland") Mark and I wrote for our friend Kirsten's daughter, Julia, shortly after she was born.  And she's almost a teenager now . . . man, this album is a long time coming.
All in all The Dying Art of Living will feature 13 relatively "new" Cloud Party songs.  I've listed the songs at the end of this history--feel free to skip ahead and check out the titles.  Also, the album features some guest stars, including singer Alisa B and Max Watkins who played cello on a couple songs.
The History of The Dying Art of Living:
We started recording this album AGES ago . . . but things happened.  In fact, not once, but twice, we began to record demos for the songs that would eventually be on this album, but, in the midst of the project, the studio(s) closed down (for reasons that had nothing to do with us--we swear.)  Each time that happened, it set us back about a year. In addition, several members of Cloud Party moved on to other projects (we miss you Joe and Chris) and things just got really busy.  Click here to hear a really early demo of "Before I Sleep" recorded in one of those other studios:
Enter Rich Bickel.  Rich had a studio in Collegeville.  I happened to know Rich's aunt, and one day (or night, more likely, with a libation) I complained about how I couldn't find the right studio, and she told me all about Rich's place. It sounded awfully familiar.  Turns out it was!  We had recorded our second album, everything and nothing, there with Tom Volpicelli and Joe Mattis. Rich had apparently bought the studio from Joe and Tom.  (Man, this is getting complicated.)
Rich in his element
Anyway, turns out Rich is a great producer and an even greater guy. It also turns out he loved our music, so it was a match made in heaven.  
(Most of) the band in the studio. Kevin is behind the glass in the studio; Control room from L-R is Gerry, Jim, Keith, Mark
That said, it took us well over a year to finish the album.  Just to tie this story all together in a neat bow, Tom Volpicelli visited us a few times (to see his old studio) and he's mastering the project at The Mastering House (his business, since the studio was sold.)
Whew!  That's quite the story.  So you see, this is not just an album for us.  It's more of a crazy journey.  We are so excited to finish this album and get it out.  I can't wait until it's in your hands too!
Jim, Mark and Evelyn
Oh, and just a quick shout-out to graphic artist Jay Kunkel for being kind enough to do some work on the graphics pro-bono before we use Kickstarter--the cool image at the top of this page is taken from the album artwork that he's working on.  He also filmed and edited the video above.  Among the pluses if this thing gets financed is that he gets paid!
Cloud Party (L-R: Kevin, Jim, Mark Keith, Evelyn, Gerry)
Also thanks to Chad DeShazo for the band photos. You rock.
A secondary goal of $4,000 will mean some extensive touring for the band and lots and lots of promotion . . .

Songs on The Dying Art of Living
The order has not been set yet, but here's the list; you may recognize some of these from some of our shows:
All the Nights
Gone
Stay Away from My Heart
Nowhere and Everywhere
The Irony of You
Before I Sleep
Sad Eyed Rose

The Black Arrow calendar will help raise funds towards building a full scale replica of the Black Arrow rocket at High Down, on the Isle of Wight. The Black Arrow rockets first began production in 1966, with 5 rockets being produced in total, the replica model will celebrate the rockets 50th anniversary in 2016.
The Black Arrows were tested at High Down in the late 60's before being shipped to Australia for launch from the Woomera rocket range.
Black Arrow rocket undergoing qualification testing
The rocket programme was cancelled in 1971 but most of the infrastructure remains in place & Highdown is now open to the public & thousands visit the site each year.
The full scale replica will give visitors to High Down as sense of the scale of the rockets tested there & hopefully inspire the next generation.
The calendar will be an opportunity to own 12 of the original artworks created by Rich Curtis for the 2016 celebrations. Each image will be approximately A4 in size rendered at 300dpi to give the best print quality on the easy to use, fold-out booklet style calendars. ( A3 in size when you include the date section & hung up ).
This includes one of the most detailed computer graphics of the Black Arrow rocket ever created as well as a range of dramatic flight sequence graphics showing the rocket on its journey into space.
Flight Sequence Graphic
The target of £450 is to cover the cost of having the smallest bulk print run of calendars produced, we need to sell just 30 to achieve this but the more we sell the the bigger the print run & the more money we can raise towards the project.
The aim is for at least £8.00 from each calendar sold will go towards creating the 50th anniversary display at High Down. The more funds we can raise the better the replica will be.
We have various options on how to create the replica rocket dependent on the funds raised from a low cost 2D display board to an inflatable version, but the main hope is to have the replica professionally built on the Isle of Wight, making use of the manufacturing companies we have.
So as well as supporting this fab project you will also be supporting a range of existing jobs & skills.
 Many thanks again for your support and getting rocket ready for 2016.
Prospero Satellite in Orbit
