Our Story: After years of collaboration, We came together in the spring of 2015 with a group of women for the Scarlet Crow Remembrance Tour. We spent months preparing for this tour, to hold a ceremonial music container to serve as a think-tank for subjects that were near and dear to our hearts. We spoke about subjects of our history, lifting the rug on aspects of cultural slumber, especially around the silencing and renewal of the feminine.
After having a successful tour, we decided to record a collection of songs. Many of the songs we took on the road to serve as a document of the prayers we made and continue to make.
Story of the Album: In January of this year, we recorded these 12 songs in our humble bedroom studio over 4 days. We sent a few songs over to Barry Phillips, who added gorgeous cello arrangements. We called in David Earl to help produce and mix one of the tracks, and then gave the rest of these songs to Yaegon of Kalya Scintilla, who supported the song's flourishing with his masterful sound-wizarding ways. After a few weeks in the melting pot with Yaegon, these songs are cooked and ready to taste.
We are now bringing them to the center of our community, and calling for your support in helping us fund the rest of our process. 
Will you help us in our "Remembrance" ??
 Why support us? We believe in the power of authentic and vulnerable storytelling to open up important dialogues in our community that are imperative for the shift into a thriving life for the future of this planet. The atmosphere and alchemy we create as a duo offers a unique doorway into many of the important underbelly issues, while holding space for them to integrate in a beautiful and nourishing way. We believe in the power of women standing together, uniting in song and voice, to create waves of immeasurable change across the lands. We take our combined craft and create an all inclusive community of men, women and everything in between to become better allies through learning and exploration.
Why are we doing a Kickstarter?
We are running a kickstarter for this album because it is a great way to connect with our immediate tribe of supporters. We feel that through the power of crowd funding, we can continue to support our community in the best way we know how: by creating compelling art. In response, our community can support us in crafting it by chipping in for the production expenses in exchange for unique, awesome incentives!
get a usb drive with our library of sounds!!!!

$7777- meeting this second goal will support us in financing a greater range of the production costs mentioned above, easily fulfilling our rewards to you, and additionally supporting our short documentary project Remembrance, filmed during our inception tour in 2015.
$11111- meeting this third goal will enable us to have the resources we need to produce our first music video!!!!
$15000- meeting this *ultimate* goal supports us in creating several music videos, plus our documentary project, and will allow us to have additional resources for a promotional campaign. It will enable us to cover all the production expenses of this album, and support us to create an even more dynamic LIVE stage show. If we meet this goal, we will literally be singing on top of the mountains to you all!!!!!

WHAT'S A KICKSTARTER?
Kickstarter is an all-or-nothing crowdfunding platform that allows makers (like me!) to generate funding through pledges for wonderful projects!
You will not be charged unless the project is 100% funded so you pledge now and pay later! Payment will go through only if the initial goal is met!
If this project gets funded, Kickstarter will hold the funds for 2 weeks for processing then release the funds to the me so I can begin production.
My campaign will run for 30 days! You can select your pledge and change it as many times as you would like until the project ends. If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to ask me :)!

    Girl Genius is an ongoing story featuring adventure, romance, and Mad Science! It follows the adventures of Agatha Heterodyne, the last of a notorious family in which the spark of mad science runs strong. We call it a "Gaslamp Fantasy," by which we mean that it takes place in an old-fashioned, Vernian world of airships, monsters, and wild inventions.
Girl Genius is published as a webcomic and graphic novel series, and also as a series of prose novels. The graphic series is updated three times a week on our web site at girlgeniusonline.com. When we have enough pages, roughly once a year, we run a Kickstarter campaign and publish a collection.
Queens and Pirates is Book Five of the Second Journey of Agatha Heterodyne–and the eighteenth book in the overall series. If you're new to the Girl Genius comics, The Second Journey is a great place to jump in!
We are Phil and Kaja Foglio, creators of the ongoing adventure story Girl Genius. We are ready to make the print version of Girl Genius: Queens and Pirates, the latest in our self-published series of Hugo award-winning graphic novels. The book will be printed as a trade paperback, with a short run of special hardcover volumes that feature a lovely "puffy" padded cover.
We used to offer pre-orders for upcoming books through our online store; which helped us pay for the up-front costs of printing the books. It also allowed us to get an idea of how many books we should be making in the first print run, especially of the limited-edition hardcover. Now we use Kickstarter, which really streamlines this process. We learn and get better at it every time we do a campaign. You can see information about all our previous campaigns on the Kickstarter Information page at girlgeniusonline.com.
If this campaign funds, all our backers will be asked to fill out our Very Necessary Pledge Manager form from BackerKit. A link to the pledge manager will be sent to each backer in an email from us through BackerKit, and we'll let everyone know when it has gone out. The pledge manager is important, because it's the only way we get a physical address to use when we mail your rewards.

Oh, if you haven't already seen, we were featured in Men's Health! Click here to read.
Quick Synopsis
We embedded with amazing indigenous ultra-runners to bring you a cinematic expression of why we all love to run. We travelled to the highlands of Japan, the Kalahari Desert in Africa, the Navajo Nation in Arizona, the forests of Finland and the streets of NYC (the famed Self-Transcendence 3100 Mile Run)  to capture the esoteric, spiritual side of running. 
We shot the film in narrative (non-fiction) style and weave our stories together in such a natural way that we're sure this film will be unlike any sports documentary ever made.
We've completed all filming and need your help to finish editing the film, doing a sound mix, composing music and doing color correction.
Our Bushman character preparing for a hunt.
Overview
Like many runners, we were inspired by the 2009 book Born to Run. But we wanted to hear even more about the deepest spiritual traditions of exceptional indigenous runners from around the world. We wondered if we could, first of all, find runners that actually embodied the ancient esoteric approach to running and then earn their trust.
But first ... a 3100 Mile Race??
The most elusive, elite multi-day race in the world, the Self-Transcendence 3100 Mile Race, takes place in Queens, New York City each summer and demands at least 59 miles a day for 52 straight days.  
We followed Ashprihanal Aalto, a diminutive Finnish paperboy and a 13 time (!) finisher of this colossal race as he returned for a record 14th attempt. We also follow Shamita Achenbach-Konig, an Austrian cellist as she attempts the Race for the first time. 
While the participants of that Race are for the most part Western, the Race was founded by the Indian spiritual teacher Sri Chinmoy. In a sense, the Race requires runners to tap into an ancient energy found in the most remote cultures of the world. We build the arc of the entire film around this race and bounce between remote, expedition-worthy locations to draw parallels between the approaches to running.
The start of the 2016 3,100 Mile Race
Monks, Navajo & Bushmen - Oh My!
Cameras in hand, we set off on a global exploration of running. 
We hunted on the run with the Bushmen of Botswana. Hunting was recently banned by the Botswana Government as one step in their attempt to destroy this ancient culture. We met a group of Bushmen hunters defying that ban who wanted us to film their ancestral way of hunting.
We ran with champion Navajo runners versed by their Elders in the spiritual traditions of running. Shaun Martin, a Navajo educator, was attempting to retrace the footsteps of his father, who like many Native American kids was forced into government boarding school. Shaun's dad would routinely escape and walk the 100 miles back to his family's homesite. Shaun was attempting to do that distance in one shot.
And we embedded with the Japanese Marathon Monks to document their epic 1,000 day running journey where the stakes are literally life or death. Once a generation they pick an Aspirant to do 1000 days over 7 years, in 100 day chunks - up to 56 miles per day. If the Aspirant fails to complete his/her daily mileage requirement, he/she must commit suicide (!). Thankfully this hasn't happened in 100s of years.
Getting access was not easy by any means. But we approached with enough humility to win over folks, some of whom had never allowed outsiders to film their core spiritual traditions. And to our delight and surprise, the stories started to overlap in absolutely amazing ways.  
Our Navajo runner on a 100 miler.
  Risking Everything
Our characters and our team risked much (in some cases their very lives) to bring you this film. We’ve completed production and have started editing. We need your help to complete our edit and share the film with runners everywhere.
Will the film change the world? We don’t know. Will it change the viewers? Can’t say for sure. Has it changed us? Yes – it most certainly has. And that transformative experience we’ve had as filmmakers and runners is exactly what we want to bring to you. We’ve all run millions of steps in our lifetimes. We’re asking for your help in taking this next big step together.

Nightgaunts - A Lovecraftian short creature film
We're adapting of one of HP Lovecraft’s classic tales of terror into an surreal short film, combining live action with motion capture and stop motion animation.
 The Story
In the year 1920, a young writer is tormented nightly by apocalyptic visions of a strange ruined city, where the last remnants of humanity are hunted down by ravenous eldritch creatures! There is no place to hide, for the great Old Ones have returned, and they have reclaimed the world as their own.
The Origin of the Nightgaunts
When it comes to the work of writer H.P. Lovecraft's, the thing that most people remember are the creatures that he invented. Undying alien gods, and shapeshifiting horrors beyond man's feeble comprehension, like the great Cthulhu, Yog-Sothoth, and the Demon Sultan Azathoth.
But these were not the first creatures that Lovecraft saw in his imagination. For years when he was younger, Lovecraft writes that he was terrified by a vivid reoccurring nightmare. In these dreams, Lovecraft found himself trapped in a strange city, with bizarre angles and alien geometry. And then, swarming out of the darkness he would see them. A race of faceless flying creatures. Horned, black, and slender, with membranous bat-like wings. Every night he would run from these creatures, and every night they would chase him down. They would pull him screaming into the air in their talons, and carry him over a hellish world teeming with shapeless monstrosities. This early experience would leave a lasting impression Lovecraft in his work as a writer, with these terrifying images creeping into his work time and time again. After 30 years, he write down his nightmare, turning it into a short piece called 'Nightgaunts'.
PLAY

Adaptation
Creating any adaptation comes with challenges, but it is especially difficult when it comes to Lovecraft's writing. The power of his work isn't in the events that happen in the plot, but its in the way he describes things. The deeply unsettling mood that he manages to create. Cyclopic images and glimpses of cosmic cycles that utterly dwarf his characters and the reader, to create an overwhelming sensation of helplessness. The constant looming threat fearfully mentioned throughout the mythos he created is the inescapable prophecy that one day mankind will be cleared off the planet when the Old Ones awaken to reclaim the world as their own. 
In our film, we want to bring Lovecraft's apocalyptic vision to life. To show one dreamer's terrifying glimpse of a future world, where behemoth alien Gods tower over the destroyed cities of man. Where the last humans are reduced to hiding like our mammal ancestors during the Age of tyrant lizards. Hiding in the ruins, like insects under a stone, and fleeing from hungry swarms of Nightgaunts that pick off the last survivors.
We aim to capture this oppressive atmosphere through our use of surreal visuals and experimental film making techniques. For inspiration, we've been looking at German expressionist artwork and films of the 1920's. In particular we are drawn to the work FW Murnau, creator of Nosferatu (1922)  and Faust (1926). 
Nosferatu (1922) and Faust (1926)
We want to emulate his expert use of bold angle, dark shadows, and bold mythical poetic images. By combing live action, photomontage, and both 3d and stop motion animation together, we aim to create a film that feels like a lucid nightmare.
Here is an early test clip that we put together last month, show some of the techniques we will be experimenting with.
PLAY

The Creature Design
One of the main attractions of our project is the chance to bring some of Lovecraft's classic creatures to life in a new way.
Now the Nightgaunts have been around a long time. For nearly 90 years, sci fi illustrators have been drawing them, and for the most part they've come to have a fairly accepted standardized look. They are depicted as humanoid demons with bat wings on their back. 
  Original Nightgaunt illustration
But for our film, we want to reimagine them as if they were creatures that evolved on another world. Living alien organisms, with adaptations that help them survive in their environment. To stay true to the source material, there are key features that we needed keep: they are horned, slender, with a pitchfork tail, grasping claws, bat like wings, and have no face. Next we looked at nature for answers.
Nightgaunt animal references
For example, the creature that has no face but still need a way to eat prey. So like a star fish, we've imagined it has evolved a mouth in its chest, and can extend it's stomach directly onto prey. Then instead of a tail, we've given it a long forked tongue that extends out of the chest mouth to taste its surroundings. If it has no eyes, it must have developed a form of echolocation. So we've shaped the horns to act like bat's ears, to channel sound into the giant ear drum that takes up the Nightgaunt's entire face. 
Nightgaunt Concept Drawings
  Nightgaunt concept model turnaround
 Nightgaunt with first pass of texturing.
PLAY

Motion Capture
Like in our last film, 'The Jovian Project', we are excited to again be using Motion Capture technology in part to help bring the film’s creatures to life. Although working with Mocap may have a complicated pipeline, it has huge advantages for us as performers and storytellers. There is so much that is gained from having a human physically perform on a set. It allows us the chance to become the creatures, and to make discoveries we never would have thought of if we were just sitting behind a computer. Using stilts, our mocap performers are forced to rethink how to move and interact with their environment with pteranodon like elongated arms and folded wings. We also get to explore the behavior of a blind creature. We've done shots where the actors are blind folded or have closed eyes, forcing them to navigate by the sound and by touch. In the end, we hope to create creatures that are believable as real animals, not just monsters. 
PLAY

  PLAY

Stop Motion 
Kat Ruiz, Stop Motion Animator
While our team embraces new technology, we are also very passionate about keeping classical styles of animation alive, such as stop motion. As animators, the work of legend Ray Harryhausen remains one of our biggest inspirations. No matter how good the computer rendering is, sometimes there is no way to replace the real thing. So for our film, we want to pay homage to the classics and find creative ways to incorporate stop motion into creating our environments and the Creatures FX. Such as in bringing to life the writhing lakes of shape-shifting Shoggoths. The downside is that using stop motion is largely more expensive and time consuming for our production than it would to be to use 3D Animation. Therefore the extent to which we will be able to use Stopmotion in our film will have to be determined primarily by the amount of backing our project receives.
About us
For the core members of our team, this will be our second film project together. Our first animated short film 'The Jovian Project', loosely based on the short story 'From Beyond', was an homage to the classic B movies of the atomic age and the horror movies of Vincent Price. Our film has met with success in festivals around the world, winning the Berlin Scifi Film Festival's award for Best Animation.
Jovian Project Poster
Here's a behind the scenes look at the making of 'The Jovian Project'.
PLAY

Given our the strong reception we've received from science fiction and horror fans out there, we've decided to rejoin forces to bring you an even more ambitious film project!
Cast:
Evan Hall - The Dreamer
In our surreal film, Evan Hall will be playing the leading role as the Dreamer, a young writer whose reoccurring apocalyptic nightmares have pushed him verge of nervous breakdown. This character is inspired by H.P. Lovecraft's own descriptions of himself in his youth, and Lovecraft's reoccurring fictional character Randolph Carter.  
At Victoria School of the Performing Arts, Evan received the Dean Storie Award for his work in Physical Theatre. This inspiration led him to Vancouver's Seacoast Studio, led by Canadian theatre alumnis Scott Swan to learn Naturalistic, Shakespearian, and Film & Television Acting. He has since performed in at least 100 different Film Productions. He has also performed throughout BC with Seacoast's long-running show, Fractured, an ensemble play about the growing consistency of school shootings in North America, where he received the Greater Vancouver Zone Theatre Festival's award for Best Supporting Actor. 
Evan and Noah have worked together on Noah Van Buhren's award-winning production "The Jovian Project" where they both used motion capture. This time Evan is on the other side of the coin, working on camera against the mo-cap characters, and is enjoying the new challenge.

Everyone Is Important To Us!
What is The Re-Taken?
In the spirit of Insidious, The Conjuring and The Exorcist, The Re-taken is an intense American female driven supernatural horror film inspired by actual events.  Women are heroes and a mother's love is a mighty force to be reckoned with in this world and in the supernatural world as well.   The story was written by California attorney, turned writer-producer, Adina Turman and features a talented multi-cultural, multi-racial cast. 
The Story 
A gifted psychic mother and grandmother, a master of astral projection is a retiring demon hunter.  She and her identical twin sister, also a psychic, are forced to use their individual supernatural talents and all the risk that comes with them, to save her daughter from an ultimate demon possession from a long ago threat.  The problem they face is that once your soul has been taken, can it be re-taken?

Rebecca Bathory in an Abandoned School 2012
Rebecca Bathory is a fine art photographer from London. Finding beauty in darkness, poetry and meaning in the forgotten and surreal imaginary worlds amongst decay. Rebecca's artworks breathe life into forgotten historical locations, reawaken old narratives, find beauty and meaning in ruin and revive the memories of lost moments in forgotten places.
  Elegant Decay
    The Manor
    The Orphans of Time series consists of 5 years of photographing abandoned buildings
The photography series Orphans of Time started in 2012, when Rebecca stepped into an abandoned school and fell in love with the beauty to be found in decay, her previous love of fashion photography became replaced by a love of capturing images of these buildings. Orphans of Time is a collection of images from over 500 abandoned locations visited during the last five years.
Decadent Decay
Unseen by the ordinary public who pass blindly by their boarded windows and fenced walls, "No Trespass" signs restrain communities from seeing the hidden world within, slowly being claimed back by nature. Rebecca finds entry to these mystical, hidden places and sensitively captures a beautiful record of them, as they deserve to be recorded for posterity, before they are lost as time rolls inexorably on. 
She captures their stories and character through carefully composed images, revealing the romance and memories of the ruins. In reality these places will cease to exist very soon and as  memories fade, they will be forgotten and although derelict places have no appeal as tourist destinations, their value and place in cultural memory is fundamental to the history of the 20th century. 
The Beauty Within
These majestic places are crumbling with time and one day will disappear entirely from view and living memory. But, there is no difference between iconic world sites, which attract tourism and the abandoned places known to so few. Hidden from the narrative of history, these places are imbued with a wealth of meaning, a history of their own, which deserves to be recorded for posterity too. It is absolutely vital to sensitively preserve this rich history before it is gone forever.
Melancholia
  Doorway to a New Realm
  Orphans of Time, the book, is a 240 page, limited edition of 2000 featuring the award winning series of photographs of abandoned buildings by British fine art photographer Rebecca Lilith Bathory. Rebecca travelled around the world for five years, from 2012 to 2017, seeking out the most beautiful, decaying locations. The book features approximately 200 full colour photos from the images she obtained.
Rebecca has chosen to self publish this series as it holds a very special part of her heart, from years of adventures in decaying buildings, she has selected her favourite and the most popular images from the series to produce this Victorian inspired book. As if it has been found decaying in the very buildings she has taken the photos within the pages.

The is short horror film follows the life of a young male who gets money from breaking into homes and selling the loot. One night while doing a usual break in things take a bad turn. Afterwards our main character is haunted by his own conscious and his sanity slowly deteriorates. 
I go to Temple University with a team of friends as we are all Film majors. My friends are Max Breen and Zack Lloyd and Evan Morson, a Penn State Film Major. (Each of their Youtube channels are in my bio). We are looking to have this film look professional by renting premium film equipment. We also have have plans of entering it in Film festivals.

Example 'Certificate of Authenticity'
Cover Image of 'Coffee Table Photo Binder' (with the inclusion of 25 'Black and White' Complimentary M&B Images to assist in initiating a Personalized Vintage Photography Collection).
'A Young Man's Life Prayer' Original Limited-Edition (11" x 14" Print)
Imagine not being able to hold on to those memories or perhaps refer to those memories captured via still images.  These images depict meanings in life that portray certain feelings of love, relaxation and a respectful view of what life is really about. Each and every photo placed in this book (and displayed via the website) defines its own characteristic as it challenges the viewer to read into the messages conveyed.
My main purpose in reaching out to the Kickstarter Community is for assistance in raising enough money to provide those special people in my life (as well as those who make generous donations) a rare customized vintage photo frame book (binder) that entails a compilation of imagery that has derived from years of photographing and capturing the innocence of unconditional love.  My grandmother, who has always thought highly of me and the success of my work, has taken ill since the death of my grandfather and I feel that her having this tangible book at her disposal could be the answer in giving her that extra motivation to live another day, due to her strong faith in me and my dream of becoming a photographer.  She does not have a computer to access my work on-line (as I strictly use on-line services for purposes of marketing), so the main idea behind this project (aside from primarily enhancing and promoting the photography business itself) is to significantly enlighten her heart by taking all of the on-line images via my website and creating a unique Avery-style 'Lasher Antiqued Victorian' Photo Book that is specifically made for her.  This photo binder includes 2" Capacity 1 Touch EZ-Turn™ 3-Ring Gaps (black) used to prevent gapping and misalignment. The book itself significantly portrays each image via an eye-catching 8.5" x 11" customized signature full-bleed, photo-quality printing on the front, back and the 2.8" spine. This photo book binder includes 500 pages, created to display professional quality satin photo prints developed specifically for darkroom printing.  Kodak photographic paper is a premium silver-halide paper designed to dramatically enhance colors while maintaining consistent tonal reproduction per a hardbound cover. The backer in receipt of this professionally made book binder copy (based on specific 'Reward Option') will have the opportunity of displaying the received 5.00" x 7.00" Kodak photo prints (25 total) for display purposes as well as room to customize the binder product based on personal preferences. This allows the backer the option of displaying additional personal family photos while also accompanying the provided vintage imagery. Coincidentally, due to the current pixelation of specific site images, many of the photos are not resizeable past the previously presented size (5.00"x7.00") in order to avoid blurry or pixelated images when the product is produced.  However, this allows for an array of sizes to be added to photo binder as backer deems appropriate.  
I have been a freelance 'vintage' stock photographer for 10 years and have been marketing this decade long dream of mine while also trying to promote myself as such via an on-line website business.  During the course of these 10 years, I have developed that website displaying my works of art (viewable at http://memoriesandbeyond.com/) and have also taken pleasure in allowing family, friends and of course the general public to delight themselves in these innocent 'times gone by'. Coincidentally, there comes a point when the business itself must become and remain virtually and technologically updated to create that user-friendly aspect, allowing consumers to enjoy even more the purpose behind the product.  I had considered (on several occasions) selling the business to someone who could carry it to its highest potential but have since reconsidered, looking to enhance the 'Memories and Beyond' Photography business on my own.   
How will the funds be spent? - I am striving to distribute the book in bulk fashion so as to provide copies for not only my grandmother but for additional family members, close friends, fellow stock photographers and of course the general public in order to help further market my personal collection of vintage photography.  The funding obtained via Kickstarter will definitely allow for additional marketing options in helping to promote a more global market and user-friendly website for purposes of personal browsing, choosing and ordering the consumer's desired images.  The website is in need of updated web design (which is currently in progress) and due to the current updating, no orders are being accepted at this time via the M&B on-line store.  This will allow time for a more detailed business plan and marketing approach.  However, once the 'Memories and Beyond' Stock Photography business is in full force, I hope to receive a huge supply of orders.  The original hardbound coffee table photo book binder will also be placed on the website as an additional future purchase item upon completion of updated web design, priced to provide a complete arrangement of on-line images (time frame of completion is yet to be determined). Coincidentally, backers via this campaign are also helping to launch a brand new limited-edition product.
Again, there are definitely costs associated with black and white film and print developing so I hope that this project is successful in its desired outcome.  Should there be any questions regarding the campaign in general (or questions regarding additional images of interest via the website that are non-related to campaign), please do not hesitate to ask. Once 'Memories and Beyond' becomes a productive on-line photography business, all images via site will be made available for purchase.

"Three brilliant female vocalists and some of Armenia’s finest instrumentalists on duduk, oud, dhol and piano combine the earthy spirituality of Armenian folk with the energy of rock and jazz."                                                                                                                                 –– Armenisch-Deutsche Korrespondenz 
“Part folk music, part classical, and profoundly moving.” 
                                                                                     ––BR Klassik                                                                            
THE NEW CD & BOOK
We’re really excited to be creating the Naghash Ensemble’s new CD and Book “Songs of Exile - Volume II” and we want you to be part of it!
Origins of The Naghash Ensemble
The idea for The Naghash Ensemble came to me when I was living in Armenia. I was exploring the ancient temple of Garni, which is in the middle of nowhere, when suddenly I heard the most amazing sound. Inside the temple, five women were singing medieval Armenian spiritual music and I was mesmerized. I kept hearing this sound in my mind for days afterwards, but as a composer it started taking on new shapes. Soon it was all I was thinking about and the voices in my head were now accompanied by a variety of Armenian instruments (dhol, duduk, and oud) as well as piano and string quartet. The sound of this new music I was creating was perfectly clear to me. The problem was, there wasn’t a single ensemble in the world that combined five female soloists, duduk, oud, dhol, piano and string quartet so...
I had to start my own.
In 2011 I formed The Naghash Ensemble with some of the best singers and musicians in Armenia.
Hasmik Baghdasaryan - Soprano  
Tatevik Movsesyan - Soprano 
Arpine Ter-Petrosyan - Alto   
Emmanuel Hovhannisyan - Duduk  
Aram Nikoghosyan - Oud
Tigran Hovhannisyan - Dhol/Dumbek
John Hodian - Composer/Piano
Discovering the Texts
I began to search for texts that would fit this new mystic, rhythmic, ecstatic sound in my head. I spent several years researching in the libraries of New York, Berlin and Yerevan. I finally came across a small fragment of text by the little known medieval Armenian poet and priest, M’krtich Naghash. Naghash's words leapt off the page into my soul and I knew I had found my text. 
“We are all exiles brother. No one has a homeland. We are bound together, the afterlife is our homeland.” –– M’krtich Naghash
All Naghash left behind were a handful of paintings and 16 poems. After some time deliberating which poems to use I became determined to set them all to music. “Songs of Exile - Volume II” will be the second group of recordings of what will eventually be a three volume set.
These poems are profound meditations on the vagaries of living a life in exile. Though Naghash was a highly regarded priest and poet in the 15th century, he ran afoul of the local authorities and was forced to leave his church, friends and family and become a “gharib” (exile). 
This concept of living a life in exile is very important to many Armenians. As a descendent of Armenian Genocide survivors, I have always been aware of the atrocities at the beginning of the 20th century in the Ottoman Empire. More than 1.5 million Armenians were either exterminated or sent on death marches. The few who survived, were eventually scattered around the globe. 
While written hundreds of years ago, Naghash’s words are, sadly, just as relevant today in light of what is happening to people in Syria and many other parts of the world. 
If you have never heard The Naghash Ensemble live, here is a short clip from a recent concert in Frankfurt Germany:
New Trees From Ancient Roots
I’ve been setting Naghash’s poems to music for the past five years, but in many ways I have been preparing for this work all of my life.
The music is part classical (it included a fully notated string quartet) and Armenian sounding (I’m Armenian and that is most of what I heard growing up) but also influenced by my years as a jazz musician, film composer, and improviser.
I have always been interested in art which has its roots in Armenian culture but reinterprets, redefines and re-imagines that culture. 
Working with some of the best musicians in Armenia, I’m constantly inspired by their fearless approach to this new music and what they bring to it. I think we have created something wholly unique and I am very excited about sharing it with the rest of the world. 
The First Recording (and a book!)
The first recording took several years to make and was accompanied by a beautiful book with extensive photos, information on Naghash, reproductions of his paintings, and the birth of the ensemble. The book, including the poems, was translated into English, German, French and Armenian. The recording sold out on our first tour but we have just reprinted it and it is now available here. 
In 2012 The Naghash Ensemble released "Songs of Exile - Volume I"
Our 2nd recording and a huge leap forward!
We are really excited about the new music we are recording for the 2nd volume of "Songs of Exile”. The first volume was very melodic and focused almost exclusively on the singers. This new collection of pieces is much more energetic, rhythmic and even funky at times. Plus the new pieces allow the players in the ensemble to stretch out. Die „Songs of Exile, Volume II“ als Buch und CD – mit Deiner Hilfe werden sie Wirklichkeit!
Die Geschichte des Naghash Ensembles
Die Idee für das Naghash Ensemble kam mir, als ich in Armenien lebte. Ich erkundete den uralten Tempel Garni, als ich plötzlich wunderschöne Klänge vernahm. Im Inneren des Tempels sangen fünf Frauen mittelalterliche armenische Kirchenmusik. Ich war wie hypnotisiert. Noch Tage später hallte diese Musik in meinen Gedanken nach und mit der Zeit begann sie, neue Formen anzunehmen. Zu den Frauenstimmen fügten sich die armenischen Instrumente Oud, Duduk und Dhol, außerdem ein Flügel und ein Streichquartett. Bald hatte ich eine genaue Vorstellung von der Musik, die ich komponieren wollte. Aber es gab ein Problem: Kein einziges Ensemble auf der Welt vereinte fünf Frauenstimmen, Duduk, Oud, Dhol, Flügel und Streichquartett. Also gründete ich mein eigenes.
2011 gewann ich einige der besten Sängerinnen und Instrumentalisten Armeniens für das Naghash Ensemble.
Hasmik Baghdasaryan - Sopran 
Tatevik Movsesyan - Sopran
Arpine Ter-Petrosyan - Alt 
Emmanuel Hovhannisyan - Duduk
Aram Nikoghosyan - Oud Tigran Hovhannisyan - Dhol/Dumbek
John Hodian - Komponist/Flügel
Die Entdeckung der Texte
Ich begab mich auf die Suche nach Texten, die zu der mystischen, rhythmischen Musik in meinem Kopf passen würden. Mehrere Jahre lang durchsuchte ich in Bibliotheken New Yorks, Berlins und Jerewans. Schließlich stieß ich auf ein Gedichtfragment des wenig bekannten mittelalterlichen armenischen Priesters und Dichters Mkrtich Naghash. Seine Worte sprangen von Buchseite direkt in meine Seele und ich wusste, dass ich meinen Text gefunden hatte.
„Wir alle sind Fremde, o Brüder, niemand hat Heimat.
 Wir alle müssen gehen, allein das Jenseits ist uns Heimat.“
 Mkrtich Naghash
Naghashs Nachlass war schmal: 16 Gedichte und eine Handvoll Malereien. Seine Gedichte sind ergreifende Meditationen über das Dasein in der Fremde und die Beziehung des Menschen zu Gott. Obwohl Naghash als Priester und Dichter seinerzeit hoch geachtet war, geriet er mit der lokalen Verwaltung in Konflikt und war gezwungen, seine Kirche, Freunde und Familie zu verlassen und ein Gharib (Wanderer, Fremder) zu werden.
Leben im Exil
Für viele Armenier ist dieses Konzept vom Dasein in der Fremde noch heute von großer Bedeutung. Als Enkelsohn von Überlebenden des armenischen Genozids erfuhr ich früh, was sich Anfang des 20. Jahrhunderts im osmanischen Reich ereignet hatte: Mehr als 1,5 Millionen Armenier waren ermordet oder auf Todesmärsche geschickt worden und die wenigen Überlebenden suchten Zuflucht im Exil.
Angesichts dessen, was derzeit in Syrien und vielen anderen Regionen der Welt geschieht, ist es bemerkenswert, wie relevant Naghashs Gedichte auch heute noch sind.
Nachdem ich eine Weile versucht hatte, herauszufinden, mit welchen Gedichten ich arbeiten wollte, entschied ich mich schließlich, sie alle zu vertonen. „Songs of Exile, Volume II“ wird nun die zweite von drei geplanten CDs.
Hier einige Ausschnitte unseres Konzertes in Frankfurt im Frühling 2015:
Die Musik
Ich habe die letzten fünf Jahre damit verbracht, Naghashs Gedichte zu vertonen – aber gewissermaßen habe ich mich mein ganzes Leben darauf vorbereitet.
Die Musik des Naghash Ensembles ist klassisch (sie umfasst ein Streichquartett und ist vollständig notiert), klingt armenisch (ich bin Armenier und war als Kind ständig von armenischer Musik umgeben) und ist zugleich von meinen Jahren als Jazzmusiker, Filmkomponist und Improvisateur geprägt.
Ich habe mich seit jeher für Kunst interessiert, die in der armenischen Kultur wurzelt, diese dann aber neu interpretiert, neu definiert und neu erfindet.
Das Naghash Ensemble versammelt einige der besten Sängerinnen und Musiker Armeniens. Es begeistert und inspiriert mich immer wieder, wie furchtlos sie sich auch der schwierigsten und ungewöhnlichsten Passagen annehmen und wie sie durch ihre Verzierungen die „Songs of Exile“ prägen. Ich glaube, wir haben etwas ganz Außergewöhnliches geschaffen und ich freue mich, dass unsere neue CD in wenigsten Monaten ihren Weg in die Welt finden wird.
Die ersten Aufnahmen (und das erste Buch!)
Wir brauchten mehrere Jahre, um die „Songs of Exile, Volume I“ aufzunehmen. Die CD hatte ein ungewöhnliches, umfassendes Begleitbuch mit Fotos, Malereien, Informationen über Naghash und die Geschichte des Ensembles. Das Buch samt Naghashs Gedichten war viersprachig: Deutsch, Englisch, Französisch und Armenisch. Die erste Auflage war nach unserer Europa-Tour ausverkauft, die zweite Auflage ist jetzt wieder im Shop verfügbar.
2012 veröffentlichte das Naghash Ensemble „Songs of Exile, Volume I“
Die neuen Aufnahmen und ein riesiger Sprung nach vorn
Wir sind zutiefst begeistert von der neuen Musik, die wir für „Songs of Exile, Volume II“ aufnehmen. Volume I war sehr melodisch und hatte seinen Schwerpunkt fast ausschließlich auf den Sängerinnen. Die neuen Stücke sind stärker energiegeladen, rhythmischer, manchmal nahezu funkig. Außerdem eröffnen sie neue Räume für die Instrumentalisten.
Hier ein Ausschnitt eines meiner neuen Lieblingsstücke:
Unser Kickstarter
Es ist nicht leicht, sich als Musiker auf Pfade jenseits der Popmusik zu begeben. Ich bin froh, dass das Naghash Ensemble sein Publikum gefunden hat und dass wir in Zeiten leben, da wir über das Internet noch Tausende mehr erreichen können.
Dass die „Songs of Exile, Volume II“ bald auf wunderschönen CDs in kunstvollen Begleitbüchern erscheinen werden, verdanken wir Menschen wie dir!
Die Studioaufnahmen, das Mischen, das Drucken der Bücher und Pressen der CDs kostet viel Geld. Unser Einnahmen aus den Touren und CD-Verkäufen reichen nicht aus, um die „Songs of Exile, Volume II“ auf dem Niveau aufzunehmen und zu produzieren, wie sie es verdienen.
Deshalb brauchen wir Deine Hilfe. Wir benötigen 15.000 USD (knapp 13.800 Euro), um die Aufnahmen und die Produktion der zweiten wunderschönen CD mit Begleitbuch zu finanzieren. Wir sind mittendrin: Die ersten Songs sind aufgenommen und gemischt. Um die neusten Kompositionen aufzunehmen, wollen wir zurück ins Studio.
Unterstütze das Naghash Ensemble jetzt. Hilf uns, die „Songs of Exile, Volume II“ Wirklichkeit werden zu lassen!
Crowdfunding gelingt nur, wenn möglichst viele Menschen davon erfahren. Jeder Beitrag hilft! Und: Weitersagen hilft auch. Wenn Dir das Naghash Ensemble gefällt, erzähl Deinen Freunden davon. Spiel ihnen die „Songs of Exile“ vor. Schick ihnen einen Link zu unserer Kickstarterkampagne. Poste es auf Facebook, twittere darüber. Je mehr Leute davon hören, desto besser. Denn: Wir finden, diese Musik ist es wert!
Danke!
John Hodian
und das Naghash Ensemble

In Storytelling, there is a common thread of events that happen in almost every story known to man. This has become known as "The Hero's Journey". Something about it is innate to Human Beings across all generations. The story always starts off in "The Ordinary World", and the Hero has to have a "Call to Adventure" to "The Special World".
 There are certain events that take place that the hero goes through to come back home a new person. These Story telling templates are no different from what goes on in real life when a person has to go to the special world to return home with "The Elixir". My travels over the past year as of June 2016 have led me to a very new and interesting road. I did not know that it would lead to where I am now. I am actually excited I have a platform in which to tell this story that has been developing in my life for this past year. 
 So, The Journey started in June of 2016. I booked a plane ticket to Cartagena, Colombia because I wanted to experience something new and exciting and I thought it would be a good place to play my music and make some money while doing this. Now mind you, We are talking about COLOMBIA! The country where everyone speaks Spanish. I did NOT know spanish before doing this. 
I was completely diving in head first (As I tend to do a lot these days!!). I had planned my trip for one month. And I thought that I would be in Cartagena the whole time. I had made a friend at my Spanish school literally a short walk from the beach. We became good friends on this trip, He was from London. I then met another guy who was staying at the same Hostel as me. He made a very serious and interesting comment. He told me "You have to see Medellin". And I felt like he really meant that for whatever reason. I brushed it off though because I was planning to be on the beach for a month straight while doing music gigs on the beach. The whole thing was planned out lol... So as time went by I started having fun in Cartagena and I met some very talented and cool musicians there. Now my friend from London Two Weeks in was leaving to go to Medellin. I honestly wanted to go too because of what the guy from the Hostel told me. So I went. I re-booked my ticket to From Medellin to Austin and I was on my way.  
I now know why that Man told me I NEED to see Medellin. Did I mention that the fruit that just grows so abundantly in this city is super fresh and amazing to the taste? Well if I didn't, now you know. Meanwhile I felt actually that on top of the amazing climate and fresh food that this city was actually a better place to gig at. I was on the beach before so everything was a little too relaxed and venues were slower with getting your gigs together. Medellin is a Metro City, so Me being from Austin, TX (The Live Music Capital of The World!) I can work my way around and get some nice gigs and make some good money. I did just that and I met some of the most humble talented people I've ever run across. Not only were the musicians talented they were classy people who showed me that no matter where you are in the world you can meet true friends.  
This part of my journey was my very first encounter with the music and Culture of Colombia. I returned in the beginning of January to escape all of the madness here in America and to play my music to people who wanted to listen. This trip I knew what I was doing, I knew where I was going and even better I had friends in the city. This time I stayed a whole one month in Medellin, Colombia. And let me tell you, It was one of the most rewarding things I have ever done. The amount of love I felt from God for giving me the opportunity to do such a thing, Traveling to another country to play my music that I made up in my apartment. This is life to me.  
I did the same thing in May of 2017 and stayed there for two weeks touring Medellin and surrounding cities. Because at this point people had started buying my music from me and asking me to perform at their venues.  
So now I am in Austin, Texas. I get a call from my friend in Colombia and he tells me that he wants to make an album with me combining my Hip-Hop culture with his Colombian Musical Culture. We had been gigging a lot together whenever I was in town and at this point for him to ask me that was like the only logical step that could happen next. That's where you come in, I can make this trip possible and continue this journey that I am currently on. I am a Musician. I create my music honestly and no one controls or censors my output. I have started making a living off of my Music. Do you know how good that feels? For me to eat a meal and pay rent because of my music is like the most satisfying thing in the world to me. I know with the completion of this album and documentary I can make this my launch pad for reaching my audience across the entire world. I have gotten this far by taking risks. I didn't just dream about it. I did something about it. I hope that my story can inspire anyone who has stumbled upon it. And if you did support my dreams and my music, Just know you have a very special place in my heart and soul.  
God Bless,
 Damon Scott Miller, Jr.

We are in very close contacts with each other and our ambitions on this project are monumental. We all come from different places in the world so it's going to be a unique experience.

In the past twelve months, I have been on a remarkable journey with four people for whom travelling to Switzerland for a voluntary assisted death has brought about impossibly difficult situations. Three of my brave and bold friends are still with us, however my co-producer and I were in Switzerland with Marie, who passed peacefully, and with dignity, on Monday 4th September.
This documentary is now complete, although we need funds to get it on the international festival circuit and have it subtitled into French, German and Spanish, so as to maximise it's broadcast potential. 
Death is the inevitable end to life, and we should be supported to have what we consider to be a ‘good death’ whenever possible. But how do we, and who should be allowed to define a ‘good death’?
Recent landmark cases have highlighted the issues surrounding assisted suicide and may be shifting public opinion in the direction of greater freedom. However, this remains one of the most challenging and controversial debates of our time.
With participation, analysis and comment from all sides of the debate; the medical community, legal experts, people who are left incurably suffering and wish to slip painlessly away, and those who vehemently oppose any legislative change, my documentary investigates this high profile argument, in an in-depth and explorative way, from an ethical, medical, legal, cultural and personal perspective. The aim of the film is to provide information as well as to encourage social and political discourse in the UK about assisted suicide by showing perspectives of the people it actually concerns.
Participants include:- Colin Campbell, Alex Pandolfo, Omid T, Marie Lopez Ramos, Phil Cheatle, Dr Michael Irwin, Penny Hall, Saimo Chahal QC, Dr Erika Preisig, Lauren Nicklinson, Dr Richard Huxtable, Revd Canon Rosie Harper, Revd Graham Sykes and the Rt Revd Dr Lee Rayfield.
As a filmmaker, I've been involved in many a controversial subject matter, and I believe the law on assisted dying in the UK is cruel and unjust. My film includes participation, analysis and comment from all sides of the debate; the medical community, legal experts, people who are left incurably suffering and wish to slip painlessly away, and those who vehemently oppose any legislative change.
I am most grateful to Colin, Alex, Omid and Marie for allowing me to follow them on their individual journeys, and to all those who have participated, assisted and supported me to date, I cannot thank you enough.
If you have a personal, political or otherwise impassioned reason to see this film broadcast, please help us by making a donation. It is much appreciated. 
Andi Reiss (writer, producer, director)
Omid’s Story:
In his mid fifties, Iranian-born Omid is seeking the right to a medically assisted death. Multiple system atrophy is an incurable but non-terminal disease of the nervous system, and its left him hardly able to move or speak, and he’s in constant pain. But, whilst this means his quality of life is seriously degraded, Omid may have some years left to live. Medically speaking, he is not ‘ terminally ill’. If successful, Omid’s legal challenge could help to make assisted dying legal for anyone with an incurable disease, even if it is not terminal, so long as they are of sound mind, although legal challenges like this in our society are not easy, and there have been a number of high-profile cases recently that have failed in the UK.
Colin’s Story:
With a rare form of multiple sclerosis, Colin had spent much of the winter last year in hospital, but had been advised there was little treatment available. In the spring, having had to move back to his first floor apartment, Colin had decided to travel to Switzerland, anticipating another winter would be intolerable. Having met with Dr Erika Preisig at the Lifecircle organisation in Basle, he had been given a date for his assisted voluntary death, and he’d asked me to accompany him, not only to film, but to be his official witness.
Alex’s Story:
Alex is experiencing the early stages of Alzheimer’s. However, like Marie, Colin and Omid, Alex is not deemed terminally ill. A retired academic, university lecturer and wholly non-accidental agitator, Alex campaigns for autonomy, dignity and respect. Dementia and Alzheimer’s disease has replaced heart disease as the leading cause of death in the UK, and for Alex, choosing when to die is an incontrovertible human right. However, he is afraid he’ll lose his mental competence, or mental capacity before being able to take advantage of Assisted Voluntary Death at Lifecircle in Basle.
Marie’s Story:
At the age of 13 Marie was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease, a crippling and incurable condition that attacks the digestive system. Now 54, although not medically defined as terminally ill, she had endured 49 operations, was in constant pain and had to visit the bathroom up to 30 times a day. She had had enough. Although having being born in Spain and educated in Switzerland, Marie had a successful career as a city analyst in London, and had lived in Aylesbury in Buckinghamshire for over 15 years. However, in 2008 she had to give up work, and although having paid over 40% in tax for many years, found herself the victim of council spending cuts. Living with her brother in Lausanne in Switzerland, She had told me she felt abandoned by the state, and has decided she can endure no more. She blames UK Government cuts for her decision to die at Lifecircle in Basel. She was angry. Ken Loach, the filmmaker campaigning against benefit cuts, upon reading about Marie, has said she is a double victim – of “a debilitating illness and a brutal ­bureaucracy”.

This campaign is to assist with funding the First Film Festival to come to Catoosa County Ga. What started out as a festival targeting the SE US independent film makers. So they could showcase their films. Has turned into a film festival that received submissions from now ten countries including the U.S. 
I have several special guests who are coming to this festival and I would love to be able to surprise them all with more than they have asked for. Most of these guests have just asked for nothing more than gas and food. For a first year festival in a small county. I appreciate what they have offered to donate. Their time, and their money. I am sure other events may have paid them more, but they generously agreed to assist this one.
So I am trying to finish funding this festival, and to try to give back to those who have donated more than I could have possibly asked of them.

The Story:
Out of the enlightenment, both science and technology are born anew. As mankind continues to advance in scientific knowledge, breakthrough upon breakthrough compound, exponentially. Through this new technology, mankind is able to transcend its physical limitations by passing through the thought dimension and entering the supernatural.
The natural will become supernatural.  Welcome... to the new enlightenment!
The Prologue:
Page by Erwin J. Arroza
Minutes after a Super X58-Class solar flare (the equivalent of over a billion hydrogen bombs) erupts towards the Earth, modern technology becomes paralyzed and social stability is dismantled. As a result, several nations seize the opportunity to wage war in pursuit of global domination. The nations rage, buildings crumble, and desolation spreads to such an extent that the masses cry out for peace. A new coalition rises with an aim to rebuild and bring progress and stability back to humanity.
Page by Erwin J. Arroza
As peace and balance are restored, nations unite to avoid another devastating, cosmic tsunami. Forces combine in a global effort to prevent another world war. A task force is formed to probe deep into the human psyche, with the intent to eradicate man's propensity for violence. Over time, this movement grows with such intensity that it results in a multi-trillion dollar enterprise called Staunch Industries. Driven by necessity and fueled with ingenuity, technology advances to a point where we are granted access to the far reaches of our galaxy and deep into the hidden depths of our imagination. Human thoughts, memories, ideas, and emotions can now be fully explored in ways we have never DREAMED!

Embarquez: voilà la signification du mot inuktitut "IKIVUQ", c'est aussi le nom donné à cette grande aventure. Deux années de travail acharnées furent nécessaire afin de rendre possible cette expédition de canot au cœur de la toundra québécoise: vingt-six jours d'autonomie en territoire inconnu.
"Come aboard" is the meaning of the Inuktitut word "IKIVUQ", it is also the name given to this great adventure. Two years of hard work were necessary to make this canoe expedition possible. Twenty-six days of autonomy in an unknown territory, in the heart of the Quebec tundra.

Les objectifs étaient nombreux: cartographier cette rivière sur laquelle on ne recensait encore aucune descente contemporaine, partager la grande beauté de ce territoire fragile, relever les traces d'une occupation inuite millénaire et inspirer le dépassement de soi. Finalement, quelque chose de bien plus personnel motivait ces six individus pour se placer dans un tel état de vulnérabilité, une quête propre à chacun que se propose d'explorer le documentaire Un Chemin à tracer.
This project had many goals: chart a river that was still unexplored by modern-day paddlers, share the beauty of this fragile territory, document the thousands of years of human life on the tundra and inspire people to surpass themselves. Ultimately, something more personal motivated these six individuals to place themselves in such a state of vulnerability, a quest unique to each. That is what the documentary film "Un chemin à tracer" will explore.
Depuis le tout début, mon objectif premier était de documenter et partager cette expérience. Vous avez été nombreux à suivre l'aventure, à nous écrire et nous encourager: je tiens à vous en remercier. Après maintenant plus de trois ans à travailler sur le projet, j'ai besoin de votre aide pour le dernier droit. Les fonds recueillis aideront à compléter le processus de post-production, un travail long et fastidieux, et ainsi réussir à partager cette aventure humaine.
From the very beginning, my first goal was to document and share this experience. Many of you have been following the adventure, writing to usand encouraging us: I want to thank you for that. After now more than three years working on the project, I need your help for the last right. Funds raised will help pay for the post-production, a long and tedious work. It will also make the translation process possible, which will allow us to share this human adventure.

Michael Watson and Jade Yumang are a collaborative duo who were chosen to exhibit in the Governors Island Art Fair in New York, NY this coming September. Their first exhibition as a collaborative team, Watson and Yumang will be converting a room into a surreal funeral home installation about the life and death of conjoined twins. This visual narration speaks of the complexity of individual liberty, dissatisfaction, loneliness, familial ties, and chosen families.
Back Story
They were united for most of their life, secure and happy, but chose to go their separate ways. Once on there own, they had immersed themselves in polar opposite career paths and lifestyles. As much as they were used to being codependent they desperately wanted to be free. The void was never fulfilled and it eventually weakened them spiritually, emotionally, and physically, which lead to their death. They each died alone at the same moment in their own way. Now they have been rejoined in death.
Installation Layout
The installation will consist of three large photographs. One will be of a portrait of the twins still conjoined and the other two will be individual portraits. There will be long table in the center that divides the individual portraits, which are adjacent from each other, and the room. The table acts as a physical and symbolic separation. There will be two identical urns at the end of the table that mirrors the large portrait of the twins still conjoined. An oversized floral arrangement will cover the length of the long table coming out from the urns to the opposite end. This arrangement will roughly be the size of a double corpse lying on the table symbolically sprouting to rejoin the twins. The floral arrangement will decay for the duration of the show.
Raising funds for
Printing and framing costs for the 3 large photos (life size); supplies and labor for the table Van rental and gas/tolls to and from Governors Island; enormous flower bouquet; fabric for table and windows; two identical urns; paint for the walls; PR costs.
Bios
Michael Watson is currently a graduate student in the MFA Fine Arts program at Parson The New School of Design. He participated in the Marie Walsh Sharpe Art Foundation summer program in Colorado Springs, CO and Governor's School for the Arts in Murfreesboro, TN. He also attended the New York Studio Program, TriBeCa, Manhattan in the fall of 2004. In 2006, Michael received his BFA in Painting from the Art Academy of Cincinnati. Michael is a native of East Tennessee and currently lives in New York, NY.
Jade Yumang received his MFA at Parsons The New School for Design with Departmental Honors in 2012 where he focused on the concept of queer form through sculptural abstraction, installation, and performance. He is currently participating in the Fire Island Artist Residency, Cherry Grove, Suffolk County, NY. Recently, Jade completed a residency in Atlantic Center for the Arts, Master Artists-In-Residence Program with Pepón Osorio, New Smyrna Beach, FL in 2012, which was supported through the Joan Mitchell Foundation Scholarship Fund. He received a BFA Honours in University of British Columbia as the top graduate in 2008. He was born in 1981 Manila, Philippines, grew up in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, and immigrated to Vancouver, BC, Canada. Currently, he lives in Brooklyn, NY, USA.

Poster
Welcome & Thank You For Visiting Our Page!
My name is Jackson R. Lazor, writer and director of Rot Hill. Over the last few years I have produced and directed various short horror films. However for years I have dreamed of making a full length feature film. 
 Almost two years ago my friend and business partner Matthew J. Kuhar (producer) and I set out to make a film that was terrifying, yet fun to watch. We ended up creating the project you see here, Rot Hill. We have focused on preproduction over the last 14 months. This provided us time to perfect the script, estimate an acceptable budget, create concept art & storyboards, and even shoot test footage (the video above). Our team has grown over the last few months to include many talented members.  
However we need your help. Matthew and I have personally invested funds into the film, but we need $6400 more to complete funding the project. We are offering different pledge rewards at different amounts along the right hand column. We are asking for your help, and for you to become apart of this project. We will finish the project, and we will have a wide home video release (RedBox, iTunes, Walmart, Best Buy).
 Against the best of their judgment, three teens decide to go camping on the infamous mountain known as Rot Hill. After one of them is found slaughtered, the town sets forth a search party. But as night nears various members of the search begin to disappear. Who will die, and who will live to tell of the darkness lurking on Rot Hill.
The Hacksaw Bride Concept Art
Above is concept art for the Hacksaw Bride featured in our film. Artwork is provided by our storyboard artist Brian Galley.
Films That Inspire Us
Rot Hill is deeply inspired by the classic slasher flicks of the 70's and 80's. Each member of our development team understands and respects the elements that made these films great. However Rot Hill seeks to find its own unique voice and stand on its own. We are not trying to reinvent the slasher genre. We are just looking to expand it and add to the universe. 
 To deliver an amazing, terrifying, yet authentic film that every horror collector/ fan would want to add to their collection. We have 3 main goals.
 1. Good Filmmaking! Just because a film is low budget doesn't mean that the movie should look low budget. A movie can look great with smart positioning  and use of lighting, camera shots, and sound work! We promise that despite our films budget, we will do everything to make it feel like a cinematic experience.
2. Only Practical Effects! Lets face it! CGI blood and gore just looks terrible. Everyone can tell its fake, and BOOM! Just like that the movie loses it's cinematic presence. We promise to only use realistic practical effects.
3. Rewatch Value! This seems to be the problem with a lot of current films. You buy a DVD once, watch the movie, and have no desire to ever watch it again. When developing the script for over a year, we focused on trying to build an interesting story, but one that you would want to revisit.This film is not being made to ride out a trend. It is intended to feel and look timeless.
How can you make this full length movie so cheap? The good news is we already own a lot of the equipment we need. We just need your help to pay for a few props, actors, and some lighting equipment. 
Production Budget
 In the end we are grateful for any pledge amount. This project will not not be possible without you. We need your support!

Welcome to Wilmington, Delaware! The City listed by Parenting.com as the #1 most dangerous city in America to raise a family. It is also the city where I grew up and became saved, the city where I received some of my education (both from universities and the lessons of life), a city where I started a family; and it's also the city that I love. I am B.K. Wilson: local filmmaker, international photographer, & activist against racism. I have worked with ABC News, trained in professional filmmaking at Universal Studios, and traveled halfway across the world to document other cultures. Now I'm documenting two cultures in, Dichotomy Brewing, my first publicly funded film. 
    I have been actively involved with the #BLACKLIVESMATTER movement since its early days with Trayvon Martin and Eric Garner. The daily reports from the media, the open discussions taking place in areas such as the bank and grocery store, and even the sermons in church all fueled my desire to raise my voice about the festering issue within all communities. 
   There's a brewing dichotomy in our nation and in my hometown. Two separate cultures: the black intercity civilians being characterized in the media as “thugs” and violent criminals, and the local police, state judges and other law enforcement that have been accused over the years of consistently breaking & bending the law to fit a “no justice, it's just us” and "good ole boy"  mentality. These are two very opposite, distinct cultures and the conflict between them is bubbling to the surface, spilling over into open forums, street protests, and neighborhood rallies. Silence is no longer expected. Truth has been limited to the news, opinions of people who don't experience the dichotomy, and courtroom sues that address individual incidents but fail to fully address the conflict between the police culture and the intercity civilians whose rights are guarded by the NAACP. But the sum of a black man’s life cannot and should not be reduced to waiving opinions. It should be decreed by the truth, that ALL LIVES MATTER. 
"It is true that all lives matter, but it is equally true that not all lives are understood to matter which is precisely why it is most important to name the lives that have not mattered, and are struggling to matter in the way they deserve."        - Judith Butler, Ph. D
   A local Wilmington man, Keith R. Booker, had a voice that has risen above his humility, while serving as President of the NAACP in Delaware. This film’s goal is to tell the story of Wilmington’s brewing dichotomy through his eyes. As the previous President of the local NAACP, he has done much for the City and for black local history. Telling this story from his perspective allows a credible, personal touch on a topic so misreported by people who don't actually live it. To avoid a one-sided perspective, I will be conducting interviews with local police, community leaders, and other lawmakers.  
    So far I have a completed script, fully drawn storyboards, an itemized budget, and a substantial number of committed volunteers willing to help shed light on this issue so the county can finally overcome this...Dichotomy Brewing. We've scheduled the film's completion for May 4, 2016. Hopefully, with your help we can earn enough to rent a silver screen for the opening night. With just a $5 contribution to the film you'll get a ticket to its screening and a public listing among film executive producers. Other sponsorship awards include: limited edition clothing and apparel, a private meeting with the cast and crew, DVDs of the film with behind the scenes footage, and for the highest contributors: an exclusive documentary project of your life by our team of professionals (see the various pledge options for further details).

The Westburner Baptist Church started as an idea and was formally incepted at Frog Pond Hot Springs in 2014.
The idea behind the camp is a parody of the Westboro Baptist Church, and in that vein, we adopt their style of protest-performance to stage protests of Burning Man Theme Camps (at their request), dust storms, heterosexuality, time, and anything else you can't really stop. 
We have secured excellent placement at the 3:00 & Plaza Portal to hold Mass this year, where we will be expounding on the virtues of the 10 Principles, listening to Alan Watts lectures, and holding Concept Album Dance Parties. 
In addition, we will also be holding two ceremonial Book Burning events at the beginning and end of the Burn, respectively, and providing a "Playa Pet" service, whereby Veteran Burners can sign up to take a Virgin Burner under their wing for the week and show them the ropes. 
Lastly, we will be hosting a confession booth, in which "Confessions to God" will be recorded and played anonymously at locations on the playa. 
While our camp has funded much of this on its own, our aspirations are in line with the Most High, and we hope to document the experience to share with others after the Burn.

State Dinto is a film for anyone who has felt like they didn't quite fit in. It's the story of a search for our Selves. This film is for immigrants and descendants of immigrants who long for 'home.'It's for LGBTQ people who are curious about our place in the human story.  This film is for anyone who has been hurt and healed by, for, and in... LOVE.
As a queer/trans descendent of Italian immigrants, I found it particularly difficult to be fully ME in any space. Within my Italian American community, I tried to hide my queerness, and within my queer community, I tried to erase my Italianness. I didn't see how these things could overlap. When I was young and just coming out as gay, I actually didn't even think someone even could be gay and Italian. So, I lived most of my life between friend groups, dancing between community expectations and who I really, really, REALLY was. I traveled around the world for years, looking for ME. Where was she?
moment of anguish
In this film I explore my roots and search for belonging- the belonging that I have searched for in all of my travels and experiences of love. I try to understand myself and family's past through my relationships with my very loving parents, and through the eyes of my Nonna, who came from Italy. However, she is suffering from degenerative dementia and has memories that come in and out without a lot of clarity. I determine to go to Italy to learn about the life she left behind when she came to America, to understand more about who I am. When I get there, I meet beautiful folk musicians and dancers, who continue ancient traditions that are both sacred and profane, of the Catholic Church, and of goddess traditions that are much older. I find that there actually are people like me, who play(ed) a vital role to the culture! The femminielli! Male assigned people who have the souls of women. 
Neapolitan trans activist Loredana Rossi
We meet femminielli in this film, and learn about them, and see that we, TRANSPEOPLE, have always been here, walking between the worlds of masculine and feminine, life and death, reality and fantasy.
While all this exploring and learning happens, I am falling in love in real time on camera and having a hard time with it. My need for romantic love rears its head when my feelings for my videographer, Adam, who became one of my best friends, starts showing up in the footage. The way that my heart orients towards him, and then breaks, is all there, for you to witness and maybe even heal from.
The film doesn't document the journey- it IS the journey, complete with all of the tears and laughter and connection and understanding that we all need in order to be fully human.  
Dancing the tammorriata at La Candelora
Your financial contribution will be going towards post-production, because even though we have the footage, it's not enough! We need to edit this film! This money will go towards paying an editor and me to make a rough cut.
