Die nachhaltige & ethische Zertifizierung der Mode 
Wir könnten uns nicht auf die Fahnen schreiben, das Bewusstsein für Nachhaltigkeit zu steigern und dann selbst nur fadenscheinig agieren. Deshalb produzieren wir zusammen mit unseren Lieferanten faire und zertifizierte Mode mit zeitlosem Design. Dabei haben wir darauf geachtet, dass nicht nur unsere Materialen nachhaltig produziert und entsprechend zertifiziert wurden, sondern wir ebenso die Arbeitsbedingungen, Energieversorgung und Wiederverwertung so fair und umweltschonend wie möglich gestalten.
Aus diesem Grund arbeiten wir sehr eng mit unserem Produzenten „Neutral: Certified Responsibility“ zusammen, um weiter an der Verbesserung unsere Entwicklungs- und Produktionsprozesse zu arbeiten.
CARTA - Zertifikate
Der Oeko-Tex 100 Standard befasst sich umfassend mit der humanökologischen Komponente von Textilprodukten. Er bewertet und sucht nach schädlichen Substanzen in verarbeiteten Textilien, die mit Verbrauchern in Kontakt kommen können und garantiert das diese nicht enthalten sind. Lizenznummer: ZHGO 034436
Der Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) ist als weltweit führender Standard für die Verarbeitung von Textilien aus biologisch erzeugten Naturfasern anerkannt. Auf hohem Niveau definiert er umwelttechnische Anforderungen entlang der gesamten textilen Produktionskette und fordert gleichzeitig die Einhaltung von Sozialkriterien.
SA8000 basiert auf den Prinzipien der internationalen Menschenrechtsnormen. Es misst die Leistung von Unternehmen in acht Schlüsselbereichen: Kinderarbeit, Zwangsarbeit, Gesundheit und Sicherheit, freie Vereinigung und die Freiheit für  Tarifverhandlungen, Diskriminierung, Disziplinarpraktiken, Arbeitszeiten und Entschädigung.
Das offizielle EU-Label für umweltfreundlichere Produkte. Unsere Produkte haben einen geringen Einfluss auf Luft, Wasser, Boden, Qualität, Verbrauch natürlicher Ressourcen, globale Erwärmung und biologische Vielfalt. Die Produkte müssen strenge Tests bestehen, deren Ergebnisse von unabhängig überprüft werden. Lizenznummer: DK / 016/049.
100% recyceltes Polyester nach Global Recycled Standard, zertifiziert und geprüft von Control Union. Ziel der GRS ist es, den Einsatz von recycelten Materialien in Produkten zu erhöhen und den durch ihre Herstellung verursachten Schaden so gering wie möglich zu halten bzw. ganz zu beseitigen. Lizenznummer: CU810963
Das Fairtrade-Zertifizierungszeichen ist die unabhängige Garantie dafür, dass die Baumwolle in unseren Produkten gemäß den internationalen Fairtrade-Standards zertifiziert wurde. Damit wollen wir sicherstellen, dass Mensch und Umwelt nicht für die Rohstoffe in Mitleidenschaft gezogen werden. Lizenznummer: 19007.

Die digitale Lösung "The Story Behind":
Durch die Verbindung nachhaltig produzierter Mode mit dem Informations- & Unterhaltungseffekt einer technischen Spielerei wie einer Computer Vision & Augmented Reality Komponente, möchten wir dir eine Geschichte erzählen: Die Geschichte des kleinen Vaquita zum Beispiel, der mit nur noch 15 seiner Artgenossen in dem Golf von Kalifornien einsam seine Runden dreht und doch allzu oft als Beifang in Fischerbooten landet oder qualvoll in Fangnetzen erstickt.
CARTA - Unsere digitalen Lösungen
Wenn du auf unsere Website cartaclothing gehst und hierüber deine Kamera öffnest, kannst du das Stickmuster durch Computer Vision wie einen QR Code scannen und wirst automatisch zu unsere „The Story Behind“ weitergeleitet. Hier erzählen wir all die packenden Geschichten von Tieren und Pflanzen, die vom Aussterben bedroht oder bereits ausgestorben sind. Unsere AR Applikation bietet dir darüber hinaus die Möglichkeit, die einzigartigen Tier- & Pflanzenarten direkt in dein Wohnzimmer zu holen und sie zum Leben zu erwecken. Dieser Teil ist für uns der Aufwendigste. Falls du uns z.B. mit dem Kauf eines CARTA T-Shirts unterstützt, erhältst du das T-Shirt bereits vor Weihnachten 2020 und die AR Applikation wird für diese T-Shirts in Q1 2021 freigeschalten. Computer Vision für die packenden Geschichten hinter den Stickmustern funktioniert natürlich direkt wenn du es auspackst! 
CARTA - Scan mit Computer Vision
Das Spendenkonzept "Save our Planet":
Um die Arten zu schützen, die noch nicht ausgestorben sind, spenden wir 10% des Warenwerts an eine Auswahl von Tier- oder Umweltschutzorganisationen und haben mit dem Jane Goodall Institut Deutschland unseren ersten Partner für uns gewinnen können. 
CARTA Spendenpartner - Jane Goodall Institut Deutschland
Wir sind kontinuierlich auf der Suche nach weiteren Partnern, um direkt den frechen Cao-Vit Gibbon oder flinken Vaquita zu schützen. Unser Ziel ist es, nicht pauschal an eine Organisation zu spenden, sondern die Spendenorganisation an das gekaufte Produkt zu koppeln. Wenn du dich beispielsweise für ein Shirt mit einem Cao-Vit Gibbon auf der Brust entscheidest, gehen 10% in den Spendentopf, welcher dem Jane Goodall Institut Deutschland zugutekommt. An die ausgestorbenen Arten gedenken wir mit einer Spende an Organisation die sich dem Erhalt der Artenvielfalt verschreiben. #saveourplanet
CARTA - Unser Spendenkonzept
CARTA sagt Danke!

What if your a spy for a Government agency, you deeply can not tell any one, but your objective, obtain, and protect a device that can be harmful to society, if landed in the wrong hands. An agent has to at all costs become a #MotherFucker, has to protect it at all costs, even from those trying to steal it.

Imagine…
… putting aside whatever it is that you are doing right now, leaving everything where it’s at and walking away into a serene forest of solitude… as you’re wandering through this forest, you stumble upon a small body of water and decide to lie down in it… you float effortlessly on the surface, nothing but pure relaxation… and nothing in the entire world matters… time slows down, all the pain in your body fades away and your mind becomes as silent as the rocks beneath you… an immense feeling of peace and tranquility arises within… no stress, no distractions… letting go of all that no longer serves you… becoming as light as the air you are breathing… just you and nature, floating together in synchronized harmony…
OVERVIEW
Help us raise the funds necessary to build a Float Center in Downtown Duluth (the Greatest City on Earth). The goal is to open by Spring 2017.
The funds will go towards construction costs, a float tank and the completion of our business plan which is where the final funds will come from.
'Floating' is relatively new to most people... it's basically like relaxing in outer space to sum it up in a sentence. You get your own float suite where you shower before and after the float and everything you need is provided: towels, shampoo, conditioner, etc...
Reserve your float time now and receive up to 53% off our regular price of $65/float (see rewards on the right).
Floating is for everyone and has a countless number of health benefits, see what it can do for you!
What is 'floating' all about?
Float tanks, also known as Float Pods, Isolation Tanks or Sensory Deprivation Tanks are being used all across the world for a plethora of different reasons: relieving chronic pain, neck pain, back pain, arthritis, depression, insomnia, anxiety, stress, recovering from injuries, enhancing creativity & learning, clearing the mind, relaxation, meditation and simply for the one of a kind experience that floating provides.
Within the lightproof and soundproof tank lies 10 inches of skin temperature water that contains about 1000 lbs of dissolved Epsom Salt which allows the body to float effortlessly above the water, basically defying gravity and giving the floater a sense of weightlessness... pretty much like being in space. Your body stretches out, your spine decompresses, tense muscles become relaxed, the mind naturally becomes calm and all the stress in your life just floats away... it is the only place on earth that provides this kind of environment.
As you lie in the tank, your mind and body will come into harmony with one another, ensuring one of the deepest states of relaxation that you've probably ever experienced.
More info on Float Tanks: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isolation_tank
Informational Video on Floating: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kPgTiYZXGtY
Documentary on Floating: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nHnbKjQGhHw
Dream Pod
Why have a Float Center in Duluth?
...For those long winter months we all cherish so deeply, for anyone suffering from chronic pain, back pain, neck pain, arthritis, stress, depression, anxiety or any physical/metnal ailment, for athletes seeking quicker recoveries and enhanced performance; artists who wish to expand their creative mind, college students who want to relax and study after their float, to escape from the hustle and bustle of everyday life, for any person who seeks complete relaxation like never before or to experience nothing and jump into an oasis in the middle of January. Floating will benefit your overall health in so many ways, even the epsom salt in the water helps to maintain proper magnesium levels within the body. The art of floating is a very powerful tool that can be utilized by anyone for any reason... but especially for those sub-zero winter months ;)
A Float Center in the heart of Duluth will bring about increased health, less stress and enhanced creativity for the whole community... as well as a place for artists, photographers and creators of all kinds to showcase their art and collaborate with each other. It will be one more addition to never-ending list of wonderful activities and things to do in the North Woods of Minnesota for both locals and visitors.
Image courtesy of Theta State Float - thetastatefloat.com
'Floating' as a solution to the current epidemic of stress and anxiety
Why are we having an epidemic of stress and anxiety in our world?
For most of us, as soon as we wake up in the morning, we are going from place to place, taking phone calls, checking Facebook, eating unhealthy food, talking with coworkers whom we don’t enjoy talking to, eating more unhealthy food, running the kids around, staying up to date on all the latest technology and reading about all the horrible things going on the world… only to get to the end of the day, watch some T.V. and sleep for a few hours before we wake up and do it all over again, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, all year round. It is a vicious cycle that so many of us go through... a direct result of living in an overstimulated information-filled environment with nowhere to go to release all of the built up tension inside ourselves. Only in the last few decades have we been living such a demanding and stressful lifestyle.
A solution to this madness is floating. Floating in a near zero-gravity environment where you are free from all sensory input to your brain, lets the body & mind relax 100%. As your body rids itself of all the stress, so does your mind. There are no distractions in this place and all of your physical and mental ailments finally have time to relax and heal.
This method of relaxation and recovery is the latest in modern technology. The float tanks themselves provide an environment that you can find nowhere else in the world. The industry of floating and floatation therapy is rising at an incredible rate. What started out in the 1950’s is now growing into a world-wide solution for an anxiety and stress ridden culture. Only in the last decade has the industry been flourishing so rapidly. Scientific research is being done daily on this matter and is continuing to show the astonishing, vast array of health benefits involved with floating. Below is a video showing some of the most recent scientific research that is being done on floatation therapy by Dr. Justin Feinstein.
Floatation Therapy is scientifically proven and there are a countless number of testimonials from people who regularly float describing the health benefits that it provides for them. It is a simple, organic and natural way of getting to the core of the problems in our lives that we face today.
"Most importantly, the float tank is not a hypothetical laboratory phenomenon, but a viable, proven technology" -Dr Henry Adams, NIMH, Washington.
Where will 'The Float Lodge' be located?
The Float Lodge will be located at 25 West 1st Street in Downtown Duluth. Across from Legacy Glassworks & Duluth Hydroponics. Sammy's pizza is just down the block as well, so you can go eat some za right after your float.
There will also be an area dedicated to relaxing, creating art, reading/writing books and hanging out before and after your float... complete relaxation space.
How 'floating' entered my life
I experienced my first float about a year ago... at the time I had just graduated from high school, knew that I didn't want to continue education at a university and thus decided to move to Colorado for the winter... previously living in Minnesota my whole life. The move ended up turning into a five month road trip that took me all across Western half of the United States, down through New Mexico and Arizona, along the coast of California and up to Oregon where I then flew out to the Big Island of Hawaii to do work trade for a Hotel/Hostel. After 2 months of living in middle of the Pacific Ocean and many nights sleeping under the stars I finally made my way back to Minnesota.
I first heard about floating on the internet while watching a Joe Rogan Podcast during Mr. Haugrud's history class back in high school. With my interest hooked, I dove head first into researching everything there was to know about this strange new thing people called 'floating' and what it's all about. I said to myself that one day I will experience floating first hand... sure enough while on my road trip across the US, that day came. I booked an appointment at a wellness center in Arizona right before taking off from Colorado...
A few days later...
...Upon waking up surrounded by cacti in my White Oldsmobile Alero which was parked on the side of a Freeway somewhere outside of Phoenix, I proceeded to drive into town for my float...
Mental Clarity is what I received from those 60 minutes of floating... In the midst of being in the tank, I lost sense of which way my body was oriented. Gradually this feeling came over me that I was floating in space and then I was actually seeing my body float through space at what felt like million miles an hour, but I was completely relaxed and calm... It was incredible because ever since I was a kid I had always dreamed about the mysteries of space, and now I was experiencing it. The feeling I had immediately after stepping out of the tank was like none other. My body felt as light as a cloud, my mind was crystal clear, I had an almost overwhelming sense of calmness and everything seemed to have a subtle glimmering shine to it.. sorta like how I imagine a filthy, mud plastered vehicle would feel right after a trip to the car wash... with that wonderful clean car smell and spotless glossy finish. I didn't just feel super relaxed and calm afterwords.. it was different than that. It was a whole new level of relaxation, calmness and healing that I noticed not just on a physical level, but on a mental level as well. I felt a greater sense of appreciation for all things. It was simply a time for my mind and body to let it's guard down and just be.. to heal and repair any impurities existed within myself. It was a feeling of total rejuvenation and healing of my whole being, unlike anything I had ever felt before.
 Reflecting upon my 'float' experience, I came to realize all the benefits floating can have on an entire community. Bringing together people of all ages and ethnicities, artists and creators, students and businesspeople to float, relax, connect and share our experiences with one another. That's when the decision to open up a float center was made. I truly feel that the possibilities, healing effects and positive benefits that come along with floating are infinite and endless.
Moving Forward
The plan is to maintain a state of the art float facility in one of the most beautiful cities in northern Minnesota: low rates, discounts for college students and [hopefully] discounts for Whole Foods Coop Owners & YMCA members, an outlet for independent creators of all kinds to create, communicate and showcase their artwork, a welcoming environment for everyone, high quality equipment and an awesome staff.
'The Float Lodge' is a central hub for people to relax, heal and become their greatest self...a place that can be used and enjoyed all year round, bringing together a community and embracing this new-found technology.
Concept Design
  Relaxation area
  Early floor plan drafts...
Development Plan
- Fund the project
- Write up draft plans for renovation
- Get a loan and lease the building
- Purchase equipment
- Begin renovation
- Open doors by Spring 2017

There's a special story behind these suits! It all started with a truly adventurous friendship between my grandfather, Robert 'Bob' Bernard and ski racing buddies Norma & Joe Lausmann. Norma began designing and hand sewing neon ski racing suits in the early 80s. She hand picked psychedelic prints and created a style never before seen on the mountain. The trio raced into their 80s around the world, competing in Downhill and Slalom Masters Ski Races - often winning Gold, Silver and Bronze in their age class.
The ski suits took on a new life when I (grand-daughter to Bob Bernard) got my hands on the them. I found that they were as big a hit off the ski slopes as they were on, at events like Coachella, Burning Man and Daybreaker!! The quality of Norma's suits is better than any unitard I have ever worn. They've lasted generations and proved to be both functional and fabulous.
it's time we bring this style back to the snow!
Fast forward 35 years... Racysuits is now a budding brand ready for its first large production! Exploring more places than ever before - ski slopes, beaches, parties and festivals - all around the world. From the snow covered slopes of Montreal and California to the beaches of Australia and Mexico, to parties in New York City and the Nevada desert, Racysuits is ready to take on the world! 
 Starting with Norma's ski suit design has allowed us to recreate a one piece suit that embodies the functionality and durability of a professional ski suit. The ergonomic pattern is designed to provide you with increased flexibility and range of motion. Racysuits can support your every move, whether you're racing down a mountain or getting down on the dance floor!
  After a year of testing, producing samples, and getting customer feedback we've added a few NEW FEATURES! 
The ZIPPERS on the arms and the legs make fore easy dressing. 
There are TWO NEW POCKETS that will fit your phone (even the big iPhone 6), your ski pass, credit cards and any other essential items. One pocket on your left arm and one hidden breast pocket for your secret treasures. 
We will emphasize the 2 LAYERS again and again! Most one piece spandex suits are made with a thin layer of material, revealing everything . . . including the burrito you ate for lunch. Our 2 layer suits give you the ultimate body smoothing support making sure your neon booty is looking extra fabulous at all times. 
  Our print selection is inspired by some of the very first Racysuits hand sewn by Norma. We've worked to create a new collection that will satisfy all of your neon dreams.
Our custom prints will be digitally printed on a blend of Poly/Elastane fabric. The medium weight compression shape-wear fabric is body smoothing and 4-way stretch. This blend of fabric retains its shape and color, as well as being UV resistant and efficiently absorbing sweat.
The lining fabric that is in contact with your skin is carefully selected. We chose an elastane blend fabric that is soft to the skin, breathable and moisture wicking - keeping you dry and warm! Poly blend fabrics are also stain and odor resistant, helping you stay fresh through multiple wears.
Below are our 3 new prints that'll be produced if this Kickstarter is successful. If you choose a Racysuits Unitard Reward you will get to select one of the following designs!
                  Our 4-way stretch fully lined suits are extremely forgiving, providing a body smoothing effect that is flattering on all body shapes. They're designed to be tight and hug your body, creating an aerodynamic design similar to professional downhill ski racing suits. We have added two new sizes to our collection now offering XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL. Thanks to 4way stretch materials our suits fit a wide range of body types!
PLAY

  We're dedicated to keeping our production in the USA. The best part is we'll be able to visit our factory throughout the production process and monitor quality every step of the way. We've also done small batch test runs with our New York factories. You can see the outcome of these on our website. Having pre-existing relationships and experience with our factories is incredibly helpful. This Kickstarter production run won't be a guinea pig - we've already worked out the the kinks! Special thanks to Maker's Row for creating a community of Makers and Manufactures helping us bring production back to the USA.
  If we're lucky enough to reach our pledge goal in August (crossing our fingers, toes and eyes) we'll email each pledger and ask for sizes, prints and shipping info. All rewards will ship as soon as we receive them. Be sure to check your rewards delivery date for an ETA.
             Dear Supporter, 
This is a very exciting time in my life. I'm lucky enough to be working on a project that I'm incredibly passionate about - rediscovering the zest for life of generations before me. The best part about this project is the community and family behind it. 
My grandfather met Norma and Joe Lausmann when he first joined the USSA Far West Masters Ski Racing Association. Their friendship took them on trips around the world, racing in competitions globally. Bob Bernard , Norma and Joe Lausmann are legendary members of the Tahoe ski community. In the 1980's they spearhead the full time adult training program at Squaw Valley and Alpine Meadows that still continues to this day. Bob Bernard was also one of the founding members of the Far West Master Junior Scholarship Program that supports deserving junior racers. 
He held community positions such as Chairman in the Far West Devision, National Masters Chairman and USSA representative to FIS Masters Committee. He also spearheaded the Spyder Masters Alpine Team along with the founder of Spyder Active Sports, David Jacobs.
Bob Bernard's enthusiasm and commitment to the ski community on a national and international level has landed him a nomination to become an honored member of the U.S. Ski & Snowboard Hall of Fame (application pending). 
None of this would be possible without the support and encouragement from Norma Lausmann, now 93. She remembers every suit she ever made, every race she ever won, and attributes her speed and success to her favorite Racysuit - black with neon pink polka dots.
Wearing Racysuits brings this lifestyle back. Imagine all of the things you love best in life, the acts, the motions, the adventures, and the people that bring you the most joy in life. Now, throw a Racysuit into the mix and tell me life didn’t just get a lot more fun!
Building Racysuits is going to take a lot of hard work but the payoff is more than worth it. Seeing people of all ages skiing, surfing, dancing, and playing in Racysuits around the world is the best reward there is! I flip out every time I see a customer share a Racysuits photo. 
Thank you again for all your support! I look forward to decking you out in spandex ;)
xoxo, 
Marina
Thank you to everyone who supported this campaign. Music by Joakim Karud, photography contributions by James Thompson, Christian Torres & Mike Michlin. Video Production & Editing by Ryan Homsy & Djordje Radovanovic.

Who We Are
Colony Handcrafted Ales will be a unique brewery, creating local ales with a friendly taproom. Since the day Colony opened, it has made a name for itself throughout the city with a unique atmosphere, quality commercial beers, well-crafted cocktails and an excellent espresso bar. Once we opened, we knew it was only a matter of time before we wanted to join the other fantastic breweries in North Kansas City with our own beers. For the past 4 months, we've been able to serve our handcrafted ales at countless beer fests around the city with great reception. We're excited to serve you by bringing great brews and a community-minded business to North Kansas City.
Master Brewer: Rodney Beagle is our guy. We've never met someone so passionate about their craft. He's an award winning brewer with many accolades under his belt between multiple brewing events. Here's just a few of them.
Best in Show (1st place out of 67 beers) - Peppercorn Whiskey Saison
Gold Medal - Peppercorn Whiskey Saison in Belgian specialty ale category.
Silver Medal - Royal Gose in the Belgian specialty ale category.
Bronze Medal - Cream Ale
Iron Brewer - 2015, 2016
The Plan
Our hope is to begin serving our own beer at Colony as early as Spring 2017. Once we meet our Kickstarter goal, we can purchase the rest of the brewing equipment and finish renovating our brewery space. Our brewery will be a 3 barrel brew system, capable of brewing 90 gallons of fresh, delicious beer at a time. This system will supply us with brewing kettles, fermentation vessels and kegging equipment to supply local bars and restaurants, as well as our loyal, thirsty, beer-loving customers.
We're excited to share our dedication and passion for local beer, made right here in the Kansas City metro! Our facility is already an inviting, comfortable, friendly taproom with a full espresso bar featuring our North Summit Slow Brew and Kombucha on tap.
What will your contribution be used for?
With your help, we will be able to complete construction, order our brewing equipment, stock supplies, etc. Our community support has already been amazing since we opened and we hope to continue that even more once our beers are brewing.
The Beer
We've already been able to take our beers to many festivals in the Midwest with great reception. We hope to feature some of these ales when we start brewing in house. Below is a list of beers that our fans keep asking for.
'83 Hamlet | Whiskey Saison - Brewed in collaboration with Wood + Salt, this Saison incorporates both rye and smoked malts to create a whiskey like appearance and taste. (7% - 49 IBU)
Ella May's Twisted Roots | Peach Belgian Strong - Made with one of our baristas peaches off of her peach tree in her parents back yard, this Belgian Ale is all juicy fruit! (7.5% - 40 IBU)
Fuller | Caramel Latte Porter - This Pre-Prohibition style Porter is made in collaboration with Post Coffee Company out of Lee's Summit, Missouri using one full gallon of their rotating single origin coffee to every 5 gallons brewed. Could be caramel, mocha, pumpkin, vanilla, or hazelnut depending on the season/occasion! (6% - 24 IBU)
Winner's | Strawberry Cream Ale - Made in collaboration with a local tea shop out of KC, this cream ale based beer is made with a tea blend including rose hips, hibiscus, apple, and wild strawberries. Summer in a glass!

 I'm new to Kickstarter – How does it work?
We set a goal -- in this case $10,000. We set a deadline for 30 Days. You pledge whatever you feel like. Remember that the bigger the pledge, the greater the reward (look above for a list of all the cool rewards we offer).
If we make the goal by the deadline, your credit card is charged what you pledged (but not until then). We will have met our goal, you get your rewards and everyone is happy.
Even if we meet our goal, you can keep pledging. You will still get your cool rewards and you’ll be able to make Colony Handcrafted Ales even bigger and better!
If we don't make the goal, your credit card is NOT charged, we DON’T get a penny and you DON’T get any of the wonderful rewards. Let’s make sure THAT horrible scenario doesn't happen.
How can I help?
Besides backing the brewery itself, you can SPREAD THE WORD! Tell your friends about the project via email, share it on Facebook, tweet about it, take a selfie with us, anything!

Love a good movie filled with horses, hurdles, and heroes? So do we! Hello, we're Jerry and Christy McGlothlin, founders of Moving Visions Entertainment, a NC-based film production company and boy, have we got a story for you! Read on to learn our heart and vision behind the movie, then pick your favorite horse (reward level) from the names on the right, and let's get riding.
"Unbridled" is an emotionally gripping, unforgettable and uplifting story of redemption, healing, and overcoming some of life’s greatest obstacles. This captivating feature film tells the tale of an abused girl who teams up with an abused horse and their journey to healing. Inspired by a true story, the movie features actors you love such as Eric Roberts (The Dark Knight; The Expendables) and T.C. Stallings (War Room; Courageous).
"Unbridled" was created to draw attention to the practice of sexual slavery, which is growing in all parts of the world, paticularly in the suburbs of the USA. Please help us expose the atrocity of child sexual abuse and trafficking. With your support we will call attention to this industry and how to recognize this abuse. And what better way to do that than through a movie?!
What is "Unbridled" about?
1. "Unbridled" tells a gripping story of friendship, healing and redemption. 
Sarah Miller (Tea McKay) is a 16-year-old high school student with a secret: she's a victim and prisoner of human sex trafficking by her mother's boyfriend (Eric Roberts). Feeling ashamed, worthless and alone, she doesn't know where to turn. When her world crashes down she feels like she can't trust a single soul. But everything changes when she meets Dreamer, an abused and dysfunctional horse. Since both Sarah and Dreamer have been abused, they relate to each other. Not being able to trust anyone else, this abused horse becomes Sarah's only confidante. Slowly but surely Sarah and Dreamer begin to heal, start to believe in themselves again, and learn to grow healthy relationships. It's a captivating story of a girl who escapes her circumstances and through many twists and turns finally finds freedom from her abusers. 
2. "Unbridled" is inspired by true stories at a local riding academy.
"Unbridled" is inspired by the Corral Riding Academy in Cary, NC. Since 2008 the Corral Riding Academy has been privileged to help over 100 abused girls through one-year long therapy programs. They pair up abused girls with abused horses and through intensive one-on-one training the girls teach the horses to trust. In the process the girls also learn to trust again. These true stories of hope and healing were the inspiration for "Unbridled." A portion of the proceeds from "Unbridled" sales go directly to Corral.
 3. "Unbridled" draws attention to the evil of sex trafficking. 
We produced "Unbridled" to call attention to child sexual abuse and the prevalence of sex trafficking. Child sex abuse and sex trafficking are far more common than most people realize. 
CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE STATISTICS (www.americanspcc.org):  
 • 1 in 4 girls and 1 in 6 boys will be sexually abused before they turn 18 years old.  
 • 325,000 children are at risk of becoming victims of commercial child sexual exploitation each year. 
• 34% of people who sexually abuse a child are family members.
With your support we will be able to show how this industry is hurting these young children. 
4. "Unbridled" showcases the healing power of horses.
The star of our movie, Dreamer, is an amazing real-life champion horse. Dreamer plays a central role throughout the story and performs several amazing feats. Dreamer's trainer, real-life celebrity Lindsey Partridge, also appears in the movie. She is a Natural Horsemanship Freestyle Champion and the founder of Harmony Horsemanship. Lindsey and her two most famous horses traveled all the way from Ontario to North Carolina in order to be part of this movie. The entire cast and crew had so much fun working with Dreamer and Lindsey that we can't wait for you to see their performance.
5. "Unbridled" features world-famous actors playing intriguing characters.
The intriguing story of "Unbridled" is brought to life by our stunning cast. "Unbridled" features epic performances by Eric Roberts (The Dark Knight; The Expendables) and TC Stallings (War Room; Courageous). Spoiler alert: You will be fascinated by Roger (Eric Roberts), a villain who is creepy but at the same time irresistibly charming. Dey Young (Pretty Woman), Jenn Gotzon (Frost/Nixon, Alone Yet Not Alone, Doonby), Rachel Hendrix (October Baby, The Perfect Wave, Roses) and the rising star Tea McKay (Hurricane Bianca, Pass the Light) put up amazing performances you won't forget.
Why do we need the money? 
We just wrapped up 20 days of filming, so we have 100% of the footage. There are breathtaking horse shots, scenes that will move you emotionally, and exciting action sequences. We know the amazing potential of what we have so far so we want post production to be just as phenomenal as the rest of the movie. This movie deserves to be finished in style. With principal cinematography complete, we ask that you partner with us to provide additional finishing funds for a tremendous boost of quality in post production.
What will the money be used for? 
The money we raise on Kickstarter will be used for editing, color grading and music scoring. More precisely:
Editor finishes up and locks the editing 
Composer creates the accompanying musical score 
Sound designer creates, edits and mixes all the final sound in the film 
Colorist corrects and beautifies the appearance of the footage 
Graphic artists design the film's graphics and titles, poster and DVD cover 
Visual effects artists fix, clean and enhance the footage 
Technical engineers master the discs 
Public relations provides info about the film and where you can see it or how you can own it
Any money above our goal will go into promotion and distribution.
Why would you want to support us? 
1. Be part of a cause that needs support. Stand by these young innocent women by supporting the movie. Help us to make this movie a great success and to get the message out into the hands of as many people as possible.
2. Receive amazing rewards. We have something for everybody. We even have instantaneous rewards!
3. Be inspired by an unforgettable story of healing. By supporting this movie you can be energized with hope and in turn help others experience the friendship, healing and redemption that is possible!
Before we hit the trails, here's a quick recap:
“Unbridled,” a feature length drama inspired by true-to-life stories at a healing ranch for troubled teen girls in North Carolina, tells a tremendous story of redemption and triumph. Watch God's unconditional love in action as our heroine overcomes formidable obstacles and ultimately finds that it IS possible to live a life filled with joy. This is the power of story: to dive deep into the human heart, to expose the evil, and to embrace all that is good, beautiful and lovely. 
If that sounds like a story you want to see, and a cause you want to support, we've got a horse for you. Simply pick your favorite horse (aka reward level, horses not included) from the names on the right, and let's ride!
A note from the producer: 
We chose to create "Unbridled" for so many more reasons than just to create another movie. The inspiration behind "Unbridled" is threefold: 
1. All girls, young men, ALL people have innate value to God and others. Our lives have meaning, and no matter what difficulties you have encountered or what trauma you have experienced, no matter how bad it has been, your life is redeemable. Many people believe that if they are emotionally scarred they cannot be healed. Many people judge others in the same way. We are here to make a statement that all lives can be redeemed and all lives should be given the opportunity to heal and be made whole. 
2. This film is about YOU. So many of us walk around with a vision in our heart, a spark, a desire, and we squelch it daily with doubts or busyness. No vision to help others is too big or too small for you to accomplish. Joy Currey (the founder of the Corral Riding Academy) started helping others by teaching in inner city schools. She wanted to take it a step further and offer a safe place for girls to heal. She began with one horse, one saddle and one girl. ONE horse, ONE saddle, ONE girl. And look at the difference her resolve has made in the lives of girls in her community. We are creating "Unbridled" to reignite that spark in your heart. What dream has been on your heart and in your mind? To reach out and tutor neighborhood children, to work with those who are down and out, train homeless with job skills, answer a suicide hotline, volunteer in a home for young mothers, to foster or adopt, to notice those around you who are needy and lend a hand, to begin a place like Corral, where hurting girls and horses are healed? What is on your heart to do? Unbridled is the encouragement that no dream to help others is too big or too small for you to accomplish. 
3. We want to draw attention to the travesty of the sex trafficking industry and child sexual abuse. I realize this is a touchy subject. I also realize that hiding our heads in the sand won’t make it go away. The statistics show that our children, those we love, and those we don’t know are unsafe. Let’s learn to protect the most innocent in our society, beginning with the acknowledgement that there is a serious problem in the world, our country and in our backyards.

Sin embargo, hacer esto por mi cuenta era muy difícil, así que busqué ayuda y encontré a un valioso equipo muy capaz de hacer todo por llevar este proyecto al éxito. About the Concert
DancEthos in concert with alight dance theater
Saturday March 1st at 7:30pm

1101 6th St SW, Washington, DC 20024
Two companies present six choreographers in a one night only show!
DancEthos Artistic Director Tiffany Haughn examines the strength and vulnerability of motherhood in Revealed and the dangers of miscommunication in a new work with original music composition by Roc Lee. Guest choreographer Erica Rebollar’s Rick’s Dream takes you on a fast paced romp through the REM cycle of sleep, as disjointed ideas overlap in the mind’s stream of consciousness.

WHO WE ARE
CHOP SHOP:  Bodies of Work presents the best contemporary dance from the greater Seattle area and beyond, alongside master classes and a free community outreach program.  Our mission is to bring quality contemporary dance to Seattle-area residents through education, interaction, dialogue, and experience; to support local, national, and international dance artists; and to promote the accessibility and presentation of contemporary dance for both new and experienced audiences.
Bryn Cohn + Artists at CHOP SHOP Master Classes 2014
WHAT WE DO
CHOP SHOP:  Bodies of Work is a two-pronged annual cultural event that fills January and February with performances, master classes, and a free community outreach program.
First, the Experience Dance Program - a collaboration with the City of Bellevue Parks & Community Services Department - offers a series of free lecture-demonstrations and introductory level modern dance classes, all taught by the Artists participating in the Festival. These free classes are held at various Community Centers throughout the City of Bellevue and are open to individuals and families of all ages, ethnicities, and demographic backgrounds. All participants in the Experience Dance Program are given a free ticket to the performances, allowing them to apply and connect their educational and physical experiences to the dance works they see in performance.
Secondly, the Festival brings together outstanding choreographers and companies for two public performances at The Theatre at Meydenbauer in Bellevue, Washington.  CHOP SHOP is unique in its approach, focusing on the presentation of highly creative, yet accessible work to both new and seasoned dance audiences.  During the daytime hours of the festival five master classes in a variety of dance styles are offered by the Artistic Directors of the participating companies.  Dance students can apply for Festival scholarships that provide free access to the full master class series, as well as a complimentary ticket to the performances.
WHY IT MATTERS
The purpose of CHOP SHOP, now approaching its 8th year, is simple:  the Festival serves as a platform to educate and offer insight about contemporary dance and its creative process, in order to forge deeper connections between artists and audiences through presentation, education, dialogue, and experience.
Spectrum Dance Theater at CHOP SHOP 2014
From 2008 - 2014 CHOP SHOP has presented or supported:
39 Dance Companies
74 Dance Works
209 Professional Dancers and Choreographers
500+ Experience Dance Program Participants
and served nearly 5,600 audience members.
WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP
Due to an unexpected change in grant award policy, CHOP SHOP is facing a budget shortfall of $8,000. Without these funds, CHOP SHOP 2015 will not happen. We need your help to continue bringing performance, education, and experience to our audience!
WHERE YOUR SUPPORT GOES
Like many arts organizations, CHOP SHOP is run on a shoestring no-frills budget, so every penny donated (after fees) goes to funding the Festival itself.  Your donation will be converted directly into Festival essentials (programs, posters, fliers, etc.) or will provide support for the artists involved (dancers, choreographers, sound/lighting technicians, videographer, etc.).   
Adam Barruch Dance at CHOP SHOP 2014
$25 = 50 programs for the Festival
$50 = 25 posters or flyers for the Festival
$75 = 1 hour of video recording
$150 = 1 CHOP SHOP Scholarship
$1000 = Performing Artist/Company Fee

Special Thanks:  Shelley Brittingham, Stephen Elliot, Jeanne Zornes, Rex Tranter, Dalton Shotwell, Richard Stone, and Lizzy Melton

WHAT IS YOMEDDINE?
Yomeddine is a coming-of-age comedic drama, a road trip where two outcasts, Beshay and Shika, discover the harshness of the world outside the leper colony where they have spent all their lives.
After the death of his wife, Beshay and his apprentice Shika travel on a donkey cart southwards to search for what remains of Beshay's family. They hope to find out why his father never came back for him after dropping him off at the gates of the colony when he was a little child. 
The film is based on real characters that writer/director Abu Bakr Shawky has met at the Abu Zaabal Leper Colony while filming award-winning documentary "The Colony", which screened at many local and international film festivals around the world. You can watch the trailer here
Flyer of leprosy documentary "The Colony"
We want to tell the stories of the people Abu Bakr met during his visits to the leper colony. A recurring story he heard was being dropped off at the gates of the colony as children and not seeing their families again. Yomeddine was conceived out of a hybrid of these true stories. Beshay, the illiterate childless leper and his schizophrenic wife; Hamed, the legless former truck driver; Gomaa, the railroad thief; Shika, the Nubian boy - these real characters find their place in the film. 
Yomeddine writer/director Shawky at the Leper Colony
AWARDS & GRANTS TO DATE
Selected for NYU's Purple List: You can read more about it here 
Selected by Abu Dhabi Film Festival's SANAD Fund. Check out the announcement on Daily Variety and Ahram Online
UPDATE: NextPix Grant Winner
OUR GOALS
We want to make Yomeddine a quality film, artistically and technically. We are going to hire professional crew and a combination of professional actors as well as non-actors, who will add authenticity that professional actors may not be able to provide for this subject. 
HOW YOU CAN HELP
It's crunch time! We've got a good portion of our production budget in place so far - with a portion provided by the SANAD Fund as well as private investors - and this is our final push to make it happen! 
We are scheduled to begin principal photography in December and need your help to raise at least $20,000 in order to meet our budget and embark on this journey.
TRANSPORTATION & ACCOMMODATION 
This will require the majority of the money raised on Kickstarter, specifically because Yomeddine is a road movie. We are going to travel along the Nile from Cairo to Qena and will need logistical power: trucks to move equipment, RVs to transport cast and crew, and to ensure they are as comfortable as possible in the conditions of rural Egypt in order to work their magic on set!
MEALS
We're going to be on the road for the majority of the film, so we will need to provide meals for our hard-working crew. Preferably, we will have a mobile kitchen in order to ensure the quality of the food.
SECURITY
Traveling for days on end through the backroads of Egypt with expensive equipment and film crew hardly go unnoticed. We will need security with us at all times to ensure safety of everyone involved with the film. We take safety very seriously and will work above and beyond to ensure a safe work environment.
FINAL LOCATION SCOUTS
The director, producers, director of photography, and location manager need to go on a final survey of our locations in order to make sure there are no surprises when we arrive at to shoot.
EQUIPMENT RENTAL
Thanks to our wonderful Producer Dina Harb we were able to secure most of our camera equipment for free! However, there are still a few items we will need while we're on the road, such as grip and lighting kits, to name a few.
PROGRESS
November: We are deep into the casting process. We will conduct our final location scouts. In addition, we will secure our transportation and finalize logistics, accommodations, and crew.
December-January: Showtime! We are going to be on the road filming our movie!
THE TEAM
 ABU BAKR SHAWKY  Writer/Director/Producer
Abu Bakr Shawky is an Egyptian-Austrian writer, director and editor. He is the founder of Desert Highway Pictures, the production company for Yomeddine. His short films The Colony, Martyr Friday and Things I Heard on Wednesdays have been screened at festivals around the world. His commercials have been shortlisted and awarded at the American Independent Commercial Producers Awards and Porsche Awards in Germany.  
Shawky’s short film The Road to Atalia, a look into Egypt’s thriving business of illegal migration, was produced by the International Organization for Migration in 2010 and featured renowned Egyptian actor Amr Waked. 
As a speaker, Shawky has participated in the European Forum Alpbach and Prague’s Forum 2000, where he was a panelist on media and human rights in post-revolutionary Egypt. 
Shawky holds a BA in Political Science from the American University in Cairo, and a BA in Film Directing from Cairo's High Institute of Cinema. He is an MFA candidate at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts graduate film program.
DINA HARB  Producer
Harb is founder and managing partner of Birthmark Films, a production company based in Egypt, her native country. Harb is a film producer and a literary agent for a number of renowned Arab novelists.Harb is currently assistant president Cairo International Film Festival while distributing a feature length documentary, which she also produced, called Yallah! Underground. 
Harb served as associate producer of Words of Witness (2012, 70 min); an award-winning documentary and produced two award-winning shorts in the United States of America. Harb’s background is project management and strategy in the field of marketing, communications and advertising. Her wide range of clients included Master Foods, Heineken and NSGB, to name a few. Harb has also produced more than 50 commercials for international clients such as Coca Cola, Pepsi, Nokia, CNN, Olympic Electric, Qatar National Bank, Danone and Danette. She is an MFA candidate at Columbia University’s Graduate School of the Arts.
DINA EMAM  Co-Producer
Emam is an Egyptian-American filmmaker and holds a BS degree from New York University in Marketing and International Business, with a Concentration in Entertainment Media, and is now currently pursuing her MFA in Creative Producing from Columbia University.
Prior to graduating, Dina worked at MTV Networks in New York City on numerous award shows and specials such as, Do Something! Awards, NewNowNext Awards, Storytellers: Kings of Leon, Storytellers: Cee Lo Green, Storytellers: Mumford and Sons, CMT Crossroads: Sting & Vince Gill and the Daytime Emmy Award winning show, Vh1’s Big Morning Buzz Live. In addition, she has worked on Sahbet El Saada, an Egyptian variety show on the arts, culture, and history in Egypt. Yomeddine is her second project in Egypt and plans to continue her work in the Middle Eastern film industry.
Her passion extends across anything that has to do with music, culture, world history and the human condition.
FEDERICO CESCA  Cinematographer
Argentine cinematographer Cesca recently wrapped Michael J Larnell's feature film, Cronies, with the support of a Spike Lee grant. 
Cesca received numerous accolades, including the 2014 ARRI-CSC Volker Bahnemann Award for cinematography.  He has worked with Gerard Depardieu, Todd Solondz, James Franco and Chloë Sevigny among others. Cesca’s work has been screened in various film festivals, including the NYFF, Venice Biennale, Cannes and the Berlinale, as well as HBO. Cesca is an MFA  candidate in cinematography from New York University's Film Program, where he studied and photographed over 20 short affiliated films in the US, Europe, Africa and South America. Cesca also holds a BA in Architecture and also studied music and aesthetics.
Federico is currently attached as cinematographer to a few feature films that are scheduled for production between 2014 and 2015. 
LAURA MOSS  Production Designer
 Laura’s film directing debut, 'Rising Up' was a critically acclaimed mockumentary about the Zombie Civil Rights Movement. The film, which won Best Director at the Boston International Film Festival, toured the horror festival circuit and streamed on SONY’s crackle.com.  
  Her film work has since screened at the Atlanta Horror Festival, Washington DC Horror Festival, Coney Island Film Festival, Anthology Film Archives and the First Run Festival, where she won a special commendation for her film, Passing.
Laura is also a production designer and special effects artist. She has designed AICP nominated and Porsche award-winning commercials, as well as Atsby Vermouth's first-ever commercial campaign. Her narrative design work has screened at top-tier festivals, including Sundance and SXSW.
Laura recently completed her studies at NYU's Graduate Film program.

Mi proyecto
De Artistas Por Artistas y su Galería Virtual es un proyecto creado y dirigido por Fernando Niragob, nuestro fin es sumar esfuerzos con otros artistas y generar contenido para promover, difundir y vender obras de arte. El proyecto es de carácter independiente y se financia de la misma manera. Programamos nuestra SUBASTA DE INVIERNO, evento para recaudar fondos y así poder arrancar programas en 2020. 
En el primer trimestre del próximo año iniciamos INSPIRA un programa de talleres impartidos por artistas participantes de la Galería Virtual; en el segundo trimestre queremos seguir generando contenido a través una serie de entrevistas y charlas en vídeo para YOUTUBE; y estamos preparando en espacios dentro y fuera de Guadalajara para hacer Exposiciones Colectivas de nuestros artistas participantes.
Mi plan
En estas fechas ya estamos recibiendo la información de la obra con la que los 42 artistas invitados participarán, también estamos en los preparativos de nuestra SUBASTA DE INVIERNO, renta de mobiliario, diseño y elaboración de papelería, publicidad y material digital e impreso (Catálogos de la galería y la subasta, pósters, separadores, postales, tazas, invitaciones y videos).
Recompensas
La mayoría de los proyectos artísticos pocos son hechos por artistas y artistas que son promotores al mismo tiempo. De Artistas Por Artistas es un proyecto cuyo eje medular es un artista y cuyo objetivo es sumar esfuerzos con otros artistas para generar contenido de calidad y acortar la brecha entre los coleccionistas, amantes del arte y público en general. 
Los discursos, proyectos y propuestas son cuidadosamente estudiados y ejecutados para que la experiencia sea, por sobre todas las cosas de excelencia y con un toque artístico. 
Nada es más gratificante que conocer de cerca la titánica labor que todo artista emprende para poder crear y no hay manera más sencilla de hacerlo que ayudarle adquiriendo, promoviendo y apoyando su obra.
De Artistas Por Artistas es un proyecto enfocado para construir una red de artistas, coleccionistas y amantes del arte para generar contenido y ofrecer acceso a través de Documentos Digitales (fotografías, vídeos, carpetas electrónicas); Visitas y Acceso a estudios y talleres; Eventos Presenciales (subastas, exposiciones, catas de obra), Adquisición de Obra Original y Artículos Promocionales (pósters, separadores de libro, postales, tazas) todo con el fin de apoyar al arte. 
¡Seguimos trabajando!

A Multimedia Website on the Past, Present and Future of one of Montreal's most Dynamic Neighbourhoods. 
(French version below)
Growing up in Milton-Park, I spent the summers playing street hockey with my friends who lived in the co-ops on St. Famille and Jeanne-Mance streets. At the time, I had no idea that the houses they lived in had been under threat of private development in the late '60s and '70s. Nor was I aware of the history of the Milton-Park Citizens' Committee and the radical 20-year battle that lead to the creation of the co-ops. 
It's important that this history be shared. That's why my project partner Julien Poirier-Malo and I are producing a website.  
Our Goals: To document the citizen-led movement for low-rent housing, present an oral history of the neighbourhood and explore the community's current challenges. 
Visit miltonparkstory.com to see what we've accomplished so far!
The Final Site Will Feature:
 • The audio documentary The Death and Life of an Inner-City Neighbourhood available free to either stream on the site or to download. 
   Preview:
An interactive map where residents will be able to post photos and add their own stories in the form of text or audio. 
A comprehensive timeline documenting many of the key events in the history of the community, from 1969 to the present. 
Infographics displaying the latest statistics on the members of the community, the neighbourhood and its history. 
 Audio interviews with a growing number of well-known residents and the people who have, and continue to make, Milton-Park one of Montreal's most vibrant neighbourhoods. 
A photo essay with 30 to 40 pictures of residents and independent business owners as well as behind the scenes shots of daily life in Milton-Parc.
How it all Started:
 The Milton-Park Story began as a group project for a multimedia journalism course at Concordia University. Julien and I produced an audio documentary on the grassroots battle that lead to the creation of the co-ops. But we felt there was more that could be added. We've since expanded the scope of the original documentary and have lined up many more interviews. We've also taken photos and started to map the history of the neighbourhood. But our website’s potential for displaying an even more comprehensive history of the community – and serving as a tool for a broad audience – is even greater. 
Why Donate?
Funding for The Milton-Park Story will help us: 
Purchase the proper equipment
Hire a web-developer to complete the design of the website 
Employ a professional photographer 
Translate the site so it is available in both English and French
Do community outreach to solicit stories from residents and to promote the project 
Why Now?
Due to the the 35-year anniversary of the co-ops on July 1 – and the looming expiry of the 35-year co-op mortgages – we are convinced that a collaborative oral history project and multimedia website that focuses on the neighbourhood will have a wide appeal both for residents of the neighbourhood and the greater Montreal community. It will also be of interest to international scholars studying co-operative housing models and land trusts.
It's an Exciting Time:
Recently the Milton-Parc Co-operative was selected as a finalist for the Habitat for Humanity Awards. In addition, resident and community activist Lucia Kowaluk was named to the Order of Canada. It's also a time of changes and renewed struggles, including efforts to ensure that the Hôtel-Dieu Hospital continues to service the community as well as the ongoing battle to preserve Parc Oxygène.
Thus far, we’ve received positive feedback from many members of the community. We have even been asked to present the project in person on July 1st at the MAI centre as part of the 35th anniversary celebration. This has motivated us to push ahead and create a website large enough in scope that it will serve as a true reflection of this unique neighbourhood and benefit the community for many years to come.
Who are we?
   Brendan King-Edwards
 I'm a Montreal-based freelance media professional, editor, and manager of The Word, one of the city’s oldest independent secondhand  bookstores. I've written numerous in-depth features including, most recently, a 2,000-word investigative feature story on medical errors in McGill University affiliated hospitals for The Dominion magazine. My writing has also appeared on citizenshift.ca, artthreat.net, Pound magazine and montreal.mediacoop.ca. My audio work includes a documentary on the Burgundy Urban Mediation Project for rabble.ca. 
Julien Poirier-Malo
I am a journalism graduate and reporter at CIBL 101,5. I'm the producer of À l’échelle humaine, a weekly social economics program, and host of the daily morning show, Les Oranges Pressées. I chose English-speaking institutions for my CEGEP and university studies, and spent a year in France to deepen my knowledge in a different cultural context. Though I cover a broad variety of issues, I focus on the municipal/local beat. Politics, environmental and urban issues, transportation and civil involvement are some of the fields I specialize in.
The Milton-Park Story : Une bataille pour un quartier accessible à tous
L’histoire d’une communauté montréalaise qui s’est battue contre un géant immobilier pour créer l’un des plus grands quartiers d’habitation coopérative de l’histoire du pays.
Un site web multimédia sur le passé, le présent et l’avenir de l’un des quartiers les plus dynamiques de Montréal. 
 Ayant grandi dans Milton Parc, j’ai des souvenirs de journées complètes passés à jouer au hockey avec mes amis qui vivaient dans les coopératives des rues Jeanne-Mance et Sainte-Famille. À l’époque, je n’avais aucune idée que les ambitions de grandeur d’un promoteur immobilier avaient menacé ces maisons dans les années 1970, et la féroce bataille du Comité de Citoyennes et Citoyens de Milton Parc pour sauver le quartier m’était aussi inconnue. 
 Or, cette histoire, il est important qu’elle soit partagée. C’est la raison pour laquelle mon collègue Julien Poirier-Malo et moi avons démarré ce projet journalistique. Notre but : Documenter cette bataille citoyenne pour du logement accessible à tous, verbaliser l’histoire du quartier par la voix des citoyens, et explorer les enjeux qui touchent la communauté aujourd’hui. Visitez miltonparkstory.com pour voir ce qui est déjà en développement ! 
La mouture finale du site inclura : 
 • Un documentaire radio intitulé « Déclin et survie d’un quartier central » disponible en baladodiffusion ou en téléchargement. 
Bande-annonce : 
• Une carte interactive du quartier sur laquelle les résidents peuvent partager leurs histoires en photos, témoignages écrits ou vidéos. 
 • Une ligne du temps détaillée qui retrace les événements majeurs de la bataille citoyenne de 1969 à nos jours.
 • Des statistiques illustrant la réalité actuelle et passée de Milton Parc. • De courtes entrevues radio avec des figures du quartier qui ont façonné (et qui façonnent toujours) l’histoire. 
• Un essai photo de 30 à 40 images de résidents et d’entreprises indépendants qui ont modelé l’image du quartier depuis ses débuts. 
Comment le projet a commencé : 
 The Milton-Park Story a été lancé dans le cadre d’un cours de journalisme à l’Université Concordia en hiver 2014. Julien et moi avons produit un documentaire radio sur la bataille citoyenne des années 70 et 80 mais, au terme du semestre, avons réalisé qu’il était possible de creuser bien plus profondément. Depuis, nous avons élargi le mandat du projet et multiplié les entrevues. Or, le potentiel inexploité de notre site web demeure immense. 
 Pourquoi financer ? 
 Votre contribution nous aidera à :
• Acheter ou louer de l’équipement (photo, vidéo, radio) 
• Embaucher un designer web pour maximiser le potentiel du site 
• Embaucher un photographe 
 • Traduire intégralement le site en français 
• Payer les droits d’auteurs de documents d’archives que nous voulons exploiter. 
• Faire la promotion du projet à l’intérieur et au-delà des frontières de Milton Parc. 
 Pourquoi maintenant ? 
 Considérant que les 35 ans du quartier coopératif sont soulignés cette année (de même que la tant appréhendée fin des subventions fédérales aux résidents), nous sommes d’avis que notre projet d’histoire orale trouvera écho autant chez les résidents que dans le monde coopératif, voire la région métropolitaine de Montréal toute entière. 
D’ailleurs, le projet intéresse également déjà des universitaires venus de l’extérieur du Canada. Et ce n’est pas tout ! En 2013, le quartier Milton Parc a été sélectionné comme finaliste pour les prix annuels de l’organisme Habitat pour l’humanité. D’autre part, Lucia Kowaluk, l’un des pivots centraux de la bataille pour la sauvegarde du quartier dans les années 70 et aujourd’hui toujours militante sur plusieurs fronts, fut récompensée par une nomination à l’Ordre du Canada. 
 Mentionnons également que jusqu’à maintenant, Julien et moi avons reçu d’excellents commentaires de la part de membres de la communauté. Dans le cadre des célébrations du 35e anniversaire, nous présenterons notre projet à la population le 1er juillet au centre MAI, en plein cœur de Milton Parc. 
 En somme, il nous a semblé évident que l’approfondissement de notre projet était non seulement justifié, mais nécessaire pour préserver le souvenir des premiers balbutiements du quartier, réitérer son caractère unique aujourd’hui et en assurer la pérennité, voire la duplication ailleurs dans le monde. 
 Qui sommes-nous ?
 Brendan King-Edwards 
Basé à Montréal, je suis rédacteur pigiste et gérant de The Word, l’une des plus anciennes librairies indépendantes de Montréal. J’ai écrit de nombreux articles de fond, dont un reportage de 2000 mots sur les erreurs médicales répertoriées dans les hôpitaux universitaires de l’Université McGill paru dans le magazine The Dominion. J’ai également signé des papiers sur citizenshift.ca, artthreat.net, Pound magazine et montreal.mediacoop.ca. Côté radio, j’ai produit un documentaire sur le projet Burgundy Urban Mediation Program pour rabble.ca. 
 Julien Poirier-Malo 
 Natif et résidant de Montréal, je suis journaliste à la CIBL 101,5, la plus grande radio communautaire au pays. J’y suis réalisateur d’un magazine d’économie sociale hebdomadaire et animateur de l’émission Les Oranges Pressées, de 6h à 9h en semaine, ralliant plusieurs dizaines de milliers d’auditeurs. Curieux de nature, j’ai choisi de faire mon parcours collégial et universitaire en anglais en plus de faire un an d’études à Tours (France) en 2011. Je me spécialise en politique, en urbanisme et en environnement, et sur les enjeux de transport et d’engagement citoyen. 
 Il va sans dire, ce sont notre expérience commune en presse écrite, en photographie, en radio et en média 2.0 et notre soif de découverte qui nous ont permis de créer ce site web en voie de devenir une référence sans précédent sur l’histoire, le présent, et le futur de Milton Parc.

Hey everybody! My name is Marlee, here's the scoop... I am a self taught artist who produces kaleidoscopic works of art in all different syles. After spending my whole life painting and making connections, I have a pretty decent sized following and a lot of people interested in my work, but here is the problem.. As any new mother would, I turned my studio room into a nursery for my super awesome baby girl, but now I need space to keep creating for not only me but for her too. Even with my day job as an art teacher my funds are tight.

Did you know that Alberta sends 2.2 million barrels of oil to the U.S. every day, 40 per cent of U.S. oil imports? That’s 50 per cent more than North Dakota, enough to fuel 20 percent of America’s cars and trucks.
And yet few Americans know much about the nature and complexity of western Canada’s energy industry, or about the costs, benefits and tradeoffs involved in providing America with such a significant amount of its energy needs.
We’re going to change that.
The Alberta oil sands and the pipelines that deliver its oil to the United States are an important part of Canada’s economy, but they are also some of the most controversial energy projects in the world. 
Despite significant opposition from environmentalists and Indigenous people, as well as the provinces of B.C. and Quebec, both U.S. President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau are championing pipelines that would increase oil sands production further—even while Canada struggles to meet its international climate change commitments.
That’s why the University of Montana School of Journalism is organizing the Northern Exposure Reporting Project, and sending a team of intrepid student journalists to Western Canada this May. 
We will travel 2000 miles by van to explore every nook and cranny of western Canada’s resource-based culture and economy. We’ll stop in Calgary and Edmonton, the economic and political capitals of Alberta, to interview politicians and industry leaders, and then venture north to Fort McMurray, the proud home and heart of the Alberta oil sands. 
From there, we’ll follow the route of the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion project to the West Coast, where oil companies hope to load Alberta oil on to tankers in southwest B.C. and northwest Washington state. 
Along the way, we’ll be creating meaningful multimedia coverage of a variety of issues, including endangered species management, Aboriginal treaty rights, and the fate of the Trans Mountain pipeline, now owned by the Canadian government. 
Our goal is for these students to come away with rigorously reported and professionally produced work that we can promote on a cutting-edge multimedia website, and get in the hands of editors and producers looking for great work and young talent.
To that end, we’d like you to join us on the Northern Exposure Reporting Project. Our students have invested $30,000 of their own money for this opportunity.  
Your support will help to offset some of our travel and equipment costs and allow us to cover more ground and visit remote communities so we can tell the stories that matter most to our readers and viewers. Here’s our wish list:
 Rental cars to get our journalists where they need to be in a timely matter 
A flight to Fort Chipewyan, which is inaccessible by car, to follow up on stories about a potential cancer cluster and the biggest remote solar farm in Canada
Help offsetting the not-insignificant cost of food, gas and lodging
A drone to take pictures and video from the sky
Your support will also help us document our work on our website, and promote our journey on a daily basis via social media—no matter where we are. 
Please join us today.

Legacy Kids Magazine is an annual publication for military children. Each volume is full of inspiring stories, artwork, and hands-on activities centered around resilience and bravery. This lovingly-crafted publication enables military kids to use their own creative voices to empower, enlighten, and uncover the truths about growing up in an unconventional lifestyle. Legacy Kids offers an outlet for children within this community to understand their own feelings and uplift others along the way.
Seeing firsthand the weight the military lifestyle had on their own kids, the Legacy Kids team understood the significance of a positive outlet for children to share their wide scope of personal experiences. The team felt that creative expression could help move young writers and artists through their emotions, and at the same time help guide other military kids through theirs.
When children understand that they belong to a community, a sense of acceptance replaces feelings of loneliness and confusion. This type of kinship can develop a strong sense of self and instill a treasured connection to other military kids.
Legacy Kids Magazine fosters this community. It is a tangible publication that highlights a wide range of emotions and experiences through bright, bold, and honest content. This creative endeavor opens an important space that allows us to see and hear military children as they invite us into their world.
When your child is done spending time with this magazine, they will walk away feeling understood and empowered to embrace this lifestyle from a new, positive perspective.
Our readers embody the resilience and bravery of all military kids. They are authentic creatives, innovators, and dreamers that come together from many different backgrounds and ages for a much-needed sense of unity and strength in community.
The contributors for Volume I consist of children and adults alike. Our writers represent the voice of military kids ranging from just three years old, all the way through to adulthood.
Skilled artists, graphic designers, quillers, and photographers carefully curated and designed beautiful, eye-catching visuals to individually complement each article. Each contributor has a connection to military service members, offering unique perspectives and imagination of this lifestyle.
Writers: Nicole Ryan from Elite Dance, Brady Gallagher from Hot Asana Yoga, Michelle Cuthrell from Of Capes and Combat Boots, Tony Cross, Victoria Reyes: Interviewee, Christin Daubert, Samantha Peterson, Jenny Lynne Stroup, 
Illustrators: Kimberly Mortson, Griffin Carrick, Alyssa Moore, Chelsea Colden, Jane Randall, Kristine Farnum, Ken Bunnell
Photographers: Brittany Raynor, Lola Vargas, Jenelle Botts, and Samantha Peterson
The Real Stars—Military Kids: Ava VanDeusen (10), Julie Geletske (7), Carlee (5) & Coen (3) Eliason, Caleb Raines (10), Mason Zamara (12), Allie Rothlisberger (11), Tessa Colden (11), Maddy (18), Brady (16), Riley (12) Shick, Sophia Vogt (11), Lilly Guinn (16), Laila Blackford (9) Tanner Corwin (12)
The vibrant layouts motivate readers to dig into content that highlights the environment, community, wisdom, mind, body, and creativity of military kids. Our writers dive into the heart of being a military kid from multiple perspectives, offering different outlooks to children looking for guidance.
Military parents explore different seasons with their children and offer valuable advice as they navigate through the military lifestyle.
The entertaining activity content allows children to immerse themselves in the pages and connect through hands-on fun. Every page is bound together with inspiring art and photography to honor military kids’ experience, originality, and heart.
As you will see below, there are many opportunities available to get involved, such as pledging, subscribing, partnering, supporting, sharing, or becoming one of our wholesalers. Your collaboration will help physically print the magazine and get this much-needed publication into the hands of adult and child readers alike. Don’t miss out on this opportunity to launch positive change within the greater service member community. We are excited to have you join us as we endeavor to encourage community, creativity, and courage in the lives of military children.
We are diverse group of individuals with unique talents and strengths that help balance the unifying theme—to inspire, uplift, and enlighten military children.
Abi Ray | Editor-in-Chief & Co-Founder
As a licensed counselor with eleven years within the service community, Abi Ray, LMFTA seeks to encourage and equip families in their personal narratives and creative expression. In 2017, she launched Legacy Magazine as a tangible way to empower service families and the communities that champion them. Most days you can find her unwinding with her husband and two daughters or immersing herself in literature on family enrichment, trauma-informed care, and neuroplasticity.
Daena Vandre | Executive Editor & Co-Founder
Daena Vandre has been a part of the military community for the past eleven years. Throughout this time, she has learned to become steadfast and advocates for self-empowerment, community, and mindfulness. Obtaining her Bachelor of Arts in English and Human Services in 2018, her passion for writing and the human psyche remains her driving force. Currently, she is pursuing her Master’s in Clinical Mental Health degree and continues to narrow her focus toward methods that can transform thinking and transcend former habits.
Kimberly Bacso | Managing Editor 
Kimberly Mortson | Lead Designer
Reinna Sherie | Videographer

THE BRAND
WINSOME is a line of clothing and curated goods based in the Northeast neighborhood of Minneapolis, Minnesota, in a warehouse studio with a mysterious military past. We design and sew our clothes in-house, and we feature goods that are made in the USA by artists and craftspeople we admire.
The inspiration for our garments is found in the bolts of fabric we start with. Our garments are designed to be modern and unique, but also to retain classic elements of fit and finish that makes each item familiar and comfortable enough to be daily staples. Clean lines, impeccable fit, and quality construction are our goals. The entire process, from sketching to packaging, is kept under our own roof in order to maintain a high level of quality and craftsmanship, and to reduce wasted time and materials. And every garment is produced in very limited quantities. In short, we keep it small to keep it awesome
THE PROJECT
In the world of boutique fashion and brands, we often feel like there's a big gap between a given company and a customer. Winsome wants to create more intimate relationships with our fans and customers, in addition to partnerships with other designers and boutiques that will lead to unexpected and excellent things. The Winsome Mobile Studio will represent ultimate transparency into our clothing design and production practices. It will bring the process of designing small, limited run collections to many cities and towns around North America. The idea was born from the desire for more interaction with Winsome customers than can be had online, and from a yearning for the kind of inspiration that can only come from travel.
The Airstream itself will consist of a minimal clothing design studio (2 sewing machines, a cutting table, clothing rack, pressing table and storage), as well as a small living space for the designer while on the road (a bed, kitchenette, wet-bath and storage).
While in a location, an assemblage of garments will be designed and produced in the same limited-run that we use in our Minneapolis studio. Materials for the styles will be purchased in or around that location as often as possible, and all production will happen on site. Winsome will then partner with local boutiques and bloggers to host pop-up shops where people can check out the locally made collection, tour the mobile studio, and hang out with yours truly.
This Kickstarter campaign's purposed is to fund the renovation of the Airstream trailer, and to get it road ready as the Winsome Mobile Studio. The trailer is a 31-foot Airstream Sovereign Land Yacht. It has not been updated since it was built in 1975, and will need a lot of work in order to become the Winsome Studio. The trailer will but gutted down to the frame. New insulation will be installed, electrical systems will be replaced and updated, and plumbing will be relocated. From there, new interior walls and laminate floors will be put in, a small wet-bath will be built, a kitchenette will be purchased and added, and room dividers and custom furniture will go in. Finally, the studio's "soul" will be added when we install our industrial sewing machines, tables, storage and notions.
This project cannot come to life without your help! Thank you so much for taking the time to learn about our ideas and goals.
