I am building a 58-panel (80" x 56" to 80" x 7") painting space to create a four-room, psychologically charged painting-in-the-round. The installation is the largest undertaking I have ever attempted and I very much hope we can all experience the completed project, through the help of your generous support. Completing the space is projected to cost $12,000, though the more funding the space receives, the grander the finish will become. The painting is primarily oil on canvas and is meant to explore our human understanding of perspective, depth, space, and architecture. The series houses an interactive seating area, inviting the composition beyond the bounds of the canvas and allowing the dialogue of the installation and viewer to change according to the human element present, creating an environment unique to each visitor.
The film "Hope in a Box" presents in-process shots of the main dining room/ living area. In building this space, I very much hope to gain perspective on not only my own sense of self as an artist, but on where and how we blur the lines in observation, experimentation, mimesis and representation-- to create, in essence, a corner of my own empire, encapsulated.
Detail Stephanie and Me
COST:
Since I can remember I have always sought to poke the proverbial hornet's nest, which of course has gotten me more than my fair share of stings. This was, however, my most logical means of figuring out what was inside and attempting to deconstruct the logic behind the beasts within. As an adult I have continued this scientific delving and ended up building a nest of my own. While I am asking for $10,000, the painting space is projected to ACTUALLY COST $12,000 (eeeek!), though the more backing I receive the more I will be able to explore the exterior. My art is experiential in nature, and I ultimately seek to present a fully sensorial interaction for the viewers. Alas, this project is financially prohibitive for a poor graduate student, thus I am asking you all to help me support my dream of building a castle of my own.
WHY $12,000???!!!??!
I am here to let you know I have very realistic and fixed parameters for the completion of this project with, of course, the support of people like you. I am so excited to see the finished space and to share this with all of you!
BREAK-DOWN:
Wooden stretchers- $4,000
Canvas- $1,200
Installation Floor/ Walls- $400
Staples, Hardware, Gesso, Misc- $1,000
Lighting and Infrastructure- $600
Paint, Thinner, Oil, Brushes- $3,800
External Frames- $1,000
TOTAL: $12,000
"Cornelia!! Why can't you just do SIMPLE things that are within your realistic time and money budget??!"
Yes, yes, yes, I have heard this before and am not naive to placing realistic parameters on the largess of my ambitions. I just often get excited about the concept and then say, "Well if this is going to happen, go BIG or go HOME!" This is my ingrained perfectionism and stubborn-headedness, I am sure. I am letting everyone know I AM setting realistic goals for completion, they are just a bit out of my grad-student-in-art-school budget. I am asking you to help me realize and complete this dream by giving what you can.
STRUCTURE:
Here is a projected floor plan for the completed space.
Floor Plan, Triptic
Detail Interior, Floor plan

Patronage starts at $1 and goes to $1000, which includes a small print, greeting cards, a "making of" book tracking the growth of the project, replication of a panel of your choice, and a meet & greet with me during a private viewing before the general public. 
I always love a dollar, but note: Beginning at $10 you will receive goodies!! The incentives are cumulative and become exponentially more awesome! As I am building my dream because of support from you, I want to send a part of me to live with you as a thank you from the bottom of my heart. Know that each item is sent with love.

THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU!
I thank everyone for reading, sponsoring, and passing this along! If you are wanting to support my dream, please do so EARLY! If the project is not FULLY funded it will die. :(( This would be beyond sad. Spread the love to everyone you think will appreciate it. You are the wonder that is helping make my dreams come true. I will not forget your support!!

Wait, what?  Here’s our exciting news!
It’s official! Our FIRST TOUR across the country! We have been asked to perform as part of The (illustrious) Dance Gallery Festival in not one but TWO cities: Houston, TX at Sam Houston State University October 17 & 18 and at the Ailey Citigroup Theatre in Midtown Manhattan on October 25, 2014! http://www.dancegalleryfestival.com
Our new duet, You Win, premiered in Tampa in June, 2014 and was also presented in Seattle at Velocity Dance Center during the July 2014 Seattle Festival of Dance Improvisation. In October, we will join an unbelievably talented group of international dancers and choreographers. Only a handful of choreographers out of the hundreds of applicants have been chosen to show their work on the Houston and New York stages. We are so grateful and humbled to be one of them and to have the honor of performing in both.
You Win (Photo: Tom Kramer)
Here’s a little bit about The Dance Gallery Festival…
The Dance Gallery Festival was created by Astrid von Ussar and Mojca Ussar in 2007 and has since become a well-known festival with showcases in two states NY and TX. At each venue, they provide a state-of-the-art theater, complete with production staff, marketing, and public relations support to showcase each choreographers work. Having been met with much praise and enthusiasm from artists, audiences and critics alike, The Dance Gallery Festival has quickly become an essential and anticipated addition to the dance world. This type of venue helps deepen the public’s appreciation and support for concert dance. In the Dance Gallery Festival’s seven year history, a tremendous amount of talent has been showcased. Their aim is to continue cultivating that talent by creating another performance vehicle that supports the growth of dance companies by providing increased exposure and performance opportunities. http://www.dancegalleryfestival.com
Brian & Erin dancing in Arc presented at The Dance Gallery Festival in 2013
Logistics…
Airfare: round trip airfare from Seattle to Houston, Tampa to Houston and then Seattle to New York and Tampa to New York. And yes, there will be a couple of cross country red-eye flights, but we know it will be worth it!
Lodging: while away from home, we need somewhere to rest our tired heads. With so many different sites online for booking hotels, we have found one that is within walking distance of the Theaters…keeping transportation costs while out of town to the rock bottom price of bringing our best walking shoes.
Per Diem and Travel Expenses: Food, water, to and from the airports and all those little things when you’re out of town can get pretty pricey!
Processing Fees: A percentage of our funds go back to Kickstarter for providing this wonderful fundraising forum.  
Why go through all this effort?
As Tampa/Seattle dance artists, the chance to perform in Houston and New York at The Dance Gallery Festival will help create national recognition for our work and future endeavors. With a performance at Sam Houston State and Ailey Citigroup Theatre, that have a history of selling out, we have the wonderful opportunity to represent dance from opposite ends of the country. We will also have the chance to teach a partnering technique master class to the students at Sam Houston State.
The cast of Arc at The Dance Gallery 2013... made possible with the generous support of people like you.
This is a huge undertaking, but with your help, completely POSSIBLE! It's a lot of money and we have such little time to raise it, which is why we have turned to KICKSTARTER and to each one of you to turn this amazing opportunity into reality. Any amount may be donated. Every dollar helps us get closer to our goal. So take a look to the right and click on one of those pledges… we will be forever grateful.

A story about a young girl named Cosmo who travels across the galaxy solving mysteries!
Cosmo The Space Detective by Ezequiel Nieto
Story Summary
Cosmic Callisto Caprica, or Cosmo for short, is having the night of her life. On the same evening that she receives her junior detective's license, Cosmo is assigned to her first case. For her first case Cosmo will travel to the luxury space station The Titian to investigate a robbery. The luxurious rings of Saturn have been stolen! The owner of the rings, Princess Rhea, a Martian of royal decent, desperately needs her rings back. Cosmo will have to follow all of the clues in order to solve her first case.

I Wanna Do That!
The move from spectator to participant is a quantum leap. Yet each Mardi Gras in New Orleans, thousands of people make it, abandoning inhibition and reveling in the ever-growing creative phenomenon of marching krewes.
To celebrate this untold story, we announce I Wanna Do That!: Celebrating the Magic of Mardi Gras Marching Krewes (IWDT), a coffee table book bursting with photographs to document and illustrate this important New Orleans-centered cultural movement. We agree with local arts critic Doug McCash who says, “At this juncture, marching krewes are one of the best art stories in the city.” 
Ok...so, what is a marching krewe?
Simply put, a marching krewe is a group of like-minded people who get together for the purpose of marching in parades that take place during the Carnival (Mardi Gras) season.
These krewes come in all shapes, sizes, and variations, yet they all share the attributes of creativity, artistry, quirkiness, humor, inclusiveness, and accessibility. Krewes are composed of people who practice dance moves, sew costumes, and create “throws” to hand out to a covetous public. People for whom participation is a badge of civic identity. People who at one point stood on the curb and said “I wanna do that!!” 
Realizing that the marching krewe field has expanded exponentially, our team knew it was a story that must be told. Two incredibly talented local photographers worked tirelessly to document the creative energy of the 2020 Mardi Gras season, with additional information collected to document more than 300 marching krewes in New Orleans. Following an extraordinary amount of photo organizing and curating, interviewing participants and writing, we are ready to launch this beautiful photographic narrative! 
 The result
I Wanna Do That! is a 9” x 11” hardcover book with about 224 pages and 250 color-rich photographs. Printed on premium paper, the book is hardback with four process color plus matte, scuff resistant nylon lamination.
Why support us when there are so many other needs in the world?
The marching krewe story is one of a continual evolution. IWDT documents this movement in a wildly culture-rich city, one that is fanatic about Mardi Gras (many of us have a closet specifically for costumes!) This labor of love is not only candy for the eyes, but a legacy publication to document this important story. It’s a book for locals, visitors, and anyone who celebrates joyful creativity. 
 Supporting our local cultural community is critical to its preservation and continuation. For each book sold, we will allocate a portion to www.feedthesecondline.org, (a project organized by a New Orleans marching krewe) that provides food, love and employment to the culture-bearers who maintain the traditions that make our city unique.  Funds raised on Kickstarter are solely to provide for expenses related to the book.  
Ok..so how is this going to  happen?
A great deal of the work has been done, now we need your help! Funds raised from this Kickstarter will be used to pay the photographers and cover the expense of designing, printing and marketing the book.
Our $18,000 goal is the minimum needed to start printing, but it is not the limit. The more books we can print, the further we can spread the good word and the joy. And the rewards are most excellent and available only during this Kickstarter!
 Ok...so, who is this creative team?
We are New Orleanians who love everything about Mardi Gras and who have the utmost passion for the wide variety of marching krewes.
Echo Olander:  This Yankee child has found home and heart in the wide bayous, smoky clubs and parade routes of New Orleans.  Since the 1970s she has been exploring the intricate layers of New Orleans culture and working to build creative capacity in the city.  Her current interest is the fertile place where self and community find vibrant connection. (instigator, writer, producer)
Yehonathan “Yoni” Goldstein: Yoni’s first Mardi Gras morning in 1990 was a revelatory reminder that there is still magic in the world. His inquisitive mind has led him through several career incarnations including: travel agent, band manager, banquet chef, poker player and project manager.  He is currently way behind schedule on creating his next Mardi Gras costume. (writer, producer)
Ryan Hodgson-Rigsbee: Ryan’s photographic heart is on the streets of New Orleans.  With a wide client list of national and local editorial publications, this Chicago native also has a number of long running personal projects exploring culture, music, and landscape in New Orleans and other unique communities across the nation.  He is relentless in his goal of reaching the public with photography that is both compelling and culturally responsible.  See more at rhrphoto.com (photographer)
Patrick Niddrie: Patrick found an outlet for his bold, colorful artistic sensibilities when he discovered photography in 2007.   Leaving his birthplace of New Orleans with nothing but camera and curiosity, his lens has guided him from the Swiss Alps to the Ganges Delta, with regular returns to document the vibrancy of New Orleans.  Patrick likes to keep things loose, leaving space for polished, spontaneous moments; a perfect match for marching krewes.  See more at patrickniddrie.com  (photographer) 
 Rewards

So what's this all about?
We are a group of four artists, Martha Beaumont, Mark Morgan, Estella Castle and James Mansfield, and we're having a residency at Degree Art, a gallery in East London in September and October 2014. We are raising funds to pay for some of the installation that we plan to create – which will be a 12ft by 8ft log cabin within the gallery space.
The concept for the show is that we will create an installation which provides an insight into the life of a modern-day explorer who decided to build a log cabin in a patch of wasteland somewhere in London. At some point, the explorer disappeared, and the cabin was discovered.
The viewer will be presented with an interactive installation consisting of the cabin and its contents. Through a series of narratives consisting of objects and artworks, visitors will be drawn into the explorer's life and be able to form their own interpretations of why the explorer built the cabin as well as reasons for their mysterious disappearance.
Who are we?
We are a group of four artists
Estella Castle 
Mark Morgan
Martha Beaumont 
James Mansfield
We met while studying at City and Guilds of London Art School in Kennington in 2012/13 and have since been working both on our individual practices as well as together in preparation for this show. We are interested in a similar range of ideas – about the construction of fictions and artifices, as well as the influence of having lived in the countryside for large periods of our lives.
For this project, we were inspired by tales of explorers from the 19th century, who went to places like the Arctic as well as pioneers who went and lived in inhospitable parts of Canada and Alaska. Bringing this to 2014, we thought it would be great to build our own log cabin and recreate this kind of experience.
So what do we need to raise money for exactly?
We are using Kickstarter to raise money for the installation element of the exhibition, which consist of building a log cabin in the gallery space at Degree Art.
Our estimates are that it will cost around £1850 to buy and transport enough timber (around 30 8 foot logs) to London. We will also be spending around £600 on tools and equipment for the construction of the cabin. We have some funding in place but are now looking to raise around 75% of this cost through Kickstarter and so have an initial target of £2000. If we can exceed this, that would be great.
And this is what you get in return!
We have a range of rewards on offer for donators.
Here are some examples:
For £10 you get a copy of the artist's book and an invitation to the private view.
For £50 you get a small print or sketch by one of us.
For £200 you get a small painting and a small print or sketch by one of us.
For £500 you get a commissioned painting by one of us, where you can choose the subject matter (up to 24 inches square).
We have a separate portfolio website where you can see the artworks which you will receive or you can also have a look at our individual websites above.

We Are Not Shadows
  Despite living in a time when more women are speaking up and speaking out about inequality, political issues, and the realities of their day-to-day lives, many continue to be treated as whispers in the void; hidden figures in the dark; shadows on the wall. This is what moved us to launch We Are Not Shadows as the first book from Folkways Press.
When compiling this anthology, we made it our mission to select writing from women of all ages and backgrounds covering a wide range of topics - many of which we feel are both timely and necessary. In We Are Not Shadows, you will find stories, poems, and essays concerning issues of race, gender, sexuality, trauma, adversity, disability, and much more.
This book will feature an extraordinary group of women stepping into the light and sharing their experiences, many of which we're sure you'll either relate to or have your eyes opened by.
Open these pages and listen as Amy Kenny writes on the lack of narratives for people with disabilities, and how disability is a life of erasure as a result.
Walk with Isla Mani through her lines of prose as she recounts abuse at the hands of a loved one and its impact on her identity.
Experience the powerful poetry of Tanatsei Gambura, who delves into the deeply personal exploration of being a woman, being Zimbabwean, being a cite of violence, and becoming an embodiment of resistance.
Just as this book serves as a platform for writers who often go unheard, we also want it to reach out and empower you to stand up and use your voice, even if it shakes.
Who We Are
  Folkways Press is a newly founded independent publishing company dedicated to the unconventional, the extraordinary, and the voices of those who've been pushed to the margins for far too long.
With each book we publish, we strive to promote literacy, support charitable causes, and empower our authors and readers by taking the literary roads less traveled.
Here, we believe that for every voice there is a story, and for every story, there is a book waiting to be written.
Folkways Press is led by Hannah Fields - a career editor and writer from Texas who loves all things publishing, non-profit, advocacy, and more. Get in touch on Twitter.
Contributors
  What we love most about our contributors is that they hail from all parts of the world! From the United States to Scotland and beyond, we love that we can connect stories from women everywhere.

  Pledges, Funding, and Rewards
  We turned to Kickstarter to launch our first book because we think it is the perfect platform to share these stories with a broad audience and, in pre-ordering copies of our book, it helps us launch more copies than savings alone will allow. This is especially helpful when the company is currently being led by one person (Hannah) and extremely helpful friends and colleagues who donate their time.
What will we use the money for (i.e., where is your money going)?
Author Payment: We believe in paying our authors for their work. So many authors go unpaid in this industry and we want to change that. Funds will also go toward paying any typesetters, designers, proofreaders, and more who are involved in this project.
Printing: Truth is, there is no expense to be spared when it comes to printing, especially if we want to bring you a quality product. And we do! Much of our funding will go toward printing, shipping, and distribution of the books.
Events: This might be a bit harder to manage due to the issues still being caused by the pandemic. However, we want to do what we can to hold events, whether they be virtual or (fingers-crossed) in-person when travel becomes safe. We want to launch this book in a unique way, and we will do what we can to make that happen!
Shipping: Because we want to make this book available to as many readers as we can reach, we also need to have the funds to ship each book and extra reward where it needs to go in a timely and safe manner.
Extra: If we happen to have any funding left over after payments are made, books are printed, and all items are shipped, all money will go back into the company so we can work on bringing you our next book!
Pledges and Rewards
For every pledge you make, depending on the level, you'll receive some great rewards such as:
A copy of the book
Your name listed in the book as a backer
A themed postcard 
A themed bookmark 
A limited-edition enamel pin
And other rewards as thanks for supporting this project!

At the end of the 2013-2014 school year, then-juniors Nina Rowan and Kayla McGovern began working endlessly in effort to make their dream of publishing a fashion magazine at Emmaus High School a reality after noticing a lack of fashion-geared activities at Emmaus. 
They since added Kayte Bridger and Emily Yen to the Board of Directors and a 40-person staff to publish a new issue every month on ehsbuzzmagazine.com. 
While the Internet has provided the opportunity to share the magazine with a greater audience, the dream is still to see a glossy-paged, real-life magazine in the hands of all the students in the halls of our school. 
Buzz Magazine currently has over 500 followers on various social media websites and close to 2,000 views on ehsbuzzmagazine.com. The magazine has added an element to the school environment that hadn't before existed. Students can now send in their #OOTD pictures to be featured on the Instagram, and there's a celebration of individual style that used to get swept under the rug. We believe we're giving a place for the kid with big dreams of the Fashion Capital a place to go. A place where heels in school isn't scoffed at, but met with a warm, "I LOVE your shoes! Where'd you get them?"
Despite the large following Buzz Magazine has garnered, the publication is currently not funded by Emmaus, making the hefty publication price of one issue, $5,000, a very difficult task.
We have done many fundraising events, including bake sales, clothing swaps, scarf sales, and frozen yogurt nights, however in order to publish our magazine by the time we graduate in June, we're going to need a lot more. Selling $0.50 cupcakes isn't cutting it. 
We need YOU!
We are very serious journalism students with dreams of working for an established fashion magazine in the future, and your contributions will help push us all a bit closer to that goal. 
Best, 
The Board

We are a four year old nomadic theater troupe whose sole purpose is to create irreverent, quirky, and innovated stage shows using puppetry to demolish the "typical" theater experiences and add a bit of anarchy to every stage that we perform on. We build, design, create and write almost all of our own shows. The theater experience we give to our audience is always one of a kind. In order to turn this group into the professional, creative force we know it can be, we need your help to get into our own space.
To produce theater in a fancy space, you have to have the Benjamin's to cover the costs associated with it. Your money will go toward production of our five show season. Your cash will cover costs such as sets, costumes, props and even puppet building. Along with that you'll help us pay for our rehearsal spaces, rental of the theater, technicians and a front of house manager. Who ever said the theater is dead must not have been talking about the money spent to produce it. Am I right?
Backing our project is the easiest way you can help. Choose the reward that works for you and click away! Remember, you'll only be charged if we meet our goal. Once you donate, tell everyone. Tell your family and friends and even that one weird neighbor that always smells like smoke and offers you a ride to the deli.
No Money? No Problem! There are lots of ways to help that don't cost you anything. Share, share and share! The more people who see and share our campaign and watch the videos, the more chance we have of reaching all of our goals and unleashing puppet domination onto the world! Help spread the word about our campaign by sharing it on your Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Do a seven second Vine video, on our behalf, to all of your followers. Save the picture below and spread it all over your social media pages. Make it your profile pic, tweet it, or do whatever it is you do with it on Instagram! Get eyeballs on this thing!
Post On Social Media!
So spread the word… but if you don't have money and you don't spread the word… then you're just rude. You're just a rude-guss.
We've won awards- been nominated for others. Don't take our word that what we have is something special. Here are links to just a few of our favorite reviews.

Avenue Q

A heart "felt" thank you goes out to Kevin MacLeod for lending his music for the video. You can check out all of Kevin's stuff at this link.
Pictures in the video also came from a project we did with Jonathan Castillo. You can see the photo session we did together here.
Our marketing Goddess Kiki Plesha who was the first to believe in us when we came to Arizona. She has started her own magazine but still has time to help our furry butts. Check out her website here. 
Thanks to Tanner Stuff for his excellent 'We Want You Poster'.
And last but not least, thanks to you. Honestly, we really can't do this without you. By helping us now, you may be paving the way for our future home. I can't tell you how gratifying that would be to not only get there, but with you by our sides. So... Thank you.
Enough with the mushy stuff! Let puppet anarchy reign!

This film is about a teenager named Marcus and his friend Jack who are up to no good, stealing and getting into trouble. They think all they're doing is having fun and playing games, but in actuality, it is much worse. They both need help and they don't know it. As the story progresses, Marcus's meets a Christian classmate who introduces himself, and they become friends. He finds out that his job is to bring Marcus to God, and have him repent for what he has done. Marcus starts to change; however, when everything is about to turn around, things get bad real quick when Jack is in trouble. Marcus finds himself in the biggest predicament of his life, and must turn to God to decide what is right. 
The trailer we put together took three days and a lot of planning. We were able to shoot six chapters of the film, and they all turned out great. We discovered that shooting the trailer proved to be harder to do than actually shooting the movie. We had to cram ten minutes of film into three days. That may not seem like a lot, but it was. Each day consisted of getting up at either five or six in the morning, loading up equipment, traveling to our location, shooting for 10 hours, then going home. It was both tiresome and fun at the same time.
In order to finish the film we need at least $20,000, but our goal is $25,000. Most of the funds will go toward equipment, actors, food for the actors, props, gas, and vehicle rentals. This project will include a lot of stunts and action, including fight scenes, car chases, parkour, and police! The plan is to show this film to churches and film festivals all across the globe, making this a very big and important project.
My team and my church are very confident this project will have a far-reaching impact. We can't wait to see the final outcome! All we need is your support!

Join the Bad Guy Nonsense Group!

Join us now in constructing a workshop in Playa Blanca, Peru, to build small scale wind turbines for houses that are not on the electricity grid - a mini energy revolution powered by you!
We are building this community workshop to be a fully outfitted test center for:
Electrification! building and servicing wind turbines installed in the local area
Education! teaching the community, national students and international volunteers about wind energy, turbine science and mechanics
Engineering! developing and testing new turbine system designs
Providing power to Playa Blanca
  Learning, building, experimenting together
The Wind Workshop - Why and How
Around 37% of Peru's rural population does not have a connection to the electricity grid. In remote areas a connection is difficult and expensive; the alternatives of running diesel generators and using candles are costly, dangerous for health, and pollute.
Communities are rightly demanding energy, and the chance to get it sustainably - Peru is already suffering the direct impacts of climate change. Luckily much of Peru has plenty of sun for solar generation, and large areas ideal for wind generation. For the last 10 years, WindAid has been working to electrify rural communities with wind energy. This type of local renewable electricity is easy and quick to install and has a clear and measurable impact for the recipients.
We now have over 50 wind turbines installed in coastal communities from Piura in the north, to Lima on the central coast and across the Peruvian Andes from Cajamarca to Huaraz. Check out our turbine map: http://www.windaid.org/about-us/windaid-impact/
We have many projects to install more turbines in our work plan, but we are limited by what we can do in our Trujillo workshop to build and maintain them. It can take us over 12 hours to travel to the site of a turbine, even after we have been able to arrange for a group to go. We identified that a network of regional hubs would help in various ways:
Having facilities close to installations to build new turbines and do maintenance
Provide adequate accommodation for volunteers on site to allow for longer stays to get more done
Be a training center for a local technician(s), who can diagnose and fix minor problems and eventually be capable of fabricating turbine systems and help us develop and test new designs
Talking about this idea with our friends in Playa Blanca, we decided the village would be the ideal site to build our first community workshop. A plan formed that we are now ready to make it reality!
The Wind Workshop - Design and Construction
The Playa Blanca Wind Workshop has a modern design but also fits in with the surrounding buildings. It will be made principally using bamboo as a local renewable resource for durability and natural beauty, and other locally-sourced materials.
It will accommodate up to 20 workers throughout the day, with dormitories to sleep up to 12. Therefore the design needs to provide versatility as rooms can change from work spaces to sleeping quarters for local community members and visiting project volunteers.
CAD rendering of the Wind Workshop - From the North
  Aerial CAD Render of the Wind Workshop - No Roof
  CAD Rendering of the Wind Workshop from the North - No Roof
  CAD Render of the Wind Workshop - From the South East
We are taking care to make the building as low impact as possible on this delicate coastal ecosystem, and will showcase the benefits of these features to our neighbors:
Grey water being reused for vegetable garden irrigation
Washroom waste being composted into fertilizer
Wind turbines for electricity
Solar hot water heaters
A rooftop vegetable garden
The workshop will serve as the WindAid Institute base of operations in the Playa Blanca area, where we will build the wind generators, develop models specific to their needs, and test and adopt the most advanced wind turbine designs.
Playa Blanca at Sunset
A History of Playa Blanca and WindAid Institute
Playa Blanca is a small village on the beautiful desert coast of Northern Peru. It was founded nearly a half a century ago as a permanent home for the fishermen and women that made a living from the abundant sea life in the rich waters.
Today there are over 60 families, two schools, a restaurant, a shop, a community centre and a church. However, it still has little infrastructure, including no access to grid electricity.
View of the Bay
  The Fishing Boats of Playa Blanca
But this small community wants energy to power their lives, and will accept nothing less than a sustainable solution that leaves them free from dependence upon an unreliable and expensive grid-connection.
WindAid Institute has been working with Playa Blanca towards this goal since 2012, installing different turbines, running workshops, and testing system add-ons.
Raising a Turbine in Playa Blanca
In 2014 we decided together on a long-term sustainable model:
Installing a small autonomous wind turbine for every house in Playa Blanca. We now have 15 systems, with plans to have up to 40 - for every family that wants one. They use the energy for lights; charging mobile phones and batteries; and powering televisions, small fridges, and cooking appliances such as blenders.
Creating a permanent facility in the village to service, maintain, and replace them independently. The community has provided the land, and we have marked out the plot.
Now let’s build!
The Wind Workshop land plotted out for building
  Sr. Abel and Jessica celebrate the first post in!
  Everyone pitches in a hand as school lets out
  Posts for the western wall set with the setting sun!
Build Phases
We are spending a fortnight in Playa Blanca this month (June) to install the support beams and erect the temporary walls and roof for the living area. We would love it if you followed our progress to cheer us on.
Phase One
This Kickstarter event is to enable us to complete the first phase of the build, through to November 2016. We will be:
Installing all remaining support beams
Putting in inner divisions, wiring the living area, and running water (non-potable)
Installing a turbine to provide power to the center
Finalizing the room divisions
Improving the walls, making the roof walk-worthy
Creating a dust free room for electronics
Phase Two
The second phase will be done by January 28 2017, when we will install a second turbine, additional tooling & equipment in the workshop, and put in all the remaining amenities in the kitchen, bathroom, bedrooms and living room so we are ready to take full project teams to site. We are offering the opportunity to join us to complete the Wind Workshop, and to attend the grand unveiling!
Help us build the Playa Blanca Community Wind Workshop right now and claim your awesome hand-grafted Peruvian reward!
Peruvian coin wallets and alpaca purses
Funding the workshop
We are aiming to raise $35,000 which other than the direct costs of running this campaign (included as a percentage in each category below), will go to complete phase one, as described above. The costs are:
Building materials $22,000
Tools and equipment to fit out workshop $8,600
Travel, food, and accommodation for build phase one $4,400
Meet the team
Over the time we are building the workshop, a lot of volunteers and WindAid Institute staff, as well as community members will be involved in some way. We’d like to introduce you to key people on the team:
Nicholas Warren - Nick helped found WindAid Institute. His enthusiasm and ability to make every day fun brings a lot of laughter to the team.
Jessica Rivas - Jess also helped found WindAid Institute. Her boundless energy and great affection for the Playa Blanca community helps drive this project.
Abel Yupaqui - Universally known as Señor Abel, he has been with WindAid since it’s inception in 2006. His creative problem solving skills have made even difficult turbine installations successful!
Martin Del Aguila Silva - The President of the "Directiva Eolica" in charge of the wind energy project in Playa Blanca, Martin has been an avant supporter of the wind turbine project in Playa Blanca, and has a natural curiousity which leads him to modify and use the wind turbines beyond what we knew they were capable.
Domingo Morales Coronado - Don Domingo was the first person WindAid ever met in Playa Blanca, and has calmly pushed this project forward from inception. He offered to help when we were still prototype testing, and has been an unwavering support since day one.
Tomas Morales Coronado - One of the first community members to have a wind turbine, Tomas has had great insight into improving the wind turbine systems. He is also excited for the deeper education that will come with the Wind Workshop, especially for the youth.

Why Bologna ?
Bologna located in a strategic point north central Italy Important tourist destination important railway and airport station and primary highway. At the heart of the Motor Valley near automotive and motorcycle industries (Ferrari Lamborghini Pagani Maserati Ducati ...) Militarily theater of important battles a few steps from the gothic line and protagonist of the liberation during the second world war.
Almost all scale models will be assembled, painted and dioramas by myself and by the team that I will create, professional builders, miniaturists of international renown, others will come from private collections and scale models of excellent prestige on the market.

What's the deal with Jeffrey Bloom?
A seemingly normal guy with good intentions, Jeff has nothing but admiration for his college sweetheart, Laura. Or does he? After moving in with Laura, he can't help but question every move.
A narrative short, Inside Boxes explores the psychology of a man whose fears ultimately take over his life. Unfortunately for Jeff that may just be the undoing for the relationship he has with Laura.
This is mine (Paul Lazo) and Michelle Kwong's BFA thesis film. It's a dramatic comedy about moving in and falling out.
Inside Boxes will be shooting mid-June and we need your help to make it happen. We're looking to create a "different" kind of movie that ultimately tackles issues of social anxiety not by examining the problem itself by saying "he's bi-polar" or "he's crazy" but by creating a visual narrative that show how these kinds of problems affect interpersonal relationships.
We need your help to do the following:
1. HOUSING AND TRANSPORTATION  - A lot of our cast and crew are traveling from out of town and we'll be navigating the entire metro-Boston area for our shoot. With your help we'll be sure to keep our crew mobile.
2. EQUIPMENT - We'll be renting lenses, G&E equipment and other assorted goods. Your donations will literally put our images into motion.
3. PRODUCTION DESIGN - We're looking to create very cluttered spaces and your donations will help dirty our frames. Boxes are surprisingly expensive believe it or not. Donations like yours will make our film's design flawless and pretty.
4. CONTINGENCY - Things go wrong sometimes. People are late, someone forgets the batteries. With contingency money, we'll have spare money just in case something goes crazy.

Meet the Team
Paul Lazo - Director
BFA Film Production major with specializations in writing and directing narrative fiction. Paul Lazo is best known in the Emerson community as the director of a number of multi-camera television shows (Amped!, Musicians Wanted, Unsportsmenlike Conduct) and Emerson's go-to Script Supervisor (Monarch, How to Make a Nightmare, The Whistler). Now he hopes to place his mind back into his major by creating this movie Inside Boxes.
Paul Lazo loves writing weird and compelling stories. As a kid, he would often write books and share them with friends. Growing up he found himself writing normal situations in abnormal ways, leading to some very strange and unique pieces. He loves creating art on 16mm film melding inks onto film emulsion. What he appreciates most about film making is that it allows you to let someone view the world through your eyes.
A piece Paul and Brad created last semester entitled Speak is free to watch on YouTube.
Last summer he had the pleasure of working as a Script Supervisor on the independent feature Theory of Conflict which is currently in post-production. He has also script supervised a number of Emerson BFAs and BAs. 
He's the Visual Media Arts Bill Bordy Scholarship recipient for 2013-2014 and takes a lot of pride and commitment into all that he does. He enjoys bad television, pizza and indie rock. He hopes to work either on set or in the studio after college.
Michelle Kwong - Director of Photography
Michelle Kwong is a twenty-one-year-old BFA cinematography major and photography minor from Long Island, New York expecting to graduate Emerson College in the spring of 2015. With a passion and interest in visual imagery, Michelle believes that film and photography are mediums that allow her to create stories and convey thoughts, ideas, and emotions she was never able to do with just words.
During her time at Emerson, Michelle has participated on various sets within the lighting and camera departments in order to hone her skills as a cinematographer. These skills have allowed her to get a taste of the professional industry by working on sets such as Mania Days, starring Katie Holmes and executive produced by Spike Lee, and the feature length version of the short film, Curfew, the winner of the 2012 Academy Award for Best Live Action Short Film. Michelle has also created several short films in the past that have been recognized by various film festivals, such as I'm Not Even That (2009) that was screened at the 2010 New York Asian American International Film Festival and 11th Annual DC Asian Pacific American Film Festival, and Weirdo Records (2013) that was screened at the 2013 Ballston Spa Film Festival and chosen to be screened at the 2014 Salem Mass Reality Check Film Festival.
You can view Michelle Kwong's reel on Youtube.
Aside from being the director of photography for her and Paul Lazo's collaborative BFA thesis film, Inside Boxes, that will be shooting this upcoming summer, Michelle has recently finished shooting the BFA thesis film, Fairy Tale, and is currently the director of photography for two BA Capstones shooting in March.
Michelle continues to develop her skills as a cinematographer and make her dream of becoming a filmmaker a reality.
Brad Cryan - Co-Writer
A Writing for Film & Television, Class of 2015 and active member of SPEC - a screenwriting workshop at Emerson. He's written a number of films at Emerson, including 3 feature-length screenplays. Last semester he and Paul came together to create an original one act called "Speak" and once again are teaming up to create the world of Inside Boxes.
On the side, Brad composes music - including the original score for four short films, all produced by fellow Emerson students. He looks forward to participating in the Los Angeles program next semester.
Taylor Kissin - Producer
 Taylor is a Junior Television Production major at Emerson College. Born and raised in Freeport, Maine, Taylor gained an appreciation for the visual and media arts at a young age. He immersed himself in every creative outlet possible, eventually winning a Maine State One Act Best Original Script award for his one act play, You’re Killing Me…
Continuing to develop his skills in media production, Taylor started his college career at Quinnipiac University where he soon found himself yearning for life in a city. After transferring to Emerson, Taylor delved deeply into the technical aspects of both film and television. During this time frame, he discovered that his true passion lied in producing.
Pamela Mora - Producer
 Pamela Mora is a Sophomore Writing for Television and Film major who best describes herself as a "cardboard box" on the spectrum of boxes. Her film Disorder (2013) won the Audience Prize in the Emerson LA Showcase and has been around the fest circuit too many times to count.
In addition to be being all around awesome she is the new General Manager of Emerson Independent Video with the goal of introducing more films into EIV's general programing. She likes Pretty Little Liars and the state of Florida, where she is from.
Laura Brincat - Production Designer
 Laura is a B.F.A. Film Production major graduating in December 2014.
She is currently in the process of finishing her B.F.A. Thesis Film entitled Fairy Tale, about a young girl who must choose between fantasy and reality. She is also the production designer of the B.A. Film Awake, Elsewhere, a film about isolation and hallucination. Her other credits include director of Weirdo Records and My Sister, production designer on The Meatball Factory, and others.

Who We Are
Victory Chimp creates cycling art, apparel and accessories to make you smile. Based at the foot of the Sperrin Mountains, Northern Ireland, our designs are dreamed up on these wild and beautiful roads and worked out back in the studio. 
Introducing Our First Kit Collection
Victory Chimp performance apparel is made in Italy, marrying the latest fabrics with our unique graphic style and humour to create highly technical, stylish and durable performance apparel for you to love. We work in partnership with fellow family-run small businesses across Europe to produce the highest quality combination of style and performance. This reputation has earned us a valued global community of friends and Chimpeurs. 
Designed in Northern Ireland. Made in Italy.
Spread the word
Know bike riding friends who'd be just excited about our kits as you are? Let them know via the links below. Every share helps us reach our goal to bring you beautiful kit to make you smile.
Kits for Everyone
Victory Chimp strives to make our garments available to all who ride a bike. From launch, our casual and performance clothing lines have been available in either unisex or women's specific cuts and across a broad range of sizes. We're taking this even further with our first kit collection, developing each piece independently to create two garments designed exclusively for their respective gender to provide the best fit, feel, look and performance. After the campaign ends you will be able to select Men's or Women's cuts in sizes XS-XXXL. We're not going to limit colourways to our Men's or Women's lines either. You can have either kit's options in any cut or size. Embrace your inner chimp, ride safe and go ape.
View Size Guide 
Banana Positioning Technology™
Integrated into all garment rear pockets, our patented Banana Positioning Technology™ insures optimally stationed wonder fruit on all rides.
We did it! With your amazing support we blasted through our target of £12,000 in just 5 days! A massive thank you to all who've pledged to our campaign so far and made our first kit collections a reality, we couldn't have done it without you. So what to do for the remainder of the campaign? Well, we've now added a few stretch funding targets with additional rewards and options to be unlocked.
Ogham
The Ogham Kit (Olive Green/Orange)
Inspired by on and off-road adventures in the wild beauty of the Sperrin Mountains and the many remnants of ancient Ireland within them. Ogham, pronounced [ˈoːm], is an early Irish alphabet found inscribed on standing stones. Each letter represents a native tree, with our pattern made up of Oak, Ash, Elder, Birch, Willow amongst others. The perfect kit for your next gravel grinder or bikepacking adventure. 
The Ogham Kit (Stone Grey/Chartreuse)
The Ogham kit is available in either Olive/Forest Green or Stone Grey/Chartreuse colourways and comprises Jersey, Bib Shorts, Gilet, Arm Warmers, Base Layer, Cap, Buff and Socks. All garments are available in Men's and Women's cuts across sizes XS-XXXL.
Stampen
The Stampen Kit (Team Issue)
Our team kit for 2018/19. Inspired by Belgian cycling passion and our two favourite aspects of the sport, the cobbled classics and cyclocross. Heard on both the road and mud-filled course, "Stampen!" (we're reliably informed by our Flemish collaborator) loosely translates as "Pedal like f—k!".
The Stampen Kit (Plum/Teal)
The Stampen kit is available in two colourways and comprises Jersey, Bib Shorts, Gilet, Arm Warmers, Base Layer, Cap, Buff and Socks. All garments are available in Men's and Women's cuts across sizes XS-XXXL.

Why Kickstarter? 
Over the last year we have designed and developed all of the garment prototypes, samples and size-sets with our factory. We've selected the best fabrics and fine-tuned the designs and colourways. We've worn them through the winter and tested them on 200km rides. For now, we've taken it as far as we can.
Now we just need your support to help us to launch, so we can bring you beautiful kit to make you smile. By pledging here, you are helping us to fund the first production run with the factory. We love this gear. Please support the first Victory Chimp kit collection and together we can make it a reality. 
Production & Delivery Timeline
Meet the Founder
Founded in 2014, Victory Chimp began life as the creative outlet of Northern Irish freelance designer, illustrator and bike rider, Ryan O'Reilly. When not busy at his desk, Ryan would either be scribbling down his own ideas or riding around the country on his bike. When the latter started exerting an overwhelming influence on the former, Victory Chimp was born. One crash and several weeks away from both bike and computer later, Ryan had plotted a course through the (mostly imagined) intersections of art, cycling, fashion and the great apes.

Dear Adventurers,
Hello! It’s me, Clara. I am the author.
Jenny is the Illustrator.

Together, we are bringing to life the true imaginings from my childhood. Why? Because of our sons.
Jenny’s son, Easton is 8 years old. My son, Rufus is 8 Months old. Jenny and I want to leave a legacy for our sons. A legacy that will create a wave of inspiration, adventure, and imagination for our sons and other children everywhere, to surf. And of course we want the time and freedom to surf that wave with them. Our hope is that this book (and others to follow) will lend us that freedom!
Easton has been our biggest cheerleader. He loves the story, loves his mom, loves Rufus, and will do anything to help this book succeed. He entertains Rufus, poses for our pictures, and delivers honest feedback. And Rufus adores Easton.
It all started when I (Clara) was a kid in the 90’s. My two best friends, Erica and Natalie, and I went on adventures all around the world. We were wolves, archeologists, professional fort builders, explorers, spies, and dragon hunters. Every day after school we would play till the sun went down.
Hunting Dragons was a neighborhood favorite. We had a lengthy list of local dragons that needed our protection. Such as the sidewalk dragon, the tree dragon, sky dragon, rose dragon, car dragon… you get the idea.
Unfortunately, we all grew up. For a while, I let myself fall into the idea that I needed to retire my childhood imagination. Even though it had been my salvation.
When I learned I was pregnant with my son, I realized how silly it was to put those stories in a box. My husband encouraged me to write one of the stories down. That is when ‘Today We Are Dragon Hunters’ came to life!
Little did I know it would launch me into a dream of becoming a children's book author! The only problem? Illustrating.
One fate filled evening I went to a women's entrepreneurial book club meeting in the cozy mountain town of Bozeman, Montana. The leader of the group asked us all to share our dreams. A nice blonde lady, named Jenny, said she dreamed of being an artist. She said that she loved painting depictions of rocks, which I found very intriguing. When it was my turn, I shared that I had written a story and I dreamed of being an author but lacked artistic abilities.
Thus a friendship was forged!
We exchanged words, phone numbers, and a plan. Since then we have been working together to bring this story to life for you!
Jenny and I chose to use Kickstarter because we believe in our book. We believe that adults and children will love it as much as we do. We believe that despite the many distractions, activities, and video games available to kids of all ages, we all need time for imagination and play.
The funds donated to this campaign will help us fulfill ours, and Easton’s, dreams. They will go to publishing, marketing, and distributing our book to libraries, schools, and book stores.
Jenny and I put our heads together to compile a list of book stores, libraries, and other places we would like to see our book.
Your donation will go toward making this happen.
A Grass Dragon Spotting
Thank you for your support! You are helping our dreams come true!

Kindling is a short social drama following protagonists, Alexia (30) and Kat (32), a lesbian couple who are trying to start a family together. After Alexia’s miscarriage and news that she is unable to conceive, the couple become distant. Their relationship is on the brink until they come across an abandoned baby in the woods. After deciding to bring the baby home, they put off calling the police and instantly grow attached to the child; caring for her as if she was their own. The baby allows the couple to bond again and imagine what life would have been like if Alexia had not miscarried.

Imagine being able to control our telescopes to explore the sky in both hemispheres from the comfort of your living room. Go from the heart of the Milky Way to the Clouds of Magellan, sail by the sun and past the planets of our solar system.
Stargazers is a project dedicated to making astronomy and astrophotography available to everyone. We plan to create a network of high-grade telescopes around the world and let you steer them in the easiest and most natural way: from the tip of your fingers.  
Last news !!
We are pleased to announce that everything is almost ready to build our first site. 
To celebrate this milestone, we are honored to offer to all Kickstarter backers an exclusive lifetime access to this R&D site. Only you will have the opportunity to book for free this site while it will not be in use by our technical team. 
Would you like to know more? check news N°5
Contemplating the sky is always wonderful and stress-free. The view gives us an insight into the world in which we live. Throughout the ages, the sky has always inspired humanity.  
Stargazing doesn’t require much to start with. The first instrument can be your bare eyes, except if you’re living in a city with so much light pollution that the stars are barely visible, or if your weather is not cooperating.  
With Stargazers App, you are no longer limited by local conditions. Select one of our international sites, and then watch live-streaming video from its telescope. No matter the time of day or the weather!
 If you want to get more involved in astronomy, add binoculars or even a telescope to your explorations. You can also add a camera for more details and deeper sky observations.  
We encourage you to join an astronomy group near your home. They’ll help you improve your skills. Imagine getting to share your love of the stars with others! We encourage you to share your explorations! You can instantly upload photos from our Stargazers App to your favorite form of social media.  
With Stargazers App, you will add to your starwatching skills. Because our telescopes are in different hemispheres, you can see and show sky wonders at any time. Just travel instantly to the other side of the planet to contemplate the skies.
With the Stargazer App, you can book time on a remote observatory. Each 12-inch diameter telescope is fully equipped with a high-end digital camera for astrophotography and assisted with an 80mm apochromatic refractor. Our system is also equipped with a cooled camera. This hardware is under your control on your remote device, such as a tablet, from Stargazers App.  
Our goal is to create a seamless system that is as natural and easy to use as possible. Use our star map to find a feature or point to a location and click. Our telescope will automatically move to this position. Our cameras are ready to take photographs at your discretion. You can also choose a space object from a pre-programmed list, such as a nebula, our sun (during daytime), or a planet. Our telescope will move automatically into the selected position. You can also just use the camera feedback and point to a location or use our directional pad to change your target.  
All the complex technology is hidden behind the scenes and maintained by a team of experts!
Who is Talking About Us
 People Follow Us Already
 Even the Experts Follow Us
 The Stargazers App Journey
 The Genesis of Stargazer
In 2014, Philippe Lopes Pinto, Stargazer App’s Co-Founder & Chief Executive, invited friends to dinner. One of his friend’s daughters saw his telescope and asked if she could look through it. Unfortunately, the weather wasn’t cooperating. Philippe met up again with his friends few months later, but this time, it was too late for the girl to observe the sky. It occurred to Philippe to build a set of telescopes worldwide so people could observe the sky no matter their location or time zone.
 The Proof of Concept
The first step of developing the Stargazer App was to enumerate what our solution was supposed to do. We then needed to see if our idea would work on any device, like a tablet or smartphone. Our critical steps on this qualitative approach were:
Capturing, editing, and streaming a video from a specialized camera.  
Steering a telescope using a high-grade mount directly from a tablet. 
Managing the power supply and equipment status. 
Preserving the local environment. If possible, we pick sites located in isolated places away from city lights and pollution. Astronomers care about the health of their observation places. As a result, we rely on solar panels and batteries anywhere there is no available electrical grid.
Having enough bandwidth to meet our needs.
Implementing fully automated behavior of the hardware and software to preserve the site’s integrity. For instance, in case of bad weather conditions, the dome should be able to shut itself down.  Integrating all electronic equipment with our own software so we can handle every unexpected situation, without being limited by manufacturer’s software. This means that, unlike most remote solutions for personal use, we do not rely on stacking existing software. We have built our own complete solution from scratch.
Making our solution available remotely with limited latencies (time lags).
Our plan required that every single step described above had to be successfully tested. Otherwise, the project would have stopped immediately. Using separate software, we have tested every component.
All the hardware, such as our cameras and mounts must have an exposed API or driver so that we could create our own software from scratch.
We’ve also tested the video streams captured from several cameras. We ensured that we could combine the different videos and restream them to your mobile device.
Finally, we also tested automated aspects to help us choose which platform was best fitted to our needs. According to these tests, we can use both a microcontroller and an embedded computer. This will allow us to use each to its best advantage.
A Well-Advanced UI App  
The user interface (UI) has been designed to be as friendly as possible. Every command is easily accessible, and as understandable as possible for ages 9 to 99. It is “fluent” which means every action is accessible with minimum steps. Our goal is to make astronomy accessible to everyone so no prior knowledge of astronomy is required. If you can point and touch, you can use this system. More experienced astronomers will be able to focus on observations and retrieve session files for post-treatment.
This video shows you how to use an iPad to select an observatory site using Stargazer App and get quick information. The video was captured in real time on a 9.7” iPad Pro.
Our First Observatory Sites: Australia and Europe 
For astronomy observations, time lag is crucial! This is particularly true when we decided to offer daytime steering. That’s why we’ve selected remote sites in Australia and Europe.  
In Australia, you can marvel at the southern sky within the heart of the Milky Way. This location is located three and a half hours from Melbourne in Victoria State. It is in a remote area far from light pollution. Our host and caretaker is very involved in astronomy. This enthusiast will take care of our installation. He already has two domes installed! We will be completely autonomous with solar panels and 4G for communications.
In Europe, we opted for the Saint-Véran site, an observatory built in the mid-60s in Provence (France). Saint-Véran is a unique and fantastic location far away from light pollution. The observatory is located at 2940m (9,650 feet) and offers a very pure and dark sky. This observatory is already well known and valued by the astronomy community. We are very proud to be able to make it available for you, soon.
The people of Saint-Véran are very enthusiastic about the project and love the idea of sharing their beautiful sky with the rest of the world.
 The People Behind Stargazers
 Our Partners
 Stargazers App plans
 Why Kickstarter?
Kickstarter is a way to raise capital through donations. Through Kickstarter, we won’t lose company control as we might through investors. Kickstarter donors will help us complete our minimum requirements before we launch the Stargazers App. Funds will help us complete both iOS and Android applications for tablets and our first telescope site.  
We’ve already started or completed parts of our Stargazer.Space project. We will offer ten observation sites worldwide. Each takes time to get local authorizations, so we have lined up these sites already. As a result, we know we have the best possible sites for very dark skies for the highest quality of astronomical viewing.  
Each site requires individualized testing and modification of both software and hardware. We are working to ensure that each site will respond to specific weather and power challenges.  
The core R&D parts of our project are completed. Our next goal is to create infrastructure and the tools that you, our supporter, needs. We wrote software for iOS first, but we expect make it available for Android, as well. To achieve this, we must port the software to Android devices.  
Our back-office uses Microsoft Azure as the backbone of the infrastructure. All our databases, websites, web services, and application logging will be seamlessly hosted on Azure.  
We already have the telescopes, cameras, and supporting hardware. All we need for this part of the project are a 32 sqft (3m2) dome and solar panels.  
Thanks to your support, our first site will be ready to take you to the stars. Future sites are ready to be completed and added to our system as our funding continues.
What Happens with Any Extra Contributions?  
Our initial campaign will complete our first installations in Australia and France. The complete Stargazers App project will host ten telescopes installed across the world. It is the minimum infrastructure that will allow anyone, anywhere, access to the whole sky surrounding the earth at any time... as promised!  
We want ten telescopes not only for complete sky viewing but to keep as many telescopes up and functioning despite locally bad weather or maintenance. We also want to ensure that there are enough telescopes for every subscriber to have convenient steering sessions. Eventually, we plan to add extra telescopes to each site.  
Each site costs between $80,000 and $140,000. Extra contributions will help us bring our dream to fruition that much sooner.

The rewards:

***Même si l'objectif de base est atteint, nous vous remercions de continuer à contribuer pour nous aider à payer les frais de déplacements et les frais connexes à la promotion de notre projet. Merci tout le monde! On aura pas besoin de vendre nos autos!!! Youpi! ****
L’équipe fait danser des entrepreneurs, des artistes, des employés dans leur lieu de travail. Une équipe de chorégraphes, producteurs-vidéos en danse (le collectif Flamant) et deux amoureuses de la région, Maude Lecours et Marie-Claude Lord tournent une première vidéo qui présente des gens d’ici dans trois villes différentes : Frelighsburg, Dunham et Cowansville. La vidéo utilise la danse pour rassembler le monde autour du simple fait d’être heureux en région dans le rayonnement de ce que nous sommes avec nos idées, talents et ressources. Amos J. a tout de suite accepté l’invitation de Maude et Marie-Claude pour créer la chanson Dance! qui accompagnera la vidéo. Lumière sur ceux et celles qui contribuent de leur tête, de leurs mains, de leur coeur, à la beauté d’ici.
Maude Lecours :   Professeur de danse et de yoga, elle crée des moments pour relier les gens en toute simplicité dans l’exploration de la spontanéité et du lâcher-prise. Auteure de plusieurs événements éphémères artistiques, elle poursuit sa mission de faire danser ceux qui l’entourent avec le projet Faire danser un village.
Marie-Claude Lord: Artiste en arts visuels et professeur de yoga, Marie-Claude croit grandement au pouvoir du tissu social en créant des événements rassembleurs autour de l’art en général ou autour de levées de fonds pour venir en aide aux gens de sa communauté. Elle rêve du projet « Faire danser un village » depuis qu’elle s’est établie ici en 2005.
Amos J.: auteur-compositeur-interprète, qui habite la région, a participé à l’émission La Voix en 2017. Depuis, il poursuit ses projets personnels en se laissant guider par son intuition. Il s’implique avec générosité dans tout processus de création en harmonie avec ses valeurs. La chanson Dance ! a été créé dans cet élan naturel pour nous aider à réaliser notre rêve de faire danser la communauté.
Fondé en 2016, Flamant se spécialise dans la réalisation d’oeuvres originales explorant le mouvement. Initié par Maude Lecours, Vickie Grondin et Carl Beauchemin, ce sont maintenant ces deux derniers qui assurent les activités du collectif. Sortir la danse de sa forme académique et des salles de spectacles pour la rendre vivante dans des lieux atypiques. C’est pourquoi ils ont eu envie de contribuer à l’esthétisme du projet et en faire ressortir toute son essence. Pour un aperçu de leur magnifique travail : https://vimeo.com/193435897
Merci de votre soutien!!!

I completed this portrait of Donald Trump - one of the largest I've ever painted - shortly before the presidential election.  I really didn't think he would win.  Since painting it, it has exhibited only once.  It has mostly remained hidden, save for the many times that I've posted the image online; via Instagram or Facebook, but most often directly to Donald Trump's own Twitter page.  I think it only appropriate that it be shipped directly to the White House for Trump and his wonderful staff to marvel at daily.  I cannot afford the shipping costs by myself - it measures 36"x48" and is made of heavy wood paneling.  It weighs approximately 25 pounds.  I also plan to insure the painting and ship it using the USPS Register mail system - the very shipping method that was used to move the famous Hope Diamond so securely.  I thank you very much for taking the time to check out my Kickstarter, and I hope that you will be a part of this project.

Firsthand Weather has seen growth unlike anything we have ever experienced in the history of the site. By putting out accurate forecasts, we have been able to exponentially grow our audience, and while that is definitely not a bad thing, our costs have gone up as a result. Our goal is to raise enough money to fund an app and also allow for a bigger audience by upgrading our hosting plan. The goal is to do a larger fundraiser later this year, but right now, we need to raise at least $500 to kickstart our project. We need to cover some initial costs before we can fully dive into our bigger projects later in the year. 
Our goal has always been to keep Firsthand Weather free. We desire for our site to grow and to offer other services and mobile applications at no cost to you. Our main objective is to get our forecasts out to more people and improve the Firsthand Weather experience by providing accurate and quality forecasts.  
The first $500 will be used to upgrade our hosting, and any money in addition to what is raised will be put towards developing an app for iPhone and Android devices. Also, money will go towards improving the Firsthand Weather website and introducing new services that are currently not available. 
We believe that if enough people come together, we can make this happen!! We're not asking for $500 a person donations, but simply are asking for small donations generally between $1 and $5. If you're able to help us out more, then great, but if we have many people contributing just a little, that can make a bigger impact!

The maternity golf clothes line chip shot is the most commonly used chip shot in the game of golf – while the technique is not fancy, this shot is generally a smart play and gets the job done.
Who I Am
I’m a busy working mom from Minneapolis, MN who loves to play golf. When I was pregnant with my daughter, Scarlett, in 2012, I realized that maternity golf clothes designed to be worn on the course simply did not exist! When several of my golfing friends – also currently in the “breeding phase of life” – complained about the same issue, I decided to solve the problem. I’m asking for your help in funding this Kickstarter project to help produce the first line of maternity active wear designed exclusively for golf.
Where I Am Today
I have spent the last several months designing and refining the initial Maternity golf collection, which consists of a golf skort and a short-sleeved golf shirt. The clothing is designed to address strict dress rules while being comfortable, so players can focus on their game, not adjusting their clothing after each swing.
The golf shirt is designed to be form fitting and will be made of athletic clothing that stretches to accommodate a growing belly. Since you won't want to tuck the shirt into a bottom with a belly support band, the bottom is designed to be worn on the outside.
The golf skort has a comfortable inseam with built-in shorts and pockets to hold scorecards and tees. Best yet, the skort stays in place when you swing due to the built-in belly band. The belly band is designed to fold over, which means the skort can also be worn post pregnancy.
Where You Come In
I am looking for at least $5,000 to fund:
Completion of the design work, including physical samples and final patterns in multiple sizes;
Creation of Shopify website, including photography, where the line will be exclusively sold; and
Initial manufacturing of a small order of product to “get the golf ball rolling”
In return for your support you will receive recognition on our to-be-created website or other items, such as first-run production of Maternity Golf Clothes Line clothing, an invitation to our launch party or a round of golf at the famed Minikahda Club in Minneapolis, MN.
Funds raised above the target amount will be used towards adding additional products. When you donate to my campaign, don't be afraid to let the big dog eat!

Hunnyball™ is a new game. We think it could be a great one. But like all games, its only as good as its players. And we want you to be one. Pre-order now, get the best deal we can offer, and help us make this game real.

The Game
If you're like us, you love beach games, and you've played most of them - traditional sports, like volleyball, and familiar favorites, like Spikeball and Crossnet, to name a few. Hunnyball is similar - the goal is to make a ball hit the ground, and it makes you happy when you do. It's the quick reactions, the difficulty, the crazy plays, and the competition that keep you coming back. Hunnyball has all that. Turns out a ball, a board, and a fear of losing are all you need to make some highlights. What makes Hunnyball different is the creativity that comes from passing/defense. It feels like a sport you can study. Every time we play, we learn something new - cut to drag a defender out of position; if they follow, shoot into the empty space; if they hold, pass for an easier shot. On defense, let them pass backwards, but never forwards. And it only gets more interesting when you add more players or boards. It's easy to have fun, and fun to get better. 

Our Goal and Promise
Our goal is simple...
We want to bring some fun into the world. And games give us all one more reason to get together with friends and family to enjoy the present. Hunnyball is not the first game we've thought of, but it is the first game that we truly believe is worth sharing.

Our promise is also simple...
If you help us reach our goal, we will get this product to you. There are no more open questions. No more blockers. We've done the prototyping, finished the design, and found the suppliers. All we need is your support, and you will have helped our family reach our life-long goal of creating something together. For that, keeping our promise is the least we could do. 

The Team
I'm Kevin Halliday, pictured above with my younger (and shorter) brother Nick, next to our best looking prototype. We began working on Hunnyball back in the summer of 2019, with our older brother Zach, and father Jim. We used to play different variations of Hunnyball growing up - using a football against a rebounder, juggling a soccer ball against a wall, or playing with lacrosse sticks, a lacrosse ball, and a lax wall. Some versions were not great, some were fun, the one we have now is the best. Just after graduating college, Nick decided to turn that childhood hobby into an adult one. Below you can see our favorite family member Hunny, who the game is named after, reffing an early youngest vs oldest game.

Our Timeline 
The Rules
Teams  
Split yourselves up into two teams of two.
Serving  
Pick a player. Have them take a shot from the outfield boundary, aiming for the center board. If they hit it, they serve first. If they miss it, the other team serves first.
The server stands in the middle of the field. The team serving is on offense to start; the other team is on defense. When both teams are ready, the server throws the ball at the board, starting the rally.
Rally  
A rally begins with the server's throw. A throw must hit the board, and can result in one of the following:
The rally goes on.  
The ball hits the board, and is caught by team on defense. The team on defense is now on offense, and vice versa.
 The rally ends.  
The ball misses the board.
The ball hits the board, and lands out of bounds.
The ball hits the board, and lands in bounds.
Offense  
A team is on offense when they are serving, or when they catch the ball after the opposing team's shot. A shot is any throw made by an offensive player with the intent to hit the board. A pass is any throw intended for one's teammate. The offensive team is allowed two passes, before having to take a shot.
After completing a catch, the offensive player with the ball may not take any steps. They may, however, take steps while completing a catch. They may also move around a single pivot foot. A single step is allowed if stepping into a shot or pass. They may also step into a jump shot or pass, as long as they complete the throw before landing.
The official rule is that you can only hold the ball for a max of 5 seconds. After 5 seconds, the player with  the ball must shoot from where they stand. If you're playing seriously,  we recommend you enforce this rule. If not, feel free to ignore it.
Defense  
A team is on defense when the opposing team is on offense. The defense may knock down any pass the offense tries to make. This ends the rally. The defense may not block any clear shots made by the offense. If it is not clear whether a blocked throw was a pass or shot, redo the point. If an offensive player wants to make it clear they are going to shoot, rather than pass, they can say "shot" out loud. After a player announces their shot, the offense can no longer pass, and the defense can no longer block. After a shot, the defense must catch the ball before it lands in bounds.
Scoring  
You can only score when it is your serve. This makes changes of possession important. A change of possession refers to a switch of the team that's serving.
The result of a rally depends on how it ends:
The ball misses the board.  
 Serving team's shot - change of possession.
 Other team's shot - point for the serving team.
The ball hits the board, and lands out of bounds.  
 Serving team's shot - change of possession.
 Other team's shot - point for the serving team.
The ball hits the board, and lands in bounds.  
 Serving team's shot - point for the serving team.
 Other team's shot - change of possession.
The defense knocks down an offensive pass.  
 Serving team's pass - change of possession.
 Other team's pass - point for the serving team.
The defense blocks an offensive shot.  
If the block was unintentional, or if it was not clear if the throw was a shot or a pass, the rally should be restarted. If the block was intentional, or if the thrower had announced their shot:
 Serving team's shot - point for the serving team.
 Other team's shot - change of possession.
Games are played to 11, win by 2.

For Consideration  
You may find you prefer rally scoring (in which a point is scored after each rally, regardless of serve). If you do choose rally scoring, consider playing games to 21.
Try playing three on three, or four on four. If you do increase the team size, try moving the outfield boundary.
If you are cool enough to have two Hunnyball sets, try playing with two boards - one facing the other. Join the two boundaries at the end of the sidelines. Both teams can use either board to score.
Note: We created these rules based on our favorite way to play Hunnyball.  Feel free to follow them exactly, or adjust them. Play however you like. That said, our goal is to eventually have tournaments, and at those tournaments our rules will reign supreme. Everyone knows you always play house rules.
