Mari Meade Dance Collective/ MMDC is a NYC based contemporary dance company that creates vibrant communities on and off stage. 
From Mari:
We have been working on this new piece since the summer of 2018. The spring prior, I decided to focus on telling a story about the journey of two sisters following the death of their mother. We've been lucky enough to have the opportunity to explore this idea over the past year, particularly through summer rehearsals at City University of New York (CUNY) Dance Initiative (CDI) at York College and a residency at University of North Carolina School of the Arts (UNCSA). During that time we had ample rehearsal space to begin building experimental creatures the sisters may encounter along their journey - like a three headed spitting monster. (Yes, gross, but also pretty cool.) I also researched outside of the studio and spent the rest of the summer sketching potential inspiration, character development, and sets; reading epic journey (or Nostos) novels; and researching The Hero's Journey through the lens of Joesph Campbell and others. Art Director Marc Witmer has also been collaborating with me for months, creating initial sketches, attending inspiring exhibits in New York, and working to create a world fitting for the sister's journey. This piece, like much of our work, includes text and acting, as well as dance that is highly physical and rhythmic in nature. With the help of dramaturges and theatre experts Melissa Gawlowski, Ben Yannette, and Maia Alexander, MMDC is hoping to bring the script, physical theatre, and movement together in an unprecedented manner.
We are currently still in process. We are constantly writing and rewriting, creating and recreating, sketching and erasing. Through these layers of building, we hope to create an epic world- both earthly and supernatural, about love and loss, relationships both personal and professional - with exaggerated characters that elicit a physical reaction from our audience- a gasp, a laugh, or simply a lean forward in your seat. This piece is a reflection of our own paths through the medium we love (dance), in that magical place we call home (the theatre), with our NYC family (MMDC). We invite you to take the leap of faith from the audience chair, and become a participant by directly supporting MMDC and our newest work through your generous donation.
This work (yes, still currently untitled...if you donate the whole $3375 you get naming rights, how about that?) premieres as part of Triskelion Art's 2019 Spring Season. June 6th, 7th, and 8th. This will be our second evening length work, and our third season being presented by Triskelion Arts. 
A bit more about Mari Meade Dance Collective / MMDC:
Since its inception, MMDC has presented works through the Kenan Fellowship at Clark Theatre at Lincoln Center; Dance:Access at Danspace St. Mark’s Church; STUFFED at Judson Memorial Church; Battery Dance Festival; Chez Bushwick AIR’s at CPR; FLICfest; Westfest at Westbeth; Splitbill at Dixon Place; Comedy in Dance Festival at Triskelion Arts; Wired Arts Fest; First Look at Brooklyn Ballet; Hatch Performance Series at The Works; and the CHIN Project at the 92nd Street Y. National and international performances include the New Orleans Fringe Festival (LA); Asheville Fringe Festival (NC); REVERBdance Festival (Boston, MA); Katlehong Arts Center (South Africa); and Lake Studios Berlin (Germany).

Hello, my name is Amy Manson and I have been a potter for 12 years. I have lived in Leesburg, Virginia for 9 years and have outgrown my home pottery studio. I am raising funds to move to shared retail/studio space where I will continue to make my ceramic works of art, sell my work, and instruct others in the love and art of clay.
Here's my story:
My passion is working with clay - a soft malleable substance - throwing, forming, and urging it into an object of both beauty and function. An object, which can be admired, touched, held, and used in daily life. This process and transformation of the soft clay into a hard and beautiful object meant to be seen, used, passed along, maybe even eventually broken and given back to the earth seems to mirror personal growth and transformation. I use mid-range fired stoneware and porcelain in my work and enjoy glaze colors and themes, which can be found in nature. I try to incorporate a combination of family, prayer, meditation, nature, and the creation of pottery into every single day of my life as part of my own personal growth and transformation. It gives me great insight and joy to create a one of a kind piece of artwork. I hope others enjoy viewing and utilizing the pottery as much as I enjoyed making it!
  I am an avid cook and have been experimenting the past few year with various forms of bake-ware, serving pieces, and other items that enhance the culinary experience. I have been making pieces to become part of your daily life as well as pieces that become part of your traditions and celebrations! I look forward to sharing my latest functional and decorative creations with you.   
I have been a studio potter for 12 years and display and sell my work in various galleries in South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. I have taught most recently at The Cooley Gallery in Leesburg  and create my work (and recipes) at my home studio in Leesburg, Virginia. To learn more about my work please visit my website:  Http://www.amymansonpottery.com
A little more about me: 
I sell my pottery to an established Loudoun county clientele and online throughout the Country. I regularly work on commission pottery pieces as well as wholesale orders. I have been teaching adult and children’s programming in Loudoun County for 9 years and previously in Charlotte, NC. I have worked to become a highly respected artist and instructor in the community. I have a large patronage and sell pottery in all sections of the county, from wineries and vineyards, to galleries, art shows, fairs and direct sales. Over the years I have also also built a loyal and amazingly talented following of students who have returned again and again, for continued instruction. I have been fortunate to have been featured in local newspapers and magazines, as well as regional and statewide publications. I am also a mom of two amazing daughters, a wife to a very patient fellow, and pack leader to a 12 year old golden retriever, and a 7 year old Husky/Shepard mix. 
Here's the plan:
I have outgrown my home studio and am moving to a shared studio space in central Leesburg. I will be making this space my personal studio, and teaching space.  I realized about a year ago, I simply cannot add more hours to my days, so I need to work smarter. I want to consolidate my business into one location! 
I have been a contract teacher for several community art schools in the area. I have cherished my time at these studios, but spend a lot of time on the road from one to another, back and forth to unload the kilns, etc. Again, in hopes of consolidating the different aspects of my business into one space, I am excited to pursue my own studio.
This studio will be a destination studio and teaching space. It will be a great place to find a one of a kind piece of pottery, Jewelry, and art in the gallery space. As a working art studio, visitors will be able to view art being made daily. Adult and children’s ceramics and art education will be a major emphasis. In addition, The Studio will be a destination on The Western Loudoun Artists Studio Tour and on the Loudoun Artisan Trail. The studio will provide small intimate classes, professional instruction, and kiln firing services. It will be a active community art environment that will encourage tourism, online sales, drop in traffic and custom order pick up. Classes and instruction will be provided on an ongoing weekly schedule, as well as 1-time events, and private summer instruction for children 
I am crowd funding through KickStarter as a "Pre-sale" of some of my top selling items. The Pre-sale will help with the start up costs of the studio: Shelving, Tables, Kiln installation, and new equipment.
Thank you for your time and interest, Please drop by to say hello and see the new digs if you are in the area!!

About 10 years ago, McKinsey and Company, through its Minneapolis office, began working closely with several prominent leaders to identify opportunities to positively impact economic growth.  It, through one of its directors, was instrumental in establishing The Itasca Project "an employer-led civic alliance whose members are drawn together by an interest in new and better ways to address regional issues that impact economic competitiveness and quality of life in the Minneapolis-St. Paul region. Its 50-plus participants are primarily private-sector CEOs. The group also includes a number of public and nonprofit leaders, including the governor of Minnesota, the mayors of Minneapolis and St. Paul, the chair of the Metropolitan Council, the leaders of the University of Minnesota and MNSCU and leaders of major foundations."  McKinsey and Company provided staff support to the Itasca Project, and the Itasca Project's previous executive director was on loan from McKinsey and Company.
At least two present Minnesota State Colleges and Universities (MNSCU) Trustees were affiliated with the Itasca Project prior to appointment to the MNSCU Board.  Secondary Education in Minnesota was clearly on The Itasca Project's radar:
"In 2011, the Itasca Project launched a task force to identify strategies for higher education in Minnesota to drive long-term, sustainable economic growth and prosperity. The work is being led by a team of 12 leaders from business, nonprofit, and higher education institutions. An advisory group of 40 business and community leaders provided input and guidance. With the help of this group, we completed a Higher Ed Strategy for Minnesota then launched three resulting initiatives: Workforce Alignment (ensuring we have the skilled workers we need to meet the future economic needs), Collaboration (developing collaborations within higher education to optimize system-wide assets and efficiency) and Research & Innovation (establish partnerships to foster and strengthen an ecosystem of research and innovation). Read: Higher Education Partnerships for Prosperity. "
Much of the research was provided by McKinsey and Company.
Incidentally, in a 2010 presentation to the National Governor's Association, McKinsey provided a presentation which revealed that significant projects were underway to overhaul secondary education in several states, including Minnesota.  The problem?  Too many employers had positions which remained unfilled due to 'skills gaps'.  The cause?  The longstanding independence of higher education led too many people into a liberal arts education.  The solution?  Tying higher education funding to fulfilling industry needs and shifting funding away from the liberal arts into industrial skills.
Chancellor Rosenstone became MNSCU Chancellor in 2011 and immediately began the process of "Charting the Future".  This process utilized nearly all of the same McKinsey and Company research which was previously provided to The Itasca Project.  Unsurprisingly, the Charting the Future report and the Higher Education Partnerships for Prosperity documents are essentially interchangeable.  
The draft Charting the Future report was presented in 2013, precisely when South Central College, Mankato and Faribault MN was in the search process for a new president.  A national headhunting firm with significant McKinsey connections found Dr. Anette Parker, whose previous employment was with AMTEC, a consortium of American Automotive Manufactures and the Tennessee Community and Technical College System.  Nearly simultaneously with Dr. Parker's appointment as President of SCC, AMTEC was featured in a McKinsey publication as an example of closely aligning educational programs to the needs of industry.
Dr. Parker, upon appointment to the college, immediately removed nearly all of the prior administration and began to severely modify programs within SCC without consultation with faculty, staff, students, or the community.  Rather, she increased her budget significantly, insulated administration from faculty, removed administration who objected to the treatment of faculty, and actively intimidated, bullied, and harassed students and faculty who questioned the direction of the school and the spending habits of the administration.  'The train is leaving the station.  Get on or get left behind', she said.  The problem is, no one knows where this train is headed.
McKinsey and Company was paid $2,000,000.00 to assist in the 'implementation' of Charting the Future.  Documents received thus far strongly support the suggestion that Charting the Future is being implemented on a small scale at South Central College prior to it being spread system-wide.
We are here seeking answers.  What will MNSCU look like when Charting the Future is implemented?  These documents exist.  
We are obtaining documents pursuant to a freedom of information request, and will be reviewing these documents to determine what the justification is for the significant systemic modifications that are being imposed seemingly without how this implementation impairs students' college experience and opportunity.  We will be presenting these documents to the public for review, and will be collecting the stories of what this implementation means. We hope to provide a series of stories and supporting documentation which will enhance public discourse about the future of education in Minnesota, and ultimately, the U.S. as a whole. 
It is time for an open, honest dialogue, based upon truth, and not imposed from outsiders who seemingly know better than we ourselves what our communities need from a college that provides an 'extraordinary education'.  Please join us.

(anche in ITALIANO)
I remember the day of my last exam when I finished my journalism masters course in Italy with a dissertation on Japanese “hikikomori". After passing my exam, an examiner told me: "I suggest you don’t focus too much on Japan, it’s not a country we’ll hear about that much in the near future”. That day was March 3, 2011. A week later, on Friday 11 March 2011, the Tohoku earthquake and tsunami destroyed the north-eastern coasts of Japan, subsequently causing the meltdown of three nuclear reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi plant. Japan needed to be reported on more than before and since then I have continued/I have never stopped reporting from the area.
Otsuchi, Japan
And today?
THE PROJECT
In 2016, Japan will commemorate the 5th anniversary of the 3.11 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami. Damage to the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Fukushima caused a nuclear crisis that Japan is still struggling with. After an initial rush to clean and rebuild the most affected areas, the process slowed down last year when many problems emerged. Among them was disinformation about the nuclear risk and its consequences, by both the government and local media, as well as the significant number of refugees still living in temporary shelters, mostly consisting of shipping containers.
Traveling from Tokyo to the northeastern part of Japan the project will focus on the coastal life 5 years after the quake, on the rebuilding process and on the measures taken to prevent further tsunamis. Also, it will cover the issue of radioactive waste management and reprocessing. The project aim at observing the challenges and difficulties that local communities are facing while trying to live with the fear of radioactivity in those affected territories. The goal is to analyze the reconstruction process of villages obliterated by the tsunami, comparing the current situation with the Japanese government's initial promises of a return to normality.
Aizu Wakamatsu, Fukushima

What is Cue?
Cue is a collaborative dance project, which will premiere as an evening length performance this May. Working with musician Ryan Hommel, Claire Maurey, the founder of The Movery, and fellow dancers have choreographed an arrangement of movement compositions, which along with improvisation create Cue. The dancers will perform on their own individual stages, measuring four by four feet.The choreographed movement is broken into sections, each with a unifying feeling and theme. In between these sections the dancers will improvise movement exploring the comforts of home. The sections thus become a task, similar to everyday tasks like work, which take us away from our home. 
The project will be performed in three different locations around the Pioneer Valley, in Massachusetts. The first performance will be at our resident theater at East Street Dance Center, in Hadley, on May 8th at 8:00 PM. Our second performance is at the Sun Studio, in Florence, on May 9th at 8:00 PM and lastly, on May 17th the show will be performed outside in Northampton at 5:00 PM.
Why fund this project?
As a choreographer I am thrilled to be working collaboratively with a number of different artist. All of the artists I am working with have donated their time, craft and creativity to the project. In order to sustain our work as artists and collaborators we have to find ways to make and raise money.
In order to fulfill our vision for the piece we would also like to raise money for costumes, lighting, curtains, flowers, a photographer, chairs, theater space and future shows!
Who collaborated in creating Cue?
Claire Maurey is the choreographer and founder of The Movery. Claire is a Mainer who loves to move and be outdoors. She trained at the National Ballet School, in Toronto, and then went on to dance with the National Ballet of Canada and the Leipzig Ballet. Leaving the profession, Claire decided to pursue life beyond ballet. Through farming and baking she's found her way back to dance. Having found a home in the Pioneer Valley Claire has found her passion for dance revived. She now teaches ballet and contemporary dance at East Street Ballet. 
Ryan Hommel is a musical staple in the Pioneer Valley. Whether it’s playing with jazz/fusion heavyweights like Alan Evans (Soulive) and Beau Sasser (Alan Evans Trio) at Bishop’s Lounge, or at The Iron Horse or The Parlor Room with world-class singer/songwriters and bands such as The Sweetback Sisters, Heather Maloney, Seth Glier and Stephen Kellogg; Ryan continues to create with some of the greatest success stories to come out of the Western Mass music scene.
The dancers of The Movery:
Stacey Funston is from Eastham, MA, and has been living in the Valley for 6 years. She graduated from Mt. Holyoke College where she studied Dance, English, and African Studies. She currently works in the Holyoke Public Schools providing after school programs to high school students.
Katelyn Tsukada grew up in the Catskills of upstate New York and is a recent graduate of Bucknell University. While in college, Katelyn studied Environmental Studies while dancing and choreographing with the Bucknell Dance Company. She moved to Northampton in August 2012 and currently works for an environmental nonprofit called the Center for EcoTechnology (CET) in Florence.
Corinne Morgan grew up in Richmond, VA and studied at the School of Richmond Ballet. She recently graduated from Mount Holyoke College with a BA in dance and biology, in addition to having studied at Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance. Corinne currently works at the Massachusetts Academy of Ballet as an administrator and tours as a magician's assistant.  
Jessica Daly grew up in North Brookfield, Massachusetts, and moved to Western Massachusetts to study Psychology at UMass Amherst. Since graduating, she has stayed in the Valley and enjoys her work as a coordinator of after-school programs within the Holyoke Public Schools. Jess took her first dance class at the age of two and though she no longer sports a tutu on a regular basis, Dance has continued to be an important part of her life since that time.
Cassie Ferreira trained at Keene State College in New Hampshire where she earned a BA in dance and theater. At Keene she worked with choreographers and modern companies that included Robert Battle, Shawn Currin and Axis Dance Company. For the past 9 years she has taught ballet and modern at Pioneer Valley Ballet and has performed in their seasonal ballets.
Uma Shannon began dancing at East Street Ballet in the fall of 2009 at the age of 13.  She has studied ballet, character, modern, contemporary, and flamenco. Uma has trained with Irina Vakhromeeva, Andre Reyes, Claire Maurey, Tai Jimenez, Tekla Kostek, Onalie Arts and Ines Arrubla among others. When not dancing, Uma loves to study Russian language, science, piano, and pottery.  
Scenic Designer: Reilly Horan
Reilly graduated from Amherst College last spring as an English and Theater & Dance double-major. She currently works at Amherst as the Graduate Assistant in the Theater & Dance department, collaborating with and supporting senior majors on their thesis projects as a scenic designer. She has enjoyed collaborating with artists in the greater Pioneer Valley as a lighting and scenic designer for the past two years, and is grateful for this opportunity to work with Claire and and The Movery for the first time.
Videographer: Trey McCain
Supported in part by East Street Ballet and The Northampton Arts Council
Thank you Northampton Arts Council for funding Cue with the $320 grant which allowed Reilly to build the stages.

A modular speaker, with a party mood, synchronized lights, and several addons, for every time of the day!
One speaker several configurations! change your light with an easy plug and play with USB addons.
Bluetooth speakers and disco balls are generally used to create a party mood. However, the music and lights are always out of sync, the disco ball simply emits the same light patterns around the room. Of course, there is an option of creating a light show using DMX-controlled lighting, but such a system is costly, fixed to a room, and overly complex.
To enjoy a party at home, some people resorted to using Bluetooth speakers and then manually moving the disco balls to enhance the mood.

We wanted to solve this problem by combining existing technology to create a speaker built to get the party started.


AI Robotic Arm 
The robot arm interprets audio input in real-time to generate movements based on rhythm and beat. This creates dynamic movements of the disco ball.

Mic Sense
The MicSense disco light increases variations and randomizations of the light pattern, further enhancing the mood as the disco ball moves

Portable
Partier is portable, so you can bring your party anywhere you want. Audio input is easy with any Bluetooth-enabled smartphone, so you can listen to your favorite tunes wherever you are.

USB Head
The standard disco ball attaches to the robot arm via a USB port. The port can also power modular add-on. This opens up countless possibilities for users to customize their speakers with other USB modules.


Partier interprets Bluetooth audio input from on the fly to move the robot arm to the rhythm and beat of the music that the speaker plays. The speaker analyzes the audio input and uses a special algorithm to move its robot arm.
The arm has a movement range of 270° vertically and 360° horizontally. As the arm dances to the music, the light from the disco ball dances in the surroundings to create dynamic lighting and mood.
The disco ball uses MicSense technology with a built-in microphone that detects surrounding sounds and changes its light pattern based on sound input. This gives the lighting effect of the dancing speaker an additional dimension, making it more dynamic and further enhancing the mood.
This effect is particularly pronounced when listening to slower music. A standard disco ball would generate light that blinks to a repetitive pattern, thus causing the light to feel disjointed when the beat slows down. The use of the MicSense disco light makes slow music more enjoyable.

The dancing speaker is portable. It has a battery life of 10 hours on a full charge and speaker mode, more than enough juice to keep the party going. The speaker uses Bluetooth 4.2 connectivity, allowing it to have high audio quality and play audio from it over a longer distance. Move around the party while playing music from your phone in your pocket!
The robot arm takes on modular accessories via a USB port. The default accessory is the disco ball. We chose to use a USB port so that our users can unleash their creativity and extend the speaker with other USB accessories.
Besides the disco ball, we are developing three other modular lights: Mood Light, Star Light, and Flame Light. We would love to hear what interesting ideas you have! We have seen concepts for a mosquito repellent module, fan module and other novel ideas.
Mood Light
With the Mood Light module, Partier gives a gentle ambient light that is perfect for relaxing. The light comes with a steady mode, and a pulse mode where cycles through four colors with a slow, calming pulse.

  The cozy mood light makes a good companion for kids, especially those that are afraid of the dark. Play a lullaby or a bedtime story with Partier and watch them drift off to dreamland under the soothing mood light.

 Adults love the mood light too. They are ideal for relaxing. The mood light also creates a romantic ambiance when you want to slow down and get intimate with the special someone.
 Star Light 
Put the Starlight module on Partier and turn your kid’s room into a starry sky. Fuel their imagination and generate hours of fun playing under the stars. Camp under the stars in their bedroom. Or become a space pirate surfing through the galaxy. With the Star Mood, imagination is the limit. And kids have unlimited imagination.

 Go a step further and play songs to further enhance the mood. Fancy being under the stars with Star Wars tunes playing in the background? Of course, the Star Mood also works well with lullabies or bedtime stories.
Flame Light
We take the mood light a step further with the Flame Light module. The light imitates the look of fire for that extra coziness and romantic mood. The flame flickers and dances like a real flame to help you relax with your favorite tunes.
Enjoy the comfort of a flame light without the dangers of a fire hazard.

The dancing speaker has LED lights all around the speaker's body that lights up based on the music. This further enhances the lighting effect and boosts the mood at a party, create a romantic ambiance if you want, and most importantly, use it wherever you are.



PLAY




Why we need your support
We have finished the development of the dancing speaker and we are excited to get it into the market to you. However, as a small startup, we cannot bring this product to life without your support. We need to raise funds for raw materials and components needed to start mass production of the dancing speaker.

 About Partier by RNS
RNS Co. Ltd. was established in 2018, with the philosophy of bringing smiles and laughter to people by making the most fun and enjoyable products in the world. By innovating existing products with user ideas and feedback, we are always trying to reflect users' needs and make our products more functional and suitable to the current environment. The uniqueness of ‘Partier’ is making a great hit in the Bluetooth audio market. We are an international team of professionals from South Korea, Singapore, and Italy, with expertise in entrepreneurship, electrical engineering, and creative marketing. Months of hard work by the team shaped Partier into what we see today.

A dramatic crime series based on the real life events of Michael Gambino and his experiences growing up in Las Vegas. Michael was born and raised in Las Vegas; his childhood was filled with great times but also experienced some traumatic events because of his fathers’ history of working with the Italian Mafia. Although Michael had limited contact with these individuals, his childhood experiences gave him insight on what would eventually become his reality, running a crew of under age kids that operated the most successful ring of illegal activities for approximately 6 years. These activities began with the production of fake id’s for his high school friends which ultimately turned into his crew and slowly grew into a nationwide operation that developed into much more than what had ever been intended. After several years of drug running, illegal nightclub operations, international travel, credit card fraud, and wild nights with exotic dancers, they received pressure from local and federal law enforcement, Michael and his crew was able to make a clean exit and conform, somewhat to society. These stories closely represent the actual events that took place during their time.

Hello my name is Louise Thomas I am an artist living and working in Berlin. This Autumn I have been invited to spend three months painting in the historic Porthmeor studios in St Ives. Cornwall. To make the most of this opportunity I have launched this Kickstarter campaign to support me whilst in Cornwall.
Whilst the goal has been reached additional funds will be used to frame and prepare works for exhibition.
 thankyou for your support!
Studios where I will work this autumn
The reason why it is important for me to spend time in St Ives this autumn is to bring to creation a series of paintings 'Magic Metals and Megaliths'. The project involves walking ancient footpaths and routes of pilgrimage around the peninsula seeking out sea tales, tin mines, wreck sites, scared wells and megaliths. I will for the first month be drawing and painting outside directly from the landscape. I will use historical documents alongside myths and (fictitious) Cornish tales to create the new works. Working with the method that I have developed over many years, I will collect and collage primary research to produce scenes of magical realism that I will then paint.
 
The kick starter works in that when people invest in the project by pledging money I will send them an original art work or a print from St Ives.
All colours run down, Berlin, 2015
Journey to the stones 2015
broken faberge, berlin, 2015
Berlin 2015
Portheras cove, watercolour on paper, 2009
Autumn in Cornwall holds great appeal for me since most tourists will have left and the coastal weather will be at its most dramatic, potentially making for excellent painting atmosphere!
I am looking to raise at least 2500 euros to contribute to the purchase of travel tickets, art materials and transportation of works.
I have included a variety of rewards so you can pledge as little or as much as you like. Every reward will be unique to my time in St Ives. These paintings and prints are limited to the duration of the campaign. I have included special rewards for those patrons able to visit me in St Ives, I hope you can join me on the adventure!
My studio in Berlin 2015

There's no doubt that Morris Offspring is a massive part of the lives of those involved in it. It is huge, it is unyielding, it is exhausting and it is addictive. Whether watching or dancing, it's more than a morris team, it's a furnace of emotion, creativity and power. 
Nevertheless, Morris Offspring's exhilarating, exciting, beautiful journey is almost at an end.  One final project - The Furnace - a collaboration with Faustus is underway and we passionately believe the importance of filming and documenting this last project.  
We were successful in obtaining Arts Council England funding, which has enabled a tour of UK venues for these two innovative groups. This Kickstarter project is about making the most of that funding and ensuring that the legacy it creates is maximised. 
A reoccurring issue for morris dancers is negative public attitude towards morris, something often reinforced by the media! Then again, how can the media know to portray it otherwise if evidence is not regularly provided? Much of the media has a set idea of morris dance, and while true in places, it is not the only shape of it and we would like Morris Offspring's legacy to counter that image. 
My Kickstarter project allows us to professionally film The Furnace and create a series of 2-3 mini-films that capture the spirit of Offspring ‘behind the scenes’: an insight into our methods, approach and personalities. 
I am particularly proud of the quality of artwork and photography associated with Offspring and would like to find a way to exhibit this. If we manage to exceed the target, then we can build on the publicity surrounding the project, and also create a permanent online exhibition of photos and film. 
Over the last ten years with masses of support from team members past and present, friends and family, Morris Offspring have made some remarkable achievements. 
From the very first performance, Flame, commissioned by Sidmouth International Festival for which Laurel gathered 12 dancers and enlisted Chris Wood & The English Acoustic Collective in 2003 - to 2004's repeat performance with an emerging Spiers and Boden. On English Ground was to 2006's 10-day tour of UK Arts Centres and appearance on the BBC2 Culture Show - not to mention a standing ovation for the appearance at Cropredy with the Morris On band. Amazing times. After a second show, Rising, there was a period of downtime while seemingly everyone had children then the team reemerged with a completely new line up of young dancers for 2011's colossal Arts Council England and PRSF funded spectacular event, Must Come Down bringing 36 young morris dancers from England, America and Canada together with musicians including Jackie Oates and storyteller Debs Newbold. The performance had that same electrifying vibe that the first show back in 2003 had - but for a whole new set of dancers, musicians and audience. The dancers decided to reform Morris Offspring and cram as much in as possible before the return trip to the USA.  So we've written fiendish new material, we've danced to a 200-piece community choir at the South Bank and journeyed to Ulverston and Sheffield. We even taught morris to conference delegates for WWF! All of this would have been impossible without unwavering support from the English Folk Dance and Song Society (and my Mum & Dad). 
Nevertheless, the workload and the finances are unsustainable where there is no option for full-time touring and 2013 sees the final outing for Morris Offspring. Your support in helping us capture these last days on film and photo for those who were unable to see the live work will be invaluable. We are aware that not everyone in the morris world values our work, we are also aware of the huge impact we have had on others, and indeed on how many people outside 'the scene' view morris. 
If there's one thing we've learnt on this incredible journey, it's that Morris is a survivor, a true dance of the people that will never be tamed and will always bring a heady mix of joy and embarrassment wherever it goes. We hope we've struck a good balance between these two vital life forces and sincerely hope we capture the best moments of both on this one last massive trip.

So many different ways to style!
The Black and White Wool Trenchcoat; 8 Coats in 1
Soversa...So Versatile. The new premium high street womenswear clothing  brand, launching in July 2020. A brand concept that provides a unique and innovative clothing solution, through timeless, quality and modern fashion pieces that would add and compliment the customer’s current  wardrobe. A concept idea that was born over 10 years ago from the Founders London College of Fashion Graduate Collection; a concept that now feels the perfect time to launch.
The range will start with a women’s outerwear range, based on the  multi wear feature, allowing one jacket to be worn in a variety of  different ways through the use of clever pattern cutting, fastenings and  layering, in a stylish and discreet manner.
The Multifunctional Trenchcoat is the brainchild of this concept and will be the first product, made in traditional cotton twill and also wool for the launch of the Autumn/Winter Collection. 
Soversa goes against the grain and the normalities of the fashion  industry – it is not about fast fashion, throwaway trends, catwalk copies or designer labels. It is a brand that wants to be loved, worn and invested into by the customer. Styles that can be used over and over again, season after season and personalised over seasons, so it remains  a wardrobe cherished staple and go-to item.
We HATE waste. Pure and simple. In this quickly evolving world where the Climate Crisis is on all of our minds daily, it is crucial that we play a key role in ensuring our products are long lasting and good quality with minimal impact on the planet.
Did you know that many designer labels produce thousands of meters of fabric and some of it is never used so sits unused to waste whilst they produce new fabrics every season? What we do here at Soversa is we utilise excess high quality fabrics and we make our collections from them - meaning you get a fantastic high quality product made from fabrics that could have ended up in landfill polluting our planet further!
By creating a product that can be styled in 8 different ways, we are ensuring that you, the consumer can still have the luxury of different styling whilst minimising your fashion purchases and global textile waste footprint and we believe that is the future of fashion!
PLAY

Sophie is the Founder behind the brand and has over 10 years experience in the fashion industry, after studying at the renowned London College of Fashion, studying Product Design Development for the Fashion Industry, gaining a First Class BA Honours Degree.
Sophie went on to work for a range of brands on the high street and at brand level, both supplier and retail side, gaining a 360 understanding of the retail business and manufacturing industry, learning how they operate, successes and failures, all of which has led  Sophie to launch Soversa. Alongside this Sophie is a Short Courses Design Tutor at the London College of Fashion, teaching Fashion Design  and Introduction to Fashion courses out of school term time.
The brainchild of the concept started with the Trenchcoat, however we have many ideas to evolve this concept through other products in the range, not necessarily having a physical functional feature, but  every piece in the collection will be versatile.
A lot of love, care and attention has been invested into the company and with a little help, we are aiming to launch the brand to market in July 2020; the scale and collection will depend on how much we raise. 
We are passionate about our brand and concept, however to make the best  impact in the saturated and struggling fashion industry, we want to test the market and build a community of backers and supporters who can help shape the brand and collection and continue with our launch for July  2020. Kickstarter feels the perfect platform to do this.
Exclusive to Kickstarter, you can purchase a Trenchcoat before it hits the web and stores in July at a special Kickstarter discounted price. We are doing this to gain interest in the product and range, and an insight into popularity of fabrics and colours. It will also help to fund the production order to stock our website and the development of further colourways and fabrics of the Trenchcoat, as well as additional styles to launch in July.
To order your Trenchcoat, or support the brand, simply:
Click the "BACK THIS PROJECT" button.
Choose your reward and press continue.
Follow the on screen instructions and you are done!
Like the concept? Believe in the vision? Purchase. Donate. Spread the love.
Facebook. Tweet. Pin. Chat. E-mail. Good old fashioned word of mouth.
Any help for this small fish to break into the bigger wider competitive world with our vision to try and make a difference.
Please use the sizing chart to help you identify your correct size.  These have been created using industry standards, so should be true to the usual size you purchase on the high street. If however, if you wish to exchange your jacket for a different size, we will be more than happy to exchange your coat for a different size within 14 days of receipt of order.  Please contact us to arrange and send it back to us unworn and with all the brand packaging. In this instance, you will liable for the return shipping costs and reshipping of the new size.
As we are a start up and offering our coats at highly discounted prices on Kickstarter, we unfortunately won’t be able to accept returns. If you have any problems with your coat, please get in touch and we will see what we can do.
Orders within the UK will be sent with FREE SHIPPING via Collect Plus. Orders outside of the UK will be sent via Royal Mail Tracked.  Duties and taxes incurred in the country of destination are the responsibility of the customer. You may or may not be required to pay a tax to release your shipment from customs. For more information, please consult your local customs office.
Shipping costs are added on to your pledge depending on your country. All orders will be sent with a tracking number.

Right in the middle of New York's ever-energetic East Village neighborhood lies Jimmy's No 43, a craft beer pub located in a subterranean space which was once a Ukrainian supper club. Head down the hallway behind the bar and you will find the Back Room where many a play has been workshopped, comedians had their first stage experience, and playwrights see their work first come to life.
Owner Jimmy Carbone is a man with a big heart. He cares about locally grown food products, (most of the menu is locally sourced from small farmers) finely crafted beers, (Jimmy created the Good Beer Seal) and the health of the arts in his community. So much so that in 2005 and 2009, Jimmy was recipient of the title “Local Hero” from NYC Arts. Today, he serves on boards of all types, but beyond this he knows the arts need a space to workshop and grow their work. 
For the past seven years, Jimmy has worked with local arts organizations to give them space in the Back Room to grow their work and their audiences. Most of this is given as an in-kind donation, knowing the needs of the arts and their small budgets. Groups like Rising Phoenix Repertory, ESPA Primary Stages Program, id Theater have held workshops of new productions in the space. The quality of the work is tremendous, and great performers-- including Reggie Watts and Ben Walker-- have spent some time on the small stage of the Back Room. 
These committed artists deserve to have a better facility to work, and Jimmy's No 43 does not have the cash to make those improvements- especially after dealing with the loss of revenue from Sandy and the post-storm recuperation period. 
We need your help to pay for upgrades for the room: 
1) Sound System: speakers, sound board, general A/V capabilities
2) Lighting: and running more electricity to the back room to make that possible
3) Deep Clean: the room needs to be cleaned, walls painted, floors buffed and then maintained!
4) Heating and Cooling: both sides of the coin need to be improved
5) Ongoing Operating Costs: cost of electricity, managing the calendar, and other things
Truly, we cannot to this without your support!

About the Exhibit: Operation Frame
The name of the exhibit is "Operation Frame" because, quite frankly, I need frames. The market in Brazil is brutal for emerging visual artists and I almost went broke preparing and framing the paintings for my last exhibit. I simply can't do that again, so I need your help to make this exhibit break even at the very least.
I need these frames to give the exhibit a professional look. This exhibit is important because it will be in the city center of Curitiba, Brazil, close to the city's most important art fair during a busy time of year, in February - just before Carnival. 
But it's not all about the phyisical frames because each of these paintings are also snapshots in time. For me, artistically, this is an important concept because it means that we can freeze - or frame - the world to help us remember that place in that moment in time, or maybe to help us hold that dream in place for when we arrive in the future. 
So by framing these paintings, I’m not only talking about the actual frames, but our imaginations as well. If you look at a painting of bottles, where does that take you? How about one of flowers or one of Barcelona? My hope is to create an exhibit that stops time for people, and what better way to do that than to have all the paintings framed.
Barcelona Rooftops
What I'm Asking:
I am asking for your support to help with framing and other hanging supplies to make this exhibit more professional. I need help with six or seven frames, which are expensive and beyond my financial means. Without your help I will not be able to frame these or exhibit these paintings.
Una Vista de Ardales
What You Get:
What do you get out of this? Obviously the artistic rewards as a result of your pledges (from contribution recognition to reusable greeting cards to postcards from Brasil (with Brazilian stamps!) to original artwork to commissioned paintings), but it's more than that. You get the opportunity to help an emerging artist get his name out there and show his work. All too often the world asks artists of all types to work for free: Kickstarter campaigns such as this help to break those expectations and allow artists to create more freely and, to be blunt, put food on the table and pay rent.
Several of the to-be exhibited pieces are available as rewards here on Kickstarter. You can see those in this blurb. The rest will be available for purchase at the exhibit.
Study of Bottles
About Me:
These are expressionist paintings painted by me, Greg Mason Burns, and were created during my time in Curitiba, Brazil. 
I am a painter who uses bold colors to create expressive paintings. My artistic inspiration is Ernest Hemingway, thus my paintings are declarative in nature. Brazil has many contrasts in it's culture, and these have greatly influenced my emotions and, thus, my art.
I originally left my job in healthcare finance in Boston to pursue my more natural creative side. My first landing spot was in Chile (without knowing a word of Spanish), but I met a girl from Brazil and followed her there (without knowing a word of Portuguese), which is where I currently live (I can order a beer in Portuguese now). I am originally from Bar Harbor, Maine, and am a graduate of both the University of Maine and the University of Edinburgh.
My website
My Facebook Page
My Twitter Account
To sign up for e-mails - gmburns@gregmasonburns.com
Bottle with Orange
And...
Exhibits such as this are of huge importance to me, as they allow me the freedom to both pursue my creative dreams and to build my resume for future projects (see my bio for more info). I greatly appreciate your support, and let's all keep our fingers crossed for a successful campaign and exhibit.
Thanks!
Greg

Male nudity has been hiding in the dark for too long.  It is often seen as taboo and no where near as popular in modern photography as the female nude.
Google the word NUDE and you will find thousands of images of nude women but very few men. And when you do find nude men it is usually in the form of pornographic material. It is very hard to find artistic or even just non pornographic male nude images.
I'm looking to break this trend with a series of images dedicated to the male nude in all his glory. Most importantly I will not be photographing a model. This will be a real person with real emotions and real character. Shoots will take place at real locations and will not involve elaborate studio set ups. Follow me on this journey of discovery as I look to lift the veil of secrecy over male nudity and the impact it has on contemporary photography.

Hello !
My name is Camilla Isola, aka RAE, I am a London based dance artist looking for funds to create a new contemporary dance piece which will be performed on the 14th of January at Resolution 2017 at The Place in London.

Have you ever heard about Resolution?

Well, if not, Resolution is a world renowned dance platform, which gives young choreographers and companies the possibility to show their work in a triple bill night. 
For this occasion I decided to create a brand new piece, Unravel, le Bolero, in collaboration with 11 male and female dancers from Laban, The Place and Rambert. The work interrogates on what drives humans to seek for body contact, sometimes delicate others rough.
Set in a dark place, a house room, a club, a night city landscape, they dance on the notes of a contemporary version of Bolero. Unaware someone is looking, they tangle together losing control while the music and the lights gradually expose the scene.

Who is RAE Dance Collective?

Led by Camilla Isola, RAE Dance Collective is a young dance group which members change depending on the project undertaken. For the creation of Unravel, le Bolero, RAE will be working with 11 dancers from Laban, The Place and Rambert.

Meet them:
GIULIA AVINO
Italian artist, Giulia, 24, began her professional studies when she was eight. She attended the Opera Theatre School and graduated from National Dance Academy of Rome (2011). Giulia recently graduated from Trinity Laban Conservatoire (1st Honours). Technique and versatility are distinctive elements that turn Giulia in a first-order performer.
CLARA SJÖLIN
Clara Sjölin is a dancer and choreographer based in London. She graduated with first class honours in contemporary dance at Trinity Laban in July 2016. Apart from dancing in Camilla Isola's work, she is currently creating her own piece of work for Resolution 2017, and dancing for MOA Company in Gothenburg in November.
LAURA CALCAGNO
Laura Calcagno started dancing at the age of 11 in her hometown Udine, Italy. She began her vocational dance training at Folkwang University of Arts (Germany), and later at Trinity Laban, where she graduated in 2016 with a First Class Honour degree. Straight after she professionally worked for Michael Clark Company and Kirill Burlov.
MADELEINE JONNSON
Madeleine Jonnson, 23, is a dancer from Gothenburg, Sweden. In 2013, she moved to London to study at the London Contemporary Dance School, where she graduated in July 2016. While studying, she worked with choreographers such as, Juri Nishi, Didy Veldman, Finn Walker. Upon graduating, she worked with Lea Anderson and Dane Hurst. 
CHARLOTTE BILCLIFFE
From Newcastle, Charlotte Bilcliffe, 22, started dancing at the age of 4. She was accepted on to the Centre for Advanced Training and straight after she attended Trinity Laban, where she graduated in 2016. She performed in Gary Clarke, Wayne McGregore’s piece. since graduating she was accepted as an apprentice with company Exzeb as well as performing with Punch Drunk and Friction Dance Theatre.  
THEO ARRAN
Born in 1995, in London, Theo Arran started dance at the age of 15, practicing breakdance and later ballet. In 2013, Theo began his training at Trinity Laban, later moving to Rambert in 2015. After returning to Laban, he is now in his final year on Trinity Laban’s undergraduate course. Theo performed in Sicily as part of the exhibition Spaces, Contexts, Habitats and for The Cunningham Company Fellows.
STEFF D'ARCY
Steff D’Arcy, is a contemporary dancer from London. She studied at The Arts Educational School, Elmhurst - Birmingham Royal Ballet School and is in her final year at Laban, training in contemporary dance. In the last few years Steff has performed for English National Ballet, Robert Cohan and The Cunningham Company Fellows.
KIERAN COVELL
Born in Birmingham, Kieran Covell, 20, studied BTEC Dance at Birmingham Ormiston Academy. He is currently in his third year on Trinity Laban's undergraduate course. Some of the projects he took part of include Motionhouse’s’ “Voyage” and Matthew Bourne curtain raisers Swan Lake, Sleeping beauty and Lord of the Flies.
GIORDANA PATUMI
Born in Perugia, Italy, in 1995, Giordana Patumi starts dancing at the age of 6 at Studio Danza Morlacchi. She trained in ballet, contemporary, modern, jazz and hip-hop. At the age of 19 she’s been accepted for professional one-year programme at Copenhagen Contemporary dance school, Denmark. In 2014 she started her BA at Trinity Laban. Alongside her dance studies she’s been playing the violin and taking drama classes.
PHILLIP HEWITT
Born 1994, in Swansea, Wales Phillip Hewitt is a dancer since the age of 19. He began his training on a Performing Arts course at Gower College Swansea, where he was a member of County Youth Dance Company 2013 and 2014. Straight after he did one year BA Dance Theatre at Plymouth Uni, where he danced in a short film with R. Way and R. Frampton. He is currently in his second year on BA Contemporary Dance at Trinity Laban.
VIOLA RANGHINO
Viola Ranghino was born in 1995 in Chieri, Italy. She started to dance at the age of 14. She trained at Opus Ballet in Florence and she performed in "Il viaggio" by Michele Oliva, in 2014. She is now in her second year at Trinity Laban where she danced in works by Lizzi Kew Ross.


RAE Dance Collective is trying to raise some funds to cover the expenses of this particular project (studio rehearsal space, costumes, marketing, travels costs) as well as pay the dancers, if anything more than the founding goal, for the performance happening on the 14th of January at Resolution, at The Place, London.

The Camden Neighborhood of North Minneapolis, specifically the area between 42nd and 53rd on Lyndale Ave owes much of its roots to the lumber industry. From the 1880 until 1930, Camden produced more lumber then anywhere else in the world. With the decline of pine in the northern regions of Minnesota, the industry shifted in the area and the story of the Camden sawmills is all but a distant memory for the community.
C.A. SMITH Early 1900's
 My project serves to provide local business around Camden with unique photos of its history with a emphasis on past and present photos of existing businesses and structures from similar vantage points. Some of the ideas I have are blended photos going from B&W to color, people: then and now and how the landscape has changed in and around Weber Park. 
Here's a good example of what I hope my end product to look like in the businesses
Here's some examples of some of the structures I might use.
Bell Boarding House in the past.
and in the Present!
 I'm hoping to capture much better current pictures, so please don't judge the results off these examples!
I plan to capture at least 15 different structures and vantage points over the course of 2015 and intend on completion to be around September with hopes of the final project being displayed in businesses this coming Fall 2015
If this project is successful, I plan to also raise funds for a museum in the streets around the Camden Historic Lumber District (C.H.i.L.D.)
I plan to use funds for a decent DSLR camera upgrade, enlargements,cost of historical photos 
Thank you for your support!

Ahoy friends near and far!
My name is John Withee, and I am the creator of the Construction Paper Tarot deck. I'm a poet, artist, and writer from the improbable little town of Kalamazoo, and most of my public work is curated at The Cucumber Boat (fb, insta, .com)

My interest in tarot came to me many years ago, and has been an indispensable meditation practice for me, not just for transformative moments, but living day by day as well. Since then, Construction Paper Tarot has been used for readings by folks just like you in many countries across the world. Awesome!
In 2014 I visited an artist collective that had specialized in mosaics in the 1990's. I was impressed and wanted to learn how to do it myself, but spent the following years returning to grad school for poetry. I finally have time to focus on this project!

I like to look at Mosaic Tarot as intergenerational communication. I want my art to be able to speak to someone fifty or a hundred years into the future without losing its ielevancy. I want future viewers of Mosaic Tarot to be able to tap into an ancient wisdom for the unimaginable challenges that lie ahead.
If you’re anything like me, you’ve probably spent some time wondering about how such a small person can make a difference in such a big world. For me, that starts right here with my friends and neighbors in Kalamazoo! There are plenty of people who need help and assistance right in my backyard. So to that end, 10% of the sales of these original mosaics will be donated to our local YWCA, where my best friend is a crisis volunteer. Further donations from the project will benefit Urban Alliance, the Tree of Life School, the future Edison Chapel, and many more organizations that fight back directly against poverty and foster community among people in immediate need in the city that I love so much. You are going to be able to watch your donation to this kickstarter grow and grow into something that is locally transformative in so many different ways.
So what is it already?! Let me tell you.
I am creating 78 individual mosaics from an estimated 400,000 individually broken, chosen, placed, mortared, grouted and cleaned pieces of broken glazed ceramic tile. About 2/3rds of them will be fifteen square feet in size; the rest, smaller or larger, depending on a number of factors, such as need for greater detail or particular significance. Ultimately the project may reach a maximum of 2,932 square feet, being composed of somewhere between 152-196 15-square-foot panels.  Those decisions are mostly dependent on time constraints.  I want to make them as detailed as I can -- but I *also* want to make sure *you* get your decks sooner rather than later!
As part of my artistic process, I smash tiles with a hammer. It is important to me that each piece is “repurposed from a moment of chaos,” something that happens to people from time to time. 
Ultimately, much of the project is going to make and early victory lap in September of 2020 when the project will be painfully and carefully moved up to Grand Rapids for ArtPrize, and decks will print and ship shortly after.  But there are going to be a lot of fun stops along the way!
I can’t do this alone. In addition to this Kickstarter, I am pursuing avenues with local grants, and there are even more ways to get involved with this project that you’ll want to check out at thecucumberboat.com! 
In the past, I have included kickstarter backers in decision-making processes, such as the layout and design of the cards you will receive. So climb aboard, poke around, and let’s make this ambitious and beautiful project to life!
There have already been many people who have thrown essential support behind this project over the years, primarily Mike Braganini for guidance on the medium, Sarah Harber for building the website, and many more – and I want you to be a part of it!

This is the Find My Rock adventure game. Below you will read a brief description about the adventure game and what I plan to apply the funding to.
When you find a rock that has been hidden by another person there is a QR code on the back that you can scan that will direct you to the Find-My Rock facebook page. Once there I ask you post a picture of you and the rock you have found and where you found it with a brief description about your trip. After you have posted your find I ask that you rehide the rock anywhere you want a new place a different states, a different country just let your imagination lead you. If you want to start your own adventure with your own personal customized painted rock you can order it on the Find My Rock facebook page.
The fund's that are raised will be used in this way.
1: Better packaging so that the product has a more professional appearance when it's on the stand alone display in the store and on the website.
2: Hire a webpage developer to better customize the Find My Rock Facebook page to make it more user-friendly and professional looking.
3: Advertising to move it from word of mouth to the store and have it ready to go by mid spring.
4: I'm also planning on purchasing a stone engraver so you can personalize your rock with a message.
5: Product stock on hand.
What each Findmyrock kit includes is one rock approximately 3-4 inches with scan Qrcode on it, one detail paint brush, one package of primary paint colors and one small can of sealer. Also included is instructions on how to do and what to do.
This adventure game needs to leave the nest and see the world.

A boy from a low income household play sports to try to stay from getting sucked into the mean streets of Chicago. He finally works hard and has to make a choice which could hurt his career. Does he go pro or to college? 
This movie will future his life going through gangs, women, violence, and academic problems.

THERE'S A TWIST!!!
For every $100 increment in donations, we will put every donor's name in a draw and pick one to receive a special reward from one of two boxes: QUIRKY PERKS FOR YOU or GOOD DEEDS FOR OTHERS!
Each box has a multitude of ideas containing perks like delivering flowers to you, building an epic living room fort, cooking French crepes for you, etc.  But, the winning donor gets to make a choice: a reward for them OR a reward for others.  For example: choose to have flowers delivered to you OR have us go out and give flowers to strangers.  These surprise rewards will be announced on Facebook, but the winning donor will also receive an email.
Chaque fois qu'un pallier de 100$ sera atteint, nous ferons un tirage au sort et le gagnant pourra choisir entre une récompense spéciale pour lui-même ou pour quelqu'un d'autre !
Livraison de fleurs, construire un château fort dans votre salon, faire des crêpes, voici quelques exemples des surprises qu'on vous réserve. Mais attention, le gagnant devra choisir : la récompense est pour lui OU pour quelqu'un d'autre. Par exemple : on vous livre des fleurs OU BIEN nous distribuons des fleurs à des étrangers dans la rue. Ces récompenses surprises seront annoncées sur Facebook, mais le gagnant recevra également un email !
WHAT'S THE IDEA?
The idea is simple: we grow as artists when we are confronted with new perspectives, new ideas, new ways of creating.  And when artists grow, that effect is compounded into the community because it encourages and inspires others to push their own boundaries.
Julie and Charlotte met in Paris in 2015 and collaborated on a shoot together.  Since then, they've kept in touch and have been discussing project ideas.  This residency project will allow them to work together again in a structured way that allows them to combine their different approaches to self-portraiture and to explore ideas of intimacy, space, and to share each other's inner worlds with all of you.
For 2 weeks, in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, Julie and Charlotte will explore ideas and create a unique series of self-portraits and duos that will challenge each other's boundaries and styles.
Julie and Charlotte's similar but unique self-portrait styles.
Who is Julie?  Who is Charlotte?
Julie Laurin: Fine art photographer who has worked mostly in Ottawa and Montreal.  She specializes in creative shoots, theatre and performing arts photography as well as self-portraiture.  Julie has a wacky world - she explores the beauty in the grotesque, the pain in the everyday, the passion in the banal.
Charlotte Forest: Primarily a theatre actress and director in Paris, Charlotte took up photography in 2010, mainly doing set photography but also producing a large body of work in self-portraiture.  Charlotte lets us into her world in an intimate, almost voyeuristic way.  Her world is delicate and silent, raw and introspective.  She explores sex, love, loneliness, pain, distance and closeness.
In a way, Julie and Charlotte have two very different styles.  And yet, they tend to explore the same topics.  The work they produce individually reaches into your ribcage - the work they will produce together will touch your heart.
A comparison of Julie and Charlotte's exploration of self-portraiture with others.
The Residency: Creation
During the 2 week residency, Julie and Charlotte will endeavour to produce an entire body of work that will revolve around an agreed-to theme.  They will also keep a journal with random ideas, thoughts, sketches and storyboards.  
The entire process will be shared with you on Facebook!
The Residency: Exhibition
The series produced by this residency will be on display at a big exhibition of Julie's work in Montreal in August 2017.  There are also plans to exhibit this work in Paris.
The series will also be on display on a special page on julielaurin.com
Quel est le concept? 
L’idée est simple : c’est en nous confrontant à de nouvelles façons de penser, de créer, que nous grandissons en tant qu’artistes. Et lorsque l’artiste grandit, s’enrichit, c’est toute sa communauté qui en bénéficie, en encourageant et inspirant d’autres encore à repousser leurs limites. Julie et Charlotte se sont rencontrées à Paris en 2015, ce qui fut l’occasion d’un shooting photo. Depuis elles ont gardé contact et se parlent régulièrement de leurs idées, envies et projets. 
Cette résidence sera l’occasion pour elles de retravailler ensemble sur un projet qui leur tient à cœur à toutes les deux. Elles pourront s’inspirer l’une de l’autre, comparer, combiner, recréer leurs façons d’appréhender l’autoportrait et jouer avec les notions d’intimité, d’espace … et de vous inviter dans leur monde intérieur. Pendant ces deux semaines à Ottawa en Ontario au Canada, Julie et Charlotte vont créer une série d’autoportraits et de duos qui leur permettra de repousser leurs propres limites et d’explorer de nouveaux styles. 
Qui sont Julie et Charlotte? 
Julie : Photographe Fine art, elle travaille essentiellement à Ottawa et Montréal. Elle est spécialisée dans la photo d’art et les autoportraits, mais photographie également du théâtre et du spectacle vivant. Julie a un univers un peu dingue, elle aime trouver la beauté dans le grotesque, la douleur dans le tous les jours, la passion dans le banal. 
Charlotte : Actrice et metteure en scène à Paris, Charlotte a commencé la photographie en 2010. Beaucoup photographe plateau, elle produit également un grand nombre d’autoportraits. Charlotte nous laisse entrer dans son monde de manière presque intime et voyeur. Son monde est délicat et secret, brut et introspectif. Elle explore l’amour, le sexe, la solitude, la douleur, la distance et l’intimité. 
D’une certaine manière Julie et Charlotte ont deux styles différents et pourtant elles se retrouvent sur les mêmes thèmes. Ce qu’elles produisent chacune de leur côté touchent un point sensible, alors imaginez ce qu’elles vont faire ensemble.
La résidence : Création 
Pendant cette résidence de deux semaines Julie et Charlotte vont produire un ensemble d’œuvre autour d’un thème prédéfini. Elles tiendront également un carnet de bord de leur aventure avec les différentes idées, pensées, croquis et storyboards. Tout cela sera bien évidemment partagé avec vous sur Facebook ! 
La résidence : L’exposition 
La série qui résultera de cette résidence fera partie de l’exposition de Julie à Montréal en Aout 2017. Et il est déjà question d’exposer ce travail à Paris. La série sera visible également sur une page spéciale sur julielaurin.com
Charlotte's portrait at the top; Julie's portrait below.

From the mean streets of New York to far-flung colonies of the future, cities are centers of adventure, conflict, and battle.  Cities are where wars are started, fought, and ended! 
After the success of the first Monster Scenery Kickstarter featuring trees, hills, and other natural scenery, Monster Fight Club is ready to present its second Monster Scenery campaign: modular city buildings!  
There’s no paper or cardboard here - every wall is sturdy, tempered hardboard. Every wall is full color on both sides, with tough UV-cured inks that will look good for years to come. 
Want to see Sophie & John put together and take apart a few buildings? Check it out:
PLAY

The walls fit snugly into detailed plastic corners, so you can assemble, disassemble, and reassemble your buildings quickly and easily. Their strength also means you can stack them to make multi-level buildings with playable balconies and roofs.  
If you want to take your games inside the buildings, have no fear!  The roofs and floors are removable to create lots of playable interior spaces: perfect for roleplaying games and skirmish miniature games!


 To see everything that comes in the Metropolis Pack Click Here
To see everything that comes in the Trees and Hills Pack Click Here
Each bundle includes enough sculpted plastic corners and connectors to assemble the buildings as shown.  The corner connectors work with all wall sizes, so you can mix and match walls from different styles and sizes. Each bundle is available in one of three styles: classic brick, modern concrete, or industrial steel. All the walls in a bundle will be the same style. 
The windows are all the same size and are removable. You can move windows between different styles.  
Each building wall features two stories of windows and measures about 5.5"(140mm) tall.  The buildings in each bundle also include a removable interior floor.  The small walls are about 5.5" (140mm) wide, the medium walls are about 8.5" (220mm) wide, and the large walls are about 11.75" (300mm) wide. 
For example, the medium square building in the City Block Bundle is 8.5" wide x  8.5" deep x 5.5" tall.  In metric, that's 22cm wide x 22cm deep x 14cm tall. The medium skyscraper pictured above is made from three of those buildings, stacked on each other.  It has the same size footprint, but is over 16" (42cm) tall!   
The more bundles you have in your collection, the more options you’ll have for building your unique city!
The buildings are the core of the Monster Metropolis Building System, but we also have lots of great sculpted details you can add to your city: signs, fences, dumpsters, and lots more! Pick which ones you'd like and add their value to your pledge amount. You can also choose add-ons during the pledge manager, after the campaign.
Individual buildings are also available. If you want to buy only Add-ons and/or individual buildings, choose the “Scouting Mission” pledge level, for the total value of everything you’d like in your pledge. 
Each individual building is two stories and about 5.5" (140mm) tall. When buying buildings individually, you can choose the style for each building separately.
Sidewalks & Signs Add-on Set (building not included)
Full-color sidewalks wrap around your buildings to tie them into any gaming surface. Each sidewalk set comes with 14 sidewalk corner pieces, in three different sizes.  You can combine the sidewalk corners to surround any size Monster Metropolis building.  
This Add-On set also includes 10 signs, with connectors to attach them to your buildings' walls.
Chain-link Fences set - now with bonus Steel Drum!
Each Chain-link Fences Add-on includes ten sections of fencing, plus enough connectors to make a fence four feet (120cm) long!  Chain-link fences are great additions to battlefields since they block movement without impeding shooting.  Each set comes with a spool of barbed wire which can be coiled and placed on top of your fences, or used separately.  The spool is also a detailed piece of scenery, appropriate for 28-32mm figures. 
Chain-link fences surround overgrown city lots
The Reinforced Fences add-on includes six sections of reinforced fencing, fortified with solid materials and two door sections. With the included connectors, you'll have enough to make over two feet (72 cm) of reinforced fencing. The Reinforced Fences look great mixed with the Chain-link fences. Each set also comes with a spool of barbed wire which can be coiled and placed on top of your fences, or used separately. The spool is a detailed piece of scenery, appropriate for 28-32mm figures.
Fire Escape and Ladders (building not included)

Don’t have a jump-pack? Left your grappling hooks at home? What better way to move up to the next level than with few sets of stairs! Each stairs add-on includes four sets of stairs, with enough platforms and connectors to add exterior stairs to a four-story building.  Each set also includes 4 ladders. Each ladder spans two building stories (one wall piece). Ladders can also be combined to span taller buildings. Every floor and roof includes a pop-out section where you can add a set of stairs. 
Brick building shown with fire escapes and ladders
Industrial Cargo Add-on Set (figure not included)
The Industrial Cargo Add-on includes 7 Pallets, 16 Barrels (8 of each type), and 16 Boxes.  The barrels are tall enough for a 28-32mm figure to take cover behind without fully blocking their line of sight.  Cargo pallets make great objectives too!
Enforcers Take Cover
Images not final. Featured art by Weiwei Xu (theweiweixu.portfoliobox.net), Deirdre Harder (www.deirdreharder.com), Elena Lorenzo (elelorenzo78.wixsite.com/elenalorenzo), (Emilia Mäkelä (instagram.com/emlimke), Sophie Engeman (sophieengeman.artstation.com), Matt Farleo (farl3o.com), and Gregory Dirr (gregorydirr.com)
The Graffiti Walls includes five new walls: 2 small, 2 medium, and 1 long. Each wall is illustrated with urban street art on both sides. Each set also includes five plastic building corners, so you'll have enough to expand your city. Graffiti Wall add-ons are available for all three building styles: brick, concrete, and industrial.
City Streets set - now includes free Power Conduit!
The City Streets set includes 4 Street Lights, 2 bus stops with movable benches, 8 protective bollards, a drop box, and 3 terminals.  The terminals make great objectives and get serve as public data terminals,  modern ATMs, or sci-fi access points. The bigger your city, the more of these you'll need to fill out your city's sidewalks!

Vents & Ducts Add-on Set (figure not included)
A key character in countless action movies, this set of vents and ducts looks good running horizontally or vertically on your buildings' walls.  It also looks great and provides cover when placed on the rooftops.  Each set includes 28 pieces: 14 straight, 6 connectors, and 6 corners. Combined, it's over 4 feet (120cm) long!
Pipe System Add-On Set (figure not included)
Each Pipe System add-on includes two long pipes, two short pipes, three corner bends, and enough connectors to attach all the pipes.   Add more detail to your industrial buildings and give your figures extra places to climb and take cover.  They also look great used separately, running closer to the ground. 

Includes 21 pieces - Figure not Included

Desperate times sometimes call for desperate measures: like taking cover in a dumpster full of trash! The Alley Garbage set includes 2 Dumpsters with removable trash-inserts, four different discarded tire pieces, 2 single garbage bags, a triple garbage bag, and 3 trash cans with removable lids.
