OOp is born with the objective that any person, company or trade can start a business without assuming greater economic risks. In addition, this project is designed for all those who want to have a physical mini-market where they can sell everything they want in a very different way than usual.
OOp helps you to make money in a simple and quick way if the product you want to sell likes the person interested in buying. This new system of sale consists of a box office-transparent small shop, a smartphone and an App that you can download for free on your mobile. In the OOpApp you can see the catalogue of products, both that are in the box for immediate purchase and those you can book choosing the one you want to take you to your address. If you like what you see inside the box office you only have to make the purchase through the payment gateway of the OOpApp and the system will allow you to open the door of the box office and pick up the product; So easy and simple. Our automated business module is protected by the Patent and Trademark Office and you will only have to decide where you are going to sell your item, set up the box office and make money. We are two entrepreneurs who met two years ago and since then we have developed this exciting project in which we believe and we have the full confidence that it will be a success. 
 This campaign acquires for us a vital aspect, since with the accomplishment of the objective we will be able to realize our dream of being able to carry out a project that helps to any person, company or commerce to generate income of different form. For us the help of the collaborators is fundamental. Without them many projects that have been beneficial to society would not have seen the light. It is also necessary to give the merit that Indeagogo deserves because it performs a very important task for countless entrepreneurs who do not have access to financing to carry out their project. We are convinced that our OOp project, your smart box office, is necessary because it applies the collaborative economy as a sales strategy, which is so necessary to take advantage of synergies and that can help traditional commerce so that it can sell more like any entrepreneur than with the minimum Economic risk can start a business. Our twenty-year experience has focused on the financial sector. 
  This experience brings us knowledge to carry out this project, assuming the lowest possible risks. We think that any idea or dream that you want to realize and carry out has to excite and motivate you every day, trying to make that dream not become a nightmare. Any project, although born of a good idea is not exempt of risks, but in our case with the financial experience that we possess and with the prudence that characterizes us in any strategic decision making we think that we minimize to the maximum any difficulty that can present. The discipline in our work and a positive attitude to the problems that may arise, are values that help us overcome the difficult path of carrying out an idea. We would be eternally grateful if you shared with all your friends and acquaintances this project through the means and channels that you consider. For us it is very valuable that you help us to spread our campaign in Indiegogo. We thank you in advance and we encourage you to collaborate with us. We are waiting for you in the Family OOp ¡¡

About our project:
We are creating a pre apocalyptic Quarantine room that will introduce the protagonist and his team. We are using a 1994 Blue Bird Real Prison Bus for the "Quarantine Prison Bus". This will enhance the players sense of immersion since they are in a place that is 100% authentic. Also, we are using sounds and lights to enhance the immersion even further. 
Please see below a short description of the story:
12 hours after the breakout  
Do you think Chernobyl was an accident? You are so naive! It was a cover up to something much much bigger. It was a desperate attempt to contain an out of control virus. Now, years later, the Russian intelligence found me and my team of scientists. They have infiltrated the FBI and managed to have us arrested and exposed to the virus. The incubation period is 60 minutes, think Kotov, THINK.
About the location:  
We are currently building this room in a 1994 Blue Bird real prison bus, this will enhance the players sense of immersion since they are in a place that is 100% authentic. The bus will be anchor in St Petersburg and will be rotating throughout all the major cities around Tampa Bay.

This Make 100 offering is for one-hundred little abstract expressionist paintings in my 2020 Enchanted Forests series.
I'm Linda Hewitt, a freelance writer and artist specializing in abstract expressionist paintings that share the mystery and exuberance of nature. I've been selling my original art at shows, online, and/or by commission since 2000. These Enchanted Forests paintings are among my favorite subject matter. There's something that's both intriguing and unsettling about the way woods change according to weather, season, and time of day, as if each part of the wood at any given time has its own particular personality. Perhaps that's why I've always found such delight in them - they're never boring and bring unexpected pleasures everywhere you look.
For this Make 100 Kickstarter campaign, I'm creating one-hundred original paintings of Enchanted Forests in their many and varied moods. Five will be 3" x 5" in size, five will be 4" x 6", and five will be 5" x 7". Eighty-five will be in what's known as ACEO or Artist Trading Card size - 2-1/2" x 3-1/2". They're called Artist Trading Cards because traditionally, for centuries, they were how many artists around the world traded examples of their work with one another.
HERE'S THE LOWDOWN ON MY 2-1/2" X 3-1/2" ART-CARD PAINTINGS:
The subject matter includes scenes from my Enchanted Forests 2020 series.
The style is abstract expressionist, and the paintings are multi-layered for a subtle effect.
Paintings vary in mood, intensity, and colors.
Paintings may be had in either horizontal or vertical format.
The medium is the highest-quality acrylic, metallics, and inks on Fabriano cold press watercolor paper.
Each painting will be signed by me.
Each painting will have a Certificate of Authenticity on the back, with the series date and number, personally signed by me.
Backers can choose: (a) the format - vertical or horizontal; and (b) the theme for each card they buy (see WHICH THEME DO YOU WANT?, below). Which art cards featuring a particular theme will be sent to which backers will be random.
The artwork is unframed but is sturdy enough to display on stands or even to hang.
Each painting will be presented in a super thick 3" x 4" toploading holder and shipped via USPS First Class Mail.
The plan is to have all paintings delivered no later than the end of May.
The larger paintings in this year's series will be as above save for the sizes: 3" x 5"; 4" x 6";  and 5" x 7" and a delivery date of June. These larger sizes of paintings, properly packed, will also be shipped via USPS First Class Mail.
CERTIFICATE OF AUTHENTICITY. Each painting, of whatever size, will have an artist-signed Certificate of Authenticity affixed to the back.  
Certificate of Authenticity to be affixed to back of each painting
NOTE:  You can elect to buy five of the 2-1/2" x 3-1/2" Artist Trading Cards and save shipping costs.
THE ENCHANTED FORESTS VIDEO. The video shows a selection of images suggesting their brilliance and variety, as well as the range of images within themes.
WHICH THEME AND FORMAT DO YOU WANT?  There are many themes that suggest themselves when I begin to paint. Several, however, come up repeatedly, as follows:
 Winter - Cool, silvery trees with dark blue sky 
Example of "Winter" theme
 Spring - Pale coppery-green trees with pale blue sky 
Example of "Spring" theme
 Summer - Golden-green trees with warm dawn sky 
Example of "Summer" theme
 Autumn - Russet trees with blue-green sky 
Example of "Autumn" theme
 Emergence - Forest rearranges itself with vivid colors of varying hues and intensities 
Example of "Emergence" theme


 Gold Dust - Thick green foliage highlighted in gold, with gold frame around three or four sides 
Example of "Gold Dust" theme
 Mystery - Closely grown dark green-and-purple wood with thick undergrowth 
Example of "Mystery" theme
Surprise me! - This may be from any of the above themes or something completely different.
Each card in each theme is unique, with the similarity relating to general approach and colors used.
CHOOSE PREFERRED THEME ON SURVEY. At successful conclusion of project, backers will be sent a survey allowing them to choose which theme they prefer for the paintings they've bought. If only one painting has been bought, they can choose one theme and one orientation. If more than one painting has been bought, they can choose one theme and one orientation for each painting bought.
MY GOAL WITH ENCHANTED FORESTS. My goal in this series is to suggest the mystery and ambiguity that's found in forests. This is my first Kickstarter art project, and I'm really looking forward to seeing who shares my love of these enchanted woodlands!
MY INSPIRATION. We live in an area of North Carolina so remote, mountainous, and inaccessible that it was once known as The Lost Province. It's a place of rocky ridges, steep slopes, dark declivities, narrow paths, long views, and valleys of every size. Here's the valley that we overlook to the east.
Our view of the valley to the east
Save for a few grassy balds, this area was originally covered in thick forests and has since the eighteenth century attracted commercial enterprises that came to exploit its oak, maple, beech, chestnut, ash, locust, black walnut, and other hardwoods. Today, it's a leading producer of Christmas trees - mostly the Fraser Fir  - and has stretches of white pines promoted to farmers by the USDA in the 1970s.
The climate is conducive to rapid tree growth; even clear-cut areas begin to regenerate within two to three years. Our best guess is that our small part of it has probably been logged at least two or three times, but each time a handful of trees have survived, leaving us with a very mixed woodland that under different conditions can seem anything from young to ancient and from happy and bright to sad and soft. Here are slivers of our place's moods throughout the year.
Slices of what we see throughout the year
Look in one direction one time, and you want to explore these cheerful precincts. Look in another direction or at a different time, and you want only to go inside and - paintbrush in hand - sit by the fire, grateful for the heavy log walls that hold back the weather and the night.

Kalsada offers a new specialty coffee origin with a social mission to bring Philippine coffee to the international stage. We work closely with farmers to produce the highest quality specialty coffee in the Philippines. Help us raise $15,000 to build much needed infrastructure for our farm partners to take their coffee from good to great.
It all started when Kalsada’s co-founder, Carmel Laurino, then a student at the University of Washington, came upon this 1909 photograph of Philippine coffee vendors in Pike Place Market. The photo sparked so many questions: Who were these men? And what were they doing in the same market where Starbucks would open shop 60 years later?
Photograph courtesy of: Museum of History & Industry, PEMCO Webster & Stevens Coll.
With this photo in mind a few years later, Carmel started an online blog as a way to get creative minds thinking about Philippine coffee.
Among the new members was Lacy Wood, a Paris-based coffee connoisseur who could bring in the necessary technical background and industry experience to push the project forward.
Less than a year later and with small financial contributions from close friends and family, she and Carmel moved to Manila, despite their online-only communication up to that point. Together they would get to come to know the Philippine coffee industry first-hand.
A bright young Manila local, Tere, joined the team and quickly grew into a coffee aficionado. She began with cupping and roasting, and soon became a trusted source of knowledge for growers on quality growing techniques.
The Kalsada Team has spent one year researching the market and another year building relationships with farmers. After a thorough selection process, we are bringing you the tastiest coffees the Philippines has to offer.
Kalsada’s core team, Carmel, Lacy, and Tere, gelled in just one year as we established ourselves as advocates for high quality Philippine coffee. We collected coffee samples, roasted coffee for the local specialty market, and learned about the experience of stakeholders at every level - farmers, co-ops, local and national government officials, and industry leaders.
We have a story we’d love to share with the world. That story starts with a photo and ends with a cup of coffee.
Auntie Rosita, Mt. Province Philippines
A Grower's Story
Auntie Rosita has a successful roadside stand. She grows coffee and works with her neighbors to collectively find buyers and seek higher prices.
While every farmer has a unique story, Auntie Rosita's infrastructure needs for growing higher quality coffee echo much of what we’ve seen across our farm partners.
Her family is fortunate to have almost 10 hectares of coffee planted, but she never has enough help to harvest it all. Her children pick some, but they make their living outside of agriculture. Auntie Rosita and her husband do much of the work themselves: pruning and weeding year round. Once every year, they harvest, depulp, dry, and dehull the coffee -- without any machines.
Auntie Rosita hopes that her children will one day take an interest in coffee so that they may see value in what she has worked so hard to build.
Kalsada provides low-cost, high-impact technology to increase the quality and value of the local coffee.
Currently most farmers dry their coffee on bilao, or woven bamboo baskets. This dries the coffee much too quickly--essentially pre-baking it in the sun and giving the coffee a papery, cardboard taste.
With simple technology and a bit of training, farmers have a better chance of evenly drying their coffee. Easy interventions like this $30 drying bed can drastically improve quality and increase the value of their coffee.
Already, Kalsada has built raised drying beds and has begun educating farmers on quality. We would like to expand our efforts and focus on one community to produce outstanding coffee. By bringing these resources to one small village, we can control quality and bring a much higher-value coffee to market.
Your contributions will help us build a small, inexpensive washing station that would centralize resources and knowledge. It would save the farmers time and labor, while bringing their unique coffee to aficionados like you.
DRINK WELL PLAYLIST
Carefully curated by Fiona Le Brun, these songs have been put together to perfectly accompany your morning brew. Drink in new tunes from artists like: Naomi Wachira, The Dove and The Wolfe, Courtney Marie Andrews, and more.
INAUGURAL COLLECTION
Our Inaugural Collection includes two 3.5 oz (100g) tins from each coffee growing region.
Benguet
Coffee from Benguet is generally semi-washed which gives it a rich honey-like mouthfeel with notes of tropical fruit and vanilla.
Mt. Province
Mt. Province’s higher elevation gives the coffee a peppery aroma with bright green apple top notes and a rich caramel body.
AFICIONADO COLLECTION
For those that know their coffee, we will give you a two month subscription of a 12 oz (340g) bag from our reserve collection. After a highly selective process, we set aside the best micro-lots and pay these farmers a higher price for their coffee. Let us send you one bag a month for two months.
BLUE MOUNTAIN THYME COFFEE SLEEVE
Hand stitched from leather and wool, this coffee sleeve would be the perfect companion to your favorite mug or to-go cup. Photographer, creative, and blogger, Hannah Dewey of Blue Mountain Thyme has designed this unique sleeve just for us.
Hannah Dewey, Blue Mountain Thyme
ESPIRITU POUR-OVER
Hand-made by ceramic artist Diane Espiritu, our limited edition pour-over and pitcher will be the perfect way to enjoy your coffee each morning. Below are the developing designs. Photos of the first prototypes are on their way!
Diane Espiritu, Espiritu Design Studio
FINE KALSADA DINING
We invite any Pacific Northwest locals to join us for a dinner, artfully prepared by the young and talented chef Aaron Verzosa of Modernist Cuisine. Join us for this three-course meal crafted from seasonal selections, accompanied by thoughtfully paired wines, and shared over conversation about the future of Kalsada and our journey thus far. The dinner is limited to 10 people, hosted in Seattle on the 11th of April 2015. (Note: This does not include transportation to Seattle).
COFFEE ADVENTURE
Have your own coffee adventure in the Philippines. We will take you to visit our farmer partners in Mt. Province so that you can experience a home-stay in our highest altitude community. Admire the view of the rice terraces from a community that is building shade covered coffee terraces to further their economic needs in an environmentally sustainable way. Meet a local roaster entrepreneur that has been roasting and buying arabica coffee in Sagada for over a decade. Transportation from Manila, accommodation, and food (including dinner at the famous Yogurt House in Sagada) is all included for this four day coffee adventure. (Note: International airfare to the Philippines is not included).
Join our Kalsada Krew instagram challenge! Want to be a member of Kalsada Krew? Use the hashtag #kickstartkalsada, and we will select winners to take over our Instagram feed for the last week of our Kickstarter campaign!
Hear what others have been saying about us

Soon after seventeen-year-old Josie is accepted into music school, in Deaf, she loses her hearing. Now if she closes her eyes, it’s as if she doesn’t exist.
But there’s this strange and beautiful boy, Oliver, who’s been watching Josie among the ancient effigy mounds near her house in southern Wisconsin, who gets in the way. And for as much as Oliver’s been watching Josie from deep in the woods, she’s been watching him back. Still, Josie can’t get the music out of her mind. 
And after a small orphan boy is hurt, then miraculously healed, Josie finds out Oliver’s real reason for living close to her in a hidden underground - he has the power to save lives. Each life he saves, however, weakens him, until he has only one left to give. He wants it to be Josie’s.
Josie’s interest in him has turned into more than just a fascination. How can she let him save her when he’s become her life?
Deaf is a 50,000-word YA novel.
You will help finance final editing, book cover design, e-formatting and promotion.

A longform piece of journalism including text, photographs and video.
I intend to break a very important story, bringing to light possibly impeachable facts which destroy the very foundation of Donald Trump's credibility and fitness for office.
President Donald Trump has been criticised for the amount of time he spends playing golf -- an accusation he himself levelled numerous times against his predecessor Obama, though neither of them comes close to the prodigious golfing of Wilson and Eisenhower.
Trump claims to hold a golfing handicap (a way of scoring players against each other even if they play at different courses) of between 3 and 4 - placing him somewhere in the 5-10th percentile, an impressive achievement for a man in his 70s. This would rank him amongst professional golfers and serious amateurs.
But others (notably rocker Alice Cooper) have accused Trump of cheating at golf, and a signed scorecard indicating his prowess has never been produced.
This multi-platform project will be a deep investigative report into the Commander In Chief's golf score, in a potentially explosive expose which gets to the heart of the President's credibility, character and backswing.
Does he shank his drives? Does he use a wood off the fairway or stick to irons? Does he tend to hook or draw his strokes (generally biased left or right?). Does he take his victories with class and defeats in his stride? Is it true that his caddy is a Russian spy?
By good old fashioned shoe-leather reporting, I will collect the deep dirt, and discover once and for all whether the President's golf game is as good as the cut of his suits and the knot of his tie.

Coming Soon: Moderation Brewing!
Before Prohibition, Mainers gathered in small neighborhood breweries for freshly brewed beer and conversation. These local establishments were beacons: they brought people together in the twilight hours after long days, inviting friends new and old to relax and enjoy the good times together. Today, Moderation Brewing is reviving those time-honored traditions in our taproom and brewery, which dates back to 1880 and originally served as an American Express office for the town of Brunswick, Maine. (It’s likely that countless packages filled with moonshine passed through our doors and into Maine’s ports, carried by defiant bootleggers until the day beer came back.) Mainers love great beer, and we’re proud of our independent businesses and local agriculture. That’s why we’re passionate about bringing you fresh, locally made and sourced craft brews in a variety of styles.Moderation Brewing is re-energizing downtown Brunswick as its only walkable and bikeable downtown destination taproom. We're brewing top-notch fresh craft beer with local malted barley, hops, and yeast strains, and bringing people together in our taproom and outdoor beer garden. We're the place for great pints in a packed house full of friends.
Original Building circa 1900
What in Tarnation is Moderation?
Moderation Brewing is built on a fifteen-year- old best friendship between Mattie and Philip, both lifelong Brunswick residents. Philip’s an avid brewer and caretaker of the “Hop Monster,” a twenty-year- old Cascade Vine, and his own carefully cultivated library of brettanomyces-focused yeasts. Mattie is currently serving her third term in the Maine State Legislature, representing Brunswick, and she’s run her own business for over a decade. She’s a vocal advocate for local food systems and an ace photographer.  
Moderation will be one of very few breweries not located in an industrial park, and we envision that our small home will be a center of the community. We take that commitment seriously, and plan to use locally sourced grains, and to return our spent grain, hops, and yeast to local farmers for feed and fertilizer. As a walkable downtown destination, we’re the perfect spot to grab a beer before dinner, after work, or while leaf peeping up the coast of Maine.  
Downtown Brunswick
The beers are diverse, anchored by a flagship Brett-fermented red ale. Philip’s personal catalogue of beer recipes includes over 50 original varieties, including staples like New England IPAs and pale ales, and adventurous takes on classics, such as a Blonde Stout that defies categorization. The space is hand-built, welcoming, and lively—we plan to offer local art exhibitions, and open the space for gatherings, fundraisers, and celebrations.
Brettanomyces-Mosaic IPA
We Can Get There From Here
We’re almost there—after three years of blood, sweat, and beers, not to mention our life’s savings—Moderation Brewing has an incredible home, a rock solid business plan, and some next-level equipment and tools for our brewery. We’re so close to the finish line, we can almost taste those first cold beers on opening day.
White Ale with Maine Ginger
   We can’t do it without our community. Like any business with a story worth telling, we’ve encountered surprises—like a commercial space with such history that we’ve had to remove the equivalent of three buildings nested inside each other to get down to those 1880s studs. We’re rebuilding the brewery floor from scratch to support the brewing equipment, which has added time and cost to the project. We’ve done much of the work ourselves, with help from some wonderful family and friends, and our fantastic contractor Pat. It’s finally happening, but we’re running out of funds for extras like our beer garden furnishings.
More than anything, Moderation Brewing belongs to our community, and we want to give you a chance to invest now in making history. Your generous pledge will help to cover our final costs and put the final touches on something special.

IS IT GETTING MUGGY IN HERE?
You may remember from the 2018 Kickstarter that we launched not only some new syrups, but new branding as well. This includes the fantastic Thirsty Trio, designed by artist Tony Canepa. Well, the idea has been in place for awhile, and now BG Reynolds is proud to be working on the... THIRSTY TRIO TIKI MUGS! 
Thirsty Trio Tiki Mugs - 3D Sculpt
The craze for tiki cocktails has been upon us awhile now, but don't let your eyes glaze over at another one, because these three thirsty fellows are a very limited edition! Designed by Tony Canepa and produced by Munktiki Imports, these tiki mugs are sure to make a smashing appearance holding your next tropical cocktail. We've seen a lot of tiki mugs on the market lately. Horseshoe crabs, barrels, even a turkey leg... but when's the last time your new tiki mug was a real tiki? Stressed, Sippin', and Satisfied are here to bring the TIKI back to tiki mugs.
The mugs will be released in TWO SETS with full retail packaging! We've got the classic tiki mug brown set, and a wild BOLD color set! You can get one, the other, or both here on the kickstarter! And each set comes with one KICKSTARTER EXCLUSIVE pin! (Design TBA)
ABOUT THE THIRSTY TRIO
The Thirsty Trio in BOLD color! (actual mugs will be 1 color glaze)
Our three fine fellows represent the three stages of the tiki drink recipient.
Stressed - Represents the unquenched imbiber. Struggling with the stress of everyday life, and waiting for that feeling of a drink in hand to escape to places exotic.
Sippin' - There's nothing in the world like that first guzzle down your gullet after being handed a frosty beverage. With your nose in mint or an orchid, the waft of cinnamon filling your senses, and that sumptuous kick of a well aged rum on your tongue you're on your way to another dimension.
Satisfied - Ahhhhh... we're back to paradise. An escape from the workaday world is now in hand, and everything is going to be just fine. Quenched to the core, from the top of your skull to the tips of your toes... especially after that third one!
What stage of Tiki Drinking are you at? Get the appropriate mug for when you're feeling stressed, and end a delightful tiki tour feeling satisfied!

In the spring of 2014, I learned that I had been selected for the Doug Varone and Dancers mentoring program called DEVICES: Choreographic Intensive (CHIN)! I was one of 16 choreographers who had been chosen to work directly with Doug Varone and his dancers, receive individual mentoring from Doug himself, and ultimately present a new work at 92nd Street Y in NYC.  In May 2014, we all participated in the intensive part of the program....creating, moving, challenging, remembering how to play in the dance studio. After this intense process, I returned home completely inspired and excited to get started on a new work applying all that I had been exploring. 
Three amazing dance artists, Michelle Pritchard, Kelly Johnson, and Alaina Olivieri have joined me on this new adventure and we have been rehearsing since May. In July, I received my first feedback from Doug and the video above is from our most recent rehearsal. I now have a better understanding of where I want to go with this work and am taking his advice to continue challenging myself. There is much to do still, but I am thrilled at the direction we are going and am so happy to be collaborating with such beautiful, talented, creative artists, which leads me to the funding part of this story.
From September 12-14, 2014, we will have the opportunity to premiere this work in New York City. To say that this is a dream come true for me is an absolute understatement! Words cannot adequately express how much it means to me to be showing my choreography in the company of so many artists I admire and respect. It is also difficult for me to describe how much the dedication, time and energy of my dancers means to me. They have all made personal and professional sacrifices to participate in this project and deserve to be compensated. I am hoping to pay them for rehearsals, 2 performances, and travel expenses.  As I am still in the emerging stages of my company, I do not have fiscal sponsorship and so I am supporting my artistic life on an adjunct salary. I know that in the months and years to follow, I will become more adept at grant writing, fundraising, etc., but for now, I am giving this a try! I will be eternally grateful for any donations to help me reach my goal and fulfill my dream. Thank you so much for your support!
Here is more information about the CHIN project and how Doug Varone and Dancers were funded to create opportunities like this for artists like me:
"On September 12-14, 2014, Doug Varone and Dancers presents the works of 16 hand-selected emerging choreographers in the CHIN Project, the culminating event of the DEVICES: Choreographic Intensive (CHIN). DEVICES: Choreographic Intensive is a mentoring program of Doug Varone and Dancers, made possible with generous funding support from the New York Community Trust. The program is supported, in part, by public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, in partnership with the City Council. The CHIN Project is presented in partnership with the 92nd Street Y."

Artistic Director Jim May and the Anna Sokolow Theatre/Dance Ensemble is seeking support for the company's reconstruction of choreographer Anna Sokolow's seminal work Odes (1965) not performed since 1968. Odes is a work in three parts set to scores by contemporary music pioneer Edgar Varèse and the second installment in a live music for dance initiative appropriately titled "Sounds of Sokolow", a collaboration with members of Fusion Bande under the direction of Kenneth Hamrick. This program underscores Ms. Sokolow's close artistic and personal relationships with the composers and artists of her day; with Odes she expresses her surprising reflection on Greek Theater and Sculpture and a "powerful work about civilzation." 
  Please help us bring this much anticipated revival of Odes, a classic work of modern dance, back to the stage. Your donation will go directly to supporting the live music provided by members of Fusion Bande and help cover the costs of an expanded company of 23 dancers required to perform the dance. Not seen for over 40 years, Odes should prove a revelation for a new generation of dance enthusiasts.

SOUNDS OF SOKOLOW PERFORMANCES

Merce Cunningham Studio
55 Bethune Street, 11th floor
New York, NY 10014

Per i nostri amici italiani

Cari amici oltremare, vi scriviamo per chiedere un piccolo contibuto per la compagnia Sokolow Theatre/Dance Ensemble che sta cercando di raccogliere $5,500 per avere musica dal vivo ai nostri prossimi spettacoli dal 10 al 13 novembre 2011. Le donazioni vengono fatte tramite un sito web (kickstarter) dove chi vuole puo’ donare dei soldi (facendo un pegno); se non si raggiunge la cifra di $5,500 per il 5 novembre il tutto si cancella automaticamente. Anche una piccola contibuzione aiuta!

Lo spettacolo presentera’ una coreografia di Anna Sokolow del 1965 (Odes), che non e’ stata vista dal 1968. Il nostro direttore artistico, Jim May, faceva parte del cast originale, ed e’ un onore per noi imparare da lui questa meravigliosa danza creata per 23 danzatori. Anna Sokolow e’ stata una delle coreografe piu’ influenti del ventesimo secolo negli Stati Uniti: il suo lavoro combina la modern dance con teatro, musica, poesia ed arte. Ha influenzato la grande coreografa tedesca Pina Bausch e ha partecipato nella creazione di molti musicals, incluso  il famoso “Hair” negli anni ‘60. Ci ha lasciato nel 2000 a 90 anni; la sua ultima coreografia risale al 1998.
Aiutaci a raggiungere questa cifra e a presentare questa bellissima coreografia con musica dal vivo! Per fare il vostro pegno, cliccate su “back this project” e seguite le istruzioni in inglese. Purtroppo non ci sono istruzioni in italiano. Naturalmente avete bisogno di una carta di credito.
Ringraziamo tutti di cuore!! E ovviamente siete tutti invitati agli spettacoli...:)
Le danzatrici italiane del Sokolow Theatre/Dance Ensemble

Hi! We're Toe the Line and we're on a mission to set #TheNewStandard from the ankles down! After a successfully launching two chapters of socks, we're ready to launch Chapter 3 featuring some of our favourite Aussie animals. But this time, we're doing things a bit differently - by getting you, our fans, involved! We've got the samples made, and production is ready to go. Now all we need is your help to make Chapter 3 a reality!
When we started Toe the Line in 2017, we were two mates that were sick of having to wear the boring black sock. The idea was formed while at a Melbourne Cup function in 2016. We noticed the crowd were well dressed, but lacked ~flair~ in their sock game. From here, the inspiration for Toe the Line was formed, where we aim to set #TheNewStandard from ankles down. 
We reached out to Georgie, our now Chief Sock Designer at Toe the Line, and began working on Chapter 1. Finally, in September 2017 we launched with 8 socks featuring designs from fairy bread and fruits to totally wacky patterns. Chapter 2 followed soon in February of 2018 featuring our fluffiest four legged friends. And now we're ready for the next Chapter.
We've produced what we think are our best designs yet. Our Aussie animals cop a bad reputation for being some of the world's deadliest creatures. While this may be true, you'd be surprised how cute they look on a pair of Toe the Line socks. We can't wait to get these socks manufactured, packed and sent to you.

Es una pieza arte-objeto de cerámica, creada bajo un concepto del imaginario de lo que será el futuro y diseñada para ser producida en serie. Uniendo esfuerzos con Cerámica la Mejor, buscamos recaudar los fondos necesarios para hacer el desarrollo y la primera producción una realidad. Las piezas producidas en esta serie limitada estarán exhibidas y a la venta en el marco de Design Week México 2017.
__
"La reconquista", translated as Reconquest, is a ceramic functional sculpture, created as a possible idea of what the future will be and designed to be slip-cast for small productions. By joining efforts with renowned local workshop, Cerámica La Mejor, we are trying to raise funds to make the development and production a reality. The limited series will be exhibited and on sale during Design Week México 2017.
Manifiesto
¿Qué será de nosotros en el futuro? Nadie lo sabe. Probablemente un día desaparezcamos, como otras especies y civilizaciones han desaparecido antes, pero ¿qué pasará con todo lo que construímos y dejamos como rastro de nuestra existencia? La naturaleza salvaje reconquistará su territorio y poco a poco, esas estructuras que hoy son edificios, se erosionarán y serán suelo fértil para las plantas que se apoderen de ellos.
Por medio de estructuras verticales con una textura que simula el efecto del tiempo y semillas que se convertirán en plantas que desbordarán dichas estructuras, esta pieza enuncia una respuesta posible a la pregunta planteada.
___
Manifesto
What will become of humanity in the future?, no-one can know. We will most likely vanish as other species and civilizations have vanished before, but what will happen with everything we have built and left behind as a trace of our existence? An untamed nature will re-conquer its territory and little by little, the structures that today are buildings, will erode and become fertile ground for plants to seize them.
Made out of vertical structures that remind us of buildings, with a texture representing the passing of time, this piece gives a possible answer to our first question.
***La dimensiones son aproximadas en cm***
***Dimensions are in cm and may vary from the final result ***
"On the day after humans disappear, nature takes over and immediately begins cleaning house ––or houses, that is. Cleans them right off the face of the Earth. They all go"
—Alan Weisman, The World Without Us.
Mi inspiración viene de lugares que han sido invadidos por la naturaleza, algunos por abandono o descuido, otros con la intención de ser invadidos. Una vez que la mano del hombre no esté presente no habrá manera de frenar el crecimiento desmesurado de las plantas y el desmoronamiento del las estructuras.
___
Mi inspiration comes from places that have been invaded by nature, some due to abandonment or lack of maintenance, some others with the intention of being invaded. The fact is that there is no way of controlling erosion and the overflowing growth of nature, once there is no one to control it.
Con tu ayuda, convertiremos esta idea en un objeto tangible. Para hacer "La reconquista" una realidad, necesitamos modelos, moldes, materia prima y mano de obra para producir las piezas. Necesitamos de tu patrocinio para cubrir estos costos. Con tu contribución obtendrás una recompensa especial, además de reconocimiento y todo mi agradecimiento por ayudarnos a lograr la meta.
Con los fondos recaudados:
Cerámica La Mejor se encargará de hacer el modelo, los moldes y la producción de las primeras piezas. Presentaremos los resultados en el Museo Tamayo, y los exhibiremos y tendremos a la venta en el marco de Design Week México 2017 Nos encargaremos de que las recompensas lleguen a nuestros patrocinadores. Pagaremos la comisión que Kickstarter necesita para que se sigan fondeando proyectos increíbles como este.
 ___
With your help, we can make this idea a tangible object. To produce this series, we need models, moulds, materials and skilled labour. We need your sponsorship to cover all these costs. With your pledge you will get a special reward and acknowledgment, as well as my heartfelt thank-you.
With the funds raised:
Cerámica La Mejor will produce the model and moulds and manufacture the first edition of slip-cast pieces. We will exhibit the results at Museo Tamayo, and for sale during Design Week Mexico 2017 We will produce and send the rewards to our sponsors. We will pay the commission Kickstarter needs to keep connecting great projects with amazing donors.

Soy diseñadora industrial por la UNAM desde y trabajo con cerámica en un taller al sur de Ciudad de México, donde experimento con formas creadas en el torno. Me gusta subir montañas y estar en la naturaleza. Esta pasión ha destapado un repertorio de texturas y colores que se han convertido en la inspiración de mi búsqueda por crear piezas con un toque único y personal.
Te invito a que conozcas más acerca de mi trabajo.
www.lailasalomon.com

The story behind each object, its materiality, its functionality and how it affects our everyday lives, shapes my work. OPERACIÓN DOUVE es un cortometraje que narra la toma de los Puentes de Carentan durante la II Guerra Mundial. La historia será narrada desde el punto de vista del corresponsal de guerra americano Roy Gardner.
Para el rodaje contaremos con la colaboración de un amplio grupo de recreacionistas históricos, venidos desde Toledo, Valencia, Murcia y otros lugares de España. Como atrezzo, aproximadamente tendremos:
- 10 jeeps de guerra.
- 2 vehículos blindados.
- 50 figurantes interpretando a soldados americanos.
- 30 figurantes interpretando a soldados alemanes.
- 20 figurantes interpretando a enfermeras.
- Un campamento militar totalmente recreado.
- Una gran cantidad de armas de fogueo y explosivos. 
A pesar de contar con todo este material (aportado gratuitamente por el grupo de recreacionistas), necesitamos recaudar dinero para mejorar nuestra equipación técnica y poder estar a la altura a la hora de rodarlo. Aparte de esto, hay que pagar desplazamientos del equipo, traslados de material y alquiler de algunos medios técnicos (ej: grabadoras de audio).

Greetings! The third annual residency for the International Interdisciplinary Artists Consortium is happening August 16th – 20th at Earthdance- an artist-run retreat center in Western Massachusetts. Fifteen other artists from Brazil, Colombia, Japan, Mexico, the Netherlands and the U.S. (California, Massachusetts and New York) will join me for four days of exchanging approaches to making work and to engage in dialogue sessions about interdisciplinary performance and its role in education. Immediately following our time together, we will serve as teachers for the Moving Arts Lab, August 20th – 23rd - a three day festival of workshops open to the general public. Included in the weekend is a larger dialogue session, sharing our findings from the residency with all of the participants, and opening the floor to discuss the importance of interdisciplinary approaches in our world today. We will also offer a faculty performance.
I need your support to cover travel expenses for all of the residency artists/teachers, plus room and board at Earthdance during our stay. Last year I succeeded in running a successful campaign, and this year, I want to challenge myself to raise enough to expand a vision that I have been honing for the last five years. What’s different this year is that all of the teachers for the Moving Arts Lab will be present for the residency, whereas in years past, some artists only participated as teachers for the Lab.
In a culture that regularly devalues artists and their contributions, it has been important to me to provide this opportunity to artists without them having to incur any out-of-pocket expenses. The residency and lab are spaces where we can continue to identify and support the values that we share, and that are in danger of being lost to a society of distraction and instant gratification.
In terms of background:
The International Interdisciplinary Artists Consortium (IIAC) is a network of performing and creative artists, educators and producers working across artistic disciplines and continental divides. The objective of the IIAC is three-fold:
-to engage in artists' residencies that offer opportunities for knowledge exchange which feed into larger social and educational structures (i.e. workshops, festivals and academia)
-to identify and sustain methods for sharing resources and values
-to expand a network of partners
Established in 2012, the IIAC has since grown to include 42 artists living and/or working in such countries as Australia, Brazil, Burkina Faso, Cuba, Curaçao, England, Finland, Italy, Japan, Macedonia, Mexico, Poland, Puerto Rico, Serbia, Sri Lanka, Switzerland, and Uruguay, and from within the U.S. in states including California, Colorado, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New York and Pennsylvania.
This year's roster includes Michelle Boulé, Krista DeNio, Debra Disbrow, Conrado Falbo, Ximena Garnica, Shige Moriya, Martín Lanz Landázuri, Ursula Eagly, Abigail Levine, Odeya Nini, Emily Sweeney, Tatyana Tenenbaum, Petra Van Noort, Larissa Velez-Jackson and Sarah Young
For more information, please visit www.interdisciplinaryartistsconsortium.com
Thank you!
Peter Sciscioli, Interdisciplinary Performer, Creator, Educator and Producer

Fund Reports From the Energy Battlegrounds!
This year will be the hottest year ever in energy politics, filled with big pipeline decisions, big energy dramas, and big elections.
This is the year of Keystone, Kinder Morgan and Canada's fossil fuel-touting prime minister's bid to be the longest serving leader of Canada.
We're a team of award-winning journalists. 
Canadian Journalism Foundation Excellence in Journalism Award 2014
With the funding from this project we'll create one year of powerful reporting on energy politics and the environment.  We'll look for connections between powerful U.S. interests and Canadian politicians.
We'll bring you reporting on where candidates in the 2015 federal election stand on pipeline projects, LNG, big oil,  and how they think and feel about climate change. 
We'll travel to where landowners face multi-national corporations who claim rights to place energy infrastructure across their land. 
We'll interview scientists once muzzled by Canada's government who are now speaking out about what they know.  And we'll be publishing stories we can't even imagine today. As the news unfolds, we'll be there.
We'll be on the ground, bringing stories back to you daily for a year. Making our target will mean we can:
Afford to cover Canada's energy story through daily, in-depth, critical reporting.
 Reach those who are hungry for our stories quickly, through search engine advertising, vigorous development of our social media outreach, and some solid consulting help on effective optimization of our digital news ecosystem.
Complete development and design work on our new site.
Produce a new book, Extract: Vol. 2 The Pipeline Wars, Burnaby Mountain Kinder Morgan protest.
The National Observer
Archbishop Desmond Tutu speaking at a conference in Fort McMurray, the heart of the tar sands. High resolution image by National Observer's Bill Weaver for $150 reward
We've developed The Vancouver Observer into an award-winning regional online newspaper.
Now we're building a new publication. 
Canada's federal election is coming, and energy policy will be at the centre of this election. 
 Your support will mean we can launch the National Observer with outstanding coverage of politics and news through the lens of energy and the environment.
Vancouver Observer + National Observer = two great teams, two great publications with investigative reporting and daily news that packs a punch. Delivered to an engaged and growing audience.
While the Vancouver Observer will continue as a vibrant local online newspaper, The National Observer will branch out across the continent and narrow in, with a sharp focus on energy and the environment.
Nationalobserver.com takes a beautiful design, integrates it handily for smartphones and tablets and makes it easy to share articles across platforms.  This is how we will deliver some of the most powerful stories of the year, with your help, by meeting our goal.  Please join us to make a new platform for energy and environment news and reporting.
We deliver
We're the team that created "The Tar Sands Reporting Project." Kickstarter called it their "Most Socially Conscious Project" in Canada of 2014. 
We produced 140 stories in the year of the report.  The investigative stories funded by the project led to the resignation of Canada's top spy watchdog, a class action lawsuit by citizens who were being spied upon by government for criticizing the oil sands, and changes to citizenship laws. The stories outgrew our local brand, "The Vancouver Observer."  And that's why, with your support, we're busting out.

8K Reward: A trip to the Great Bear Rainforest
Get off the grid with us for some deeply relaxing and educational down-time, while learning about how divided factions negotiated for over 19 years, ultimately putting their differences aside to protect the Great Bear Rainforest's trees.
Spend seven days on the Island Roamer sail boat, exploring one of the world's most gorgeous coastal regions. Its future hangs in the balance, as oil and gas projects and companies work to push pipelines through the wilderness to the coast.
We'll use evenings for story-telling, exploring the issues around oil extraction and delivery to market, and alternative sources. During the day, we'll observe wildlife, waterfalls and witness a part of the biggest migration of fish on the planet. We'll watch whales in Douglas Channel and look for the iconic Spirit Bear  by a turbulent stream in a mist-laden rainforest.

This book / story will become a Hollywood movie. Not because it’s about me or because I wrote it, or that I am someone special, unique or different.The reason is because consciousness awakenings are happening to more and more western people who have little or no understanding of what is happening to them, nor do they have the ability to recognize it in others. There is one consciousness manifesting in all of us and in mankind as a collective whole. It's nature is to evolve. As the understanding of its manifestation becomes more and more prevalent in western culture, the relevance of the higher teachings of the east becomes paramount.  Sooner or later in this lifetime or another, circumstances in your life will force you as an individual expression of consciousness, to evolve into the non linear subjective state of conscious awareness. The details will be different but there is only one truth, one consciousness, and it’s evolving through you right now.
It matters not if you are Christian, Muslim, Hindu, Jew, or practice no formal religion or spirituality at all. You are part of It… You won’t leave here by death but by transcendence. I am an educated westerner, holding several professional licenses, numerous patent. I have been a business owner, steeped in capitalism and entrenched in the Newtonian paradigm of intellect, logic, and reason. The following excerpt from my book is only one of many experiences that has forced the quest for understanding the truth of who and what we are. There is no stone left unturned questioning reality, sanity, truth, and purpose.
I was driving home from my David Hawkins study group, and was having trouble determining what was real and what was; what I would call transparencies. If you have ever seen auras before, I would describe these transparencies as being something similar, only they would surround various objects, although some were not associated with any objects or form at all. I wasn’t really aware of it at the time because all seemed real, or at least appeared to have form. I was pretty confident that I was on the right road and headed in the right direction but my sense of space and location seemed to be in another dimension. I had been seeing these transparencies for about a year now, mostly in the morning while driving to work. They would usually fade away when I looked directly at them. Tonight, they were not fading away. 
I made a left turn onto what I thought was the turn to go home. I proceeded straight ahead and I saw a pair of headlights in the immediate distance pointing directly into my eyes. I had turned down the left side of a divided highway and was going head on into oncoming traffic. I immediately pulled a u turn and was able to right myself onto the correct side of the road, but was unable to determine exactly where home was. I knew I was in the area but the ability to rely on my sense of location, logic and linear thought was an impossibility. Time, space, and location which are linear were not accessible to a nonlinear state of mind, that I appeared to be in. I had been in this nonlinear subjective state of thought many times before but had always been able to get to where I needed to be. To use logical sequential thought while you are in a state outside of time and space is not possible. 
I wish I could explain how I got home but there simply is not the ability to describe it in language. The closest linear concept understandable would be that of relying on intuition. Even this is not an adequate description. It’s like there is an intuitive sensing that takes place outside of logical sequential thinking. It appears to act outside of time, space, and location. It is truly outside of the ability of language to give adequate description. This intuition comes from a source beyond the thinking mind. 
Implosion
The removal of form. I sit here in the one room that I rent, in a home that I don't own, with a coffee pot, a microwave, and a picture tube tv. It's not a fancy flat screen either. Counting all of the clothes I have, it would take fifteen minutes to load all of it into my 16-year-old Honda civic with no air conditioning and no radio, and drive to Alaska. Maybe, it would be cooler there!. I have 21 dollars in the bank until my next pay check which is a week from now.
On April 16, 2006, the upstairs bathroom toilet seat had broken and I took the brand-new Chrysler 300 we had purchased the day before to Lowe’s, to buy a new toilet seat. The car had less than 100 miles on it. Our three-story home in a fancy suburb of Atlanta was the center home of the cul-de-sac. As I drove up the hill to the house, I proceeded to enter the driveway that had a steep slope down into the garage. I suddenly felt this (lump) thump, and heard the sound of an aluminum lawn chair crunching and an awful groan. More like an oh shit?. Oooooh shiiiit! Oh shit! I realized that the car was on top of my wife Liz and that the only way to get it off her was to back up, so I backed up.
It was a beautiful Easter Sunday in Atlanta and Liz had decided to sun bath in the driveway, on one of those low beach chairs. It was impossible to see her the way the driveway slopped into the garage. Her shoulder was fractured in several places, she had several broken ribs, a broken tail bone, and a torn femoral artery. The good news was she did not have brain damage nor any paralysis. She was alive but barely. After surgery, she spent about a week on the surgical recovery floor and was then moved to ICU. I'm not sure exactly how long she was in the hospital, but after discharge, she was confined to a hospital bed at home in the living room. We had visiting nurses who tended to her until the insurance company stopped paying. Upon being discharged, Liz had been home only a few hours when she was on her way back to the hospital via ambulance due to excruciating pain. The broken bones and torn artery were causing horrific problems, and the road rash was so extensive that the nurses had to train me on wound care, so I could tend to her when my insurance ran out.
As she was going through surgery that evening, I received a call from the insurance company. They informed me that the call would be recorded. So, I was forced to relive the accident in slow motion and in graphic detail. This detail included what Lowe’s I had gone to, what isle I had shopped in, what toilet seat did I purchase, the color, and how much I paid for it. I took the call in the hall of the hospital and once it ended I found myself on the floor. About two weeks after the surgery, I was driving in to see Liz and my mind was spinning like crazy with so much on my plate. The police questioned me. The police questioned Liz asking her if she wanted to press charges. My kids had probably talked about the accident at school and DFCS showed up at my house. Financial pressures, on and on, and all of a sudden, it felt like all the circuits in my brain fired all at once. My mind crashed. I’m not even sure to this day exactly what happened to me. I couldn't figure out if I should continue to drive to the hospital, eat something, lay down, call someone, or if I had to go to the bathroom. Somehow, I made it to the hospital. I was walking down the hall and one of the nurses I had come to know saw me and asked me if I was ok. I said no. She literally took me by my arm and walked me to the emergency room. I was treated in ER but I'm not exactly sure what they gave me. The brain crash came back periodically for the next few years but it was never as intense as the first one. I was totally powerless over when it would come and how long it would last. The only way I can describe it is that it felt like all the circuits in my mind fired all at once and fried my brain. It seemed like I needed to be rebooted.
Last fall second daughter was abducted from the local Walmart at knife point, assaulted, raped and dropped off naked in a parking lot begging for her life. After several weeks had passed, and with help from local media coverage, they found the suspect in a hotel room, by identifying her stolen car in the parking lot. His picture and the kidnaping had been captured on the Walmart cameras. The picture used by the media to ID the guy had been taken from the grocery store camera of him using her credit cards. He was charged with 7 felonies for this one incident. Several of the charges carried thirty years to life, if convicted. She now has a hand gun with a carry permit and knows how to use it.
Shortly after my daughter's kidnapping, my 20 year old son  was coming home from work on his motorcycle and was hit at an intersection by someone making a left turn across traffic on a divided highway. I suppose that as far as motorcycle accidents go, he came out pretty well. The worst of the injuries were severed tendons in his right hand that required surgical pins, all of which resulted in permanent loss of mobility in one of his fingers.
My youngest daughter (who I haven't seen in several years) was married at age 21 to a gentleman who was associated with what I believe to be a church cult in South Carolina. No one knew when the wedding would be, nor was anyone from her side of the family invited. I have spoken to her once in the last four years and that only took place through her husband acting as an intermediary.
My oldest daughter from my first marriage is a graduate of University of Florida and teaching at the University of California working on her Ph.D. She had dated a young man from the 10th grade, through High School and College, and is now married to him. My wife and I were invited and attended her wedding. As we entered the church and guests were being seated, typically an usher would escort the ladies to their seats. We had not been greeted and were pretty confused as to exactly where to sit. So we just proceeded into the sanctuary and sat down in two vacant seats where available on the brides side about half way up the isle. As the father of the bride I was not involved in any aspect of the wedding, pictures, or reception. Thank God for the grooms family. We sat at the grooms table at the reception and left shortly after.
I had founded and built a company around intellectual property that I had invented. The technology had 12 issued patents. We were working with The Gates Foundation and a think tank group, and had 18 months of field trials in Africa and Southeast Asia completed. My financial position as a result of Liz’s accident was vulnerable and 15 years of blood sweat and tears was compromised by those who would do so. I thought we were on the same team. 
We lost our home of 18 years where we had raised the kids, and the entire family was split apart. Since the year 2006 there has been nothing in my life,  I mean nothing that I could do, to stop, slow down, control, or influence events. No decision, prayer, choice, event, person, circumstance, job, company, anything, anyone, had any impact. Nothing worked for me period! My life had imploded completely. I have moved six times in the last year, lost three generations of inheritance money, been foreclosed upon, and went bankrupt.
Ok God you have my attention!
What is my part? What is it in me that needs to change? The miracle is recognition that I need to change how I think.  
Dear God, I ask you please to help me change how I think. ...

Working Title: "BEAT" Beat is a fun, Compelling urban musical drama, The twists and turns in the story will leave you at the edge of your seat like any of the other big time shows around today. The show is based in London. It follows the lives of the two main characters John and Tamera, when their parent mysteriously disappears one night leaving them alone with their infant baby brother Richie. With debts pilling and bellies getting hungry John begins to feel the financial strain of not having parents to support them. He soon turns to his brother from another mother called Michael who provides an easy escape to his problems at hand. As the story line unfolds we will find out more about johns parents, who they are and why they disappeared. The first season will run for about 10-15 episodes What makes this a Musical drama is the fact that we will be using 1-2 artist from the music industry (GRIME, HIP HIP & RNB) to feature in each episode. Each song will be a cut scene at any giving time in the episode and will compliment the story line at the point of insert!

So there I was, in the Crescent City with my dear husband visiting his delightful Aunt Beulah. I won't mention her age, as a lady never tells her age, but let's just say there have been 16 U.S. President's, some with multiple terms, in her lifetime so far.  Being from Los Angeles, I’m used to urban life but New Orleans has a special quality about it that other cities don’t, making this town enticingly different. We were only going to be able to spend one week with Aunt B, as she likes to be called, and on that first morning after our arrival, she asked me if I would like a cup of coffee. I needed something to combat jet-lag, so I replied “Yes ma’am!” I had no idea that I was about to experience some of that New Orleans difference…
I was sitting at Aunt B’s table thinking about some of the things we were going to do that day, and brought the cup to my lips. That first taste had my full attention. I stared into my cup, expecting to see something different, but no, it just appeared to be… coffee. But the taste! WOW! I glanced at my husband and he was just smiling at me, knowing that I had just experienced Aunt B’s Special Coffee. I told Aunt B “This is the best cup of coffee I’ve ever tasted. Do you mind my asking you two things: How do you make it, and may I have another cup?” She laughed and said “Why no, honey! I’ll share my secret with you!” I had another cup as she explained the history of her unique brew.
In New York City, there was an establishment known as the Horn and Hardart Cafeteria. Aunt B had enjoyed the coffee there in the early sixties before moving south to where it didn’t snow. After becoming a “regular” at Horn and Hardart, she watched the head barista prepare their famous coffee, incorporating a single secret ingredient made their coffee stand out from the others. Aunt B learned how to blend the coffee and the “something something” and has kept the recipe close to her heart ever since. This coffee has been enjoyed by Aunt B’s friends and family in New Orleans for many years, and now I look forward to sharing it with my friends and family, and maybe some of you as well! Since I was fortunate enough to marry her favorite nephew, she willingly shared the name of the “special” part with me. I promised that I would not reveal what the secret is, but I can still share small amounts of pre-prepared dry mix of this with a select few of you.  If you are a coffee drinker, you have never tasted anything like this. A rich, buttery flavor unlike any other.

Hello, new friends, and welcome to The Iola Project.  
Ravynn tweeted: "Ugh I just want to get a bunch of Black feminists together and start a site where we write Bitch media quality takes on popular culture but with the interactivity of Buzzfeed."
Perhaps moments after that tweet, the idea for The Iola Project began taking shape in my mind. 
The idea was simple: I wanted Black feminist popular culture reviews and analysis about all our favorite things on a site where you could do more than just read. I wanted a site that taught readers as much about our Black feminist foremothers as it did about our contemporaries while you perused. And I wanted people to get paid for their time.
In order for such a huge project to get off the ground, I knew I needed help. So I called the baddest Black feminist I knew: Taylor Leigh Lamb. With Taylor’s assistance, The Iola Project began to develop sharper contours and the intentions became clearer. 
From our name, which was derived from Ida B. Wells’ pen name when she wrote for the Memphis Free Speech, to our site colors, which come from Alice Walker’s quote, “Womanist is to feminist as purple is to lavender,” everything that we do at The Iola Project is part of a larger goal of celebrating Black feminism, in all its forms and iterations. In addition to our popular culture reviews and analysis, we will write under Black feminist pseudonyms with an accompanying guide to why we have chosen our names; we will pay homage to our foremothers in our weekly “Letters to the Ancestors” column; and and we will encourage you to, in the wise words of Dr. Claudrena Harold, do the reading by offering up reading lists and reviews of our favorite Black feminist texts.
Ida B. Wells-Barnett
It is important for you to know that this is not a woman’s magazine. This is a Black feminist magazine. If you are Black, identify as a feminist and have all the feelings about popular culture, your words are welcome and valued here. We are seeking to amplify those voices. If you are non-Black, identify as a feminist and have all the feelings about popular culture, join our community.
If our ideas surrounding this project encourage you to follow us on social media, tell a friend, or maybe even donate. It will take $12,000 to cover start up costs and three months worth of content. 
But for something like The Iola Project? I think it’s worth it.

MEET OUR INAUGURAL STAFF
Ravynn K. Stringfield
Ravynn Stringfield is a PhD candidate in American Studies at William & Mary, researching Black Women and Girls in fantastic, futuristic and digital narratives told through new media. She currently writes and curates guest content for her blog, Black Girl Does Grad School. Ravynn serves on the Board of Directors for Contingent Magazine and the Editorial Board of Third Stone Journal. When she’s not researching, writing or reading for her dissertation, she is likely somewhere drinking coffee, playing with her dog or boring someone to tears ranting about Lois Lane.
Taylor Leigh Lamb
Taylor Leigh Lamb is a writer and theatre artist from Virginia Beach, Virginia. She believes strongly in the power of art to impact social change, and plans to one day make these impacts through theatre and writing. Taylor is a Sagittarius, with an ardent love of Beyoncé, and Buffy the Vampire Slayer is her favorite TV show of all time. She believes the last sentence is equally important as everything else she said here.
Editors
Holly Genovese
Holly Genovese is a Ph.D student in American Studies at the University of Texas at Austin with graduate portfolios in Women's and Gender Studies as well as African and African Diaspora Studies.  Her work focuses on prison writing, African American literature, intersectional feminism, popular culture and black poetics. She received her MA in history in 2015 from the University of South Carolina and her BA in History and Political Science in 2013 from Temple. Her first journal article, "Not A Myth: Quakers and Racial Justice" was published in the March 2015 edition of Quaker Studies. She is a contributor at Book Riot and a blogger at the US Society for Intellectual History. Her journalism and criticism has been published in Teen Vogue, The Washington Post, Electric Literature, Literary Hub, The Chronicle of Higher Education, and many other places. 
Trayc Freeman
Originally from Virginia Beach, Trayc Freeman is a two-time graduate from the University of Virginia, earning a B.A. in African American Studies and an M.Ed in Educational Psychology (with a Social Foundations concentration). While working towards her B.A., Trayc became a member of Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. and is the current President of the Zeta Mu Sigma Alumnae Chapter. She currently works for UVA, but hopes to eventually pursue a Ph.D. focusing on Black education, more specifically, the value of having Black teachers and administrators in schools both historically and presently. In the meantime, she runs her own Black history blog and has officially declared editing as her favorite pastime.
CFO
Leah Franklin
Leah Franklin earned her M.B.A. at the University of Maryland University College and her B.S. in Communication Studies at Towson University. Leah has planned and produced events, live and taped shows in Miami, New York, Atlanta and Los Angeles. She currently works for a management and consulting agency in the DMV but has dreams of running her own business with her family. When she is not planning, she is at the beach, online shopping (because who goes into stores anymore) or quoting her favorite movie, “Love & Basketball”. Her hobbies include rewatching Michael Scott make a fool of himself, singing her heart out to Queen Bey and spending time with loved ones. 
Social Media Strategist
Monet Timmons
Monet Timmons received her B.A. in English and African American Studies at Emory University in Atlanta, GA. Her research interests include 19th and 20th century African American literature with an emphasis on Black women in the archive and public memory. Monet has extensive background in archival research through Emory's Rose Library where she examined the manuscripts of Alice Walker, Audre Lorde, and Claudia Jones. Monet continues this passion for archival research and Black literary studies at University of Delaware as an AAPHI (African American Public Humanities Initiative) Fellow.
Board of Directors
Kelsey Watkins, J.D.
Chardé Reid

How This Came About:
Comprised of the brilliant minds of Bailey Stanfield, Justin Putney, and Dylan Moham (and not to mention, the friends and family supporting!) We were sitting around on a Skype call when Bailey, out of the blue asked, "Justin, don't your parents have a t-shirt heat press?" to which Justin answered, "yes we do, why". Dylan, almost as if he was anticipating the topic to arise anyway, exclaimed, "I have been looking at the shirts at school and have thought to myself, HEY I can do that!" And just like that, the ideas started PUMPING out. Backed with passion and a youthful vision of hope for this becoming much bigger, we came up with a killer name, both intentional in the fact that its an acronym and unique....because it is!
OUR GOAL:
With our goal at $225 we will be using the money for Shirts, Heat applied transfers, and Stickers!
So...What is Quiet Wave Shirt Republic?
It's all in the name! Lets dissect it. 
QWSR: Pronounced <Kwey-Zahr>, like the word Quasar. It's honestly just an awesome acronym.
QUIET WAVE: We are going to release and create each shirt in collections of two. Wave One is what we are starting with (the images pictured) These will be out in June, and we are hoping to have enough funds from the first wave to continue Wave Two that will come out in December!
SHIRT: We sell high-quality shirts, sure to fit your liking!
REPUBLIC: That's where you come in! Each wave we are going to release polls online to hear which shirt of the two was best, and additional feedback is greatly welcomed!

The Back Story
When the going gets tough, the tough get going, and writers write, musicians play and painters paint. Often the best creative work is borne of some sort of angst. For me, this last couple of years has been interesting. My studio has filled with a body of work that I feel should be shown in its entirety. My best friend's battle with cancer lead her (and I) to New York City, a place we'd always meant to visit together. A place where she grew up, and I only read and fantasized about. New York has been both an electric adventure and an exhausting battle ground.  As she braved one harsh situation after another, I, in my front row seat, could only marvel at the shear unfairness of it all, as well as her matter of fact bearing of it. Manhattan just seems like the obvious place to exhibit my blinking responses to what felt very much like falling down Alice's rabbit hole. In some of my paintings I paint of things that perplex me, others, things I was outraged by, or frightened or inspired by, even grateful for. Not all of it illness related. So now I have a good sized series of paintings ready to be displayed, and a very good opportunity to do so in an artsy area in the heart of Manhattan. 
  The Project
So here I am back on Kickstarter trying to raise funds to carry this out. I had previously only contacted galleries and submitted work hoping for the opportunity. Now the opportunity has come to me and I am only held back by the logistics. Transporting large painted canvas, framing, and advertising are part of the equation as well as the space rental. A solo show in New York is a giant undertaking. With the help of my family and my new friends in the NY art biz I am trying to keep the costs as low as I can. Its important that I am clear that I am not doing this with the traditional goal of painting sales. This is much less practical and far more personal than simple commerce. Its also more complicated. I am creating the opportunity for an experience, both for myself and for anyone visiting the space. I am creating a dedication to my best friend and to every other person who has ever courageously pressed on through  harrowing moments in their life . If one person sees one painting and feels lifted or understood or encouraged by it, THAT will make it. I created my art to take myself into and out of the harshness, if you become distracted or uplifted for even one moment, that makes it memorable, and for me, it makes it art.
The Show
The show which has been retitled (again), will be called Out of the Rabbit Hole. This because,  though we certainly appreciate the opportunities we've had to spend time in NY, my friend and I agree, it is time to make our way out and home and onward. The show will open on October 11 and close right around the end of her required  stay. This actually happened by coincidence, ( is there such a thing?) so all will neatly commence together. What better way to celebrate!? I am also in the process of creating a website so anyone can go online and see the paintings, read about them and if they want to, even buy one through amazon or paypal.
Rewards
For pledging  your support for me in this undertaking I want to share my art with you. I will have original paintings, T-shirts, canvas tote bags, even baby onesies with  my paintings printed on them, there will be note cards and signed prints. For anyone wishing they could visit the show but not geograghicaly
one reward
able, I will offer a free download or DVD of the opening night. I so appreciate you taking the time to visit my kickstarter sight and hoping with me that I am successful. 
Still painting!

JUST GIRLY THINGS is a new dance theatre work from the Danielle Georgiou Dance Group (DGDG) that is premiering at the 20th anniversary of the Festival of Independent Theatres at Dallas' Bath House Cultural Center.
JUST GIRLY THINGS will perform on the following dates:
Friday, July 20 at 8:00 p.m. 
Saturday, July 21 at 5:00 p.m.
Sunday, July 22 at 2:00 p.m.
Thursday, July 26 at 8:00 p.m.
Sunday, July 29 at 5:00 p.m.
Saturday, August 4 at 8:00 p.m.
JUST GIRLY THINGS is a devised, collaborative dance theatre piece written by Danielle Georgiou and Ruban Carrazana, with the performers. Original music and lyrics by Justin Locklear, Cory Kosel, and Trey Pendergrass.
This delightfully raw and painfully honest work of dance theatre centers on the complicated relationships between women and the obstacles that they place between each other in an already tenuous environment. Being a woman is a “disadvantage,” or so says society, but is that really true?
Chock full of songs and dance inspired by 1990s pop culture and television sitcoms, this musical comedy shows the lengths women will go to resist disappointment and achieve “perfection.”
Following the tradition of other works from the award-winning company, JUST GIRLY THINGS will explore the themes of its source material by deconstructing the style of a sitcom and presenting a fresh, exciting, and chilling look at pop-culture.
Angela Davis as Mandi and Marti Etheridge as Lizzy; Danielle Georgiou as Cassandra and Colby Calhoun as Rooster. Photos by Trenton Ryan Stephenson
Where will the funds go?
Your donation will go to cover the costs of the production, including costumes, set construction, and to pay fair wages to the performers and designers. We're working hard on our end, but we need your pledge to help make JUST GIRLY THINGS a success!
Kickstarter is a unique platform for funding creative endeavors. In exchange for your support, we offer a variety of rewards--and our endless love! Because funding is all-or-nothing, it is imperative that we raise our full goal of $2,500 to move forward with this project; otherwise, nobody will be charged, and the campaign will not be a success. 100% of the money earned here will go towards building the piece.
To learn more about DGDG, visit http://www.dgdgdancegroup.com/
Please support this project in any way you can, and spread the word - it would mean the world to me! Thank you from the bottom of my heart!
Sincerely,
Danielle Georgiou
The cast of JUST GIRLY THINGS. Photo by Trenton Ryan Stephenson.
