Hi, I'm Madeline von Foerster, an American painter living in Germany. I make paintings using a 500 year-old mixed technique of oil and egg tempera, invented by the Flemish Masters.
Photo ©Oliver Wachenfeld www.oliverwachenfeld.de
My paintings have contemporary themes: endangered species, vanishing biodiversity, and deforestation. The leitmotif is humanity's troubled relationship to nature; how we can heal it, and ourselves.
In the "Mische" technique, as it's known, a detailed underpainting is rendered in tempera on a red ground. This is later enhanced with oil glazes, creating a signature luminance.
My artworks are in collections around the world and have been featured in numerous publications, including "100 Painters of Tomorrow" (Thames and Hudson, 2014). I was also the subject of a television portrait on ARTE's "Metropolis," broadcast in Germany and France. 
ABOUT THIS CAMPAIGN:
I've been working since 2014 on a series of paintings entitled Uprooted, which will be exhibited at the Academy Art Museum in Easton, MD late 2017 (See title painting and three additional paintings in the section below). I am planning a beautiful, 100% recycled catalog of the show. In order to cover the up-front costs of design and production, I am offering pre-sales of the catalog, as well as a gorgeous assortment of prints, art cards, and rewards that you will not be able to get anywhere else.
ABOUT THE EXHIBITION:
From Uprooted: Heinz's Cabinet, Oil and Egg Tempera on Panel. ©Madeline von Foerster 2015
Uprooted is a series of paintings that tell a story. It's the adventure of a wooden jointed doll, or Gliederpuppe, carved out of wood during the 16th century as an objet d'Art for a Curiosity Cabinet. She inhabits a realm that is full of precious items collected from the natural world: taxidermy, coral, ivory, and the like -- but nothing that is alive. Our Gliederpuppe gradually attains a kind of consciousness; over time she even learns that she is made out of material that was once a living tree. She feels a longing to return to existence in the forest -- to be surrounded by vibrant life rather than dead objects. We join her on this journey of discovery and redemption.
From "Uprooted:" La Nature Sauvage, Oil and Egg Tempera on Panel ©Madeline von Foerster 2015
The Curiosity Cabinet, or Wunderkammer -- the setting for much of this series -- is a motif used in many of my paintings. It so perfectly symbolizes humanity's dichotomous impulses towards nature: a laudable curiosity and admiration, combined with a fetishistic, ultimately doomed desire to contain and possess. Ironically, the Curiosity Cabinet is an ever more apt symbol for nature itself in the Anthropocene: fragmented, isolated, and reduced to human possession, for human ends. Appearing in many of the paintings are examples from an entire genus of Hawaiian snail that was "collected" into extinction, and other animals who were similarly "loved" to annihilation. 
From "Uprooted:" Mirabilia, Oil and Egg Tempera on Panel. ©Madeline von Foerster 2015
Almost all of us live our lives surrounded by objects that have histories we never think about -- our wooden furniture may have once been a tree towering in the rainforest, home to innumerable other creatures. Millions of people buy ivory, without comprehending that they are contributing to the extinction of elephants. Like the Gliederpuppe, we suffer from this alienation and separation, even if we cannot identify it. It is a pang no amount of consumption can assuage. In a sense we are also trapped in this cabinet-world full of collected objects, removed from our source. Even if we can never return to a life in the forest, we can affirm the preciousness of life and its living products, ourselves among them -- this is the message of Uprooted.
I'd be honored to have you join me for this adventure!

What is A Better Home and Garden?
A Better Home and Garden is an installation-based art exhibition that will be at Bunker Projects in February 2019. The show will highlight interdisciplinary artists: Selena Hurst and Derek Peel and is curated by Emma Vescio. The show aims to create experiential rooms that simulate what we accept as real while highlighting 70s-80s interior design trends.
What is Bunker Projects?
Bunker Projects is an artist-run non-profit residency and experimental gallery that serves as a platform for emerging artists to develop their practice and create new works for an exhibition. By providing an immersive live/work space alongside intimate cultural programming, we foster a spirit of innovative support, connecting artists with Pittsburgh’s active and growing arts community.
Bunker's contemporary art space  values the process of making art and exhibiting work to the public. Bunker specializes in installation and multi-disciplinary work by independent artists.  On first Friday of the month, in this case February, Bunker premieres a new show for Unblurred Gallery Crawl.
 
Who are the artists? 
Hurst simulates the appearance of interior objects and surfaces in photographs, life-sized stickers, and floor-like sculptures. The images printed on adhesive vinyl merely resemble curtains, but they are transformed into functioning objects when positioned on windows. Her work questions the boundaries that divide and define the real and its representation. 
For this exhibition: Selena is working with fabric to create small, sewn objects, working with wood to create a ball-pit like structure that visitors are able to jump into, and is looking to purchase astro-turf to tie into the retro vibe.  
Peel employs common objects and materials in their work to connect us with our fragmented surroundings.  Their sculptural figures and installations imply varying degrees of distress, confusion, imperfection, and are often contradictory.
For this exhibition: Peel is working with carpet, ceiling tiles, LED lights, and small installation works. Their work requires technical skill and time in order to be executed well.
 What will we do with your funding? 
The funding of this project is mainly to cover the remaining costs of these installations. While the work has been conceptualized and the pieces + outlines have already been made, the remaining details need to be paid for. Along with installation aspects, there are marketing and curatorial details that will be placed in the gallery that need to be paid for as well.
With $1000:
$750
Installation Materials include:
Astro-turf (About $325)
Fabric (About $250)
Ceiling Tiles ($40)
LED Lights ($54)
Carpet ($81)
$200
Lumber can be classified as an installation material, but will coincide with other exhibition needs.
$250
Marketing Materials include:
Printing costs (~$100)
Paint (~$60)
Posters (~$50)
Vinyl information stickers for gallery (~20)
Plexiglass (~20)
The Impact
It is crucial to allow artist-run spaces to continue to survive. Bunker Projects continuously supports artists by having the location and space for experimental work, but often times the money to produce these pieces is very expensive. While there are plenty of spaces for installation-based works in Pittsburgh, your contribution will be supporting two emerging artists to create experiential works that are not funded by a major institution. Not only will you be supporting these artists, you will be supporting the art community of Pittsburgh, the curator who wants this exhibition to highlight both Selena and Derek's work, and Bunker Projects. 
While this exhibition is open, there will be events in the space to discuss the works, a potluck or brunch alongside an artist talk, and gallery hours on Sundays so you are able to see the exhibition beyond our opening + closing events.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute, that's okay. There are a couple of other easy ways to help:
 Share our Kickstarter: Invite friends who would be interested to contribute via e-mail and social media.
 Follow Bunker Projects: Sign up for Bunker's e-mail list and follow on Instagram and Facebook.
 Follow Selena, Derek, and Emma: All three contributors to this exhibition work hard in Pittsburgh and have many other events/exhibitions. Selena's Instagram, Derek's Instagram, and Emma's Instagram.
 Check out the space: Come visit Bunker Projects during the exhibition or our First Friday event! We also have performance art events, film screenings, potlucks, artist talks, etc. in the space.
If we surpass our goal, we will be able to pay the artists a small stipend for their work and time they spent creating these installations, purchase food/drinks for the opening + artist talk, and the rest of the money will go to Bunker Projects.
We cannot thank you enough for taking the time to look at this project. We hope that you are able to make it to the exhibition! 
- Emma Vescio

Flint City T-Shirts opened in 2003 with the goal of providing high quality screen-printed apparel in our hometown of Flint, Michigan.
Our shop not only prints custom screening orders for clients, but we also create retail designs that reflect the toughness, resilience and spirit of the community.
To this end we are celebrating our 14th anniversary by printing this limited edition "Believe in Flint" t-shirt. The design shows Flint's iconic Weatherball. It is used to this day to show the community what the upcoming weather will be and is visible from anywhere in the city.
The shirts are 5.5-ounce, 100% cotton and are made in the USA. From the cotton to the fabric manufacturing to the sewing of the finished shirt, the shirts help create and sustain jobs right here in America.
If you would like to purchase more than one shirt please make your pledge $25 more for each additional shirt.
We will use the money raised to improve our Downtown Flint retail storefront and to continue to provide the community with our services.
Flint City T-Shirts is excited about the future of Flint. Our city has been through some difficult times, but we know we will make it if we continue to Believe in Flint!

I've been through so much in the past 20 years no one would believe it even when I put it in black-and-white. You may think that this book should belong in fiction because the stories I have to tell sometimes seem greater than life itself, but it's definitely nonfiction. I have doctors,nurses,family friends and others to verify every word.

Our Shop
We are a small bike shop in the heart of the Leschi neighborhood of Seattle. For the last three years we’ve had a plethora of questions about when we would be coming out with a kit. We held off because we wanted to make sure they’d be done right, and by right, we mean quality kits, a design that paid homage to the heritage of the sport, and one that was unique without going in a direction people would expect. We have put all those elements together, and we’re pretty excited about it. Our hope is for this to be the start of limited edition kits to offer to the cycling community. Because we are a small shop though, it's tough sometimes to put up the capital to be able to order kits of the quality we want to be represented in the shop. That's why we are looking for your support.
Who are we? 
We are a bike shop whose customers, employees and owner believe in the soul of bikes. As our manager of the shop explained to us when we hired him "For me a ride is never just a ride and a bike is never 'just a bike'...Cycling is a gateway to freedom, a new view of self and mental quiet...I want to work at a shop that gets that...A shop that is the center of its own community" - Bob Grunau. 
Our Kits:
Sleeve Detail
The kits themselves are coming from Squadra, a company that has been around since 1996. That’s not a long time–when it comes to heritage brands–but deep in their history is work with Maurizo Castelli. Yes, that Castelli. Squadra was born out of that guidance. While not as ubiquitous in the world of custom kit as Castelli, the quality is on par with the more popular brand.
As for the design: we wanted a look that would pay homage to the to riders of the past. We figured it was best to start with the Champion of Champions: Fausto Coppi. Being the dominant rider of his time, Coppi was also a cultural movement. In post war Italy you were either with the urban Coppi, or you were a Bartali supporter, who’s deep Catholic faith was indicative of a Italy that has falling into the past.
To achieve this end, we asked Heartthrob Racing’s Tim Hubner to design the kit. We sent Tim a picture of this great rider in his classic Bianchi kit and said “Something like this.” Tim more than delivered with a light blue and white jersey that says The Polka Dot Jersey across the front in that beautiful Campagnolo script. On the right hand sleeve is a cartoon of the man himself. Underneath it reads “Coppi Lives, Coppi the Myth” in Italian, a line he gleaned from William Fortheringham’s excellent bio: "Fallen Angel: The Passion of Fausto Coppi"
For the shorts we went with your basic black, and the letters PDJ along the leg in a cream color, as it was back in the day. The shorts will work with your favorite plain jersey, and the jersey will work with you favorite pair of black shorts. The pairing will look great, but you can mix and match either with your favorite kit. We will have women's specific sizing!
We are also going to do a run of classic cycling caps. 
Cycling Cap
Back Panel of Cap and Bill Underside
If we reach our funding goal and you select a donation of greater than $100, we will contact you afterwards to get your sizing selection. All the orders will be compiled together and will be submitted to Squadra for printing. Turn-around for this is approximately 4-6 weeks after the completion of the project. These will be a limited edition series and once the kits are gone in the shop, the design will be archived away. 
We also have a funding stretch goal. If we reach $4500 in total donations and you have pledged greater than $100, we will throw in a cycling cap with your order. This stretch goal will allow us to carry a good amount of stock in the shop for those not as cool as our awesome backers to get their hands on some amazing kits.

The Story
At GenCon a few years ago, I was looking around the convention center and wondering why events like this weren’t more common at the local level. There were 80,000 people traveling in from across the world just to attend this gaming event. This inspired me to create a plan for a permanent location where gamers could come and do what they love most. 
Five years ago, I opened East Coast Gaming (ECG).  We quickly grew to where we are today and have even had the need to move to a bigger location to support our growing customer base.  As a result of having a big open play space, we stumbled into the hosting video game tournaments that have become a weekly staple on Mondays.  In addition, we now provide a venue for at least 2 groups who have large monthly events that fill the place. 
Over the past several years, "board game cafés" have become more common, but we will be the first in the Research Triangle area. The Research Triangle is full of active gamers and recently ranked in the top 20 of best gaming cities. Not only has there been an increase in individuals gaming, but we have also seen a number of corporations express interest in  engaging with their employees through gaming.
With the expansion of the bar and café, we have decided it’s time to re-brand East Coast Gaming to GAMERS: Geekery and Tavern.  We will become a unique blend of board game café and event space designed to serve the gaming community. The venue will have a small but quality food menu...great drinks – coffee, local sodas, beer and wine...and be designed to host groups of all sizes.
GAMERS will use proceeds from this Kickstarter to help fund the development of our unique board game café project, which we expect to be complete in early July 2019. 
The Venue
Gamers: Geekery and Tavern will be located at 107 Edinburgh S., Suite 213 in Cary NC. It is just over 4,200 square feet and is located on the second floor of the newly renovated MacGregor Village.
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Macgregor+Village/@35.7542941,-78.8198184,12z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x89ac8d2b7abd05f5:0x5ea48cdfa466ac24!8m2!3d35.7367485!4d-78.7986623
Gamers floor plan has been designed to allow for a wide assortment of activities. There is a large room set up as a board game café area where patrons can play games on over-sized tables. Inside that area is a social game section composed of couches and chairs where large social games (such as Werewolf) can be played. There is an E-sports area with couches and chairs where patrons can stream Twitch TV across multiple televisions and/or play their favorite console games. There is a tournament area where card and video game tournaments will be held. Lastly, there is a private Game Lair which can be booked for group activities (such as D&D). 
Floor diagram
In the center of the room is a large area where the kitchen and bar are located. Patrons will be able to order food/snacks and drinks (beer, wine, mead, coffee, sodas, etc.) while they are playing. 
How will it work
Similar to other board game cafés, there will be a $5 venue fee (or $10 per family) and this will allow you access to the entire board game library for the day. The board game library will start with over 200 different games to choose from. There will be a wide spectrum of choices, staples like Monopoly and Yahtzee, European style games like Settlers of Catan and Ticket to Ride, social games like Apples to Apples and CodeNames. We will be regularly adding games to the library so it can grow and stay up to date. If you are coming for a specific event that has an entry fee (say Friday Night Magic or Smash Brothers tournament) your venue fee will be included as part of the event entry fee.
We will also offer both monthly and annual subscriptions for either an individual for a family. Individual memberships will be priced at $15 per month or $120 annually; family memberships will be priced at $25 per month or $240 annually. Membership will include unlimited access to the game library, discounted pricing on events, and a free appetizer on your birthday every year. 
View of the bar area (in construction) circa June 20, 2019


Ladies and Lords of the Tavern
Members of this club will receive upgraded drink and food options. When ordering beer – the beer will be served in a 20oz mug instead of a 16oz mug. When ordering wine or mead the pour will be 8oz instead of 6oz. (For drinks available by the glass only.) When ordering food there will be items marked on the menu where members can receive either food refills or upgrades. The menu is still in a small state of flux as we optimize the kitchen, but these items will be visible on the menu we post closer to the Kickstarter completion.
TIER LEVELS
The tiers we have outlined break down into a few different categories. Rewards in the ‘Introductory Level’ tier are designed for someone to either follow our process or receive passes to come check us out after we open. Rewards in the ‘I Want to Join the Party’ tier are designed to provide memberships and include the ‘Introductory Level’ tier rewards. The ‘Let’s Make it Yours’ tier allows people to put plaques with a name or saying in the tavern and includes the ‘Introductory Level’ tier rewards. Lastly, the Legendary Endeavors rewards offer custom-designed individual experiences or membership.
A couple of clarifications about the memberships. One-month memberships will expire on August 31st, 2019. One-year memberships will expire on August 31st, 2020. Lifetime memberships will expire with you. The benefit of joining the ‘Ladies and Lords of the Tavern’ club is upgraded drink sizes; pints will be served in 20 oz. glasses, wine and mead pours will be 8oz. instead of the normal 6oz.

Lifetime membership. Lifetime membership into the 'Ladies & Lords of the Tavern'. Fully customized over sized mug or wine glass (you help us design) that will be stored ON SITE and only be used by you when you visit. Automatic invite to the launch party (for 2) if that stretch goal is unlocked. All items from the "Introductory Level" tier.

Private event for up to 60 people for up to 4 hours. Food and non-alcoholic drinks are provided. Full access to the game library and a dedicated game master for the duration. Great team building exercise.

Jumping Jacks is off to a great start but we want to take it to the next level in our facility. We're offering these great rewards and in return the funds will be used towards cooling off the warehouse, building a laser tag area, and outdoor mini-golf.  
Cooling Off Jumping Jacks for next summer means you can play longer and have another local option to beat the heat while having fun with the kids. Every dollar counts when you're trying to cool off a space this big and this is your opportunity to be part of the solution!
We're looking to add Laser Tag to our experience and believe it will enhance our offering to our birthday party packages and to the older crowd. Who doesn't love a little friendly competition amongst friends. 
We're so close to finishing our outdoor mini golf area we just need a little kick-start to purchase the remainder of the obstacles, then a little hard work will bring the course alive. 
Thank you for being part of the solution and for supporting a local small business. We hope you find these offerings to your liking and that we'll see you soon!

Thank you for considering supporting Departed Soles Brewing Company, opening up soon in Jersey City, New Jersey!
My name is Brian and I'm the owner of Departed Soles Brewing Company (www.departedsoles.com), as well as the brewer, tour guide, bartender, janitor, and any other title you could think of.  I greatly appreciate you taking a minute or two to check out the brewery's Kickstarter and for any consideration you give towards helping me out.
What is Departed Soles Brewing Company?
DSBC is Jersey City's FIRST Craft Brewery and only the second functioning commercial brewery and tasting room in Hudson County.  We are going to be the first brewery in the State of New Jersey, and really anywhere nearby, that is specializing in making Gluten Free craft beer!  DSBC will be making non-gluten-free beer as well, but more on that later!!
Panoramic view of the brewery equipment
Who is Departed Soles Brewing Company?
Departed Soles is a one man operation currently!  Well, one man and one four legged friend. My name is Brian, and the Australian Shepherd by my side is Bogan. Don't get me wrong though, we hope to expand and employ locals quickly...
Brewing became a passion of mine after spending time working at a dive bar in Boston, and then living where Craft Beer seemed impossible to find.   In 2009, it became a "give a man a fish, or teach a man to fish" scenario and thanks to my older brother, I was home brewing that Christmas.
Several years later I was accepted in to the American Brewers Guild Brewing School's Intensive Brewing Science and Engineering program, with a focus on Breweries in Planning, and graduated in December of 2012. 
We've been looking for property to start our brewery ever since then and are glad that that chapter of the book is almost done being written! 
You can keep track of the progress we make on Facebook!
My Mom, my Cousin, Bogan, and I after a long day's work!
You said "we" there, why?
You will often catch me saying "we" when talking about the brewery. It is something that I wouldn't eliminate from my vocabulary or train of thought even if I could.
Departed Soles was originally a basement-born plan between my best friend and I to start our own brew pub.  He was a local teacher who also worked at a nearby restaurant and I was regularly brewing beer. In fact, he was also Gluten Intolerant and that was the reason I was experimenting with gluten free recipes.  Nobody should have to drink a vodka cranberry during a football game!
He often said that I would never leave my family business to chase our mutual dream, and he was probably right.
Unfortunately, in October of 2010, he was commuting between his two jobs and involved in a car accident.  He passed away later that evening with his family by his side.
So, while it is just one half of the original duo pushing forward with the dream, I know I am not doing it alone. I know that he is "up there," inspiring me and guiding me, getting me through the bad days and celebrating with me on the good ones. There isn't a day that goes by that I don't miss him.  He pushed me to be a better person, and without him, I would never have ventured down this path and been as good as a brewer, or person, as I am.
Departed Soles Brewing Company is dedicated to his memory.
I would be remiss, however, if I didn't add here that my family is a HUGE part of DSBC. I would also not be the person I am without my parents, and this brewery would not be what it is without them.  The love and support, as well as hard work, got me here, and my brothers' work cannot be taken for granted. Thank you all!
Isn't the name a little depressing?
Despite what you may gather from the above story, "Departed Soles" is not meant to be morbid, or about death at all!  It is "Soles," not "Souls," after all.
Departed Soles is about the people that do something a little different, defy the odds, go against expectations, chase their own dreams, etc. Departed Soles are not the people that walk in line, but get out and march to the beat of their own drum.
Departed Soles beer is about going against the grain!
Our logo captures a lot of what New Jersey is, as well as the Urban, City vibe we are embracing!
Is the beer actually good?
During my final week at the American Brewers Guild Brewing School we hosted a bottle share at the house I was staying in.  Amongst the many good beers from around the world that were available, I presented my teacher with GoodbiPA, the flagship gluten free offering of Departed Soles. He liked it so much that he brought it to his wife and presented it to her. She took a sip and said "Mmm that's good, what is it?" His response was "Would you believe that's Gluten Free?"
A few weeks later, the same beer took home a BEST IN SHOW award at New York City's Homebrew Alley, winning its category against glutenous beers along the way.  There were approximately 777 entries in this contest, with the category it won being the most entered amongst all BJCP categories.
(The events of that night before finding out I won the awards are a great story... ask when you visit the brewery!)
Since that time, my brewing has been nearly 100% dedicated to perfecting Gluten Free Recipes.  We're not just making a gluten free beer to appease a particular crowd - we are making a Gluten Free beer that folks with and without the intolerance will enjoy.  We don't want you to have to buy a 6 pack for a friend... we want you to be able to buy a case for everyone!
DSBC will launch with two beers in distribution: GoodbiPA, our flagship Gluten Free IPA that rings in around 6% ABV, as well as A Dark Night, our Black IPA that is also made of 100% Gluten Free ingredients.
Our tasting room, however, we will feature a rotating selection of beer that is both Gluten Free and Non-Gluten Free.  Our initial selection will include a Nut Brown Ale, a Red Ale, and more.  These beers will be scaled up to the full system once our keg fleet can satisfy the demand.  The Tasting Room will also feature collaborations with local brewers and breweries!
***We are currently going through the certification process to call the beer "Gluten Free" officially, but they are and will be made with 100% gluten free ingredients regardless***

Why did you wait so close to opening to launch a Kickstarter?
I launch this campaign knowing that it may look a little odd.  There is the chance, after all, that the brewery is open before it ends (if we keep our fingers crossed, keep working our tails off, and pray very hard).  There are three reasons for this:
1) Firstly, I did not want to promise anything that I could not deliver. This thing will happen right here in the Powerhouse Arts District of Downtown Jersey City!
2) Secondly, the craft brewing community is extremely close knit.  The New Jersey Craft Brewing scene has been fortunate to see a great amount of growth in recent years and, in light of that, a lot of Kickstarter campaigns.  Out of respect for the people running those fundraisers, and the awesome people supporting them, I did not want to launch a campaign while another NJ brewery was fundraising.
3) Finally, health.  During the build out process I was seriously injured and essentially out of commission for two months.  Not only did this cause some serious delays, but it caused some unforeseen expenses both personally and for the brewery.  I could not present myself to you during that time, in the condition I was in, and ask for support while I could not be physically working.
See, we even have a Google Places Page. We're too legit to quit now!
What will the money be used for?
The million dollar question!  Or 15,000? We could use more...
As mentioned above, there were some costs during our build out phase that were unforeseen that pushed the brewery beyond the start up budget and initial investment. While many of those bills have been paid, or terms struck, there are still bills forthcoming that need to be addressed, and there are still expenses before getting the beer to you.  These funds will not only go to those.
More particularly, these funds will be used on:
Gluten Free Certification - This process costs several thousands of dollars and involves site visits, product testing, and special processing procedures.
A FORK LIFT! 
Finishing our build out - Duct work, audio presentations, and installing a fantastic draft system.
Virtual Tour - So you know as much as we do, if not more!
Expanding our keg fleet - We currently have enough kegs to distribute approximately 20-30 bars. We would like to double that.
A Keg Washer/Racker - In order to serve you the best beer, whether it is in our tasting room or out around the Tri-State Area, we need to get it to you in the best manner & condition possible. This means quality equipment, and in this case, ensuring that the way it is getting to you is clean, sanitized, and properly filled. The best way to ensure that is to do it in 1 step, not multiple.
Permits - Our state requires a permit for everything, from brewing, to selling, to the vehicle transporting the product. These annual fees are due at the beginning of the summer.

THANK YOU AGAIN FOR YOUR TIME AND CONSIDERATION!  PLEASE FEEL FREE TO ASK ANY QUESTIONS YOU MAY HAVE!
Sincerely,
Brian & Bogan
PS - We will post pictures of the rewards as soon as the proofs are finalized!
An idea of what a Hoodie Koozie MAY look like
An idea of what 750 ML EZ Cap bottles look like - Imagine our logo here!
"In memory of..."

Many of you - like myself – might have fond memories of the Manchester Storm ice hockey club from the late 90’s to the early 00’s.
Granted I was only 8 or 9 at the time but I remember some fantastic stuff. Many a heart was broken when it was announced in 2002 that the club would be folding due to financial difficulties.
It’s come to my attention that this year (2015) would mark the 20th anniversary of the once great hockey club. With this in mind I wanted to create a little something to commemorate it.
I’m proposing a limited run of shirts under the banner of ‘Sons of the Storm’ for those of us who still hold a candle for them in our hearts.
Who's with me?!

UPDATE #4: I'm typing this on 10/18. Sometime in the last few days, we realized we were over 200% funded. Wow. Thanks. We really don't know how to say thank you enough times. After I made the project live I had a short panic attack after worrying that maybe $800 was "too much." What if we only got $400 or $600 and so had nothing and had to fund Volume 2 out of pocket. And now we've doubled the original Goal. Thank you, thank you, thank you. Since typing that doesn't seem to do our feelings justice, Chris "Terry" Durston even made a special video for our backers. GO watch it.
UPDATE #3: On 10/13, we crossed $1400, all our contributors are being paid $20, twice as much as our first stretch goal (and, mathematically speaking, infinitely more than the $0 they signed up for!). We currently have no more stretch goals. Any funds left over after creating and distributing Volume 2 will be rolled into the Skullgate coffers and used for promotions or saved for future volumes.
UPDATE #2: As of 9/29, we've reached our first stretch goal, so all our contributors will be paid! Our next goal is $1400. We've also added a number of digital add-ons you can add to your current pledge.
UPDATE #1: Now that we've exceeded what we need to produce the book, we would LOVE to be able to pay our contributors for their stories! So that's our stretch goals: not a premium foil cover or a hardcover edition, but paying artists for their work.
 STRETCH GOAL #1 -  $1100. All contributors are paid a flat rate of $10
 STRETCH GOAL #2 - $1400. All contributors are paid a flat rate of $20
  That's it. Simple, fair, and (I hope) appealing to backers like you who generously support independent authors. 
(Placeholder-actual cover art and title still undecided)
Volume 2 of Tales from the Year Between is an anthology of weird science-fiction that brings writers from around the world to create an original, shared world and then write stories set in that shared universe. We have just finished recruiting a new array of 24, talented collaborators. Soon we’ll start building our world and spinning tales, and in February we will have a fabulous collection of thrilling sci-fi to share with the world--with your help!
 Tales From the Year Between 
Part literary magazine, part writing club, and all creativity, Tales From the Year Between is the best-selling speculative fiction anthology with a unique premise. Twice a year it gathers a disparate group of authors from all across the globe to collaborate in shared world-building and creative writing. Using a modified version of Avery Alder’s fabulous game The Quiet Year as a massive writing prompt, each volume of The Year Between begins with nothing more than a simple premise (“a desert fantasy world, like D&D’s Dark Sun”). Contributors participate in a week-long “game” to create a shared canon of people, places, events, and themes. From this chaotic melange of ideas, each participant then creates their own stories, poems, letters, and even recipes, all set in the world they created together.
Volume 1 generated the world of Achten Tan, a strange, post-apocalyptic fantasy world inspired by old pulp fantasy, TSR’s Darksun’s, and the weird-fiction of China Mieville, MT Anderson. The resulting book, Achten Tan: Land of Dust and Bone. debuted as a “Hot New Release” on Amazon and garnered glowing reviews.
But the idea of Tales from the Year Between is to keep moving on to new worlds. So now we’re gearing up to do it all over again. New collaborators, new world-building, new stories, new book. It’s going to be completely unlike the last volume, which is what makes it so exciting!
Volume 2 - Untitled Space Adventure!
We can’t tell you much about Volume 2 because the nature of this project means it hasn’t been made yet. Our contributors come to us with writing skills and a willingness to create together, but the world is a blank slate. Together, we will begin with the sketch of a premise. For this book, we begin with a crew of space marines who have stolen a sentient alien ship and now find themselves stranded at the far side of the galaxy. That’s it. All the details--who they are, what the ship is like, what planets they discover and what adventures they have--is all unknown until we play The Game.
Buy a copy yourself! It's a fantastic game.
The Game is a highly modified version of Avery Alder’s The Quiet Year. Over the course of a week, the 24 contributors to this book will take turns suggesting locations and resources, adding details to the characters, and responding to random prompts drawn from a deck of cards. By the time everyone has taken their turn, we will have an outline of a year in the life of our crew: their names and ranks and relationships, the drama and tragedies that have befallen them. It will be a big, messy, shared cannon.
And then each writer will set out to tell a story in that world. We encourage our writers to push boundaries and genres. Last time we got flash-fiction and journal entries, letters and traditional stories, even recipes. Who knows what we’ll get this time? We don’t, which makes us giddy with excitement.
Art and Interior
We will be commissioning original art for the cover. We don’t know what the subject will be yet, but we will be using the same artist as Volume 1 for a wrap-around illustration. The four sections of the book will have full-page spreads of high-quality stock art. Aaron Hockett, who provided the maps for Achten Tan, will be doing maps for this book as well. 
The final maps REALLY makes Volume 1 stand out!
In addition, he’s also doing a 12-page graphic-prologue. The manuscript will be compiled using Vellum, a software program that creates a slick and professionally formatted interior layout.
A sneak-peak at the thumbnails for the graphic prologue by Aaron Hockett
Rewards
When completed, the book will be available in all digital formats (Kindle, Nook, ePub, PDF) as well as in print via Amazon or wherever books are sold.
 If you back at a level for a digital book reward, when the campaign ends you will be able to select the digital format of your choice.
Digital edition available on every device!
If you back and receive a regular paperback, the book will be shipped to you directly from Amazon using their KDP print-on-demand service.
The print books are sweet! You want one!
If you back at a level to receive a signed book, it will first be shipped to Editor-In-Chief Chris Van Dyke. The books will be signed, numbered, and noted that they are from the 2020 Kickstarter Campaign.
Why Kickstarter?
We are a new, independent publishing collective, and even when produced using print-on-demand are set costs that need to be paid upfront to getting a book up and running. If you support this campaign, you are helping by getting us the funds when we need them most -- before we go to print!
Base costs:
Custom cover art -- $230+
Purchase ISBNs -- $60
Registration through IngramSpark Distribution - $50
Stock Art for website and Internal - $50
Webhosting ($5/month, ongoing)
Printing costs for each physical copy (varies based on number of backers)
  Also, by purchasing your copy of Volume 2 through this campaign, you are buying directly from us, not through the Amazon, B&N, or some other third party. This means more of your money goes directly to Skullgate Media and will help us make more Volumes going forward!
Timeline
As of October 1st, we have finished recruiting the contributors to Volume 2! In the third week of October, we will be playing The Quiet Year to establish the world. Writers will be working on their submissions all through November and into the start of December, then we will move into layout and copyediting. Our goal is to have the book finalized for prepublication on February 1st and available for traditional purchase on February 15th.
Digital copies of the book will begin shipping to backers via email on February 2nd. Print copies will be ordered on February 15th. Depending on shipping (twice, if you order a signed copy) paperbacks should arrive by the end of February.

Welcoming class atmosphere for every body!
Hip Expressions is a growing group of dancers, yogis, and supporters - we moved into our new expanded space with only ONE bathroom and no walls.  Since then, we’ve done much of the construction ourselves but now we need YOUR help so we can finish the construction of our Studio.  Then, we can get out of line, and back to what we like best - DANCING!
**We have ADDITIONAL costs now too, our home theater just shut down and we are working on transforming our Studio space into a Performance Art Space!  We've been doing our monthly shows for over 10 years now, and we're excited to host them at our OWN studio, but we need lights, curtains, backdrop, and more... and definitely more than one bathroom as our attendance is around 100 people a show!**
Our mission is to provide a path of creativity, health, and self-development through dance and movement arts, in a safe and nurturing environment, for a community of all ages, shapes, and sizes.  
We offer inspiration, motivation, and transformation, at our Studio/Community Center and beyond.  We promise a creative experience for every spirit; the exploration of well-being, self-expression, and personal fulfillment through our classes, performances, and events.
Be Strong, Be Sexy, Belly Dance!
Dance & Movement for Every Body
Hi, I’m Johanna Xenobia. I moved to Florida in 2000.  My resolve was to add to the positive energy of the universe by sharing what inspired me - belly dance!  I met belly dance artist Karen Sun Ray and immediately we realized we shared the same mission - to not only inspire people, but to create a community of dance.  In 2004, we founded Hip Expressions, a collective of artists, teachers, and live music and dance performance projects.  
We had a minor setback when I was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2007, and the belly dance community nationwide pulled together to help me out by raising over $25,000 to help pay for my surgeries and chemotherapy treatments.  I was shocked at the power of community!  I was so honored and grateful - I knew that I would spend the rest of my life nurturing our art form and the community surrounding it.  To evolve our art form, and inspire others to collaborate in the process!
Less than a year out of my last treatment, we got to work, and opened our first small studio, 680 square feet, with six teachers.  We wanted to start small, but immediately knew we had to go bigger!  Within three years, we exploded out of that space into our current 3600 square foot space (more than tripling our square footage!).  Our teaching staff of sixteen now encompasses a plethora of art forms that support health and wellness - not just belly dance, but also Nia, Yoga, Polynesian, Samba, Burlesque, Jazz, Hoop, and more!
We are lucky, the new space had beautiful hard wood floors and mirrors already installed, saving us a bunch of setup, but there was lots of work to be done.  It was larger than we anticipated, but everything fell into place for it to work and so we took the leap.  Now our mission was to build within the space - it was one big room with one bathroom - and it was up to us to do the construction ourselves.  We’ve successfully put up a few walls, creating two spaces and have plans for a third room, along with a lobby, boutique area, and a treatment room for massage.
Then, construction slowed… by law, we need a 2nd bathroom - a great idea for the number of people we have come through here on a daily basis!  Not only do we have more classes, but are also hosting our monthly showcases (running for over 11 years!), studio events, overnights and more.  Now the lines are even longer and we are asking for your help - we can’t continue to grow without a bathroom - and we can’t wait in line any longer!
Just last week, our regular performance venue/dinner theater closed!  Now we need a place to host our Studio Showcases, we've been running them monthly for eleven years and it's not time to stop now!  No problem - we will convert our current large studio space (about 1400 square feet) into a 100 seat theater.  Now, we definitely need two bathrooms to host these shows!
We embrace many genres of dance & performance art.
Main Goal: New Bathroom
This bathroom will also have a shower, and we’ll install a water fountain too.  Selling bottled water at $1/bottle towards our bathroom is slow going, and the girls are patient but nature calls...
($5700)
Stretch Goal #1: Air Conditioning
We need to run ducts to the new rooms - and buy a new unit for the small room.  It gets hot.  Especially during the Florida summers, where our classes get full (‘cause it’s too hot to do anything outside), and then it’s too hot to do anything inside too.  Don’t let us turn into a hot yoga studio, p-p-p-please!
($7700)
Stretch Goal #2: Another Wall
So the Drum Class does not disturb the Yoga Class.  Yogis vs Percussion, it could get ugly. Enough said.
($9200)
Stretch Goal #3: Lights
Our fixtures are out of date, and we are running on pretty IKEA lights which are great but we’re squinting.  It’s bad for our eyes.
($11200)
Stretch Goal #4: Theatre Conversion
Lights, backdrop, curtains, sound system, etc!  
($13700)
Extras…
There’s always something else!  Fixing the hole in the floor in the first bathroom, a new mini-fridge so we can store food and drinks for dancers, yoga blocks, yoga straps, trim, caulk, more mirrors for the walls, you name it, triple the price you think it’s gonna cost and you’re close!
PLUS we want to start offering on-line classes - this means rigging up the Studio for video!  Video equipment isn't cheap...  But just think, then you can experience all the joy of Hip Expressions - right in the comfort of your own home!
Testimonial:
This is a WONDERFUL studio!!! I have danced all over the country, and really, it is rare that you find a place this dedicated to creating a true environment of expression, dance, family, and fostering the artistic growth of its students. Belly dance is the studio's focus, but lots of other dances find a home here as well - Nia, bollywood, odissi, yoga, burlesque, polynesian, jazz... Also - talk about bringing in amazing performers for amazing workshops - I'm in heaven!!!! THANK YOU!!!!! Oh, and if you want to book some amazing performers for an event? THIS is who you should be talking to!
~ Stephanie Marie

When I stumbled upon my roommate building an AR-15 rifle in the garage, it led to an exploration of the role that guns play in our culture, the effect this tool has on a new friendship, and the treacherous and confusing nature of our mediated realities. 
I never planned on making a movie about guns; they were never on my mind — until suddenly it seemed they were all around me. I didn't know how to feel about this sudden proximity to firearms in my life, but I knew I wanted to understand more about them, both as a tool and as a symbol.
I believe very passionately in the power and potential of micro-budget cinema. Everything I have done in my adult life has been to serve the idea that powerful movies can be made within extremely small means by properly structuring and utilizing life's most precious resource: our time.
Making this film has been intense already, and we haven't even shot it yet! The polarizing nature of firearm ownership has proven to be an exceptionally treacherous battleground of ideologies and temperaments. We do not shy away from this complexity, and in many ways it is precisely the goal of this film: to stimulate more conversation around this subject in a way politics cannot do. It’s no secret that this country was founded at the barrel of a gun — now we are all living in that shadow...
Shadow of a Gun is the story of two neighbors who form an unlikely friendship:
Tom is a working class intellectual stoner and gun enthusiast. He works a day job and lets off steam after work by building guns in his garage. His workbench is his sanctuary, his escape from the problems of the world and his solitary meditation.
Jason lives alone in one of his parents' properties and spends his days trying to cure boredom, often by exploring the lives of others through media and pushing social boundaries with divisive behavior.
When Jason crashes his drone into a neighboring yard, he meets Tom. Jason shows interest in Tom's life, so Tom shows him his workshop. Tom's passion for building guns quickly becomes contagious, and Jason decides he wants to build his own...
Shadow of a Gun traces the beginning of this new friendship; a means through which they explore the foibles of routine, isolation, and their place in the world.
It's going to be an intense experimental journey to the heart of a complex issue with a group of wonderful collaborators and some of my closest friends. We're shooting the movie throughout the summer and editing as we go...
  Micah Van Hove (director/producer)
Micah is a writer/director and film journalist who has been exploring the possibilities in micro-budget cinema since 2009. His first feature film Menthol premiered at Santa Barbara, Sofia International, and Brooklyn film festivals. His work as a music video director has premiered on Vice, NPR, Stereogum and more. As a regular writer for No Film School since 2013, Micah has sought out to stimulate thoughtful discourse and elevate films that reflect a commitment to personal and courageous work.
Micah is fascinated with the foibles of youth, alienation, and expectation.
Joe Marine (director of photography)
After studying film and photography at Fitchburg State in Massachusetts, Joe interned at Ridley Scott's Commercial and Music Video production company in Los Angeles, and then went freelance full-time in 2011.
He was one of the first writers hired at the filmmaking website No Film School in February 2012, and became its first Managing Editor the same year. Joe has written and directed a number of his own short films, and is in post-production on his first narrative feature Happy Birthday, Gerald Norton.
Jeffrey Reeser (editor)
Jeffrey Reeser is a screenwriter and freelance editor living in Los Angeles and has written several novel adaptations. His ability to approach subjects with equal parts sensitivity and objectivity lends a sober, thoughtful eye to all of the images he dreams up and assembles. Not afraid to speak his mind, Jeffrey enables and facilitates constructive creative friction — a key ingredient for all members of a production to operate at their best. After studying Dramatic Arts and Film at the University of Southern California, Jeffrey edited the Gusmano Cesaretti film Take None Give None, a feature documentary about the South Central motorcycle club The Chosen Few.
Morgan Greenwood (composer)
Morgan's soundscapes are both chaotically organic and eerily mechanical, and often sound like the birth of an organism on a conveyor belt. From his spellbinding work in Azeda Booth, to his role as ½ of the LA-based group Baths, Morgan's work captures the majesty of a human spirit that refuses to be confined to automated life. Morgan's music is a perfect match to support the story of a newfound mechanical fascination.
Kazdyn Nicholson (assistant editor)
Kazdyn provides an irreplaceably steady and supportive energy in the editing room. After jumping head-first into editing Micah's first feature Menthol, Kazdyn came out the other side with an impeccable understanding of how to support a director's vision. Shadow of a Gun will be edited on an ongoing basis over the summer, and Kazdyn's expertise and presence will be key to keeping our timelines organized and functional.
Gage Siuniak (drone operator)
  Dominic Pino (Tom)
A first time actor and all-around thoughtful human being, Dominic is part of a rare generation of new actors who aren't actors at all — but people willing to put their personal predicaments in front of a lens. A purveyor of truth and a pretty damn good Chess player, Dominic's philosophy towards life and guns lends a crucial edge and reality to the experiential nature of this film.
Jake King (Jason)
With a background in theater and music from the University of Oregon, Jake lends his curiosities to storytelling — in whatever form they may take. He made his break into film acting with Micah Van Hove's Menthol (2014). Beneath his accessible exterior is a dynamic trojan horse for subversive behavior, perfect for delivering performances rife with ambiguity. Jake is a tireless foot-soldier in the excavation of the problematic reality around us.
  We've organized an awesome group of supporting actors to help tell this Southern California story. 
Stefan Dezil (Vern)
Justin Johnson (Patrick)
Charles Ward (Roger)
Josh Beck (Ryan)
Mike Bash (Bash)
Johnny Wactor (Officer Tracey)
Luke Eberl (Richard)
Charlotte Lindèn Ercoli (Campfire)
Where does your money go?
We believe in keeping production sizes small, mobile, and cost efficient. The modest budget for this film will cover the bare necessities as we all work through the trenches of the story from June through August 2016.
Camera — We're shooting on ARRI Alexa, which is a relatively heavy camera for the often guerrilla situations that we'll be shooting in. A camera assistant would go a long way towards stabilizing and saving time in these situations.
Sound — We need to be able to hire the right production sound professional to get the cleanest audio when shooting in less than ideal (often guerrilla) situations.
Time — Our two leads are played by non-actors, so we have to pull them out of work in order to be able to shoot consecutively. This might derail their lives, but hopefully we can help repair some of the damage.
Locations — We are shooting in Ventura County in Southern California and there are many locations that fit into the world of this film. For scenes in which the main characters are wielding firearms, proper location management is a must-have safety precaution.
Crew — This film is as minimal as it gets, but we will need additional crew for various stages of the production. This includes Assistant Directors, Location Managers, a Grip/Gaffer, and a Boom Operator.
Props — Putting safety first, we will need exact replicas of the real weapons used in the film for many of the scenes.
Day Play Casting — To fill out the world of this film, we are bringing in a lot of great actors and non-actors to act as the backdrop to the main story.

EXHIBIT A: Game Set Up Table View
Story:
After chasing her Great Aunt’s naughty parrot into a grandfather clock, Alice finds herself in Wonderland, once again, for her third adventure. 
A spree of mismatched killings are plaguing Wonderland and Mrs. Minus and her Civil Serpents are investigating these Jigsaw Murders of which Alice is a prime suspect...

In this cooperative dice placement game, players take on the role of Alice. With the assistance of Celia, her automated twin sister, plus other colorful characters, players work together to collect clues to clear everyone’s names.
Automated Alice is based on the novel of the same name by award-winning author Jeff Noon.

Feel the rush of racing against the clock! How well will you spend the little time you have?
Player interaction! Will your group agree on the best placement of dice, or will there be any objections? 
Press your luck! Will you keep what you’ve rolled, or try for a more difficult match?
Experience the excitement and relief when defeating those sneaky serpents!
Enlist help from colorful Wonderland characters, each with their own unique special abilities.
There are four different types of Clue Cards:
EXACT NUMBER: Die must be the exact number and color shown (or wild) to match each die space.
EXACT NUMBER OR HIGHER: Die must be the exact number, or higher, and color shown (or wild) to match each die space.
ODD OR EVEN NUMBER: Die can be any odd number (1/3/5) of the exact color (or wild) to match each odd die space, and any even number (2/4/6) of the exact color (or wild) to match each even die space.
SUM: The total dice face value placed on the card must be equal to or greater than the number listed. The exact color (or wild) must be matched for each die space.
Some Clue Cards have special abilities. After collecting these cards, their special abilities can be used once, at any point during the game, and then discarded.
 There are six different unique Case Files: 
Each of the six Case Files represent a different character with their own unique special ability which you may use each time you visit their file. You may use multiple special abilities if you visit multiple Case Files on your turn.
There are five colored dice in the game:
RED, YELLOW AND BLUE: Must be matched to their color and face value.
PURPLE: Considered “wild” and can be used to match its face value for any color.
GREEN: Represents Mrs. Minus’ league of Civil Serpents. Green dice block your progress but must always be placed first. 
EXHIBIT B: Case File showing dice placement matches
 There are three areas on the Clock Tracker: 
 Clock Face – Keeps track of the game rounds.
   Dice Hold – Any unused dice at the end of a player’s turn are placed, here.
   Civil Serpent Threat Tracker – Any unplaced Civil Serpent dice are placed, here. Once all six spaces are filled, the game is lost.
  EXHIBIT C: Civil Serpent Threat Tracker getting higher!
“I really like the look of this one. It’s so bright. So colorful. It looks like a light, cooperative game – which there are very few of  those. They are usually these big grandiose things going on. I like the  dice chucking part of it. I like the graphic design. I like that it’s an  Alice in Wonderland that’s not super dark…”
“I really enjoy dice chuckers and cooperative games, and this one check both of those boxes..."
"...A number of my games went to the final round, even the final couple of rolls, to decide whether I've won or lost the game."
"There's also a good amount of strategy..."
"Choosing when you use your Clue Cards to trigger their ability is an  important part of the game as you definitely want to make sure you have them when you need them towards the end of the game, and not spending them too quickly.”
 “Automated Alice is fun mixture of luck of the roll and strategically using the options open to you. It’s bright and colorful, has a really fun table presence with all the case files and clue cards, and its rules are easy to learn and teach making it a great casual dice game with enough depth to keep everyone engaged.
The range of abilities is where the challenge of the game really comes through. Figuring out the best way to move from case file to case file, using their abilities while also choosing locations where you have the best chance of placing your dice is where the strategy of the games lies, and where players will be discussing optimal moves.
Additionally, there is a nice sense of escalation built into the gameplay. As more and more clue cards come off the boards, it becomes more and more difficult to place dice, ensuring that more dice go to the Hold and Civil Serpents become more dangerous. You are also more often faced with press-your-luck choices, balancing risky rolls against having to send dice to the Hold at the end of your turn.”

“Players are given plenty of choices, so they never feel like the dice are playing the game and not them. If you enjoy dice games, definitely check it out...”

I started Shady Oak Barrel House in 2013 to dedicate my life and passion for wild and sour barrel aged beers. This is the next step in achieving something truly wild and with a true Sonoma County terroir.
Traditionally, brewers used something called a "coolship" to both cool down the unfermented beer (wort) after the boil, and also inoculate the liquid with the local wild yeast and bacteria. The beer then gets transferred to oak barrels to undergo a long aging process, and is finally blended to the brewer's taste. Sonoma County, with all of its unique agricultural areas, is a prime region to make spontaneous beers, and to capture the true depth of the region. And to capture this I'm making a mobile coolship.
I'm partnering with another local brewery, Barrel Brothers Brewing Company, out of Windsor, CA for the build. We have already designed and made the preliminary plans for an all stainless steel coolship, which will then be mounted on a trailer. The basic plan is to brew, then drive out to different locations in the area and let it get inoculated at the location.
Stainless steel construction and fabricating is not an easy or cheap process, and the coolship will include sanitary stainless steel welds and fittings, as well as a lid to use during transportation. Mounting this onto a trailer is also a complicated process, for it has to be able to accommodate the weight of the steel, as well as the liquid, and it must be mounted in a way that is safe to drive around with near boiling temperature liquids sloshing around until I get on location.
The funding received will go towards the parts and labor of creating the coolship trailer. If successful, I will be able to bring a truly sour and wild, agricultural beer to the community.
